GAME: Puerto Rico
RANK: 14
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Superbe. A perfect mix of strategy and interaction. I always want play once more after a game. The best game I own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good game, not too heavy not too light, but overhyped.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A great game, with clever and well crafted mechanics, but I'm afraid it's not my cup of tea. 
The role selection model is simple and functional, reducing downtime and overall playing time. It also helps beginners in learning the game, with each player going through each selected phase every turn, an useful bonus for a game that doesn't lack its complexities: from the specific rules of each role to the proper understanding of the various buildings. 
On the long run the gameplay seems to rarely diverge from a limited number of optimum strategies, also being, quite often, really sensitive to the number of players and their skill level. Interaction is limited to selecting roles and buildings that can advantage you more than your opponents and not selecting the ones that do the opposite, but, to me, it still feels like a multiplayer optimization rush with almost no direct interplay and little space for errors. 
Still, a really good piece of work per se.

Rio Grande version. Simple but solid and functional components. Not really impressed by the text-only building tiles: function over form, I suppose, but even a small illustration could have been the final touch (the San Juan based alternative, here on the Geek, is a good example). Really good rulebook. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
It seems overwhelming at first, but it's really not that hard of a game to understand.  Even though you have to read and reread the buildings to determine how they are used in the game, I give Puerto Rico  a "ten". 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fantastic supply management game, superbly balanced, with every game very different.  Also the 3, 4 and 5 player games play significantly differently.  Extremely well designed.

Update:  Not sure if I've read too many negative comments about this game on BGG, but when I played it last night I didn't seem to enjoy it as much as usual.  I'll downgrade it from 10 to 9.

Played this week and still love it.  A 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 6.5
The first time I tried this I thought: That's it? I much prefer the different choices the cards in Agricola have to offer, vers. the few buildings you can build in Puerto Rico.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Variable Phase Selection, fast play, low downtime, (generally) playing against players (not the game, although it is through indirect mechanical interaction more than anything else), and a long supply chain really amount to a decent game overall. The greatest coup was getting my parents to play game after game after game. Two downsides are that you either need more buildings, or content to deal with your existing options as it's a static setup. Second, it is the namesake of the problem that many other "seat-order dependency" games suffer from where it's the responsibility of the person next to you to keep you in check more so than players across the table. Really fiddly in my experience, although I suppose some of that can be reduced. I loathe the instruction manual. I understand why this is considered Seyfarth's star accomplishment.

Update; This is a game that I find I enjoy best when I binge and I think that's because of the setup time. For some reason the second and third game generally make me happier than the first one of an evening, so it rarely comes out anymore. It's a game that I love playing it with a select group of people (my parents at holidays), but that's it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This one is as great as everyone says. There are many different strategies you can implement that make the game different every time you play. Quality components at a great price too.

RATING: 7.5
I remember the first time I was introduced to this game... I wanted to rip my eyeballs out. Of course, this was back in the dark ages when I was just getting introduced into these newfangled board games, and I'll admit I was a bit overwhelmed. How far we have come... I tried it again a few months later and it quickly became a favorite of my wife and I. And now we barely play it. The life cycle of games...

Still, a great game, and a classic. Of all the "gateway games" we own (Ticket to Ride, Settlers, Carc, Dominion) this is the one I like the best.

RATING: 8
The big one. Puerto Rico. I feel I have barely scratched the surface of this game. The mechanics work all too well - you really feel poor and desperate at the start of the game, by the middle you are frantically trying to decide what everyone will do and whose set up is the most threatening and then at the end there is a tremendous sense of time running away from you. A great game. BUT. It seems that to sit after a weaker player (normally me) gives a very big advantage and so to get a satisfactory game everyone must be of a simialr standard.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Highly strategic, innovative, interactive game that is relatively easy to play.  The role selection mechanic, where it feels like it's your turn every turn, and where each role can be very strong or very weak depending on the game or the timing of its selection within a game, might be the best game mechanic I've ever experienced.  One of the most popular games in my group, and probably still the best game I've ever played.

Own the [boardgame=12382]Extra buildings[/boardgame] and the [boardgame=159761]Nobles[/boardgame] mini-expansions from the [boardgame=40688]Treasure Chest[/boardgame] as well as the [boardgame=108687]Limited Anniversary Edition[/boardgame] which contains both of the above mini-expansions as well.

Every time I have played this game, it has been with people who have played the game 10x+ my play experience so I get crushed in actual score.

That being said, the game is still enjoyable. It is engine building and there are very many valid ways to build an engine and claim victory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Pros: plays fairly quickly; simple mechanics; tricky short-term vs. long-term strategies; decent components (though you can't read the buildings' text without picking them up or referring to a cheat sheet).

Cons: so-so theme (Plantation owner???); small player interaction (with some auto-play turns and lots of dependence on other player's role choices); somewhat unforgiving of play mistakes (especially early on). No dice rolling.

Conclusion: it's a successful game because it works as printed. The game does get fairly heavy in the late stages and some players will have brain lock-up (yours truly) over a crucial decision (followed by brain fatigue after the game). It's not a game that I would seek out to play (like in tournaments) but if others clamored to play it, I'd reluctantly join in. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
A lot of choices and strategy here, which is usually a good thing. Unfortunately, I find theme thin and uninteresting and some the mechanics needlessly obtuse and arbitrary. I guess you have to play it several times before you "get" the strategy, but there wasn't much there to interest me. If the strategy isn't intuitive or if I can't figure out what to do after a game, there has to be *something* inherently fun or interesting about the game for me to want to play it again. It's not inherently fun or interesting to me though. Maybe it was partly because of the theme, but I found Ingenious and Qwirkle more engaging and interesting that this game so it wasn't just the dry theme.

RATING: 1
This appears to be one of those games you either love or hate.  I'm sorry, I'm probably swimming upstream, but in the 4-5 times I've played it, I have formed an extremely negative opinion of the game.  The Turn order always messes me up.  The guy in front of me invariably takes what will screw me over or what I need the most.  I just don't get the strategy or the appeal of the game.  You could not pay me to play it.

Then there are all of the "unofficial" expansions that people are printing out and tossing into the mix that makes it even worse.

After trying to play a few more times my opinion has not changed.. in fact, I hate it more than ever.

RATING: 8.5
2010 - 8
Is it the best game ever as indicated by it's #1 rating on BGG?  Probably not, but that doesn't mean that this isn't a fun game to play.  As others have stated, there are, at times, "wrong" moves that can frustrate experienced players.  However, as long as you stay light hearted and remember that it's just a game, you can't go wrong with Puerto Rico.

2016 - 8.5
Six years later and PR is still a fun experience.  I don't play it nearly as often, but when I do, I always appreciate the beauty of this game.  If played with my favorite group, this one is a 10.  With a random group, probably a 7.  I figure this averages to 8.5.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
First play tentative rating. I see why this game is a classic. It's an elegant game of perfect information. It's easy to learn, hard to win. Although this is definitely a euro, you need to be extremely aware of the people around you and they can greatly impact your ability to win. Even though the game seems simple enough conceptually, the strategy can be quite complex. I have a feeling that on replay, I may move this game up to a 10. It's just such a pleasing game: you build, you plant, you deliver... and then there is a frantic rush toward the end as you desperately try to get those last points. If I have one complaint it's just how dull the art looks. If there was an art update, it would be perfect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.9
To me, this game is sort of a "multiplayer chess"... It can be too scripted, and if you play against really good opponents, you're sure to get your ass kicked with less gaming satisfaction then if you lost other eurogames.


I much prefer Race For The Galaxy, especially with expansions, but I can definitely see why this game's rated highly overall here on BGG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
PR is really a very good economic game!! not very complicated game rules (may need 2-3 games to know the building functions). Each turn, you just need to chose a role (out of 6 to 8), and take the action with the chosen role, huh! is it simple? not really!! since the role you chosen may affect other players, so to make a decision in mid game is quite brain-teasing!! You need to manage money and victory point in terms of building, manpower, resources. 

Moderate game time, PR usually can be finished within 20 turns. You can play it in casual way as exploring the game with your land development. Great design. San Juan (card game) is recommended as well ( I have played SJ first such that I know PR easily)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The quality of this game is heavily dependent on the players of a given session - because there is no randomness (aside from the players' decisions) and no hidden information of real consequence, the only risk you take is in underanalyzing your move, which can make play a little sterile. Also, if a weak player is to a strong player's right, it can completely unbalance the game. Despite that, this is an interesting, well-crafted game that is quite enjoyable if played by people of equal skill level. Do yourself a favor and avoid strategies for this game; part of the fun is feeling out what works for yourself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
After one play, I hardly feel I have scratched the surface of this game. It is clearly deep, involved, rich, and very strategic. I have some knowledge of the lighter card-game San Juan, so it came fairly naturally to me, but it is a complex affair. I was surprised to find it wasn't a long game, even with five players. It certainly didn't outstay its welcome. The only significant criticism for me is the appearance of it. The theme is dry and the board/tokens reflect this. It's all text, very little imagery and rather boring to look at. Compared to the lovely artwork in Agricola (a game of similar weight) it looks a little tired. But I was glad to find that in my first play of Puerto Rico, it lived up to the hype.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2 plays / 5 players.

LIKE: Quite competitive with 5, but in a fun way. Lots of interesting combos to explore.

DISLIKE: Some very strong player order binding that can be beneficial or hindering. The game plays strongly to those who've played before and know some combos, so first-time players will sometimes struggle their first time through.

OVERALL: The first time I played it, I could tell I liked it. The combos were great, but the game is really about timing and trying to maximize the role you choose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What more is there to say about Puerto Rico?  One of my favourites and a landmark in board game design.  After many plays, I see myself always wanting to play this more.  

I love the balance of tactical considerations with long term strategies.  You also need to pay careful attention to what your opponents are doing.  This is one of the most subtle, rewarding and enjoyable games I've ever played.

Also, I just got both expansions for $15 on Craigslist!

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Puerto Rico is a classic Euro game, and between the deep strategy and near complete absence of luck, it lives up to the hype.  Some complain that new players can "play wrong" by taking suboptimal roles, but I feel like this is just a part of the strategy of the game.  You can't expect the other players to do what's best for you (or even for themselves).

+Deep strategy.
+Multiple paths to victory.
+Introduced (or at least popularized) the role selection mechanism.
+Little down time.

-Steep learning curve.
-With all buildings available every game, games could potentially end up playing out similarly, but I think there are so many options, this is a very small concern.
-Calling the brown worker tokens "colonists" whitewashes the issue of slavery in the game's theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Deceptively simple game mechanics.  Tons of depth.  Setup time drags it down a little.

RATING: 7

My first eurogame and it's a classic. Multiple paths to victory... minimal luck and the luck that is present merely changes the path to victory. GREAT game!

RATING: 6
I like the strategy part of this game. There is very little 'chance' element as players themselves choose the events of the turns. This ensures that each game has a different feel and that there are more than one way to win. - UPDATE: Those "more than one way to win" paths are actually pretty fixed, as there are a certain number of strategies that has been categorized as "the right ones" by people who have played this game a lot. This limits the fun for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Type of game I like but am notoriously bad at. At least in my mind. Needs an upgrade/update in components and graphics, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
This game is best when played with exactly four players, and with the inclusion of two key tournament rule variations:  first, the players starting with corn start the game with one fewer doubloon, and second, the costs of building the university and factory are switched (university now costs 7, factory costs 8).  

The tightness and balance of the tournament-variant four-player game is a thing of beauty, particularly among four similarly-skilled players.  If there is a newbie with three other more advanced players, then... well, let me just say it is generally best to find yourself seated to immediately follow the newbie's play (a newbie rarely seems to appreciate the best and worst moments to select the Craftsman, for instance, so the player immediately following the newbie gets the benefit of continually having first go at the market or the ships following production).

I don't particularly like this with three given the omission of the Prospector role (which has the benefit not only of money, but of also being the only role that doesn't grant other players a benefit--sometimes a key play).  At 5 it is certainly playable, but the higher money count to start the game and the influx of even more money via two prospectors makes the price of the buildings not exactly at scale (the first player to build on the first turn can select a tobacco storage or a large market, for example).  

I still find this to be an enjoyable design after 15 years--though maybe part of it is nostalgia since this was the game I credit with really getting me back into board gaming.

RATING: 7
A game of Puerto Rico is a bit like a date that went ... okay. It was nice. It was a nice place, food was good, we had a nice talk. Interesting. Everything was ... fine. Sevenoutoften, would date again. Call me. Maybe.

Puerto Rico is an old classic, which means it has well-balanced dynamics, a wide variety of possible strategies, it is typically ... fun ... to play. But again and again, I find myself playing it with new players, who (understandably) fall back to the usual strategy of producing lots of stuff and shipping it for victory points (even winning the game with it), which gets boring in the end. Obviously, one could play it against a group of more experienced players, but then again ... there are so many more interesting fishes in the sea. Let's have coffee sometime?

RATING: 9
One of my favourite board games. First of all it is quite easy to learn the basics, which is perfect for new players. Another big bonus, which is beneficial both for newcomers and veterans is the short playtime. The reason for this is of course that shorter games tend to be played a lot more than longer ones. 

The game also offer a lot of tactics, which include indirect interaction with other players. I don't mind that the interaction is not direct in this game, since most of your moves affect the other players in some way. This is a game that will always be a part of my collection.

RATING: 10
This is a great game for almost any group and is our family's favorite - beating out Settlers of Catan.  It is challenging for adults and hard core gamers, yet children (not real young) can play.  We played recently and my 7 year old son won and we didn't let him either.  I couldn't believe it!  It also plays shorter (or at least seems to) than indicated on the box.  The main thing is when the game is over ALL of us wish it would've lasted longer - this game never drags on.  Something I can't honestly say about any other game.  An added benefit is the price.  Compared to other games and what you get with this - tons of bits, this is the best value around.

RATING: 8
Quizá sus componentes no están a la altura de los estándares actuales, pero sigue siendo bonito ver cómo tu isla crece y se convierte en un pequeño mundo lleno de trabajadores, edificios y campos... También es uno de los juegos mejor equilibrados de todos los "Euros duros", con muchas estrategias y formas diferentes de desarrollar tu isla.
Sin embargo, y a causa de la mecánica de roles, cuando juegan jugadores experimentados con un novato éste puede desequilibrar el juego entregando la victoria al jugador sentado a su lado.
-------------------------------------------------
Maybe its components are not up to nowadays standards, but it’s still nice to see how your island grows and becomes a small world full of workers, buildings and crops... It is also one of the more perfectly balanced games from all the hard Euros, with many different strategies and ways to develop your island.
On the bad side, when playing with an unexperienced player he can totally unbalance the game giving victory to the player sitting next to him...

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A worthy game for the innovative turn-sequence system alone - and there's more.  The game also combines the "multiple paths to victory" as in Princes of Florence, and the "break normal game rules" aspect of some CCGs (or Cosmic Encounter, Ursuppe/Urland etc.) in the form of purple building functions.  (And yes, the buildings can be very powerful.)  And yet the balance between the various game elements (building costs etc.) seems to be just right, so that there is no single obvious winning strategy (at least it seems so) nor elements which become useless because they're too weak.  A most excellent, finely-crafted game.  Perhaps the best of 2002, my bet for DSP winner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
if i need to give one 10 mark for game, i will choose Puerto Rico.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I played this game just three times, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple plays.

I wasn't really impressed by Puerto Rico after the first couple of plays, but I enjoyed it a lot better the third time. I like the fact that the game flows so smooth and easily. The action selection mechanism is simple, but really clever and deep enough to grant an interesting game-play that keeps everybody at the table engaged the whole time. These are all characteristics of a very good design. On the other hand I can't say that I enjoy Puerto Rico so much that I wish to own it. 

The first reason is the visual impact of the game and the component quality. I played two editions so far and both of them have this really thin cheap cardboard and kinda poor artwork. Everything feels very bland... which it's surprising. You think that a game as popular as this one would have gotten a nicer edition. The second thing that lowers my enjoyment of the game is the limited amount of strategies that it offers. The game is always the same every time you set it up. That's similar to Caverna, which is a game I love, but here there's only a very small amount of buildings and some of them are clearly stronger than the others. They don't allow enough variety to make me want to go back to the game and explore it more.

At the end I think that Puerto Rico is a good game and an example of simple and yet deep design. On the other hand I think it shows its age a little too much and nowadays there's similar games on the market that do the same thing better. Still enjoyable though!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
#1 on BBG. Rightfully so.

[b]Affordability[/b] - [microbadge=39229]
[b]Functionality[/b] - [microbadge=39224]
[b]Originality[/b] - [microbadge=39224]
[b]Quality[/b] - [microbadge=39227]
[b]Reusability[/b] - [microbadge=39222]
[b]Variability[/b] - [microbadge=39222]

[b]Solo Variant[/b] - [listitem=1129360]Puerto Rico SoloPlay[/listitem] by [user=GameRulesforOne]GameRulesforOne[/user]

:thumbsup: The amount of required table space is pleasantly small for the amount of components.
:thumbsup: There is an interesting puzzle to work through in terms of choosing the order of the roles.

[microbadge=30754][c] [/c]There are significant gameplay differences with the solo variant, which makes it a poor way to practice.
[microbadge=30754][c] [/c]The text is prominent and easy to read, yet there is a distinct lack of artwork.

:thumbsdown: Decisions are rarely challenging, and there is little in terms of interesting mechanics and enjoyment.
:thumbsdown: There is a significant disconnect with the theme so that there is no emotional attachment nor narrative.

RATING: 6
[b]Impressions after 1 play:[/b]
It's a good game, luckless, in which you try to build plantations and other buildings in order to gather as many VPs as possible.
What I like about it:
- that you cannot trade the same goods as before (at least until the trading house is emptied)
- that you must fill the boats in order to ship the goods, which creates some nice strategies
What I didn't like:
- it's bland....let's say tasteless... although much better and more complex than San Juan, I still prefer RftG

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
STRATEGY

A rather complex game set in colonial Puerto Rico involving the production, trade, and shipment of corn, indigo, tobacco, and coffee. Very strong strategy component (which explains its Board Game Geek rating), similar to San Juan. Check out the Board Games with Scott review for a great rules refresher. 

An "official" two-player rule set is linked from the Puerto Rico files area on BGG.

We own the expansions for the game that are included in the Treasure Chest. They are in the box.

Recommended with 2-5 players (best 4). 90-150 mins.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Still the greatest boardgame ever, after 7 years.
I have played over 700 times. 
Incredibly deep, you can play 50 or 100 times and still not fully comprehend this game.
Incredibly well balanced, almost no luck involved, the outcome is determined almost entirely by player interactions/decisions.  'Luck' occurs in the form of player chaos / player role selections which could hurt or help you.
The game doesnt even take the 90 mins stated on the box, once players become familiar with it, it takes about 45-75 mis, depending on #players.  (Played online, this goes to 20-30 minutes for 3 player, 30-45 for 4 player, 45 to 60 for 5 player.)
I cannot recommend this game enough, it is absolutely amazing. It is the most perfect boardgame I have ever played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A good game that has no luck involved in the game.  Players can win with employing different strategies.  Player with the most victory points wins the game.

Good points: Quite easy to play once you get the hang of the game.  By choosing different characters, players have different advantages during each round of the game.

Bad points: There is hardly any bad points about the game.  

If compared to Caylus, I think Caylus has slightly more dimension than Puerto Rico.  It is important to both have money (to place workers) and resources (to build buildings and castle) in Caylus but in Puerto Rico, there is only money which is important for buying buildings.  The resources of Puerto Rico can be the various types of plantations but it can be taken for free, but the building resources of Caylus has to be harvested with placing of workers.  With royal favours in Caylus, it also adds more strategy into the game.  In all both are good games, but I think Caylus is slightly better than Puerto Rico.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dropped from a 9 based on a few minor factors (player order issues and a semi-scripted game start the most notable). That said, this is a game that deserves its high ranking here - thematically richer than many of its brethren, strong player game engine development, and a great length-of-game makes this a favorite!

RATING: 7
In my experience it's pretty rare to find combo-driven game where all the pieces are so well balanced against each other. That alone deserves a high rating.

It's also good with multiple player counts and doesn't take too long to play so it gets thrown in the bag when arrangements are uncertain. The reasonably sized box helps for that, too.

My favorite thing about Puerto Rico is the dance around who is going to take Craftsman. I wouldn't mind finding a game with the same tension but without the engine building.

Update: lowered to a 7 due to the engine building. It can be quite a bit of fiddling just to arrive at the meatier decisions. It's still good, but looking at my other eights I like them much more.

RATING: 8
each turn you select one role, and use the benefits associated with that role. Problem is, everyone else gets to take that action as well - so make sure you are not helping them more than you help yourself. Also notable for best euphemism in my games collection (it describes the workers delivered to you as "colonists" when you know full well they're slaves). It deserves its reputation and has seen many plays from me.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I love some of the game mechanics behind PR, especially the role cards (and the monetary incentive to pick a card unused in the previous round). 

However, I find PR to dull, dry, and boring. It's too mechanical: build a plantation, build a matching production building, place colonists on the plantation and production buildings, produce a good, and then ship goods for victory points but only if the ship is free. There are other things you can do to get money, increase production, etc., but overall, the whole process is not fun.

My other criticism is that at half-way through the game, it's pretty clear who will be the winner. You can see the strategy play out and guess which roles will be selected. If you are collecting more points and/or money half-way through the game for a particular role, then there is not much that can be done for others to catch up and pass you when that role is selected. 

*** UPDATE 1: I played PR again with 3 other gamers for the first time as an experienced euro-gamer. I had a much more positive gaming experience - the game wasn't as dull as I remembered it. Now that we all understood how euro-games work in general, we all picked up on the different strategies for winning. ***

*** UPDATE 2: Meh, only mildly interested in ever playing this again. ***

Played Puerto Rico several times before I started tracking my games played (approx. 5-8 times).

RATING: 8
Puerto Rico was the third game I bought. I had only played El Grande and Settlers of Catan beore buying this game. Both of the previous games were taught to me so I did not have any experience making my way through a rule book. The fact that this game breaks down the common notion of what a game 'turn' is didn't help either.

Needless to say this game went unplayed for a long time until I found some one who was willing to teach the game to me and my game group. After being taught the game all I thought about was Puerto Rico. Having played Race for the Galaxy before hand helped me pick up on many of the more subtle complexities of this game as well. Truly a classic and one that I will be playing for a long time to come.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A fantastic game with one of the early role-selection mechanics that remains interesting.  Planning around the turn order cycle is challenging, as this is a game where you are definitely not going to be able to do everything you want to accomplish in a turn.  The economics are fairly simple, but that cycle is what makes the game so interesting.  I wish more people in my play group were into this, because I think this has the potential to be a very competitive game once everyone has had a few sessions to figure out their preferred strategy.  Sadly, the set up time keeps this off the table more than is fair.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Puerto Rico feels like clockwork. It's a classic. It has an incredibly clean, smooth design. I would recommend it to anyone interested in trying out the whole 'Euro game' thing who doesn't mind if the game's theme is a little dry and detached. Puerto Rico has a soul, but it's not very thematic.

My issue with PR these days is that the base game is just kind of played out for me. The options are pretty obvious and I feel like I'm sort of just going through the motions.

I like to add the expansion bits to spice things up. But it doesn't seem to happen very often when PR hits the table!

RATING: 10
I find it slightly dry and mechanical, and not quite as much fun as Settlers or Princes of Florence. It's also difficult to gauge one's progress relative to the other players, which reduces the tension factor somewhat.

Yet it intrigues and draws me like no other game has done. Each game is better than the last, and it promises to deliver strategic depth and replay value second-to-none.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2-5(4)

This is a solid design that scales very well and offers all players the freedom to, generally, do what they want. The buildings really allow players to define their game and while there can indeed be kingmaking and the like, I think this effect is exaggerated, especially if you alert new players as to the interactions and risks of certain actions.

This is indeed a game where you have to be keenly aware of other players' statuses and play to that.

---------------------------------------------------

The 2p variant is good, and quite a bit deeper than San Juan. Multiplayer it's also very good. Not a whole lot of things going on, but enough that you're pretty engaged (without being overwhelmed). The key is timing your cycle against other players (such that you leech their actions and they don't leech yours, if possible). Production values show their age a bit, and there are some imbalanced elements (first corn player and craftsman being two famous ones), but it's an enjoyable classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Puerto Rico was an interesting game to initially learn, but I'm just not excited to play Puerto Rico compared to other games.  Simply put, there isn't enough variation or player interaction:  no direct contention for board position, no trading, no fun really.

RECOMMENDATIONS: 
 - San Juan (the thematically related card game) has a similar feel, but is much faster to learn, setup, and play.
 - Agricola is a similar type of game with much improved game mechanics such as start cards and varied player action order.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
:arrowE: [u]Synopsis[/u]:
Pick a role. Everyone gets to take the action, but you do it better. The granddaddy of Role Selection, a giant among Euros, the shoulders upon which much stands today. Produce goods through the combination of plantations and related refinement structures, ship said goods for points, sell said goods for cash, buy buildings, populate the island, utterly screw your opponents. 

:arrowE: [u]What I like most[/u]:
You know, there are a crap-ton of Role Selection games nowadays. You know what else? Fun as they might be, they're not as good as Puerto Rico. This game laid the foundation for the mechanic, and frankly, it still does it the best. The action economy is so hinged on timing that it is impossible to play well without reading the table and noting trends and patterns. One must decide when to help oneself while also ensuring that the simultaneous action helps everyone else as little as possible. Watching the different role fire off at specific points is like watching an elegant set of gears tick from one moment to the next. I especially like the tipping point when everyone's economy is stable enough to start plowing through Captain and Builder actions.

:arrowE: [u]What I like least[/u]:
The illustration and (especially) graphic design are pretty lame in the original version, and I missed the boat (HA!) on the "Limited" anniversary edition which improves both. Good thing [person=50716][/person] made this exceptional redesign, which is the best in class for all categories!

[imageid=2986688 medium]
:arrowE: [size=13][url=https://play.spotify.com/artist/3fvnWc7bLQVnkrtFI298rl][b]PLAYLIST[/b][/url][/size]

[hr]
11/16/17 EDIT: I'm moving this rating from 8 to 10 because, frankly, Puerto Rico only gets better each time I play it. To be honest, I don't know why I ever rated it anything else. With all of the great games available today, few of them eclipse how lovely and gripping this "old" game is.

RATING: 8

Experience does not count as much as being able to plan a few turns ahead.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A great great game, the best I've played. Always fun, fast and strategic/tactical with little to no downtime. Easy to learn, hard to master and plays suprisingly different each time, even though there is very little random elements and no luck involved. It has a nice amount of interaction and every decision is a tough one. It's also in my opinion a great and tight 2-player game. I actually think it plays best with two. It does need the expansion buildings in order to have enough variance for dozens of plays against same players. The 2nd edition/Anniversary-edition art is great and the game even has some theme to it.

Fun factor: 5/5
Strategy vs. luck: 5/5
Mechanics/gameplay tied to the theme: 3/5
Component/art quality: 4/5 (with "Anniversary"-edition art, but thin cardboard and awful coins)
Replayability: 5/5 (with the "New Buildings"-expansion)

I don't get into the whole optimizing-the-bejeezus-out-of-it as other Euro-drones might; there are other ways I would prefer to spend 90-120 minutes. RATING: 9
A superb, solid and serious game (albeit overrated, over-analyzed and over-played). What others do almost matters more than what you do. Much of the time your role selection is practically forced and involves no real choice; for example, if you take Craftsman you'll probably get screwed when the next player takes Captain. (The whole game seems to be funneled through the Craftsman, by the way.)  Having said all this, I do admit that the better players seem to win most of the time, and by 2017's low standards this is certainly a masterpiece.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Puerto Rico's flaws are more apparent now than they were 10 years ago.  The fixed player order, and the ease with which a novice can inadvertently throw the game to the player to his left, are major drawbacks.

But Puerto Rico marks a true inflection point in the history of modern board games, and deserves its status as a classic.  I still find it interesting after dozens of plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the first modern games I played and it's a really good one.  It's famous enough that it probably doesn't need me to say much about it.

The nearly luckless pieces all fit together really well with lots of different choices offered -- primarily but not exclusively in the role selection.  Players can also follow different strategies to victory, using the different abilities offered by a variety of buildings.

After playing it a lot, I haven't played it in a long time as I've explored other games.  I'm curious if it will drop to a '9' when I revisit it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
PROS:
*) Very little luck
*) Subtle player interactions, that become apparent only after a few plays
*) Different winning strategies, and you need to think ahead
*) At any given time, the number of choices are very limited (which makes the game relatively easy to learn)
*) Handy box, easy to take along
CONS:
*) Player interactions are not direct (which I personally miss)
*) At any given time, the number of choices are very limited (which makes you feel sometimes you can't control your destiny)

Upped this game from 7 to 8 after I realized how the subtle player interactions work.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
While much has been praised about the game's design there are cracks in the fortress of the top rated game.  Players are likely to feel that there are significant options to play a strategy.  In truth this selection is more limited than not.  A player's actions are almost entirely dictated by the actions of other players.  This happens from the first turn and does not end until the game is finished.  This may leave players feeling like the game plays itself out rather than the players participating.  It's okay, but not the best game out there.  [GTI Code: TGSD]

RATING: 9.2
An excellent, classic worker placement game where you're building plantations and buildings to gather up resources and then ship them for points. Plays smoothly, and I enjoy the role choice mechanics and rotation, keeps things exciting for a number of plays. Not the best game ever, but it deserves its popularity, and I think there's a lot of crossover appeal with games like Castles of Burgundy or Le Havre.

RATING: 10
This is a great game.  It's one of those games where every time you think you have it mastered, it presents another level of complexity.  I love the lack of random elements (aside from the plantation selection, of course).  With a playtime of 45 minutes to an hour, this is my favorite short game.

The expansion is nice, but not at all necessary.  Most of the new buildings mirror the old ones in premise, if not exact function.  However, you can create some interesting combos with new and old.

The nobles are pretty broken.

The big problem with Puerto Rico is playing with inexperienced/aloof players.  The game breaks because it's too easy for a new or lazy player to hand the game to the player on his/her left without even knowing.
Another problem is the buildings are slightly imbalanced, some will be chosen more readily than others and if you deviate from this basic strategy by.. for example.. choosing the Office you'll likely run into cashflow trouble.

RATING: 8
A lovely Euro, and really not dry at all (as some Ameritrashers love to deem it). The only drawback is slightly steep learning curve and the dreaded "winning strategy? Sit left of the newbie." syndrome. But if you like Euros, you'll like Puerto Rico, hands down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
More than a decade after its release, Peurto Rico still manages to offer an incredibly rich euro-style gaming experience that competes with more modern titles. This is a game that every euro-gamer should try. 

For casual gamers, the game scales relatively well 2-5 players and offers immense replayability. The only "turn off" to casual/family gamers is learning the numerous buildings and how they interact with the various roles; simply put, the game will likely take a few plays until those players grasp the important nuances.

For competitive gamers, the game has low randomness and offers tons of brain-burning and tense decisions. That being said, there are some issues/complaints. For one, there seems to be a limited number of viable strategies (Building vs Shipping). Secondly, there seems to be an inherent advantage with sitting to the left-side of an experience player. And thirdly, the strengths/weaknesses of each strategy is really dictated by the group play; This makes the game more tactical and creates imbalances with odd-player counts. For instance, if 2-players are focusing on a shipping strategy and 1-player is focusing on a building strategy, the shipping strategy is likely to be more viable as those actions are being selected more often. As a consequence, the 4-player game is considered superior... but for most gamers, it works quite well 2-5 (Use Craftsmen Angst variant with 2-player). 

The only strong complaint I can make is with the component quality. For such a popular and widely-distributed game... it's very disappointing that the game art/components haven't been upgraded. 

The iOS adaptation is well done; they managed to place all the relevant information on one screen and create something that's easy to follow. The only things I would change would be some zoom-function, especially for the captain action, and an online lobby to make matchmaking easier. Other than that, it is a pleasure to play and the interface is better than BoardGameArena. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The full game as grown on me, but I would need the expansion tiles before I would buy it.

The expansions don't help remedy this- now instead a knife fight in an alley' you have a knife fight at a bar.

RATING: 9
Juego maravilloso. Mecanica del juego sencilla de explicar y varias opciones de victoria distinta. Como juego introductorio excelente...

Edito a 30-6-2011: Mediante la elección de roles se crean cada turno las fases que se han de jugar. Cada rol crea una fase y da un bonus a la persona que lo hubiera elgido. Se traen colonos a la isla, se crean plantaciones,  edificios, se hace producir a las plantacionmes y se llama al barco para exportar los bienes producidos... Sencillo de explicar, algo más dificil de controloar y con muchas posibilidades de pasarlo pirata... Realmente explicarlo a no-jugones es un placer... Les ves cómo se les van abriendo los ojos... y es que por algo el Puerto Rico es un juegazo. Para mí por detrás del Caylus o el Agricola, pero es que para ser justos el PR fue anterior a éstos y se puede jugar con no jugones ya que no abruma...

UPDATE: Once I prepared my gaming group for more complex games, they really digged this one. Even my wife's grandmother loves it! Not only it's a great game, but it's also a great game that is enjoyed by most players, gamer-like or not!

UPDATE: I've started noticing it always playes more or less the same. I've been told this issue is solved with the expansion, but the game itself, without the expansion, is just not as fun as it used to be. Still a solid 8, but no longer a perfect game for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
There's so much that has already been said about PR and I don't think I can add anything new to the chorus of praise.  It's a great blend of tactics and strategy.

It has a great feel and a nice look to it.  One of my friends has commented several times about how she likes how "everything has it's own little place." :)

It's a thoughtful game and for the most part my group gets pretty quiet while playing and the interaction can seem sparse at times.  However you WILL hear cries of anguish or cackles of glee when one person gets blocked out of a crucial trade or shipment.


Some of the game's critics do bring up good points.  A players success can sometimes feel greatly tied to their position on the table and the game suffers a bit when playing with people of varied experience.  Plus there are times when it feels less like you are playing more against a system rather than people.

Overall I think the impact of these problems do not take away from the quality of the game.  It's a great experience.

Update:  Great game but the "Cult of the New" has ground down the rating a bit.  Still a tip top game.  But there are so many games out there!

RATING: 8
This game is a pretty good game from the few times I've played.  However, it is not for the feint hearted, and the finer points of the game take some time to pick up on. It suffers from the "who every sits to your left" syndrome, that is, that player determines to a great extent, how well the player to their right does in the game.  Also, it's kinds of a steep learning curve because every buildign presents itself as an execption to the rules, that is, it takes a while for a new guy to pick up on all the options that are there, and it slows down the game a bit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
This game used to be my favorite that I always wanted to suggest to play. Now it's not so much. I don't like the chess-like feeling of "OK, if I take the Builder, I'll build this. He'll probably build that. And she'll probably build that. Then he'll take the the craftsman, and She'll take the trader. Then next round he'll take the mayor...no, that doesn't work. OK, what if I take the craftsman?". You need to think too far down these decision trees, planning out not only your own turns but predicting each opponent as well. A catalyst for AP. Still, it's a great game underneath that, but that aspect can get very frustrating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Set up is tedious, as is clean up.
The game is very delightful to play with people of the same skill level, but if you are not evenly matched with the other players, the game starts to feel too scripted and feels like you are a puppet in a game.  

This "puppet" aspect of the game soured it for me pretty badly.  If played as a light, non-serious game, I give this game a 9, as a game that I play with others at conventions and on BSW, I rate it accordingly here.

RATING: 9
Nagyon tetszett ez a játék, szívesen játszanék még vele. Amikor az első partit játszottam, akkor az a fajta társasjátékos voltam, aki két játékot ismer: a Catant, és a Carcassone-t. Ezek után érthetően sokk-ként ért a Puerto Rico, jóval komplexebb a másik 2 játéknál. Másodjára már sokkal jobban élveztem, nagyon tetszik a szerepek folytonos váltogatása, és az, hogy az egyes műveletek nem minden körben hajtódnak végre. A véletlen szerepe egyedül az ültetvények felcsapásánál jelenik meg, épp ezért a rutintalan játékosok szerintem meglehetősen nagy hátrányban vannak. Akivel én játszottam,annak pl. kialakult (nyerő?!) stratégiája van a játékra, ebben a helyzetben elég esélytelennek éreztem magam. Szükség lesz még néhány menetre, hogy készség szinten átlássam a játékot, akkor több eséllyel vágok neki.
---
Minden játékkal egyre jobban tetszik!
---
Közel 500 játékot kipróbálva nosztalgikusan gondolok erre az elsők közt kipróbált játékra. Azóta már rengeteg jóval összetettebb játékkal találkoztam, de ez a szerepválasztós mechanizmus mai napig az egyik legeredetibb ötlet, amivel találkoztam. (Oké tudom, hogy a Citadella előbb volt, mégis...)

RATING: 9
This game has grown on me a lot. It plays quick and a good balance of strategy and tactics.  If it wasn't for the buildings, I would rate this a 10.  The buildings provide a tough barrier for new players.

4-15-07
Oh who am I kidding?  This is a 10.  I can't think that I will ever get tired of playing this game, especially with the expansion.  The criticisms of "screw your left" shananagans and feeling like you are forced to choose certain roles are completely valid.  However, that is only a problem if you let your OPPONENTS tell you what you should do.  They aren't there to help you win, they are just telling you to do certain things because it will help them out.  Throw them a curve ball here and there and they'll stop trying to force you to take certain actions.  There is just so many things going on in this game it is insane.  A lot of strategy/tactical goodness to be had here.
UPDATE: 9 -> 10

5-19-2007
As great as this game is I am going to have to deduct a point.  It just irritates me how this game cannot handle a group of varying skills.  So many times that the newbie/novice just helps out and sets up random people.  It is especially bad if they helped someone get a huge head start by letting them trade.  I also don't want the coin to fall in favor of me as I know the victory is not well earned.  I still like the game very much, but not as enthusiastic about it due to it's "fragility."  This really sucks the fun out of it.
Update: 10 -> 9

Update: 11 Nov 2007
I played this game again with 2 new people and I just did not enjoy it.  Typically teaching games to others is fun for me but the fact that the left-player binding is just too much for me.  Puerto Rico is really only fun when the players are about of the same skill level.
Update: 9 -> 8

Aug-08-2008
If playing with experienced players of similar skill level, then this game is a 9.  Unfortunately, I really really dislike the left/right binding effect that happens in this game when dealing with weaker players and it really just frustrates me to see someone getting crazy windfalls from mistimed crafting.  With that in mind it ranks down to 5 that I don't even want to play it.  So I'll just average the two extremes down to 7, which actually falls in quite nicely on how I feel about the game.    I'd play it if people want to and need a few more players, but I wouldn't request it and don't need to have my own copy.
Rating: 8 -> 7

Update: 2012.12.31
After trading it away, I ended up requesting this myself and playing with my friend's copies quite a bit.  I was even sad that when they don't bring it.  This game just hits such a sweet spot.  It is a fast game with such great depth.  No other game has such a great depth to game lentgh ratio.
Rating: 7 -> 9

RATING: 10
Every choice is rife with ramifications.  Little downtime.  A good blend of short-term play and long-term planning.  Each play is simple, but the total is complex/chaotic while still being manageable.  Good for two players; even more control and less downtime.
Not perfect though. 1) it takes too long, 2) five player games have too much chaos, 3) a non-optimal play by one player can seriously adversely affect others, and 4) the last few rounds of the game are less interesting (though very important).

I enjoy the economic aspects of the game, though at times I feel a little strapped for cash and it negatively affects my enjoyment of the game.  I find it scales very well and have enjoyed the two player variant even more than playings with five.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the tightest and most satisfying game-play/boardgame experiences I've ever had.  No wonder this game was #1 on the BGG charts forever long.

2.1.12 - After 5 plays in, this game continues to impress.  I can't say the same about Le Havre, which I just traded away.  PR continuously provides a rich gaming experience regardless of the outcome.   

4.3.12 - Since my last edit, I've had a chance to play a couple of 4 and 2 player games.  This game has not lost any of its "flavor," even though I've had a chance to play several other games in between my last group of plays (i.e. TtR: Marklin, Power Grid, Twilight Imperium 3 - all good games by the way), and I thoroughly enjoy the PR no matter if I win or lose.  This game belongs in any gamers collection.  One added recommendation, if you are a fan of Euro-style games, think about shelling out the extra money to get the Anniversary Edition for the nicer components, plus both expansions.  This will be a game you will most likely own for a long long time.

4.20.12 - PR is quickly becoming the crown jewel of my game collection.

RATING: 8
[COLOR=#959595][SIZE=7]Spiel des Jahres Nominee 2002[/SIZE][/COLOR]
[b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 2002[/b]
Alea Big-Box #7

[i]Posted: 10/3/05, Rated: 8[/i]

After four or five games of [i]Puerto Rico[/i], I can say that I really like it.  From the stutter-step turn order of the Governor placard, to the seemingly myriads of tactical uses for the different roles (offensive captaining is so much fun!), there are a lot of nuances to absorb.

I have not yet tried the online version of this game on BSW, for the simple reason that I don't want to be ridiculed for being a newbie.  I know I am.  My skill level is proportionate to my gaming group, and we enjoy playing this game.

However, it is a bit more complicated, and takes longer to play than [i][thing=8217]San Juan[/thing][/i].  Right now, [i][thing=8217]San Juan[/thing][/i] gets more table time, simply because it is easier to approach and to learn.  For that reason, [i][thing=8217]San Juan[/thing][/i] gets the "9," and [i]Puerto Rico[/i] the "8."  Perhaps in a few months time as the group's abilities improve, these positions will be reversed.


[url=http://www.boardgameswithscott.com/?p=80]BGWS Review[/url]

My only complaint is the University;  I've never bought it.

RATING: 8
Since it's the highest rated game on BGG I had to try it out and got an opportunity in a game of 4 players. 2 were beginners (me included) and 2 had played it a few times before. I had played San juan that is the sister game to Puerto Rico alot of times before but Puerto rico proved to include a great deal more elements and tactical choises.
First time playing it was hard to go for a strategy and the order in which you can take your turns and who sits before you and what tactic they go for will influence you a great deal in this game. Doing your own race can easily become a nightmare if the person ahead of you (in all but 1 turn when you are first) uses a tactic that will cancel out the effect of your brilliant tactical scheme.

Overall this is among the better games I have played but I can't put it as number one as I've enjoyed other games just as much or even more.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A wonderful design, with a good deal of strategic and tactical depth. The role selection mechanic is very interesting, and the rest of the game works very well, with a good implementation of chance (plantations), scarcity/demand, and a reasonable amount of player interaction for a game that provides each player with his own board rather than allowing for interaction on a common board. The main problem plaguing Puerto Rico, and perhaps the only thing really holding it back, is the 'player on the right' effect, where the player to the right of the player who makes a bad move (generally crafting, but sometimes neglecting to take a role that would disproportionately help the next player) benefits the most. Over a number of rounds, this effect can greatly affect the results of the game. In some games, a player makes a bad move that benefits everyone else equally (mostly in widening the scoring gap); in others, a player makes a bad move that benefits one other player, but can later make a bad move that benefits a different player. In Puerto Rico, a poor player provides a large advantage almost exclusively to the person who has the first opportunity to capitalize on the mistake. It's not just a problem of 'Player X failed to stop the leader', but a problem of 'Player X's actions unevenly benefited one person throughout the game'. Still, Puerto Rico is a great game, and it is hard to fault it too much. (2009-07)

Update: For players of equal skill, I'd rate this a 10 (rating was previously a 9 due to the 'player on the right' effect). For more mixed groups, the rating suffers a bit. I'm not sure by how much, as it is certainly still enjoyable, but it isn't as good of a game without all players operating at the same level. But this is true of most games, so it's hard to fault Puerto Rico for it. (Addendum: I suppose there may be some balance issues with 3- and 4-player games due to the trading house only having 4 spaces, rather than N spaces [e.g., one player gets a double-trade opportunity in 3p, or one player gets shut out in 4p] but -- as with the 'player on the right' effect -- I'm not sure this is a flaw meriting a decrease in the game's rating. If anything, the fact that there are some buildings that are of marginal utility in [i]any[/i] strategy while others are highly beneficial in almost any situation is a bit of a fault. However, this makes competing for those few buildings tense, rather than simply allowing players access to a victory point buffet through every building, which is a good thing in my view. So even the 'imbalance' in the building set is ok.) (2014-01)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Door velen verkozen tot het beste spel van de moderne spelen. Vernieuwende spelmechanismen zorgen voor een geweldige spelervaring.

RATING: 8

There is also great interaction though out the game play as each role picked by your opponent will have an effect on you. Fast moving and interesting, a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Finally got around to playing this game (Have owned for a year). We have a weekly game night and this was always pushed aside do to the length of time to learn and then lenght of time to play. This is a really, really good game. The machanics are fun and incorporate many of my favorite mechanics from different games. Everything you do effects the entire group so player interaction is high. It does not need to be devious and you are not attacking other players however everything you do will either positively or negatively effect everyone else.
 
Even though there is a lot going on it is not difficult to play, you really need to dive in to fully understand the rules. Play time was also not as bad as advertised. We stayed within the projected game time on our first run while figuring everything out. This game can be played in under 120min. Bottom line, this game is really all it is cracked up to be and deserves it spot at the top of every board game list. One of the best games I have ever played. I thought about strategies for 5 days after my first play. Wow. You really need this one in your collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A fun time, it struck me at first play and made its way home sooner than some others I was aware of around the same time. A bit out of order in fact, and that really tells you what you need to know.

Yes I thought it would fit my current regular group better than the others, and yes it has performed well in front of a mixture of that group.

Bottom line is the game has been enjoyed, and is a solid worker placement game, there are no lasers or muskets even in this one, if you want to manage resources and workers, then this one is for you. While reading to learn is ALWAYS prudent about new games,Its elegance shows through in play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
People in my group have played this a lot more than I have, and resulting game play through difference in skill level has been a bit frustrating. Tonight was the first time where I played it with another novice, which gave me a bit of a chance to explore without being clubbered from all sides, which was great.

I can see it being a great game, but I don't see it as great to the exclusion of so many other wonderful games out there. Still feel that even though there are many strategies you can follow, too often I feel forced to take the "obvious" one, either because otherwise one player benefits disproportionally, or simply because it's the one move that screams out to be made. It also feels shorter than I would like it to be. The ending can come really sudden, it has a habit of finishing two or three turns too early for my liking. Still not sure if the sort of game play I like best actually fits in the turns available.

It's a game I would love to like more, but it hasn't done it for me just yet. Maybe people have just raved about it a bit too much, it made me wonder from the beginning if this would be my ultimate game too. And judging against perfection, so far it falls a few hurdles short.

It is telling that I had it for over 2 years before I cracked it open. The temptation to play wasn't exactly urgent, despite all the good stories. Maybe I am really looking for something else from my game nights, or maybe I have just too many alternatives around me to get bowled over by a single game. It isn't always the best game that pleases me most.

UPDATE: starting to bore me a bit. Maybe I feel it is becoming a bit too mechanical. Maybe playing too many games with similar mechanisms just now. Rating down from 8.5

RATING: 8
Tästä kaikki alkoi. Puerto Rico oli ensimmäinen uusista "kunnon" lautapeleistä, mitä pelasin. Ja olihan se hyvä. Pikkasen kaavamaiselta tuntui kuitenkin jo muutaman pelin jälkeen. Sitten tuli vielä Caylus, ja ai että ku se oli hyvä. Sen koommin en ole Puerto Ricosta jaksanut innostua. Ehkä tätä onki pelannu liian vähän, kun ei nappaa. (17.3.2009)

Arvosana nousussa, kun pelejä on taas kertyny pitkän tauon jälkeen. BSW:ssä pelattu useita pelejä, livenäkin muutama. BSW:ssä peli voi mennä alle tuntiin, eikä livenäkään pelit ole venyneet samoihin mittoihin kun silloin joskus. Pelejä on voitettu sekä laivausseolla, rakennusääryydellä että hybriditällillä, joten taktiikoita riittää. Ompa tullut kokeiltua jotain hämäriäkin juttuja, eikä tulos ole mikään katastrofi ollut, joten vaihtelua riittää. On kyllä hyvä peli. Pikku hiljaa koiteltu myös lisäosaa, ja bsw:ssä tulee randomilla muutama rakennus siitä, joten vaihtelu on mukavaa ja piristivää, mutta ei liiallista. (26.2.2010)

RATING: 9
I've heard complaints that the game lacks sufficient randomness, that there's an objective Best Move you can make on any given turn -- and that some players will lose their shit if you do anything else.

Whatever.  I've never encountered anybody that insufferable, and I still have a hell of a lot of fun playing this.  (Though I admit, the implications surrounding the "colonists" and their "colony ship" do squick me out a bit.)  This is a role selection and resource management brainburner that forces me to think several steps ahead, and bite my nails in the hopes that other players' choices won't hose my carefully laid plans.  Even when I'm doing poorly, the game keeps me engaged from start to finish.  It's a classic for a reason.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Doesn't work with 2p.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Every time I play this game I'm amazed by the simple, but deep mechanics. The only random factors include choosing the player order (literally where you sit at the table) and the selection of the plantations that will be available. A masterfully balanced, role/action selection scheme drives the game. Bribes increase the value of roles that are not selected in any given round to encourage players to take advantage of them in following rounds. Multiple game end possibilities (out of colonists, out of victory points, or out of building space) lead to a game that never ends in quite the same way and usually tends to end just as a few people are really gathering momentum. Perfect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not boring, but not entertaining either.

This game is such a tight design. The game play was awesome. Can't wait to play it again. I would not be surprised if my rating of this will increase with more plays.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Clear rules, a little bit of theme to help you getting the rules, many different but balanced strategies and a lot of interaction. The interaction is what makes this game really good. After your first or second play, you may not know it, but this game is extremely interactive. The interaction is just elegant. Its not about stealing action spaces, or resources from someone. Not about attacking someone. Its about doing things that benefit you the most, and everyone else less. The role selection mechanism, that forces you to think what every turn gives you and everyone else is just great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This game is great! A 2 player, 3 player, 4 player, and 5 player are all different experinces. Five player seems to be the most random. I love the idea and components of this game. Its play time is quick. Best to play with experienced players.

11/1/07: This game is good, but is missing a much needed expansion. Not just different building tiles, but also some new roles. The mechanics and theme have a nice flow, but the game is feeling more and more scripted. Only the 2 player and 4 player games appeal to me and even those games can't have any new players. I have lowered my rating to 7 as it slowly slips out of my top 10. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I finally played and I did not like it anywhere near as much as I thought I would.  This seems like a game for those people who like playing one game a lot and trying to grasp the little nuances of that game.  It is not a game for people who pull out a particular game and play it occasionally.  

With the exception of some new games which get played a lot when they first come out, I tend not to play the same game over and over.  I believe you do have to play this game that way to properly learn how to play it even slightly well.  

I know people who play it regularly and really enjoy it and I will not be playing it with them since I know going in that I wouldn’t even be competitive since I really don’t care a lot about [i]Puerto Rico[/i] or its strategies and there are lots of other deep games which will allow most players to be competitive.  

It might be different if I thought the edge the experienced players had was pure skill, but I feel it is more a familiarity of the workings of all the different (and way too many) parts of the game which give them the advantage, not skill.  There are also lots of fiddly bits to this game and no place to put them while playing.  It really needs a larger center board to organize the roles, the goods, the "colonists", the plantation tiles, and anything else which doesn’t have a set spot.  I’ve played 11 of the 13 big box Alea games and this would be my tenth or eleventh favorite of those games.  I don't think it is a bad game, it just isn't one I expect to ever be excited about playing again.

RATING: 7.5
Lovely, well balanced, thoughtful and fun. I am going to go out on a limb and call it "Agricola lite". 

Update - Just had my first game with less than 5 players and I nearly changed my rating down a couple of points. 5p is certainly the sweet spot.

Update - after 5 games - you know what, I am getting a bit bored with PR. It is an OK game but at well over an hour is too long for something that seems to play out in the same way over and over again.

Further update - yawn, just so negative. You are never trying to improve your own position or really plan a strategy, just working out how to do things that minimise the benefit for other players. An OK game but I would rather play others.

Update after 29 games: Starting to see the attractions of PR again, it is tough for new player in a mixed group but a game between experienced players can be good fun.

It might not offer the thrills of narrative and the laugh all around of other games in my collection, but Puerto Rico offers its own charms on its own terms. It's a tight, dense, thinky game in which one can plunge and still find room to dive. I love this title, particularly for three. I've learned to embrace it for what it is because it does that so well.

RATING: 7
I absolutely loved this game when it first came out--I would have given it a 9.  But the better I got, the less I liked the game.  Luck barely plays a role so what you're left with is a game where the luck that [b]does[/b] occur (namely, the seat draw) dominates unless a player makes a "mistake."  And then when a player makes a mistake, people usually get very upset about having their perfect game ruined.

Nowadays, I'd much rather play San Juan.  A 7 might be generous, but Puerto Rico entertained me for a very long time, and it was an innovative design.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm a big fan of this game. It doesn't have theme You can feel (it could be called "Aruba", "Cuba", "Jamaica" instead of "Puerto Rico"). Game is about producing goods like coffee, corn and the like and exporting Your products (don't know where, maybe Europe, doesn't matter). To produce You need plantations and processing buildings. When You have them You need to hire colonists (without them You can't manufacure). If You're ready to sell some stuff You have to bring it to the local market (You will get money) or freight it to "Europe" (victory points). 

- game is extremely involving, rules are easy to learn but gameplay is very challenging
- playing time (approx 80-120 minutes), 1-5 players
- it comes with expansion buildings in the box
- game is "super dry" & ugly ;) but for me it doesn't matter if I enjoy it.

STRONG RECOMMENDATION!

RATING: 8.5
Puerto Rico is rated highly for a reason.  It is really well balanced and prevents any one single strategy winning every game.  You must know how to adjust to what is presented and try to force your opponents into inadvertently helping you.  However, the game struggles in that playing with individuals who are not at a similar experience level can completely unbalance the game.  An inexperienced player choosing an ill advised role on a turn can tremendously change the flow of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Another classic.

Puerto Rico has made me realize a game feature that I love but had never noticed: chaos.  By this, I don't mean the random luck that people frequently associate with the word, but true chaos in a mathematical sense.  The tiniest change of decisions in this game can have an immense ripple effect on the rest of the game.  I've played it hundreds of times, and while there have always been moves/strategies that are "better," it still plays out differently each game.

Sometimes we look back and wonder what happened that made a game go such a different way, and it's always the tiniest of details. I love that.  It's a sign of a perfectly balanced game, and one that has so far provided great replayability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Classic through and through

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I really tried to like this game, but many of the mechanics are contradictory in nature and very limiting in the wrong ways.  The odd-ball combination of these strange mechanics takes a supposed strategy game makes it into a "luck-of-the-draw", "First to Fortune" game where no strategy really works, and it just becomes chaos and waiting for whoever ever lucked out to win.

Crop Exportation:  Resources shipped out get the same victory point valve no matter what.  This means more expensive and harder to build crops (Tobacco and Coffee) don't grant you anything over the simplest crops (Corn).  Yes, the more "valuable" crops can get you more money on the market... if you are able to sell them (given the market being locked down or loosing most the stock during the shipping phase.)

The cost to harvest more expensive crops ruins whatever financial gains you might have.... IF you can even get those financial gains.  It's very easy for a player to be stuck trying to get the crop/processing plant combo working... and the player with the most corn crops is just churning out victory points like there is no tomorrow.  Even if you are able to sell you expensive crops by some chance, it only is enough to break even from the effort wasted on the processing plants.

Timing/Order Screw-overs:  It is very easy for another player's timing and phase to put a halt on whatever progress you've had.  Finally managed to produce that expensive crop?  Just wait until another player chooses the shipping phase right after you... and all the other players load junk onto the boats that prevents you from getting some victory points out of the deal.  (Warehouses you say?  When can I get the money to build that when the market is completely clogged up since someone else offloaded similar crops before me?)

"Walking Dead" very easy:  It is very easy to get hamstringged by circumstance and be stuck walking dead for the entirety of the game with no real effective means of recovering.  You could play your cards right and still be undone in a spectacular way.  You could try to recover, but often those efforts will similarly destroyed or will be too little to make a difference.  Hence, you are just idly waiting for a game victory trigger to occur.

Worker Allocation:  It is very easy to build useful buildings, but be unable to use them during key phases.  Yes, you can be Mayor can get new colonist and allocate them... but it is usually a moot point and you've already missed out on key production phases, shipping phases, and other events by the time you can move workers where you need to.  And if you are in the wrong order position, you will often not receive the worker you need... even if you are contributing the most empty spaces that translate to a larger pool.

Accessory Victory Point Buildings:  Many of them are decent... But due to limited financial flow and the chances of being crippled for a majority of the game, you won't be able to purchase them.  A VP building could easily net you the winning points, but you'll be stuck unable to acquire it or you'll devote the resources to get it... to only have other players negate the VP bonus by cheesing/working the system in cheaper fashions.

The game could be much better, but I don't think the developer really understands economics, psychology, and game theory very well.  There are signs of some purposeful intent to create a game that is a resource producing, city-building strategy game... but the mechanics fall short and just make it in a luck/luckless fest that shares more in common with Monopoly.  (At least in Monopoly there is player elimination which would at least bring mercy to player stuck walking dead.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good fast moving game having surprising depth for what initially appears to be a simple Euro style game. All of the elements mesh together almost perfectly and it is rare to find anyone that doesn't really enjoy the game once they've been introduced to it. It's easy to learn but has some depth and has a good fun factor. On the other hand, despite the elegance of its design, I'm finding my interest gradually waning (something I'm finding with a lot of the Euros that initially caught my interest). See my review for more details (by Bubslug).

RATING: 8.2
Ahhh... the sound of sea gulls and the surf crashing in the bay.  The smell of burning driftwood coconuts and seafood and rum drifts from a nearby table and we need to manage the trade center.

This game is a very enojyable game but some imbalance could arise with experienced players(CAYLUS COMMANDO!!!) out of a lack of chance to change initative.  Changing initiative even once a game could make this game a lot more competative.  That being said there are some lovely mechanics where players have a chance to selct rolls they will take on each turn.  Coosing a particular roll allows the chooser a slight benefit with that roll(ie builder gets a slight advantage at building a particular building....)

For a nice review, check out Board Games with Scott's video review.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Interesting game that gave us the concept of role selection with a "kicker".  Everyone gets to perform the base action the role permits (Settler, Mayor, Captain, etc) but only the player who picked the role gets the extra kicker or "privledge" (Extra colonist, VP, etc.).  At first it is fun to develop and manage the new colony of Puerto Rico but after a while the game gets stale.  There's little in the way of player interaction other than trying to predict what roles the others will play and trying to "piggyback" your plans on top of their selections.  Also the game can suffer from inadvertend kingmaking when there are different levels of players in the game.  (ie a new player in a game with 3 veterans)  Definitely only play with 4 or less.  Anything more and the game really slows down and starts to feel like the game is playing you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The artwork looks a little dated in the standard edition though, it could benefit greatly from a new edition with some of the better components and art from the Anniversary Edition.
