RATING: 10
Got this game back in 2003. Opened it, saw the 16 page rule book, read it, put the game back in the cabinet, never tried it since. I mean, how in the world am I going to explain my wife how to play this? Sold it.

Update+ Recently I bough this game again for 10 USD (TrU sale). Read the rules again and it made much more sense this time. I introduced it to my wife and neighbor and they both liked it. We played a 2 player game and two 3 player games. Lots of interesting mechanics and it seems there are several ways to win the game. Initial rating an 8, but I have to play it another 2 or 3 times before I can give it a final rating.

Update++ I have played this game about 12 times now, and it is still great. it works with 2,3 and 4 players. I might give this a 9.

Update+++ Played it about 15-20 times now and I love it. It helps that I win quite often. Prefer to play with 4 players, but 3 works as well and even the 2 player version has its charms. It's a 9.

Update++++ Okay, I have had this game now for about 4 years, played it about 25 times and I still love it. I introduce the game to about 5 or 6 people every year and they all like it a lot. I have played Agricola quite a bit as well, but personally I feel Puerto Rico is just the more fun game of the two. I really like the strategic play. You first start building your engine and then towards the end of the middle of the game you start to reap your rewards, and your opponents are just amazed to see how much money/goods you are raking in the whole time and there is nothing they can do about it. Awesome!

RATING: 10
I don't doubt the champions of this game as they describe its depth and beauty and whatever else.  I just don't understand how they can consider this game fun.  Either a game needs a modicum of luck (like the draw of cards -- something even Agricola has) or its need sufficient depth that even after a large number of plays there is no definitive strategy (e.g. Chess, Go).  While I have only played it twiceo, I was left with the feeling that if I played it enough times, it would degenerate to Player 1 to play and win.  No thanks!  

After the second play, I see the interaction between players but I still feel it is Player 1 to play and win.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
On the basis of this and Princes of Florence, I'm tempted to say there's an emerging genre here, which alas doesn't appeal to me much at all. Clearly it has appeal to many, but I would forewarn against introduce newcomers to gaming to games like this.

In summary, I played this and though it's a cross between Citadels,. Princes of Florence, St. Petersburg and Die Haendler - unfortunately I prefer the simplicity of Citadels and St. Petersberg and the elegance of Die Haendler miles ahead of this melange in Puerto Rico.

The learning curve is large here, lots of fiddly detail when it comes to buying from a library of buildings with different benefits. The player interaction is moderate or low, with no central arena in which action takes place that stimulated my imagination, but rather each player holding their own little board and hoarding goodies on it strategically. There is a very clever and very impressive role selection mechanism that drives this game, but you can get much the same thing in Citadels which doesn't take itself so seriously as a game (I admit) - has less distraction around the role mechanism and a little more plain old luck.

I can't help but wonder why games like this aren't made with a central board depicting the island of Puerto Rico and everyone playing their buildings and plantations upon it enabling some interaction in terms of layout and territory perhaps and definitely some sense of interaction which these solitaire boards fail to provide me with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Chaque joueur possede un plateau de jeu qui représente son domaine sur lequel il va pouvoir construire des batiments ou placer des plantations et les activer au moyen de colons.

Un joueur est désigné comme Gouverneur. Tous les joueurs recoivent un peu d'argent au début ainsi qu'une plantation en fonction de leur position. 
En commencant par le Gouverneur, chaque joueur va choisir un role définissant une action a résoudre (que tous les joueurs vont pouvoir réaliser en commencant par celui qui a choisi le rôle) et un privilege (seulement pour celui qui a sélectionné le role)

RATING: 10
Yes, this game offers the ultimate enjoyment with theme, strategy, variation, and balance when players are of equal experience. Absolutely top-notch. The higher learning curve makes games more one-sided with beginners, so it doesn't come out near as often as it should and keeps it from being a perfect 10. Very engaging, trying to decide how to optimize that choice of which role to choose, while also trying not to provide an advantage to your opponent. Timing the shipping role, when to trade, produce, and build at the optimal time challenges the players every turn. The various roles and their actions are wonderfully woven together. This game should provide scores of exciting and compelling gaming experiences.
Includes New Buildings expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a very good game, and definitely deserving of its accolades ... but it doesn't get a [10] from me.  The thing I like best about this game is that there is no downtime between player turns; everyone is fully involved, all of the time.  However, there are certainly a few drawbacks to the game for me.  After a few plays, various players' favourite strategies become a little predictable (but only a little; the extreme variety of options at every turn does make for a lot of permutations!).  Also, the building strategy seems to be far too dominant; it wins before shipping gets a chance to develop.  And the bonus VPs from large buildings seem always to be the clincher; if they were the same (physical) size as all the other buildings, then the building strategy would need a couple more turns to declare the end-game condition, giving those who are shipping a chance to collect a few more VPs.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I think this is a good game, but not great. Often felt like multiplayer chess, which sometimes is just not exciting enough. Very vulnerable to sub-optimal play by one or more players. Never take the producer role and you'll do well.

The more I play, the more boring the game gets. The factory is much more efficient to every other strategy. Rating revised down.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
For me, this game is the epitome of a euro game. There are so many ways of indirect player interaction, there are multiple strategies, every decision seems both non-obvious and important, yet it isn't too dry or too math-y.

I love the role drafting, where every player gets to do the action of the chosen role, and the one who chooses gets an extra benefit. I love the open building market with limited supply which creates a race for highly demanded buildings (especially the 10-cost buildings). I love how the trader only accepts one resource of a kind, making it important what your neighbors are planting. And I love how you can force everyone to sell their resources with the captain, making the timing of the role selection critical. There really isn't anything that I don't like in this game, which is something I can say about very few games. 

[microbadge=796][microbadge=29032][microbadge=40] BSW

# of players: [bgcolor=#00CC00] 3 [b]4[/b] 5 [/bgcolor]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favorite game ever. I get sick sometimes of luck and dice, and this game never stops amazing me. It is pretty easy to teach, and people usually have it down by part way through the first game, but the strategies are complex and neverending. I never seem to win, but I still crave it. I think that is  a great sign of a game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An excellent game, the wealth of strategies available make it a solid challenge. There's almost no random factors, you just have to second guess your opponents and try to calculate how best to turn the variable turn structure to your advantage. RATING: 8

I rarely play this game live due to needing the right group of folks, but play on BSW a good amount where you can usually find solid opponents.  Think it plays better with 3 or 4 players than 5.

RATING: 9
  An absolutley pure gamers game in the best sense and at a medium weight to boot!  The occasional criticism of it being "multi-person solitaire" is made by the lazy player.  There are multiple 'opening' moves (as in chess) that can become routine and may lead to a good position in the middle game, but a great player will smoke them.  This game can be incredibly deep.  I don't always play it that way, but I love that I can if I'm in the mood. 
  It gets a nine for the long set-up time (10-15 min).  I can knock out a game of the PC version in that time however the AI is pathetic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Amazing game. Heavy player interaction, thought-provoking decisions, simple rules, and some of the most elegant mechanics in any game. The fact that your role selection affects everyone else so profoundly is what makes the game so engaging, and so deep. 

After my first few plays, I thought the game was starting to get "samey," and I REALLY hated the slave thing. I got over the slaves because 1) the theme is so abstracted that it's impossible to consider anything "historical" at all, and 2) the colonists aren't slaves if they're also running the markets, university, city hall, etc. 

As for "samey," the more you play, the deeper the game gets. You begin to realize things about the game you never thought of initially, and you start to see chains of reactions that extend 3 or 4 turns in advance. It's this amazing depth that makes PR really stand out from other Euros. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Great game at first, but after a while, it just wasn't as fun to bring out anymore. Tedious setup, and gameplay is nearly silent while players brood over the choices in front of them. I really like the mechanics of them game, but each time my friends and I play, it devolves into 1) "Who has corn?" 2) Proceed to screw the corn player by getting some corn of your own (otherwise, it's a good bet he/she will win,) and 3) Buy a small market before they're gone! Each of our games starts out something like this, and for the rest of the game, we just go through the motions of building, trading, shipping, etc. Not all that fun. The final count-up of victory points can be a tense moment if you put a lot of effort and thought into your choices, but usually the end feels rather anti-climactic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Puerto Rico is a very good game, but it doesn't quite have the legs some other classics have, simply because it's not very tolerant of players of unequal skill levels.  This game can easily be thrown to an opponent by just a few misplays by someone else, and you can't do anything about it.  But with a group of similarly skilled players, it's quite good.  It also feels a bit "samey" in that the games tend to blend in with one another.  Still head and shoulders above most other games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played this again for the first time in many years and was reminded that it is both better and not as good as I remember. It's a very clever and interesting game, but also more chaotic than it looks, and over-analysis and over-competitiveness can completely ruin the enjoyment. Of the whole genre of games that Puerto Rico has spawned, from Caylus through Agricola, it remains by far the best (setting aside San Juan and Race for the Galaxy, which I sort of think of as a separate genre). But, unlike the best Knizia games like Tigris & Euphrates, Modern Art, or Beowulf, Puerto Rico just isn't infinitely replayable. It falls into patterns, and just doesn't vary enough from game to game. No hidden information, the only variation is through the flow of plantations ... not good enough. It's still a fine game which I enjoy, but it needed more variability to be a true classic.

Which is one reason I really like the new expansion from the alea treasure chest, with the Aristocrats. It seems to mix things up better than the first expansion did, better balanced and more open. It was fun to play again, especially with 5 (which I think is substantially the optimal number).
---
First, I find I must be the bad guy again and put a stop to this "greatest game ever" talk. Puerto Rico is an excellent game, no question. Amongst the best. That said, it does lack the true elegance of the top-10 types - the simplicity and tension of Modern Art, the simplicity and fun factor of Settlers or Starfarers, or simplicity and the variability without imbalance of El Grande. And in truth, I like Traders of Genoa more, because it has the same wealth of options with more player interaction and without the problem of knocking out players who get behind the power curve early. Still, all this said, Puerto Rico is an excellent game, up to Alea's remarkably high standards and in fact one of the best in the line. Several paths to victory are apparent, and none seem dominant. The game plays *very* fast, as is pretty unforgiving for a German game; mistakes in the first few rounds can and will cost you the game. Fortunately, it's still an engaging game even if you aren't winning, and the actual winner is often a surprise (since there is somthing of a "hose the leader" element, you want to be careful). Anyway, the only systemic weakness for me is that the game is rather light on player interaction & variability from game to game. These same problems weakened Princes of Florence in the long run - every game is essentially the same. The starting conditions are the same each game and there isn't much variability inherent in the system, unlike in Ra or Traders of Genoa. Still a very solid and interesting game, but one that played itself out sooner than one might hope, unlike the true classics (Settlers, Modern Art, etc.), and much as Princes of Florence did (although not quite that fast). Still highly recommended, and the Alea brand remains my favorite for serious games (whatever happened to Hans im Gluck? they seem to have moved down-market).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What can I say that hasn't been said. If you like Euros, you will almost certainly like this. 2 basic strategies (building and shipping), but enough variation within those (plus the fact that which one is "best" is going to be heavily dependent on what the opponents on your left and right are doing) to keep the game entertaining.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I realize that most people who consider themselves serious boardgamers would rate this game a 9 or a 10, but I've got to give it more reasonable 7.5.  Puerto Rico is an excellent game with layers of strategy that unfold like the petals of a blossoming lotus.  Nevertheless, there are many small components, and the complex rules are further mystified by a poorly translated rule book.  There's limited player interaction, and some of the buildings seem nearly useless (the University?).  These factors contribute to the relative lack of play that this game gets from my group, but when we do play, there's no doubts about the greatness of PR.  If your gaming group prizes strategic multiplicity, you should pick up a copy of this game and let the brain-burning begin.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very very good economy/point engine game, and probably one of the first ancestors of this type of game where you have so many options and strategies to potentially pursue.

On your turn, you select a role, which you do followed by all the other players.  You just get to do a slightly better version of the action as your reward for choosing it.  Roles do things such as make you money, buy buildings (which you need money for and give you special abilities), generate goods, sell goods, ship goods (which scores you points), etc.  Basically, they allow avenues for you to build up your money and victory point engines.

One of the criticisms I often hear about Puerto Rico is that differences in player skill level can make this one difficult to play and enjoy.  It's true that other players making dumb decisions can kind of rain on your parade inadvertently, but if you don't want other peoples' decisions to matter, you probably shouldn't be playing games.  I'll still agree it's more enjoyable if all players are around the same skill level, though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
played
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Great game overall. The first deep eruo game I was introduced to and it really blew my mind. It may be dry for some players, but if you are ok with that then you are in for a great gaming experience.

It was my first time playing, kind of complicated but I can see how it would be a really fun game.

RATING: 10
My all time favorite game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.94
Love the mechanics here, even though I'm playing for the first time in 2016, I get why this is as talked about as it is. I feel like this could be higher with better components and if I had more people to play it with. I could see this being in my top 3 of all time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Updated 6/16/10. 

Puerto Rico is a very enjoyable game, and the perfect step up from something like Catan.  The strategies are obvious enough to be graspable by new players, but with enough variability to lead to mastery.  With players who know the rules, it's quick, fun, and can often be cutthroat.  It really deserves to be a regular in any gaming group's rotation.   

The game has its downsides, however, which prevent the rating from going any higher (and, in fact, have lost it points regularly): (1) The theme is a bit dry.  It feels more mechanical than intuitive, and labels like "Quarry" and "Hacienda" feel too disconnected from the function of the thing they designate.  (2) Set-up is a bit of a chore.  (3) Without regular play, our group falls into default strategies (e.g., Tony is always doing the most shipping and invariably owns his own wharf; I go construction hut early, but usually run out of cash; Jenn buys markets and trades like the dickens).  Because we don't play it very often, we haven't "solved" it yet; but the comments of others suggest that this could be a potential problem for long-term playability.

I finally moved my rating down to an 8 when I rejected a very reasonable trade offer for this game, and it dawned on me that it is not something that I ever feel the need to own.  It's a very good, very enjoyable game.  But just one lacking the intrigue, the challenge, the soul of an elite game.

RATING: 9.5
Each decision that you make affects other players in a way I've seen in few other games. Many times, the effect isn't even negative! If you want to build, everyone gets to build. If you want to harvest crops, everyone gets to harvest. Easily the most balanced game I've ever played. You win this game by having a superior strategy to your opponents. Luck plays virtually no role.

RATING: 8
This, for me, is how little luck multi-player games can be done right. Where our actions help or hinder others depending on the timing.

Which is the primary tension of the game, timing our actions (role selection and end game triggers), such that they help us the most, help others less, and ideally hinder others as well.

I appreciate that you have a strategy going in, but the actions and strategies of the other players will force you to modify the plan during the game.

On the problematic side, if someone refused to play this game because of how Puerto Rican plantations used slavery (first the Tainos, the natives of the island, and once they were wiped out by the Spanish, black Africans (branded on their foreheads to indicate ownership)), I would certainly understand and we would then go play something else.

RATING: 7
Love the role system here - I was not surprised when it got stolen from so much. Overall this is a satisfying and well-crafted resource game, and I also really dig the need to use the different endgame conditions to your advantage - getting the game to end on YOUR terms is a large and interesting part of the strategy.

Update: After years of not playing it, I am downgrading this to a 7. Which is maybe a silly thing to do, but this is a desire-to-play rating, rather than strictly reflection of competent design. I suspect if I played this right now, I would find it wholly engaging throughout... but I think it lacks a kind of excitement or bite that makes something addictive for me (that most of my 8+s have).

RATING: 8
I have played enough Euro games to say to myself that I don't have to defend this game anymore.  This is a fantastic design, don't get me wrong.  The only problem is that it has worn out its welcome for me.  It just really isn't that fun anymore.  I'm pretty good at it, but not great, and it is not a game that I want to be great at.  There are too many other games that have great mechanics, little luck, but are much funner to play.  Also, I am to the point (after 75 or so games) that I realize that I mail in most of my turns of this.  You get to the point that where there were once choices, there really aren't anymore.  And whoever sits to the left of the noob has a great shot at winning.  Sure, plenty of people out there can crush me at this game.  But that's fine....let them play a dry game with no fun if that is what they want to do.  I would rather play ItSotE, Power Grid or Princes of Florence...tense with more decisions than you can shake a stick at....and they never get old.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
To me the most versatile game ever. 

It plays great at all players counts 2-5, with a very different feel at each number. 

The game is so intuitive that I have played this with complete non-gamers, and I still see it being played as a staple at 'lighter' gaming groups (this and power grid seem to be the step-up games of choice even over ten years later). On the other hand it is deep enough to reward very skilled play and remains interesting to gamers after hundreds of plays. 

It also seems to satisfy both gamers who like a lot of interaction and inter-player effects and those who like engine building resource management games. 

I personally love how every move involves both offense and defense -playing well demands determining what others need and what actions they are likely to take in upcoming rounds. It's the only game I have ever played that actually has the feel of building a company in a competitive economy.

RATING: 7
[u]October 2008:[/u] After a long moment when I wanted to play other stuff (newer stuff), I find myself wanting to go back to this one and play again.

[u]December 09:[/u] Puerto Rico is a classic. It's also one of my oldest game. Although this game was what created my game group (it was both Vincent and Hadrien first games with Matthieu and I). I can't say it is one of my favourites. I've always had a hard time playing it and can't really get in it competitively. [u]March 2010:[/u] [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/497399/multiple-player-review-puerto-rico]My review[/url]

[u]December 2010:[/u] Changed my rating system, the game is now rated 7

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Puerto Rico is definitely one of my favorite games with almost NO luck involved - therefore, I give it an almost perfect rating! 

Sure, there is "luck" involved in who is the first player and the positions you sit in, and if you sit right after the only new player in the game you have a better chance to win as the new player will probably take craftsman more than other players... Besides that, the only luck is which plantations turn up - and that is such a little amount of luck that it has almost no impact on the game. 

However, it’s obviously not only because of the lack of hidden information and luck that I like this game a lot; otherwise I would like games like Chess and Through the Desert much more. 

In Puerto Rico, you need to have a good strategy but also be able to adapt to changes and make some tactical moves when the other players screw you. I really like that you can force people to ship when taking the captain when they hoped to trade their coffee/tobacco, and, in general, the roles are such a great mechanic! You need to think about which one to choose, and even though you e.g. don’t have any goods to trade, it can be wise to actually pick the trader in order to avoid the other players from getting it with even more coins on it so they will benefit a lot for choosing that role. You really have to consider not always picking the role which will benefit you the most but also which role will benefit the others the least – that’s the key to victory.

Regarding the key to victory, there are two main strategies in this game: the shipping and the building strategies. I think they are pretty balanced and I’ve won with both and lost against both. The success depends on the number of players, the interaction and what strategies the other players choose. Of course you can mix the two strategies, and obviously you need to ship even when you’re using the building strategy and build when you’re using the shipping strategy. The game could perhaps be a little boring after several plays exactly because of the lack of variables/luck and the two strategies, but the various buildings and especially the buildings of the expansion and how they interact help the game never getting old and boring!

This is truly one of the greatest games ever created!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A clever and highly original design but the choices often feel rather obvious. THE most obvious being to invite the new player to sit on your right! I prefer Cuba to this one because there is so much more going on though Puerto Rico is a excellent introduction to role selection and eurogames in general.

RATING: 9
I've only played this a few times and I enjoy it, but I'm split. The competitive side of me salivates at this and wants to learn the optimization strategies. UPDATE Fall 2008: I set this aside for a while and recently came back to it---it blew me away this time. As I learned to teach the game better I got a better return on my opponents involvement and we started to feel the total immersion and paths to victory. Raised from a 7 to a solid 9. Found the right crowd! Only thing keeping it from going higher is that I have become somewhat locked in on a strategy that is tending to always work with my group. Since no one in my group is likely to go all serious/academic about it and push their play I keep falling into the same patterns with my play. I will have to break out of that approach to keep this fresh.

2010: Update, no one put the effort into really learning the shipping/corn strategy and we moved on. People liked the casual variability of Stone Age much more.

RATING: 8.5
Have now had a chance to play this game multiple times, and it is fun every time.  An excellent game, and very deserving of its rating.

Excellent mechanics, well-crafted game play, and I have yet to suffer from the "you're sitting in the wrong spot" conundrum that seems to permeate this game at times.

Addendum to my original comments:  A new strategy for me, as played by my opponent in the last game that thouroughly kicked my keister (scoring a whopping 64VP in a 4 player game).  Anyway, I like the fact that there are so many different strategy builds that can win this game, and not one strategy that is overwhelmingly better than any other.  One guy at the last game said that playing the "Hospice" first is a guaranteed victory, but I disagree - obviously, I tried that strategy, and lost.  This game gets better and better as I play, and I am very impressed with everything about it.

RATING: 7
Almost everything I read about this game strikes me as wrong.  After several plays, I don't think it's terribly well designed or balanced.  If you're player A, you might well lose the game because player B fails to choose the role that most limits player C.  No well-designed game has this attribute.  It/s also a bit awkward and clunky, any elegance in the game's basic choose-a-role mechanism lost amid the zillion special privileges and building-based special-powers.  I have it at "7" now because it's reasonably engrossing on a tactical level, but I suspect it's going to keep dropping.  I don't think this is all subjective anymore, I now believe the game has some serious, objective problems.

RATING: 8
Wow. Great game. I can see where some people might find this too analytical, but I really enjoyed my first game. After one play, I find myself thinking about different strategies. I expect I'll add this one at some point.

This could be a lot of fun as long as I don't play with people who are ultra-competitive.

Update: bought it after my first play. Now, I face the challenge of finding people to play this locally.

Another update: busted this out on a game night with two other couples, and it went over very well. For anyone even slightly beyond "the gateways," this game is very accessible despite its reputation for heaviness.

Update: Hadn't played this game in a while, as my exhuberance in this hobby led to a flurry of new games. Finally revisited Puerto Rico for a third play, and after buying about 45+ other games, it is still dang good. Slick as heck, plenty of strategic choices, smooth elegant game play. The only thing that shows its age is the subpar, underwhelming game components. Other than that, it's a game everyone should try at least once.

Update: again, another long gap between plays, but this still holds up. This game offers things I particularly enjoy in games: reasonable playing time, some flow and rhythm to the game, and relatively simple choices (choose a role!) with numerous consequences. It's no wonder this is a classic.

Update: OK, traded this away in a math trade, but only because I upgraded to the 10th Anniversary edition.

RATING: 8
A classic, though I somehow evaded playing this game until 2005.  As with many games of its general German ilk, there's no one set strategy to win, especially with larger games in which buildings get sold out very quickly, which makes a willingness to adopt new strategies key.  This is best played with players of roughly the same experience with the game, of course.

Although I like this game, I'm not in a rush to pick it up since so many people have it.

RATING: 10
This is by far the best game I have played in a very long time, if by a long time I mean ever. Although I own other great games, this one was so well designed and thought out that it has no luck value involved at all. Like chess you have to think about your opponent's moves and what will help you most while not helping your opponent. A fantastic game that will be played many times.

Overall Score 10, Appearence 9, Components 9, The Box (storage) 9, Rulebook 9, Ease of Play 8, Mechanics 10, Involvment 10, Replayability 10, Uniqueness 10, Luck 0 v Strategy 10 (The higher the number the more it leans that way.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Efficiency engine games don't tend to do it for me, but my first play of this classic was a very pleasant surprise. The engine building is complemented with a heavy dose of tactical setup. Getting in-phase with the game seems critical. Manipulating the phase seems ideal. In this way, it feels oddly similar to Container. While they are entirely dissimilar as 'economic' games, they have a common 'feel'. I look forward to more plays - learning the buildings better, getting more comfortable with the roles, and starting to pay more attention to the other player tableaus. I can imagine that the lookahead in the game can be quite interesting. On another note: San Juan is one of my most played games and I expected PR to feel more similar than it did. As much as I love SJ for nostalgia reasons, PR felt like the much better game. No surprise there, I suppose. (Note: My rating of SJ will continue to reflect nostalgia.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
No thanks.  Not interested.  I won't make the mistake of playing it again.  I do not like economic snowball games.  This is not to say it is a bad game, just that it is a game which specialises in things I don't like and am not interested in.  This is a game that is clearly a member of the "I'd rather go home alone in the dark than play this game again" set.  The very strong right/left binding does nothing but ensure this game is strenuously avoided.  

The economic snowball aspects are accompanied by so little non-mechanical player interaction that any chance of being interesting are forever lost.  The fact that the game tends to break when played by players of unequal skill and relies heavily on the right/left mechanics (keep the player on your left down/from winning) pretty much seals its fate for me.

TV2017, BGG100
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A well balanced game with deceptively deep strategies.  Despite many comments I've read, I truly don't believe there is any one strategy (i.e., harbor, corn shipper, etc) that is better at the outset than any other.  Playing Puerto Rico well consists of keeping an open mind and looking for opportunities as they develop.  Play is slightly on the complex side for the German style games (i.e., Carcassone, Settlers, Adel Verpflichtet), but still very manageable.  Princes of Florence is still my favorite of the Alea line, however.  

UPDATE:  I think, some of the analysis, as well as the theme, has lessened the game in my eyes.  It hasn't been played by my group in quite a while, and it probably won't be any time soon.  Not exactly ready to give up on it, though.

UPDATE: Puerto Rico is a decent game, but for the Euro experience I prefer Agricola or even Princes of Florence.

RATING: 5
:sugar: :( :what: :) :D :) Puerto Rico is a fine, even laudable game -- I would define it as sitting on the borderline between the super-popular gateway games and the heavier gamer's games. If PR makes sense to you and doesn't feel overwhelming and is actually fun, you're a good candidate for the heavy stuff. If not, you're probably not. The main thing that keeps this one in the "games I like" category and not the "games I love" category is this: it's a bit [i]brittle[/i], with the best moves being somewhat common knowledge amongst experienced players and not being obvious to new players, which makes games of PR between people of differing skill levels dicey, but not in an interesting way.

RATING: 8
Fantastic game for it's time where the players compete about building up the most prosperous colony and send merchandise back to their countries and make as good a profit as possible.
This is a landmark game that have helped the hobby along a great way.
The mechanics in this game have been used by many others but have then also added other chrome to their games. Puerto Rico is arguably the most refined of the games in this genre.
The simple rules but complex interactions have made this game popular among many others than the usual gamer crowd.
One side of the game that some have problems with is that to develop your colony you are using slaves as workers in the colonies.

RATING: 8
I picked this up on a whim when I found it on a deep sale. This is probably the most complex game I have, and it's interesting, because the rules are pretty straightforward and simple to understand once you go through it once or twice. The depth and complexity is readily apparent after that, and I can easily see why it's been in the BGG top 10 for so long.

After primarily playing it with the official 2p variant, I tried it out with 3p, and it almost feels like a completely different game. Lots of different strategies open up, and the potential to snatch up paths to victory from other players is increased. The game is also much longer, but that's not a terrible thing. Just something to keep in mind. Still a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I almost feel like there's not much more praise that could be given to Puerto Rico than it's already received (with 30k ratings and 8k comments at the time of this writing), but here goes!

Puerto Rico is probably the best game I own and have played. I would never turn down an opportunity to play it. Thousands of people on the Geek have already sung this game's praises, so I'll just mention a few things that I love about Puerto Rico.

First, once you get to know the game, Puerto Rico is fast-moving and keeps every player involved. There is very little downtime in the game, and when there is you can be planning out your next move. Every player's action choice affects the other players in important ways, and the game almost never leaves you feeling left out of the action.

Which brings me to my second point, and one of the things I really love about the game. Unlike many other Euros, Puerto Rico is thick with player interaction in all kinds of subtle ways. While there aren't a lot of opportunities to directly mess with the other players, you always need to be thinking about how what you do will help or hurt them. Choosing the right action at the right time can bring you major benefits even as it hurts your opponents.

While every player is, in some sense, "tending their own garden," Puerto Rico forces you to constantly consider how your choices will help or hurt opponents.

Other than that, Puerto Rico is also packed with different ways to win. Every time I play the game, I feel like I discover something new about what works and what doesn't, and it always creates a new and wonderful experience.

While this may not be the best game for the casual crowd, it moves very quickly and smoothly once the game gets going. I've explained this game to people with almost no board game experience, and they've snapped it up and jumped right into it right away.

Puerto Rico is one of the best games I've ever played, and I would recommend it with no hesitation to anyone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In 2002, this game would have been the bee's knees. Today, it's still pretty darn good. From a strategy standpoint, it's hard to find fault. The role selection and the associated bonuses force players to make all kinds of interesting decisions. I'd likely rate this a 9.5 if strategy were the only consideration. However, factor in that the game's setup and tear-down take a long time, the components are of low quality, the game looks ugly, and it's a nightmare when playing with people prone to analysis paralysis. The best of today's games have a more pleasing aesthetic and higher quality components while playing equally as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Puerto Rico is a very good game that deservedly has had not just a day in the sun, but rather, several years. The basic concept of this game, action selection is, in one sense, shades of everything that happened in the German game industry for the 5 years that followed its publication, as the tile selection that drives the game here is not far removed from the individual action selection that the workers represent in games like Caylus and Agricola.

PR is a heavily tactical game where 2 mainline strategies exist, one, scoring points by shipping goods, the other, scoring points by buying buildings, preferably the large, end game bonus buildings. Despite the fact that these are relatively known quantities, and have been for years, the game is still compelling.

Rating this game is difficult to do now. I haven't played it regularly in years. It was one of the earlier titles that I latched onto, and when I had less than 10 games, it got a hell of a lot of table-time, often 5+ games in a single session, all in a row. My group rapidly moved on to the expansion though, and crafted a building group that we thought was more interesting using many of those buildings though, and as a result, I can't rate the base game higher than 8, though it is a 10 when I can add in the buildings I like from the expansion.

Really though, if you haven't played this yet, and if you like Euros at all, then you should just go out and buy it. Seriously, buy it. The game is addictive in the early going, and as long as you avoid the plethora of strategy guides that were published over the years you should get double digit plays out of the base game before it starts to seem scripted, easily. A lot of the burnout talk that you see circulating here is fueled by the option of online play, which meant that some people were playing it literally in excess of 1000 times. Other than traditional games like Go and Chess, and perhaps card games like Tichu and Spades I don't know of any games that can stand up to that sort of rigour, so don't shy away from the title because of that. It is one of the most significant imports from Germany, period, and is justifiably recognized as a modern classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
2005 What a great game! All these decisions and a reasonable playing time.  My first German style game and what a revelation.

2006 I still really like this game but one of my regular opponents is starting to get too much deja vu and thinks the game forces people down similar paths each time. In a three player game you can win without the habour or the wharf but why would you try.

2007 I think we have developed favoured patterns but I still try to evolve my game by integrating what seems to work from my opponents game and trying out variations. Small changes seem to produce significant outcomes.

2007 We were obliterated at a convention it has put us off.

2013 This game needs to be played a lot to improve understanding since the relationship between player order, role choice, building types etc defies simple analysis.  When this was my only Euro game this was an option.  The deliberatly obtuse relationships between elements of the game do not float my boat any more.  Through the Ages, Power Grid and Race for The Galaxy cover this ground with mechanics that are easier to understand and I find it increasingly difficult to find the motvation to revisit this venerable and deliberately obtuse classic.

2014 Online play has softened my opinion of this game.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of those rare cases where the opinions of the masses are right.  Almost.  I initially scoffed at this one due to its pretty boring theme (Puerto Rico? C'mon...)and its apparent complexity.  I bought it based on the reviews and haven't looked back since.  This is a beautiful, elegant game that plays kind of like other games but as whole is entirely unique, easy to play, and most important of all, FUN.  The depth of strategy Puerto Rico affords is unparalleled in German-style games and the constant need to adapt and assess other players' actions provides a deep yet subtle level of interaction beyond simple diplomacy, trading, or auctioning mechanisms.  This is truly a game not to be missed by anyone with so much as a casual interest in games but the disclaimer here is that it's not endlessly replayable- in fact, I think the game has about 20 plays before a nasty, hateful burnout sets in.  It's important, magnificently designed, and should be on any gamers' shelf but will I play it ever again?  Maybe not.  It was great while it lasted though.

RATING: 7
I saw this at the local gaming store, and thought to myself, Hey Puerto Rico, I guess I'll pick it up, Hundreds of Geeks can't be wrong. I picked it up, got the ol' group together and played. Oh my god! This game *is* amazing. The first thing I would like to say about the game is that the rules are not complicated. This is what was originally stopping me from picking it up, I thought it was super complicated. It takes 10 minutes to explain it to a new player, and then you are up and running. Elegant play, trash talking, and very little random element. On each player's turn, every other player has something to do, so it keeps everyone interested. Usually in a game, I wait until I am done my turn, then run to the bathroom when I have to go. With this, I find myself waiting until my turn, because I don't want to miss anything. Solid good game people. Give it a try, although I am sure you already have.

Edit 12/14/07: Lowered the rating to reflect current feelings. This was one of my first purchases in the Euro/light strategy game universe, and I was very impressed. Before this game, I only played a lighter fare of western pop culture games. After considerable time owning it, I found that it just didn't hit the table all that much. More detailed review pending.

RATING: 10
Probably the best game I own.  Has a nice balance between complexity(heaviness) and accessibility for new players.  I have introduced this game to many of my friends and family members and it was an instant hit.  The best quality of Puerto Rico is its lack of randomness combined with a constant flux of variable strategies that unfold from turn to turn.  This keeps the gameplay infinitely fresh.  It even works well as a 2 player game with the rules variant.  It is the heaviest game that my wife will play with me.   I also like that when I lose a game I can usually determine which gameplay choices led to my defeat.  Although I don't ALWAYS want to play it, I can without reservation list it as my favorite game.

RATING: 6
It's probably a better game than my rating.  Certainly, the mechanic of choosing a role that allows every player to do the action, with a slight advantage for the chooser, is pretty innovative (and cool).  But I find the theme (obtaining slaves - that is, colonists - to work your crops and erect buildings) pretty dry and not terribly interesting.  It's clearly a game where one could explore many different strategies and experience with the many possible combinations will lead to better play.  But that's not the main thing I'm looking for in a game.  Rather, I'm looking for drama and surprise and new ways of thinking.  If you like to go deeper into the analysis of your games, your rating will be higher.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Puerto Rico has suffered from willful neglect on my behalf. When I first saw the game, I had only just begun playing boardgames, and the complexity went way over my head. I also disliked the fiddly bits (I have big hands). Over the years, I have done my best to avoid the game whenever possible, but there have been times when I was forced to sit down and play. The first thing that still strikes me is the apalling quality of the game material. This is an Alea big box, and it uses thin cardboard exclusively, and tiny wooden chits. The VP-system does not work, because VP are meant to be closed—why then is it necessary to make change from time to time...? On to the game, then. Actually, I like it, provided you play with fast players who don't think forever to make a decision. The mechanisms are polished, play is rythmical without becoming a Bolero-like excercise as is the case with Caylus, and the role-choosing with its extra privilege is intruiging. 

Nevertheless, there are downsides to this game. You absolutely need to have players of your own level to play against. Puerto Rico is a game of efficiency, and while you may not necessarily play bad on a single turn, better players do slightly better consistently on every turn. (This is discounting making really bad moves which help your opponents more than they help you.) They are able to do better because they have seen more strategies, and know what buildings will help them most. Consequently, I suspect there will come a definite moment where you are simply 'done' with the game. (I notice this in certain comments.) It is tantalisingly solvable and processional: I suspect a good portion of its (overrated) high notes stem from this fact. It's a good game if you're still learning the ropes, but excellent it is not. (Then again, I define excellent as 'I don't know what it is, but I'm sure I can recognise it when I see it.') Finally, but not really surprisingly, is that this game fails at 5 players. There is a nasty shortage of buildings in the game, and a few early decisions can completely lock one or two players out of the competition. I intensely dislike losing because the game point blank refuses to let me win; being able to correctly assess this situation 1/3rd through breaks the game to an uncomfortable degree for me. A game like Endeavor gets this aspect 'right', although I suspect that it is precisely the hard fight which draws some players to Puerto Rico.

[u]3 PLAYERS[/u]: 6
[u]4 PLAYERS[/u]: 6
[u]5 PLAYERS[/u]: 4

[b]Update[/b] I seriously doubt Puerto Rico would have attained its nigh-legendary status had it appeared a decade later. I played it again since whenever, and found it boring and processional. I suppose that if you want to study the various effects of growth and timing of an artificial setting, Puerto Rico isn't such a bad choice as the amounts of money and resources aren't that large, thus keeping the analysis doable. But as a game, it's boring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
For a long long time, Puerto Rico was my favorite game.  It still easily qualifies for top 10.  I love any game with role selection, and Puerto Rico is designed in such a way that optimal play depends on being able to predict what other players will do.  Because there are a variety of successful strategies, it's always fun to try to and balance your approach against what other players are trying to accomplish.  I also think PR solves the common problem of having nothing to do when other people are playing their turn with the everyone-acts-on-every-turn mechanic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very fun; not hauled out much these days, but has had a lot of plays. Probably would have been a 9 in the past, but it's lost some of its shininess, and I really wish that a few of the buildings were priced more in line with how good they actually are.

(Way back in the day when we first started playing, I was a little disappointed at how little player interaction there was. Boy, was I wrong. Once you get beyond the "how do I make these pieces fit together?" level of play, an immense part of the game is about figuring out what other people are likely to do, and how your action assists or thwarts others. Unfortunately, it's finely balanced enough in this regard that there are some kingmaking issues - a slip on one player's part can give some other player a really big boost, and it will nearly always be the player just-downstream, which, sadly, makes "sit to the left of the less-experienced player" a notable advantage.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Components: All bits are made of wood, and all tiles are a thick cardstock. I'd like the buildings better if they had thematic pictures on them, and/or if they were easier to read from across the table.


Experience: Having only played this game twice, many years apart, I am still lukewarm. The two main choices seem to be which role to choose, and which building, if any, to buy when the Builder is chosen. I enjoy puzzling through which role is best for me and least good for the others, but the buildings are so varied in their effects, that with only two playings under my belt much of the game is spent in confusion as to which structures are granting which powers to which players. With it fresh in my mind right now, I can see that I need to find more synergy with my choices, and better timing.

First Played: 2004-04-21
Last Played: 2012-02-07
Eagerness to Play Again: Within a year

Plays (2):
4 players: 1
5 players: 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Here's an example of a game that is so beautifully balanced in its strategic elements, that the optimum strategy is nothing less elegant than maximizing your opportunity flexibility. I suspect some people (such as perfect plan fans) will hate that.  I, for one, think it's terrific.

If this games suffers from anything, it suffers from having simply been played too many times.  While every bit as much the same game it ever was, there are just too many other games out there for one played a hundred times or more to retain its original charm.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Thumbs Up[/b]: Objectively, it is a great design, and has proven to be so due to the many inferior games of a similar nature that have been released since. I do not really enjoy this style of efficiency engine game, but I admire the game so much when I play it that it becomes a positive experience.

Things I really like: The possibility of getting screwed during trading and shipping adds great tension to the game and really gives it its tactical depth; good strategic depth in the selection of which commodities to invest in; great fun when the Harbor gets going!

Things I really dislike: Fussy setup; fussy play; insufficient player interaction to offset the imbalances between the different buildings.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of those games where after you play, you want to play again immediately.  It takes a while to figure out the rhythm of the game (which is affected to a good degree by the group).  You cannot pick one fixed strategy, you must adapt to where you are in the rhythm.  Sometimes you should be a builder, sometimes a shipper, sometimes a 50/50 mix.  I've won by large margins with all three strategies.  If you love to build, but the rhythm dictates a non-building strategy you had better become a shipper for that game.  This frustrates people who like to make work out a fixed strategy and keep making incremental improvements to it over time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A modern classic. What else to say? Well, I will say that I can't win this game and don't want to play it again. So there.

RATING: 7.5
Also got my first game of this in on an iPad app version - and this is an EXCELLENT way to play - I'd imagine it shaves a good 30 - 45 mins. off of playtime vs. the cardboard version.  This game is interesting but I was taught by a veteran, hardcore player of the game. To be honest I am still entirely in the dark as to any real strategic approach to the game - I was buying everything totally blindly.  Game does feel like multiplayer solitaire as is so often commented, and after a while my teacher sailed past me in production and became more focused on scoring more than the computer opponents.  This left my first game a bit disappointing - I didn't really feel involved in the game due to not knowing what I was doing.  However I would definitely play this again - it definitely looks like there is a lot to mastering the game and I can't really appreciate it until the strategy "clicks" a bit more for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.7
Fast, fun, & NO DICE!  This game of economic growth is outstanding.  It reminds me quite a bit of the old school video game "M.U.L.E." where players attempt to out produce their enemy by creating diverse resources.  It's probably impossible to confirm but I wouldn't be surprised if the creator of this game had played that video game classic.

Probably the strongest aspect of this game is that it is "simple to learn yet difficult to master".  The rule book is tiny compared to many advanced games.  I have seen 4 year olds play this game with 40 year olds and both enjoyed it very much.  That is sign of a quality crafted game.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Amazing game, multi-dimensional. Definitely not 'solitare' like, but attacks against opponents are not directed. With two player variant can become chess like (in a bad way) where games follow predetermined openings to mid games. With 4-5 players this game is amazing. 2 year update. Even with 4-5 player, the games eventually becomes chess like with clearly 'correct' and 'incorrect' plays. Dropped from a 10.  This is really a 10 for the first 30 plays, but I have stopped calling for it to come to the table, unlike my other 10's. With the expansion now, I am interested again, and think it has very long term legs. 9.5...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
2-5 players, medium heavy, 90-120 minutes, city building

Having played numerous games, both offline and online, I can fairly say that this is my favourite game. Despite its age, I haven't come across more recent games that rival this one. 

This is a strategic game, there is no luck involved, but the rules are fairly easy once you understand the game mechanism. There are several routes to success and usually it stays exciting to the end who will win the game. For non-gamers this one can be quite difficult at first, but after one or two games people know the mechanism and the various roles and buildings and what they do. 

The games works quite well with 2, 3, 4 or 5 players, which I consider a bonus as not many games do. I'm a fan and want to play this again soon!

I'm hoping to get my hands on the limited edition at a decent price and otherwise consider replacing this one by the reprint, which also includes both expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.24565
My first Eurogame.

It took a few rounds but by the time the governer changed, I felt I understood the basics.

Being able to 'indirectly' affect the opponents with nearly every decision meant I slowed the game down somewhat, weighing up the available decisions and I never felt I had time to mentally explore every option.

I imagine that after another game, I'll be familiar with the building roles, possible strategies and will finally be at a stage where I feel able to compete.

game 3:
This game has a lot of options you can try for at the start - the violet buildings, with unique abilities, really forcing you to take some time to plan your strategy. Somehow, it doesn't feel as overwhelming as Caylus. Maybe because only a few are purchasable at any time, minimising the starting building choice.

The final violets really 'suggest' strategies, hopefully pushing folk down different paths.

Though not very interactive, working out what a shipment/sale would result in and what buildings you need to grab before others are vital skills.

RATING: 7
Still enjoy after all these years. Yes, seating order can matter if playing with inexperienced people, but I'm playing to enjoy myself not to dominate. One of the few games where it seems like every choice you make can effect everyone else playing, which is why newbies can throw everything off. I also like that it feels at the end of the game like you have built something and made progress, even if you lose, unlike so many euros today (Stefan Feld, I'm looking at you).  

I have the deluxe version so traded away my regular set, which looks dull in comparison.

RATING: 9

RATING: 10
Excellent game, but quite difficult if you're stuck in linear thinking. You must manage your strategy in a non-linear progression. Although the game would seem to be a highly STRATEGIC game, it is in truth very TACTICAL instead. You can (and should) work on a long-term strategy, but you will be forced to respond tactically in ways that will most certainly change your strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
The decisive breakthrough in modern boardgames!

I knew this game many years after its launch (and after knowing other modern games), even so, i was absolutely delighted by that new concept: In his turn, a player should not only worry about making the best for him, he must also worry about making the less possible to benefit the others! This happens because an action choosen by a player affects also all the others. The actions less choosen then take credits to make them more appeal (an ideia later reproduced in other games).
Other cool ideias are the hidden victory points (making players unsure about finishing the game or not), the slot allocation of boats and the rules to force endgame (completation of player´s mat, and the run out of settlers or VP from the "bank").
There is not a straight strategy to win as, in different games, players may take different options, however,the most significant drawback of the game is that the player seated on the left of a newbie can get really benefit (on account of the new concept mentioned earlier that is hard to perceive at first), as the player´s turns always run clockwise and are not variable.

RATING: 7.5
[3 Mar 2017] - 7.5 (3 plays)
I'm always hesitant to start a game of Puerto Rico but once I do, I have enjoyed the experience. The heart of the game is trying to set yourself up so that no matter what role is selected, you have a decent action. Shipping goods back is huge and you need to look early on to get that engine going. In my plays, the VP building tiles have not made that big of a difference in scoring. I have not played this at the lower player counts but the board feels like it would be too open with lower counts.

RATING: 8.5
Puerto Rico is a really challenging game.
It is a lot of fun but even if the rule book has a lot of examples it can sometimes be a bit confusing.
If played with the rules right, Puerto Rico is not that long of a game.
I enjoyed playing it as it gives a lot of strategic depth and has a couple of different victory conditions in case you are being blocked by players in specific tasks.
Once you understand the feel for the game it is easy to play & teach.
The ammount of role information & buildings can sometimes be overwhelming but in a single play you can learn them all.
Give Puerto Rico a chance and I am sure you will enjoy it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
- Gameplay and replayability: 3/3. A thoroughly enjoyable game with almost no downtime.

- Luck factor: 3/3. Zero luck factor. To be honest, this is not 100% true as there is a tiny bit of luck involved with the plantations that come available. However, this has never determined the winner.

- Player range: 3/3. I have no idea why the game is marketed as a 3-plus player game, as it is equally fun with 2 players as it is with 3 and 4. The rules for the two player variant only differ very little.

- Duration: 2/3. Puerto Rico takes some 1.5 hour to play, which is pleasantly short

- Learning curve: 1/3. For an experienced gamer the rules are lightweight, but someone who is not used to playing board games it takes some effort to learn. Some people might be put off by it.

- Theme and looks: 2/3. The components are beautiful and the theme is plausible enough, although some aspects of the theme feel somewhat artificial and pasted on.

- Set up/clean up time: 0/3. This is for my part the only drawback of Puerto Rico. Both setting up and cleaning up take a lot of time, even after taking some painstaking measures to speed up the process. If you intend to play sometimes with 2, sometimes with 3 and sometimes with 4 players, you have to count on spending half an hour for the setup + cleanup.

- Documentation: 2/3. There is sufficient documentation to be able to learn the game easily.

- Durability: 3/3. The components won't wear out easily.

- Portability: 0/3. Not intended for traveling.

- Summary: Even though the setup/cleanup is a nightmare, Puerto Rico is a great game to play and replay with any number of players, especially if you like strategic and zero luck games.

RATING: 9

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2-5

Doel van het spel:
De speler met de meeste punten (puntenfiches + punten van de gebouwen (bezet/onbezet) + extra punten van bezette grote gebouwen) is de winnaar. Bij gelijke stand wint de speler die de meeste dubloenen en goederen heeft.

Voorbereiding:
Iedere speler krijgt een speelbord, geld (zie hieronder) en 1 plantagekaartje (zie spelregels).

3 SPELERS:
+ 2 dubloenen
+ geen goudzoekers
+ 75 puntenfiches
+ schepen: 4,5 en 6 laadruimte
+ 4 plantagekaarten open
+ 55 kolonisten

4 SPELERS:
+ 3 dubloenen
+ 1 goudzoeker
+ 100 puntenfiches
+ schepen: 5, 6 en 7 laadruimte
+ 5 plantagekaarten open
+ 75 kolonisten

5 SPELERS:
+ 4 dubloenen
+ alle rollenkaarten
+ 122 puntenfiches
+ schepen: 6, 7 en 8 laadruimte
+ 6 plantagekaarten open
+ 95 kolonisten

Speelverloop:

De speler met de gouverneurkaart begint. Hij neemt 1 van de rollenkaarten en voert de bijhorende actie uit. Daarna voeren ook alle andere spelers met de klok mee deze actie uit. De speler die de rol koos heeft recht op een privilege. Wanneer elke speler een rol heeft gekozen, eindigt de ronde. Aan het einde van een ronde wordt er op elke niet-gekozen rol een dubloen gelegd. De gouverneurkaart schuift door naar de volgende speler.

De 7 verschillende rollen:

1/ Landbouwer:

Actie: neem een plantagekaartje (na deze fase worden alle niet-gekozen plantages verwijderd en komen er nieuwe plantages open te liggen). 

Privilege: neem een steengroeve in plaats van een plantagekaartje. 

2/ Burgemeester:

Actie: Verdeel de kolonisten van het schip (beginnend bij de actieve speler) en plaats de kolonisten op je gebouwen/plantages. Bezette gebouwen/plantages vervullen hun functie, onbezette niet. Aan het einde van deze fase komen er minstens zoveel kolonisten op het schip als de som van alle onbezette velden bij de spelers (niet van de plantages en steengroeves). Opgelet: Er worden steeds minstens zoveel kolonisten op het schip geplaatst als er spelers zijn.

Privilege: De burgemeester krijgt 1 extra kolonist uit de algemene voorraad. 

3/ Bouwmeester:

Actie: gebouw bouwen (nooit 2x hetzelfde gebouw bouwen).

Privilege: 1 dubloen korting bij de aankoop van een gebouw.

4/ Opzichter:

Actie: De spelers nemen om beurt hun geproduceerde goederen (bezette plantages leveren grondstoffen op). 

Privilege: De opzichter krijgt één goederensteen extra van een product naar keuze, dat hij net heeft geproduceerd.

5/ Handelaar:

Actie: Volgens beurtvolgorde kunnen spelers maximaal 1 goederensteen aan het handelshuis verkopen. Men ontvangt daarvoor de aangegeven prijs. De handelaarsfase eindigt wanneer elke speler 1 keer aan de beurt is geweest of wanneer het handelshuis vol zit. Als laatste handeling wordt het handelshuis leeggemaakt indien er 4 stenen liggen. Liggen er slechts 1, 2 of 3 stenen, dan blijven alle stenen liggen.

Privilege: 1 extra dubloen bij de verkoop van een goederensteen.

6/ Kapitein:

Actie: De spelers moeten om beurt goederen aan de schepen leveren. Een speler kan telkens enkel goederen leveren van één soort. Op het einde van deze fase mag je slechts 1 goederensteen overhouden (uitzondering: pakhuizen). Als laatste handeling lost de kapitein alle volle schepen.

Privilege: De kapitein krijgt bij een levering één extra punt.

7/ Goudzoeker:

Actie: Geen

Privilege: De goudzoeker neemt 1 dubloen van de bank.

Einde van het spel :

Het spel eindigt aan het einde van de ronde waarin aan minstens 1 van de 3 voorwaarden wordt voldaan:
1. een speler bouwt zijn 12e stadsveld.
2. er kunnen niet voldoende kolonisten op het kolonistenschip worden gelegd (burgemeesterfase).
3. alle puntenfiches zijn op.

Belangrijke regels:

+ De speler mag niet weigeren een rol te kiezen. Hij mag echter wel een rol kiezen, die hij vervolgens helemaal niet kan of wil gebruiken.
+ Geld en goederen moeten steeds zichtbaar zijn.
+ Maïs wordt direct van op de plantage gewonnen, het heeft geen productiegebouw nodig.

Burgemeesterfase:
+ De speler mag tijdens deze fase steeds zijn kolonisten herverdelen.
+ Als een kolonist(en) niet tewerk gesteld kan worden, dan gaat hij naar San Juan. In de volgende burgemeesterfase kan je hem terug inzetten.
+ Geen enkele speler mag vrijwillig kolonisten plaatsen in San Juan.

Bouwmeesterfase:
+ Je mag maar 1 gebouw bouwen in je beurt .
+ Elke bezette steengroeve die je bezit, vermindert de bouwkosten met 1 dubloen. Een speler kan echter bij de gebouwen uit de eerste kolom (overzichtskaart) slecht één bezette steengroeve als vermindering laten gelden; bij de 2de kolom maximaal 2; enz... 

Handelaarsfase:
+ Het handelshuis neemt alleen goederen van verschillende soorten op (uitzondering: magazijn) 

Opzichtersfase:
+ Is een betreffende goederensoort niet meer voorradig, dan krijgen de spelers niets.

Kapiteinsfase:
+ Elk schip accepteert slechts één soort goederen. Een schip aanvaardt geen goederen die al op een ander schip aanwezig zijn.
+ De kapiteinsfase blijft gelden totdat er niemand meer kan leveren. Het kan dus zijn dat je meermaals aan de beurt bent.
+ Je moet zoveel goederen leveren als je kan, je mag niets achterhouden. 
+ Voor elke goederensteen dat je levert, krijg je 1 punt (puntenfiche).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
It's a waste of time - there are so many better games out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Pretty decent Euro game. I don't think I can add anything that hasn't already been said about the mechanics (and subsequent issues) a dozen times already. Much lauded when it came out over ten years ago, by now I think much better and more interesting (not to mention less contentious) games have appeared. Were it released today I think it would probably rate about a full point lower, but there you go. Still, I give it a shot from time to time.

I do think that 3p has issues with the default setup, as the player that starts with corn has won every single game I've ever played online. It's also obvious that some buildings are more valuable than others, with a few clearly overpriced, and even the designer has stated he would alter the cost of certain buildings were it released today.

Anyway, don't take it too seriously, and avoid the sharks. That pretty much means avoiding places like BSW altogether, otherwise you'll get sworn at if you make a sub-optimal move. Or just do what I do and play a game in 10 minutes against the computer.

RATING: 8.6
[March 2017 - 8.6]
The more I play other games, the more I appreciate Puerto Rico for all the reasons below. 

[November 2016 - 8]
Puerto Rico continues to grow on me. Despite playing a ton of other games, this one has staying power that makes you appreciate its simple mechanics of gameplay and interaction. You're doing your own thing, but always feel invested in others' turns as its essentially your turn as well. I also really enjoy the variant two-player game. 

[October 2015 - 7.6]
I've grown to appreciate Puerto Rico some more. If you play with people who know the game and you're at the same level, the games go a little faster and are close.  I wish the expansions were more widely available as some different building could help bring more variety to the game. 

[July 2014 - 7.3]
I always enjoy a game of Puerto Rico, but in the end, it's not a game I want to rush out and tell everyone about.

RATING: 9
Game pieces and boards are a little bland, but wow! what a good game.

Some games can be a bit lopsided if you aren't paying attention to what your opponents are doing. Similarly if you get too far behind there is pretty much no way to come back.

If you can avoid those problems it is a tense back and forth with lots of fun ways to hose your opponents. e.g., making them ship when they don't want to or going to the market when they can't sell anything.

RATING: 6
The governor changes every round and I have found that it is almost impossible to get reelected.  I did not know that there were such strict term limits in Puerto Rico, so this game is very educational.  Also, if coffee is worth so much more than indigo, then I must question the intelligence of the guy who runs the trading house.  He should really try to get more than one coffee, and then he could sell the extra one on ebay and get like four or five indigo!!

This game should really be named "Commonwealth of Puerto Rico" because that is its official name.  Puerto Rico means "rich port" in Spanish which sounds nice but I will not award an extra point for this because this game is German not Spanish.  However I will DEDUCT a point because it is politically incorrect to call the slaves "colonists."  This makes light of their struggle.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Another report on PUERTO RICO (PR), the recent Eurogame release from RioGrande games: it's a very good
(possibly great - depends on a few more playings) game. Played four games on Saturday with 3,4,4,and 5 players. 
It has a "Civilization" feel in a way - building up an infrastructure to gain more money, production, buildings and/or victory points. PR is MUCH less detailed and much more streamlined, of course, however, all of the tough decisions of "too many options - too little time and money" are present. The mechanics are simple and elegant, making it easy for beginners to play, but there is a depth of strategy which will make the veteran players wanting to play again and again. 

The comparisons to Princes of Florence (PoF) are inappropriate, in my opinion. PoF seemed like a slow moving multi-player solitaire game to me, whereas, in PR I was always keen to see what the other players were doing and their decisions rarely took more than a minute. So the interaction and game flow in PR are FAR better than in PoF. 

I think PUERTO RICO could end up as one of those Top 10 games of all-time which you can pull off the shelf and play years from now. 

Highly recommended. 9 out of 10. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is the one game I continue to play again and again.  My wife will play it, my non gamer friends will play it, my gamer friends will play this.  It is a complicated game, but what makes it so good is the multiple paths to victory.  It is complex and yet simple enough to teach quickly to anyone.
Now that I have owned this for 6 years, it is the one game that I keep coming back to.  It is relatively easy to teach but has an excellent amount of depth and replayability.  I anticipate owning and playing this for years to come.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Yeah, it wins awards and everyone loves it, but there is just not enough conflict.  Yes, there is picking a role that maximizes your benefit and minimizes others, but anything more agressive than that and you are just allowing everyone but you (doing a suboptimal thing to hurt) and them (the one being hurt) to jump ahead.  That's not competition.  This game is just elegant solitare.

Update 5-7: Hey, expansion came out and is pretty cool.  makes the less chosen roles more attractive and adds some neat new buildings.  When you are good at it player conflict reaches Agricola level, but Agricola is more fun because when you look back down you have something cooler than in PR.

RATING: 8
This one has a great reputation here on the Geek and is quite deserving.  It is a great game and I'm always willing to play. I don't rate it as being the best game ever though.  I prefer it as a 5 player or 4 player game. 3er just seems too much like a race.  Caylus is a much better fit in the 3er slot.

I'm starting to come around on the opinion that 5 may be just too many to play this game.  Often you can have a very bad game no matter what decisions you make.  This happened to one of the players in our last game.  I'm bumping this down from a 9 to an 8 because I've come to realized that while I'm always willing to play this very good game...I don't always want to suggest it.

Now I think this game plays best with 3.  The options to victory really open up for building or shipping.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Puerto Rico has been hovering around the edges of my awareness for quite a while. My friend Sam had spoken favorably of it, and had suggested we play it while he visited over the Christmas holiday, but I had convinced everyone to play Catan: Cities & Knights instead. Eventually, as my collection grew, I finally bought a copy. I admit to feeling some reluctance about the game because of its ranking. My concern about the potential of hype delayed my purchase of the game.

I ended up liking it quite a bit when I finally purchased it, and ended up downloading the free Excel implementation of the game and playing it a lot. So much so that I found myself quickly exceeding the experience level of most of the other people I played with and thus winning all the time. This wasn't fun for me and wasn't really fun for them, so my play of the game ratched down substantially to the point where I rarely play the game any more. (My girlfriend comments pretty regularly that she misses playing it.) In the last few months my plays of the game have actually increased because of my girlfriend's desire to play and because of the fact that I have lost a lot of what I once knew. I still win quite a bit, but my mind isn't as entrenched in the game as it was so it is more fun both for me and other people.

I rarely play this anymore, because Race For the Galaxy feels like a largely superior replacement.

RATING: 9
one of the best strategy games in existence. Is extremely tight and well formed

RATING: 10
Stunning game. Players are settling Puerto Rico in the decades after Columbus&#039; discovery of the new world. They produce goods on their plantations, sell them in town (for money) or ship them back to the Old World (for victory points), lure colonists, prospect, trade, build and so on. It&#039;s all handled in a very elegant manner, using the personality card selection mechanic from Verrater. An excellent and immersive 90 minute game and thoroughly recommended.

RATING: 7
Puerto Rico is great in the sense that it best represent meritocracy, and I love the "role drafting" mechanic in games.  The player that wins in PR deserved to win and did not luck into it (people complain sometimes of the winner playing adjacent to weaker players but I think that is just usually sour grapes).  That said, it is a terribly unforgiving game as well.  If you get behind, you will lose unless your opponent makes a mistake.  There is no high risk gamble to make up the difference, which means that sometimes you will simply be waiting for the hangman.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Deserving of all the praise it has received, my play group played this once or twice a week every week for well over a year without tiring of it. It has only two flaws in my estimation, though neither kept us from loving the game:

1) The Guild Hall building seems improperly balanced. The abundance of production buildings, and the need to acquire them naturally anyway through the course of the game, makes the Guild Hall much stronger than the other large buildings. If players aren't very careful as a group, the player who buys the Guild Hall wins almost every time.

2) If you play with the same group of people time and again, the game will have a tendancy to get "on the rails." Players will tend to make the same decisions every time, pursuing the same paths to victory. Make sure at the very least you don't sit in the same order each time you play it. And adding in the expansion set and randomly determining the buildings to be used (rather than drafting) can really help snap you off the rails. (Though the Union Hall is ever more imbalanced than the Guild Hall... what is it about Halls in this game?)
