RATING: 8
When I first played this, I thought it was boring, simplistic, and predictable. But my appreciation for this has gone up with every play. I keep finding more to do, more to find, more unexpected synthesis coming from the game. Definitely a good sign.

I'd definitely rather play this than most of its successors and imitators.

Update: Interaction in this game is subtle and often goes unnoticed, but is the real crux of the play of the game.  JohnRayJr said it best: 

"Puerto Rico strives for the ideal of non-random, no-luck play where the variability emerges almost entirely from players' actions. Each decision you make is a wave that other players are trying to catch. Each wave that comes your way is designed to flatten you. The game is smooth, fast, accessible, deep, complex, and variable, and it makes it all look easy."

+1

Gave to a friend.

[b][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/58462/puerto-rico_short-guide_game-summary]Puerto Rico_Short Guide_Game Summary[/url][/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Puerto Rico simply rocks.  Every turn has its phases, but you never know in what order they'll occur or who will initiate each one.  There's a definite cooperative element, because rarely can you do something that benefits you without helping someone else as well.  You really have to be careful about who you may be helping!  The game's biggest drawback is that it requires players of reasonably equal skills; otherwise the newbie always hands the game to the old pro with a bad move or two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.7
This game is awesome.  I love the constant shift of the game.  It is very fluid and you must pay attention to strategy to be successful.  You have to plan for not only what you do, but also for what the other players are doing to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Tough to play with inexperienced players, because they can easily make mistakes that impact everyone else, but it's still one of my favorite worker placement games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Lots of fun!!  A little bit of a learning curve.  Various paths to victory, intersting decisions and some subtle screwage equal a great game.  Can be unbalanced when playing with a mix of new and experienced players.    
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very fun game with unique strategies for winning. I love having getting to act on almost every turn, and having so many options for winning. This game is a classic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
This game gets an awful lot of hype, but it isn't so high in my estimation.  I first played it years ago, and somehow won (with a large amount of coaching).  I've played with new players and experienced ones, with 3, 4, and 5, with serious board gamers in tournaments and Magic players dabbling in something different.  

The nearly-no-randomness aspect makes it practically an exercise in groupthink, as well as mapping out what ripple effects your actions will have.  You almost have to ask yourself, "OK, if I take settler this time, will he take prospector or mayor?  Will the next person take the remaining one or craft?"  The ability to predict means the requirement to do so, if you want to win against good players, that is.  Worse still, it's not just about taking the best move for you, but making sure the players downstream don't get set up with anything 'too good', handing them an edge, if not the victory.
This makes it all the more frustrating when the [i]single[/i] random element, the plantation tile draw, doesn't go your way and the corn (or coffee, or whatever) remains hidden.  I wonder how many games are swung by the simple lack of the crop a player was building towards?

I'm also frustrated by the lack of balance/variability in the buildings.  It's always the same ones, and they always get bought in the same pattern.  Some of them are clearly amazing, and others almost worthless.  Then there's the issue of starting turn order, and who gets the best seats for initial crops, plus who gets to sit to the left of the new player and who has to sit left of the shark.

The single worst thing, though, is the lack of scaling for player counts.  With 3 or 4, it's probably ok, but with 5, you start butting up against the piece limits a lot more.  There aren't any more copies of the buildings.  There aren't any more goods in the supply.  Frequently, as you pass into the late game, taking craftsman shoots way up in value, just because it's the only way to guarantee that you actually get your stuff.  I've seen people with a factory and 5 types of goods online get stuck with a measly couple barrels and a buck (instead of the decent haul and 5 they were entitled to), because they were to the right of the player taking craft and got hosed by the arbitrary piece limit.  A bunch of barrels can get stuck on boats or in the trading house, and the players upstream will simply empty out the remaining supply.  This sort of passive-aggressive screwage is PR's bread and butter, but I find it way more annoying at times than other games that are far more confrontational.

Anyway, it's just not fun for me anymore (if it ever was), and I'd rather play something that is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
FL

RATING: 9
Puerto Rico is like a old Oak tree that is simple and elegant above ground while beneath its roots are complex, twisting, and substantial.  Tons of depth and tough decisions that should play in 90 minutes and as a bonus, it is very simple to teach.  One of the best games around.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Puerto Rico was an extremely influential game, but I find several things about it unpleasant: it's too long, too deep (it rewards experience too heavily), has too strong of a feedback loop, and it overwhelms players with too much strategic space and too steep of a learning curve at the beginning of the game.

Unless all players are equally matched and playing optimally, the game can lack tension for multiple types of players: new players, players who haven't memorized the buildings, players who make an early mistake, or players who spend less time looking ahead. Even if players are closely matched at the beginning, they may all be able to tell who will win and who will lose when the game is only 2/3 complete (which means you can spend up to an hour knowing you will lose).

For people who want to explore the depths of a game with exactly the same group of equally matched players, and derive enjoyment from gradual mastery of its depth, I'm sure Puerto Rico is rewarding. But that's not what I want from a game.

I'm glad designers realized the game was too deep and too long and created spinoff games like San Juan, Race for the Galaxy, and Glory to Rome. They all improve on Puerto Rico in some ways (mostly by reducing strategic lookahead and reducing playtime).

But card game reimplementations tend to remove the thing I like best about Puerto Rico: interaction. Because you can see the full state of other players' positions, you can anticipate and thwart their plans. Having a hidden hand of cards and using simultaneous action selection (as in Race for the Galaxy) removes too much of that anticipation and interaction for me.

So what game feels similar to Puerto Rico, while improving its shortcomings and retaining its interaction? Splendor!

Splendor allows you to see other people's positions and thwart their plans (it actually provides more blocking opportunities than Puerto Rico), it lets you plan ahead (but not too far) by looking at a shared game state, has you gathering pieces that later combine to improve your position (gem discounts in Splendor are the same thing as quarries and buildings in Puerto Rico). Yet Splendor lasts 45 minutes, is easier to teach, has a game state that's easier to parse, and is better at maintaining endgame tension.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is an addictive game - just have to love how their are so many ways to play out each game - never the same twice... it is basically a finely tuned economic maximization game - where you also need to keep an eye out for your neighbors as well... 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

very good economy game.  I don't love it, but its solid.

RATING: N/A
[b](My very first PR Game-5 Players)[/b]
I think I've found my new favourite game. After owning this game for over a year, I got to play it for the first time tonight. Man, this game is good. Now I understand how BGGers can stomach playing this game over a hundred times!

I was less confident with the components (no graphics on building and thin cardstock; I can't stand with these) and the lack of brief/short explanation of the buildings displayed on board. So I went gaga and printed out every single player aid that I can find. After my first play, I can official say they're not really necessary (the universal head player aid is handy though; role and building sides). Those printed on the board is more than enough. But I hope future players will find my printed player aids useful somehow.

[b]Comment on 2-players experience with the official rule.[/b]
Puerto Rico is also good with two! Man, I can't get enough of this game. Hopefully I will not burnt out. The rule feels right and it didn't change much with the normal 3-5 players game. A round will end (change of governer) when both players have picked 3 roles respectively.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I admire this system a lot: little downtime, all players usually involved; having a player pick a role and each player perform the action was very innovative.  But it’s too calculational and deterministic; it has the puzzle/optimization feel of many Euros.  Too much non-spatial lookahead is needed to do well.  In our games, taking the craftsman is a bad idea (in 5 player game)--chooser typically gets locked out of trading and shipping-- leading to some game stagnation since no one wants to pick it.  Also, some buildings’ costs seem out of whack for their utility (small market, university), and player order is too influential: the first player usually falls behind while the 4th or 5th player often wins.  A nice game to admire, not to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I don't have very fond memories of it, but it's a classic, it's much appreciated by players everywhere, and we owe him credit for the "Renaissance" of Board Games we are living in the 2010s. I'll come back to you someday and maybe I'll change my mind!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.73
One of the classics and maybe first Euro I played somewhere in the first decade of 21st century. It brought us remarkable [b]role selection mechanic[/b] that is used in two of my very loved games: Twilight Imperium and Race for the Galaxy. It's about building colony in Caribbean Puerto Rico, expanding San Juan with various early industrial buildings and plants, employing workers (avoiding to say slaves), growing food, producing goods and selling them for money or shipping them off the island for points. Mayor with the most points wins. Very good game with a moderate replayability for up to 5 players. There is also hard to get expansion which I want to try.

[b]Update:[/b] Dropped to 8.9 from 9.0 due to the lack of variability.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Role selection which gives everybody the same action but gives an exclusive bonus to the player who selected the role.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games. "Turn within a turn" structure can be confusing for new players, so teaching the game can be difficult.  I like the fact that the game is relatively low on luck, and several strategies (and combinations of strategies) can lead to victory. 

A big part of the game is predicting what other players will do (and selecting an appropriate strategy based on their actions), but there isn't a lot of direct conflict.  It's virtually impossible to "gang up on" other players, and the amount of "screwing over other players" that can happen is relatively minimal. 

High replayability.  There's a reason this one was #1 on BGG for so long.  It's an older game, but really is a fantastic one. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I like this game, but everyone playing needs to have a similar mindset for a good game. A mixed group of hardcore analyzers and carebear play-for-fun types will leave neither party satisfied. 

If you are the win-at-all-costs type playing with new or casual players, you may have more fun playing a goofy suboptimal strategy than what your min/max brain is telling you to do.

There's little player interaction and little luck involved, the biggest luck factor would be who sits to the left of the most inexperienced/worst player in a competitive game.

RATING: 8
Puerto Rico is an amazing game. I really love the game, unfortunately the others in my regular group don't really enjoy it all that much. I also think it kept being looked over for newer, flashier titles, which is a shame. Luckily many folks at the meetups I attend play it often so I am sure I'll still have many opportunities to play it (including online play at Board Game Arena).

The tough decisions, the multiple strategies, and the lack of luck really make the game great for me. Plus it has little to no downtime as the turns are quick and what others do greatly impact your decisions.

RATING: 7

RATING: 7
UPDATE: I've swung back to like PR more again. Granted, I don't hang out with those "beard and suspenders" types that analyze everything until it's not fun any more, so YMMV. Yes, the "player on the right" thing is definitely there. If everyone is on the same level, it can be pretty great though.

A classic game. It's quite good but maybe not worth all the hype. It is a really good game (an excellent game that everyone should try at least once, mind you) but just misses...something to put it over the top. I really think that San Juan gives you enough of the PR feel in a much more elegant package.

My main problem with it is that you can get too thrown off by the "player on your right" syndrome and that can get really frustrating. Think "continually getting kicked in the teeth for a hour and a half" frustrating. No, I'm not bitter. Okay, I am.

RATING: 7
The most innovative aspect of this game is the role selection and how bonuses are added to unused role.  It's interesting to see a euro that uses victory points without a track for all to see, making the end game more tense.  There are 3 methods of ending the game which is in the player's control which usually ensures that the game rarely feels stale.  I like that the game plays fairly quickly when everyone knows what they're doing.  My only problem is that some of the buildings feel useless for their cost.  Even though I like Puerto Rico, Race for the Galaxy has completely replaced this game for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Considered by many to be the crowning achievement of Euro game design this game has everything that makes it a classic: 1) Many viable strategies that interlock in always interesting ways 2) asymmetrical roles that players can take each round 3)  money management that makes you bite your nails 4) beautiful game material and 5) already proven durability.
This is one of the games that can be the ideal gateway to Eurogames in general, as it shows perfectly what this medium can achieve. A classic.

The game still is a bit of fun once you get into it, but not my favorite by a long shot.  I would reccommend it with a warning.  Not for the light gamer.

RATING: 10
The King of all board games (IMHO). I have been playing this game for years, and I still chomp at the bit to play this gem. Building a successful factory, or establishing a corn wharf are extremely fulfilling, and the 'craftsman angst' is delightfully excruciating. I have yet to play a game that comes close to reproducing the Puerto Rico experience, which in the current age of board games speaks volumes, and confirms the timelessness it holds. The two expansions add some spice, but aren't super necessary because the base game is the best there is. Simply the best.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
+Beautiful blend of tactics and strategy
+VERY interactive
+Relatively simple to teach for its depth and complexity
+Games last for a very satisfying length of time and do not overstay their welcome
+Multiple different game end conditions give players lots of opportunities to try to close out the game at the ideal time for them
+Lack of too many options at the same time keeps the game digestible while those available choices are all interesting and have noticeable impact on the results
+Near simultaneous play keeps everyone engaged

-Aesthetically lacking
-The game is generally very satisfying, but not really exciting
-Some excessive and unintuitive complexity, variety of phases make it slow to teach despite the overall simplicity
-Winner can become obvious partway through the game and then it becomes a matter of playing to a foregone conclusion
-Dislike it at 5 players as it exacerbates issues of a bad player skewing the game towards the player who goes immediately after them (don't run out of goods or space on ships as easily in 3 or 4 player)

Location: Oberlin

RATING: 10
I keep coming back to this game.  The more newer games I play the more Puerto Rico's brilliance stands out.  There are lots of good games, but I don't know of any that offers everything that it does, including
1) Depth of strategy (with very little luck)
2) Lots of player interaction
3) The enjoyment of building an economic engine
4) Very reasonable playing time (and player numbers)

It's still the best.

RATING: 7
[1 play] Yeah, finally played Puerto Rico.  For years I’ve been--probably "avoiding" would be putting it too strongly, but definitely not seeking this out.  It just didn’t appeal, based not so much on what I’d heard about the game itself, but about the behavior it brings out in (some) people.  

So it was actually pretty agreeable.  PR is an interesting game, lots to think about, and I can see why people like it so much.  I definitely don’t like it as much as Agricola, but am looking forward to playing again.

And the bonus was that I finally got some benefit out of the hours of my life that have been wasted playing Race for the Galaxy, inasmuch as RftG made the role selection aspect of PR familiar.

RATING: 7.5
Puerto Rico makes great use of role selection. Much of how well a player does will revolve around the actions they choose and how well they predict their opponents' actions. 
A good strategy backed by the right buildings is also essential.

Quick decisions will have you completing a game in under an hour. There is tension as much of the score is not revealed until the end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After 2 quick plays this evening I discovered that PR was neither as complicated or as confusing as I originally thought. A buddy and I played the "official" 2 player variant and I walked away with the delicious taste of intrigue on my pallet. A wonderful example of less random and more strategy. This game is for anyone that likes to think while gaming. Brilliant.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I kind of liked this game when I first played it, but after 15 or so plays I've gone right off it. 
This may be due to the people I usually play with (my wife and another couple) where they always all go for a shipping strategy.  This bores me to tears and I just can't make a building strategy work when they keep shipping all the time. Also, the 2 girls don't quite 'get' the idea that your best move is the one that disadvantages everyone else the most (especially the 'leader') - so the result is usually a foregone conclusion. 
I agree with a number of people who feel that 'the game plays them' - and because the result depends so much on what other people do, it's almost impossible to try out any strategies and knowif they are reliable or not.
OK - rant over......

RATING: 9
It's #1 for a reason, isn't it?  Wait...now it's #2!  or #3?  or #2?  At any rate it's near top of the yo-yo.

This kind of game definitely appeals to me a lot, and although I probably wasn't ready for this earlier, I think we are now, especially as our children get older.  One comment is that people less experienced with the game are at a large disadvantage - it's best with a group of four equally skilled players.  I've played it several times now, and it's a decent meaty game that rewards repeated play.

Upgraded with [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/911762/puerto-rico]illustrated tiles[/url] that include [gameid=12382] and [gameid=40688] expansion - see my [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/649398/a-pictorial-overview-an-edition-of-puerto-rico-wit]pictorial review[/url].

Also owned:
[gameid=12382]
[gameid=159761]

Recommended: 
- swap costs of university & factory - (see [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/538221/poll-would-you-play-pr-wthe-designer-suggested-ch]variant[/url] suggested by designer).
- Players starting with a corn plantation should start with 1 doubloon less than players starting with an indigo plantation (see [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/article/5473055#5473055]here[/url]).

Two player game  - see my [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/679445]comprehensive analysis and comparison of all the popular variants[/url].
1. Craftsman Advantage:
a) Official Alea variant [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/1583/puerto-rico-variant-for-2-players-doc]here[/url] (Office and Wharf are both very powerful).  
b) Amended Alea variant: to keep nearly all roles being picked, use the 6 basic roles (no prospectors) and have each player choose 2 roles a turn, leaving 2 unpicked.
2. Craftsman Angst (Alternative Alea variant): use 7 basic roles and have Governor choose 3 and opponent 2, to prevent back-to-back Governor Effect.  See [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/679955]this article[/url] for a full description (thought to test, to keep original tight finances: governor only adds 1 doubloon instead of 2?).

Other possible amendments to 2 player variant:
- choose 12 violet buildings at random (ideally including expansion buildings) 
- replace Construction Hut with Office, or reduce Trading House size from 4 to 3.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's taken me over 5 plays of PR to warm up to its design. It's a good game, and while I'll never go hog wild for it like some, I'd like to put in another dozen plays exploring it. It's not an intuitive game but rather a deduction as to what the best play is based on the wake you'll leave behind for other players. It's always felt constrained to me in that your job is not to decide which option you want to take but rather to find the best choice of those before you and choose it (and there is only one best choice). That sort of analysis felt very dry at first, but now I've come to find the fun in it (nothing like actually winning a game to whet the appetite). 

I see others commenting that the building decision space is not as large as it appears due to some buildings be clearly superior to others, and I do see a couple of my friends playing the same game every time, so I'm not sure how long the shelf life is here, but I'm happy to explore it. My rating is up from a 5 at one point to a 7.

RATING: 1
This game not only defines the term "tacked on theme," the theme it superficially adopts is racist.  As a reward for surviving the Middle Passage, the slaves, I mean "colonists" get to toil in this gutless, boring eurogame. 

To be clear, I don't object to games covering difficult subject matter, and as a wargamer I have no problem playing as "[url=http://youtu.be/hn1VxaMEjRU]the baddies[/url]."  However, Puerto Rico's disingenuously whitewashed depiction of exploitative economic practices is cowardly and embarrassing.  

This game is also unforgivably dull.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
[b]Sold[/b]
Finally decided that the turn order dependence of this classic game was just too much to keep it on my shelf.  I have it on the iPad if I really get an itch to play again.
[b]previous comment:[/b]

Puerto Rico is a classic design, with a great balance and very elegant systems.  However, the lack of any sort of variable setup, mixed with the strong dependence on player order, keeps it from getting a higher score from me.  When it comes to role selection games, I think I prefer those where roles are selected simultaneously (ala Race for the Galaxy), rather than in player order.  Puerto Rico pioneered a lot of great concepts that other games have benefited from, and I give the design mad respect for that, but I find myself wanting to reach for those other games first.

I actually prefer it at 2p, but only when playing with the "craftsman angst" variant.  This removes the player order effect to the game, and makes it much stronger IMO.

RATING: 5
Based on one playing, this seems like an overrated pile of cardboard rectangles with a lot of text on them. Well designed, but too contrived. All the different building powers seem arbitrary, and easy to add more powers since they don't fit together naturally anyway. The tiny amount of interaction in character choosing seems chaotic and dependent on turn order. I think it would have made a better card game than board game because there isn't any spatial interaction.

RATING: 8

Finally got a full game and whilst it's very very good, it's not all that. Not much player interaction other than trying to stop the others doing better than you. But, planning and getting the phases right and having cash to build early all make it a neat experience. There's a lot of german text on buildings with conditional rules, so get the Rio Grande edition. It's these rules that make the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Holy crap is this game great!  It can be intimidating for players because this is structured in a "here's a whole bunch of mechanics, hopefully you can figure out how to win!" sort of way.  But I love how the only random element of the game is a collection of face-up tiles which the players have essentially equal access to, demanding that players successfully anticipate one another's choices in order to succeed.  Good replay, even after playing enough times to sort of sense which sort of conditions you're playing with, and how you should best react.  Nice components, too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Fun game, lots of interesting decisions and room for strategy.  I find it hard to find people to play with amongst my mostly non-game-geek friends.  It's usually easier to play a shorter game than this, but I am working on getting them used to the idea.  It tends to take 90-120 minutes when we play, but we're still getting the hang of it.  It definetely takes some fun out when you play with people who are new to the game and are not quick or too bright.

I could get many plays out of this before getting sick of it, but I can see how eventually I would.  I usually choose other games to play, but after a while without my PR fix I need to break it out.

One other thing, it brings up some sensitive issues depending who you play with.  I have some Puerto Rican friends and I played this with them, and the first thing they noticed was the little brown guys, the "colonists" - are really slaves.  Who worked the plantations?  Colonists or slaves?  It would be less offensive if at least I painted them different shades.

RATING: 6

In the beginning you feel like you're creating a little colony and the choices are many, but as you get more experienced the gameplay quickly become more and more scripted, the choices become few and tactical and the turn-order-bond become so strong that it decides the outcome if the players are uneven.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not the most popular game in my circle, but Puerto Rico really stands out in my collection because of its overwhelming focus on long-term economic planning over turn-by-turn opportunism and blind luck (though there certainly is a little of each of those there too).  While it appears pretty intimidating, the game is actually quite simple, with the entire gameplay being each player picking roles in order to carry out actions to ultimately garner them enough victory points to win.  It doesn't tend to drag on like Catan or many other games I enjoy occassional do, but it definitely isn't a filler game either.  There is also a two-player variant, which is pretty fun, though as usual, more is always better.  So far I have only played with two and three players, but I am looking forward to the higher levels of competition and additional factors that come with four or five player games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
+12
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I think this is a good piece of game design, but it has been replaced by Race for the Galaxy for me. Race for the Galaxy keeps nearly all the parts of Puerto Rico that I like, dispenses with the rest, and adds tons more variability in a shorter time frame. Still, Puerto Rico is a classic action-selection game; it simply lacks variability and has been surpassed by similar games. I am glad I owned it in the past, but I never need to play it again.

DESIRABILITY: No desire to play it again.

REPLACED BY: Race for the Galaxy

Played 30+ times. Less mathematical, but about the same interaction as Princes of Florence (so, open to charges of "multiplayer solitaire"). Still mostly indirect interaction. Not quite as tense as PoF for me. Even though I like this game and enjoy playing it, there are quite a few games I'd rather play. I feel that Taj Mahal and P.O.F. are both better than this game. Getting a bit bored of it,a nd find the game can drag too much. As neat an ideas as it is, I really this this game is blown all out of proportion for its 'greatness'. It's a solid 8, but not an obsession. [Owned, then sold, then traded for again, now trying to trade away.]

18th play: 5. Oct/14. After a long layoff, I came back to this game, very curious to see how I would feel about it. In short: my tastes have changes, and this game has been overtaken by others of a similar style. Race for the Galaxy is so similar, but puts a sci-fi skin on it (which I prefer), reduces both set-up and play time considerably, and offers more variability through not just expansions, but even the large draw deck.

RATING: 6.62

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekbuddy.php3?action=doanalyze&gameid=3076&groupid=4204&B1=Analyze]Ratings[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A more intricate and deterministic incarnation of the San Juan/RftG mechanic. I prefer RftG due to the shorter downtime (via its simultaneous turn mechanic), the wider variety of and greater access to powers, and the less fiddly economy (Puerto Rico requires plantations, production buildings and colonists in order to produce goods).

There is a lot of fiddliness in the colonist replenishment, limited goods, shipping space and trading house space; these provide opportunities for denial that RftG lacks.

Understanding the rudiments of the game, I don't dislike it as much as I used to.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[System Game, Economic, Investment] {2P:8, 3P:6, 4P:10, 5P:6} Amazing game of economics and interaction. Puerto Rico is fairly simple, plays quickly, and is deeply thought-provoking. It scales beautifully from two to five players (it's best with five). It's not really "deep" in the traditional sense, but timing is the main cog to the variability of the game. You'll be talking about games after they end, then want to play again immediately. Elegant mechanics, multiple roads to victory, interesting strategy and subtle yet vicious tactics make this a must-have for any German gamer. ***UPDATE: Affirming my 10 rating for PR. Still fantastic, 120  plays later. However, I no longer believe that I can label PR as the "deepest game of all time", or even as the "greatest game of all time". It's simply one of the best that I have played, but I cannot hold it above E&T, PoF and MtG. Regardless, it is an obligatory addition to any gamer's library. *** UPDATE: Dropped from 10 to 9 due to weaknesses in the 3P and 5P games, which magnify the weak player syndrome and detract from the enjoyment of the game. E&T and PoF do not have this adjacency problem. PR is still a great game, but it's not in the class of E&T and PoF. *** UPDATE: Ok, after playing a ludicrous number of games of PR I'm pretty sure that the 3P and 5P games of PR are simply not balanced. You're liable to get whacked in the trading house just because of the timing of the game and not because of anything that you did. That's just not acceptable. It might have been a good idea to made additional trading houses that scaled like the ships scale. As it is, the 4P game is still one of the best that boardgaming has to offer, but I'll only play 3P or 5P if asked. The 2P games remains pretty good, if a bit chesslike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating seems to be falling. No longer has a place in my top 10. It's not a bad game, but after playing so many deep, rich and fulfilling Euros, this one really lacks the oomph. 

I love that it is economic, and I love that it works well with 2, but I just don't find the decisions that interesting or satisfying for some reason. I miss the pain in making decisions in this game. 

Mostly, I'm annoyed because I can't figure out why it is *so* popular.

RATING: 9
Indestructible !

All people (gamers, geeks, newbies, my wife, my parents ...) which i introduced to Puerto Rico really like this game and want to play it again and again.

I must say it has everything to be attractive :
- rich without being heavy or over complex
- planning
- interaction
- tension
- multiple paths to victory
- great replayability
- relatively easy to explain

For me, the mechanism that brings all the tension to the game is the filling of the ships and the shipping to the old world by the captain.

Puerto Rico must be present in any respectable game library.

Awesome 2 players game.

RATING: 6

The only thing that dampens my enthusiasm for it are the stories of how a newbie can completely throw a game to more experienced players if scripted strategies are not followed.  And once those optimized strategies are learned, I imagine it becomes less of a game and more a procedural "going through the motions".  I'd rather instead just play a game that can be grokked relatively quickly and is fun for *everybody*, despite the players' experience-level...

RATING: 7.5
This game offers an incredible amount of player interaction, moreso than most other euros I can think of. However, its greatest asset is also my greatest source of frustration with it. You're often so dependent on the actions of others that bad or even mediocre play from another player can drastically affect you. That gives Puerto Rico a strong kingmaker vibe and an almost random feel in a way to me. But that being said, it's still a wonderful game worthy of its accolades.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nós somos o “Cristovão Colombo” e nosso objetivo é colonizar Porto Rico. Nós devemos plantar, construir, produzir bens, vender e exportar estes bens para as metrópoles. A diversão do jogo fica na escolha de ações, colonizar, povoar, construir, produzir, vender, exportar e minerar, que cada jogador tem como opção. O jogo se desenvolve em conseqüência dessas ações e por tanto o peso da sorte é mínimo. O seu rendimento depende, principalmente, das escolhas que você fizer em cada momento do jogo. Outro ponto alto do jogo para ter um bom resultado é, além de escolher as ações corretas, montar combinações de edifícios que tragam mais retorno durante o jogo. No fim, quem acumular mais pontos, decorrentes das exportações e edificações, vence.É verdade que o setup e setdown do jogo são demorados mesmo assim é um excelente jogo e foi por muito tempo o nº1 do BGG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I never got around to playing this one until 2010.  I expected to feel like I had seen it reimplemented in far superior ways, but that is not the case.  While Puerto Rico has clearly stamped its influence on many games, it does not at all feel like a 'rough draft' of its concepts.  I find it as refined and balanced and tense as any similar, subsequent games.

RATING: 7
Easy to learn.  Really fun.  Flexible number of players.  I like how everything you do effects other players. I like how this game is just simple enough to let you plan three turns ahead. You can score boons for yourself and mess up your opponents' plans. 

This used to be the second or third game I would teach to new players after something easier to teach like Dominion are Carcassone. I think it has been supplanted by Phoenicia though. 

After owning this for 7 years the game is a little stale for me. There are about three strategies in the game (my opinion) and I think that one of them is the best. A game with good players would still be really tactically challenging and rewarding, but it will take some investment to get players to that level. That time is better spent elsewhere these days. 

I'm leaving this at the 7 I gave it originally because it deserves it. I would still play this game and still use it to teach newcomers. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Brilliant game about imperialism.  The best part is the game's ingenious turn-taking mechanism; one player selects the next move and all the player's take that move.  There is so much to like about this game though.  It's not too long, has a lot of depth, you get to build things, and there are several different paths to victory.  Definitely one of the best games out there.

RATING: 8
The ultimate Euro city-building game. PR is a game that really requires several plays to make the best of it, and that's good, because I would definitely play it almost any time. It gives you space to experiment but also rewards skilled players.  The best feature is that there are actions for every player to do on every turn, so that keeps everyone in it.  Relatively easy to teach to newcomers as well. There are a few things that aggravate me about Puerto Rico in terms of turn order and timing, but it's aggravating in a good sort of way. PR is a standard of Euro gaming.

RATING: 9

It is fun anyway and I recommend it greatly. (It has some beauty issues since the buildings are not illustrated. You may change that by some cutting and pasting, it takes some work but it's totally worth it)

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It is funny to say that at a 6, Puerto Rico has actually risen in my standings (I used to have it at a five).  I can see what people love about this game, but it also might be the same elements that have made me luke warm to it.  It feels very much like a solitare experience, and it also seems to a degree solvable.  It has a learning curve for developing strategies therefore giving experienced players a huge advantage over those not as familiar.  My most recent playing, after not having wanted to touch it for a year, did spark some interest in me.  I shall get this on the table again soon, and reevaluate my love/hate for it. 

UPDATE:  I am raising Puerto Rico's score to an 7.  However, with this game seemingly overplayed by so many it is hard to entertain a game with like leveled players.  I still find that the learning curve in accordance to the game's many stategic options makes the game lop-sided if not attended by gamers with similar handicaps.  This phenomenon is highly noticeable in Puerto Rico, where in other games it is less black and white.  In post game analysis when one or two players are just beginning to notice small mistakes, and errors in judgement, while others are writing disertations (making the former  overwhelmed in a gaming analysis shadow) it makes for an uncomfortable and bewildering feeling.  I am no longer blind to the game's depth, nor do I find it dry or inexcusably label it solitaire as I did in my early impressions, I do however find that the age of the game coupled with the diversity in experience of players makes Puerto Rico flawed by no merit of it's own.

UPDATE:  8!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Clearly an execelent game.  Replayibility is outstanding.  However, it is better online than FTF for a couple of reasons. Firstly, the fiddle-factor at least doubles the length of the FTF game, Secondly,in a game with players of mixed skill levels, the outcome is often determined by the weak players - more so than in the average Euro.  On-line both of these problems are solved.  The fiddliness is gone (games take about 10 minutes per player) and most of the time, all players are strong, so the game results are less dependent on the poor play of the weak.  FTF, it is a good game that I will play occasionally.  On line it is a solid 9.  This is the only Euro I have played on-line more than a time or two... I played about 90 games on line over a 3 month period during 2005 or so.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Addictive game that keeps you coming back for more. Empathy is essential. The expansion gives it new life.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.7
Owned since 13.03.2008
I've only played it, as a game for 2... but it works very well! 
 
Played as a 3 p game on my PC. It's far much better! If I played it with 3 real, I'd rate it 9,5. 
 
You need to learn how does every building work. No. You don't need to learn. You must remember, to discover your own tactics. It doesn't mean that the game's difficult or something. You just need to play a few times. For me that's just one of the game's pros. 
 
EDIT: After 4p, unfinished gameplay: game's cutthroat. It's very hard to figure out what's the best role to get, when you didn't play for 5 months. Very interesting, nasty decisions. In a 4p game you can see how does your system work. My didn't. 
Edit2: After 4p finished gameplay. Just great! The most intriguing is the interaction.

When your opponents don't try new strategies, or don't try to improve the old ones - this can get a little repetetive. With newbies there is a ,,who's sitting next to whom" syndrome. 
Anyway - great game. Multiple paths to victory. Very, vey good.

EDIT
After 10+ plays - GRRRRREAT!
 
2-5 players 
[2,0h-2,5h]

RATING: 8
What I used to think: 
Fun game, but for the type of game that it is, I'd rather have Princes of Florence.

What I think now:
The more I play the game, the more I enjoy it.  True, I've only played 3 games with people, but I've been playing a lot of Puerto Rico using Tony Mitton's Excel program, available on BGG.  It's challenging, and while not as much fun as playing with the real bits, you can get through a 5 player game in less than 10 minutes.  While I'm not sure it's the BEST game of all time, I can understand why it's rated that way.

RATING: 7
1 x FtF

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
As someone else in these comments said, I don't mind playing the "bad guys" in a board game. I love playing Jack the Ripper in Letters from Whitechapel. But that game makes no bones about who Jack the Ripper was or what he did. Puerto Rico, on the other hand, is a disingenuous take on the history of slavery and slaves (here revised to "colonists"). It provides a simulation of slavery and glorifies the practice from the colonizer's perspective, and that is not a version of history I'd like to participate in. 

Put differently, would you play a game set in the American South, where you play as plantation owners, and to achieve victory, you put black "workers" to work in cotton and tobacco fields? Or a simulation of Nazi death camps, but with the Jews renamed as Untermensch or some other euphemism?

I won't comment on the mechanics, which apparently are timeless. As for the presentation and production quality, it's about as low as you can find for a game in production today. Generic art, or in some cases, no art, just... words in color.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I don't like the fact that this game doesn't work well with players of unmatched skill.  I also don't like the fact that the game lacks a centralized board; to play well, you have to track all the other players' individual boards, and frankly I find that aspect tiresome.  Furthermore, Puerto Rico's build system requires players to absorb quite a bit of "building trivia" to be able to play well; I think learning that kind of information is completely uninteresting.

In short: yes, it's a generally good game, but I don't get the hype.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A good game most of the time, but has balance problems.  Many games are decided half way through, use of the wharf can easily break the game unless all players are expierenced at how to counter this building.

Virtually all games suffer from one classic problem some from two but this game suffers from three!!!

Weakest player: if just one person isn't very familiar with the game or strategic with their moves they disrupt the game and usually spends most of the game throwing points at the person to their left because of the next weakness.

Rummy effect: who sits to your right, and what they do, effects your game as much as what you do!!

Last is the steam roller:  this is where an early lead merely accelerates the growth of a player and in a 5 player game there are rarely more than two or three people in the running half-way through the game.

If you are looking for the best game of this genre try "Princes of Florence," or a newer game, Agricola.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pros:
* Multiple paths to victory
* Every decision you make is important, and will affect the rest of the game (both for you and the rest of the players)
* You need to predict what the other players are going to do in order to stay competitive
* Of course the whole role-choosing mechanism, and the fact that everyone gets to do something when it's your turn is very interesting
* Very low on luck. 
* Very high level of player interaction.
* I like the modifying or breaking of the rules that come with the purple buildings

Cons:
* Long setup time
* Fairly steep learning curve.
* All the bits, and lack of a central board can look a bit daunting to first-time players
* A beginner might accidentally give too great of an advantage to the player next in line if played with dissimilar player skill levels.
* It is an "optimize your economic efficiency" game. If you don't see the fun in a good optimization puzzle it is likely that you won't like this game either.
* Like most efficiency games, it can be a little "math-y"
* It invites a lot of analysis, scripted "best-moves", and bickering about said "best moves" from optimal play purists. Simply don't play with these people.


There is a lot to take in for the first time player because of all the different houses.  I usually try to explain the key concepts before the game, and then take the houses a few at a time during gameplay (as they start to become affordable). 

There isn't a lot a direct interaction with the other players, and none of it is of the nuke-your-opponents kind. The game is still full of interaction, it's just a more subtle and indirect kind than you might be used to. This is perfectly ok with me, but you might feel differently.

When you are new to the game, the lack of overt conflict has the effect that, it rarely feels like the other players are out to get you; you even get to build your own little empire on a board separate from your opponents. You get to see your strategy through to the end and then see how you did, compared to the others. I think this is a very smart design choice because you have a lot to digest during your first few games even if you focus only on yourself. Of course, as more seasoned players know, you really need to keep an eye on what the others are doing. Half the game is figuring out what all the other players are going to do and play accordingly. Either to mess up their plans or to ride their coattails

During your first plays, you rarely feel like you are in a bad position. Sure, some other player might be earning more money or shipping more goods right now. But you always feel like your own empire economy is just about to get to the next level, putting you in the lead any second now.
After you get more acquainted with the game, you will start to see who is really doing well and who is not. But at this point you will also see _why_ people are in the places they are and can change your play accordingly.

Uneven player experience can be a big problem because the beginner might accidentally give a very big advantage to the next player in line. Try to play with people of similar experience levels. 
Many players also complain that the beginner is playing the "wrong" moves and therefore messing up the game for everyone else. I don't agree with that, simply because I think that messing things up for the other players is a big part of the game. And I would rather see that as a breath of fresh air in a game where everyone else has obviously got stuck in a rut, playing the same moves game after game. 

I think the game scales fairly well and, with the official variant, is even a great 2-player game. With less players you can have more control over what you do and can more easily predict what the other players will do. With more players there is more competition for resources, trading opportunities and shipping space in the cargoships. I think I prefer the 4-player game over the other alternatives, and would say that the 3-player game is the least interesting. The buildings and the strategies associated with them will be better or worse depending on number of players. Turn order will also become more of an issue with more players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b]Puerto Rico[/b] [i]Andreas Seyfarth 2002[/i] 
A true gem that was Boardgamegeek number one for more than three years and it is still very well consolidated in the top five. It is indeed a superb design, very easy to explain but rather deep and hard to master. It works like a swiss watch and has mechanics that have been inherited by many other excellent games like San Juan, Twilight Imperium 3 or Race for the Galaxy. Turn order and newbies can affect the game but when all the players have equal level playing it is a fantastic experience. An eurogamer´s dream, and now with its deluxe edition that looks amazing (although it is a bit too pricey) this is one of the best options in the market and a must have in any gamers collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Wow, what a disappointment for such a high rated game. Between the sleepy theme and the lack of character interaction I can't fathom why anyone would play this more than a handful of times. I'm so happy that I got my copy free. If you revel in a no (or next to no) luck, all strategy game with no (or next to no) player interaction game that has a considerable setup time to boot, then come on down and play some Puerto Rico.

I'd much rather go to Puerto Rico than play this game. My trips there have been a blast, this game... not so.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The mechanics of this game are great.  I have the anniversary edition, which I think is worth it for 60 bucks, not for 90 or whatever the MSRP is.

It is best when playing where everyone knows what they are doing, as every choice that someone makes has a pretty big impact on someone else.  So an unknowing player can definitely gift wrap things for the player to their left pretty easily without realizing it.  I do think this is less of a problem than most people thing though, as the trick is to be able to profit from everyone's choices - you might not be the best shipper, or builder, but you can get something done no matter which one people choose.  

This is another game that I have made the mistake of thinking that non-gamers will grasp easily, and it's not.  They can fight through it, but usually it's better to start with something else a little lighter.  Plus, it's a game that definitely rewards good play, and a new player will get hammered, particularly if they aren't used to any sort of game in this genre.

In terms of gameplay, I think it moves along well, and seldom do I see people pouring over a choice.  It is done in 90 minutes, as it states, even if you aren't being a taskmaster about people moving along.  I think it's best with 4-5, but you certainly increase the likelihood of getting screwed, or someone just making a bad play.  3 people is probably the best number to play to see who is the best at this game.

Bottom line - I think it is completely deserving of it's lofty place on the rankings and think it should stay there for a long time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first play of PR was somewhat under protest but it was another player's turn to choose the game and I couldn't say anything. I see now why this dusty, old-Euro is a BGG perennial that is only spoken about in the most reverent tones and I'm kind of kicking myself for not trying it sooner. 

PROS
-Length of the game is much shorter than I expected. What little down time existed was due to people being unfamiliar with the building tiles and what they allowed you to do.
-PR keeps everyone involved by the simple fact that if someone takes an action, everyone can take that action.
-Solid player interaction beyond just tile denial. The finite market, the trader, the boats, and the action selection all play a role in making timing and being aware of other players' boards crucial!
-Several ways to rush the end game.

CONS
-It is dreary and boring to look at. Perhaps that anniversary edition would make this better.
-It's a perfect information game, like chess, so there is a perfect move in every situation and, if you don't take it, a more experienced player will beat you.
-CR said that, in his experience and what he's read, the player who is able to buy more of the big bonus tiles will win the game. Don't know if that is true but I won the game and had one or two more than the other players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
2-5 giocatori
90-150 minuti
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
GREAT GAME
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Decent mechanics, when taken in the abstract. Because it has so many piece limited items, Puerto Rico has exceptionally common kingmaker actions, especially when played with three players. This means that the winner is more often determined by their ability to manipulate the other players than their own game choices. Most likely you'll either love or hate that Diplomacy like aspect of the game. The omnipresent piece limitations also mean that many of the paths to victory will be foreclosed to many players, making execution more important than planning. I feel the game end arrives too unpredictably, others think this is a feature. The largest mechanical fault is that a few buildings are poorly balanced, apparently just for the sake of clean progressions of numbers. Some of the setup is fiddly too (e.g. counting out large piles of counters). If the people I've played with are any indication, the first turn is "solved" so you can save five minutes by distributing those resources as soon as the first player is chosen.

I usually don't put too much stock in themes, but in this case the theme actively works against the mechanics. Players are punished for building sustainable colonies, but rewarded for colonies that peak early, even if they are likely to collapse. This cognitive dissonance often causes new players to do poorly, and I've found that the best advice for newbies is to pointedly ignore the names and other theme elements, and pretend the game is completely abstract like Blokus. I may be old-fashioned, but I think an important (the most important?) function for a theme is to make the game accessible to new players. When the theme makes the game harder to play the game should have been left abstract. I also find the short-sighted thinking Puerto Rico encourages annoying, and don't like games that teach this self-destructive personal trait; however, much of that is inherent in the colonization theme - an inherently long-term business. With a different theme (or no theme), the mechanics might not feel like they reward short-sightedness.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A deep nearly luck free game.  A little too intense for most casual games, but not in the same depth league as go and chess.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
OK! Nyelvfüggetlen. Nincsenek kártyák

The best part of this game is the fact that there is no randomness, none at all.  All gameplay is based on the players decisions, nothing is left to chance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Well-crafted game that initially rated a 9 for me.  The growth of the individual colonies makes for a constructive, friendly atmosphere, yet the player interaction is rich and challenging.  I knocked the rating down to an 8 because I've burnt out on the game, and am reluctant to play it these days.  Heavy play reveals the building choices to be more restricted than they should be, with several of the buildings rarely or never built by veteran players.  The solution is to incorporate some of the more useful buildings from the expansion (but avoid the gamebreakers Union Hall and Forest House).  My other criticism of Puerto Rico is that an experienced player will obliterate a table of new players, making the game demoralizing for the novices and un-fun for the veteran.  For this problem there is no real solution other than playing with those of equal experience or perhaps trying out goofy strategies when playing with less experienced players; try to keep things very lighthearted in these situations.

RATING: 6
If your face turns red with anger over failed dice rolls, a game like PR is the way to go. I find, however, that a complete elimination of luck has also killed an element of surprise that adds to the fun of boardgames. Don't get me wrong, dice scare me just as much as the next gamer, but this game seems to be missing something and that is what I can come up with.

Still...7 is a fantastic score. Great game. The roles are fabulous, the number of choices is very exciting. This game is actually rather new to me, however, and as I play it more, I expect my opinion of it to grow rather than wane.

12/2009: I think I was wrong. My opinion is staying the same. I just don't know how I feel about a game where you are sometimes trying to decide which actions you need to avoid because it will give the players after you a distinct advantage. Big problem when playing with people that concentrate solely on what they are trying to accomplish. It is just too frustrating to watch people choose 'Craftsman' when the player to their left will score so many points if they do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[JAN 09] [Rating: 9]
I think this game deserves its high praise it has been given on this site as I keep coming back to this game from time to time. Even if there are only two main strategies in the game (buildings and shipping), there are almost endless possibilities to tweak them. The interaction in the game is indirect, but very apparent through the role selection (which is used in a very good way in this game). There is very little randomness to the game, but still the games play out very differently and you have to adjust your strategy to the decisions other player makes.

I rather play this game with casual players than with experienced players that complain about that the inexperienced player helped the player to the left. The criticism of the game is valid, but it is not fun playing with moaning players. It’s only a game.

The game plays well with any number of players I have played with, which is three, four and five players.

RATING: 8.2
Really, really good game. One that I failed miserably at, but I can tell that the game has a lot of secrets to unlock and great replayability. Plus, the player interaction is surprisingly high for a euro, so where you ship and what you trade (and when) really determines what other players can (and cannot) do. Especially in a five player game. I really enjoyed this one and I think it could rise further upon subsequent plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Seven plays. The positives are obvious: there's lots to think about and in between games you can try to work out your strategy for next time. On the negative side, I don't care for heavy perfect-information games where everything can be mapped out and the game is only about processing information. I like there to be some little bit of surprise or the unexpected in games, and I don't mean blind randomness...I mean situations when temperament has some bearing on play, when you don't necessarily know how your opponents are going to react. Also, the attitude of the other players makes a huge impact on how fun the experience is for me; playing with intense people who get bent out of shape if someone makes a bad move is not my idea of a good time. All in all, the good things and the bad things average out to a rating of seven and a half. 

By the way, I really like Thi Nguyen's comments on the game: "No soul, no guts...just analysis, analysis, analysis. Don't get me wrong, I love me my look-ahead. But games like Go, games like El Grande, there's openness, there's wildness, there's maneuvering room."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of the first more "euro" of the euro games that I played/owned. I like the level of complexity that the play offers - it being complex enough to allow for relatively oblique strategies, but simple enough that you can analyze another players situation/moves without it taking forever. A very strategic, fun, and easy game. The only thing that counts against it in my mind are the thematic elements, which appear dry and unimportant therefore almost rendering this a game of "white bits" and "yellow bits" instead of "sugar" and "corn".

RATING: 8
2004 acquisition.  First heard of the game after I discovered BBG.  Have read the rules and now waiting for the right time to introduce it to my better half.

7 years on in 2011, we played our first game!

We've only been playing 2-player games so far.  The rules are of moderate complexity but once you've played it, the game makes sense.  There's a fair bit of screwage, for example when you pick the captain role when the opponent can't ship and thus the goods have to be wasted.  Personally, this is a better game than Agricola due to the fact that the Mrs likes it much better than Agricola and so the chance of it hitting the table is infinitely higher!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Who needs San Juan when there is Puerto Rico? The only downfall is that the building tiles consist of text only (unlike some homemade sets or San Juan which got beautiful graphics). I don't like the "game ends" rules which end the game very abruptely when it gets going. Furthermore I consider variable turn order as an important balancing feature (see Caylus, Age of Steam, Agricola), PR is static to the turn order which makes it prone to be abused by experienced players. Sorry that I had to downrate this game continuarly (it started with an 8) and also because it seems that there are two dominant victory strategies (shipping and building). Even more, there are too many unthematic restrictions by the rules. It's hard to understand for me why this average game was for years on top of BGG.

RATING: 8
Played 20+  I like it best with 4 or 5 players. My appreciation of Puerto Rico has varied over time. It took me half a dozen games to get into it during this phase I would rate the game a 7. The game then fascinated me for the next half dozen plays where my interest peaked at a 10. I am now down the other side of the enjoyment curve; I do not enjoy the mood of play with everyone frustrated when another player does not make the play they had counted on them making. This is a heavy weight, 90 minute strategy game, my ideal category of game. The main reason this game now holds up in my rating is because it is easy to find experience willing players. If the gaming community put the same efforts into Amen Re, Taj Mahal and Princes of Florence these games would push ahead of Puerto Rico in my estimation. May 04

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I like the role selection.  It gives you great options to hose over other players.  For example, you can find yourself in a great position where you are the only one to benefit from your selection, plus you get your bonus.  It's also interesting to try and synergize your building and plantation selections.

The art is a little bland and the chits seem thin compared to standards of current games.  Gameplay is overall dry, but has more interaction than I think it's given credit for, due to the interaction of choices on other players options.  

  It probably doesn't have the replayability of it's prime BGG competitor Agricola, due to Agri's large variety of card decks.  
Still, I almost think I enjoy Puerto slightly better.  

That being said, I prefer Galactic Emperor's implementation of role selection and as such, don't see myself ever purchasing Puerto unless on deep discount.

RATING: 9
I'm with the folks who think this game is like a fine watch - the pieces of the system work well together. And for me a well designed system is very important to a serious game. Filler games can have flaws, but an entree should be well prepared.

This is one of those games where you want to take 2 or 3 actions on your turn, but must choose only one (role).

I think this copy is first edition (2002) as shown in version choice, but not sure what's different in second edition.

Played a few times in the first few years after PR was published, but haven't played much recently. San Juan is a more practical (time/portability) choice. I do like how it is fairly straightforward to teach PR to someone who knows SJ.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Love this game. Pure strategy, no relying on card draws or dice rolls.

RATING: 8

RATING: 6
First rate after four plays: 8.5

May 8th, 2009: after five plays my rate goes up to 9. I expect it to go it even higher once I learn strategies more complex than shipping corn.

May 26th, 2009: the rating goes up to 9.5. I love how the game unfolds, when you start with a little and end up with a plantation that works like a clockwork mechanism. Best game ever?

22nd August 2009: I am updating my rates so that they would be in compliance with BGG rating scale. Rate down to 8.

21st February 2010: Got bored little bit with it. It's a good introductory game and will hit the table relatively often as friends of ours do love this title, but I myself am very far from being the biggest fan of this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I just do not see the "deep strategy" that many other seem to think is in this game.  Over the course of an average game there might be two interesting decisions to make; the rest of the time the game plays itself.  Everyone has their own board and victory-point chips are hidden, so it's extremely difficult to tell who's in the lead at any time.  For a game with limited player interactivity this is disastrous.  It turns what might be an interesting sort of race into an I-don't-care-let's-just-finish-this-damned-thing trudge.

The winner is almost always a surprise and the point spreads are always tiny, even when someone seemed to be clearly ahead or playing better than others the whole game.  It's not clear to me just why this is, but it makes the game totally unsatisfying to win.  The game ends, everyone counts their chips and buildings and whatever, and whoever wins is like, "oh... I guess I won.  Ok."  No sense of accomplishment because it's not clear why you won.

The result is a muddled, arbitrary mess.

And if you're going to whitewash a game about slavery by calling the slaves "colonists," at least represent the "colonists" with markers that aren't dark brown.  I mean come on, people!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

3-5 players

Good with 3,4

RATING: 8.1
A game that lives up to its hype.  

The role choosing mechanic works very well and the balance of choices, resources, and opportunity makes for some very interesting decisions.  A forced awareness of each other player and their goals brings this game out of multiplayer solitaire territory and creates an interactive experience that is still rare in many engine building and resource gathering games that have come since.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Another overrated game on the geek. While it´s a good game it has it´s (partly big) flaws.

After many many years, I played it again, just to recheck my older imperssions. Well, it didn't change. My main concern is, that you don't play the game, but the game plays you. There's just not as much influence and strategic choices as people say. On your turn, let's say you got 3 remaining role cards and around 80% of the time, the best choice is immediately given. You rarely need to think what's best, unless you are first and need to be aware of the other players boards, but that doesn't happen each round.
It may even happen, that you can't do anything good at all, when all the roles were used before you had the chance.

It's a good game, but nowhere near the top 10.

RATING: 9
This game is an acquired taste, but one that is oh so worth acquiring. It takes a few plays to see just how well all the different mechanics work together rather than just seeming like a themeless mishmash. Granted, theme is a place this game suffers; it feels very dry and sometimes more like an optimization exercise than shipping goods, but after several plays, my rating has increased. It is a lot more elegant than I intially gave it credit for, and the learning curve to do well is not as great as I first thought.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've got to remember to use the factory strategy more often -- it gives you bonus doubloons even when other people take the craftsman.  Also, I should always buy the Guild Hall first of all the big buildings, because it's worth a lot of points to anybody (whereas others might be worth only 4 or 5 points).  Remember that the production buildings are cheap (3 doubloons for a large indigo plant == 4 points with the Guild Hall, which are the cheapest points you can earn in the game) and plentiful (they can't run out in a 3-player game, and rarely run out with more players), so even if you don't have the production buildings when you buy the Guild Hall, you can obtain them quickly enough.

RATING: 7
A good 'gamey game' with a stronger adherence to theme than most. Players choose strategies based on selection of crops and buildings. Resource scarcity of both of these items and also scarcity of shipping, production and trading means a careful eye has to be kept on what other players are doing. 
Can be fiddly to setup (lots of bits metered out in exact quantities).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What can I say about Puerto Rico that hasn’t been said already? For me Puerto Rico was the game that introduced me to a world of middle-to-heavy Euro Games (like many others, Carcassonne and Settlers were my entry point back into gaming). I immediately fell in love with flow of the game, the simple enough rules with complex, highly interactional results. I know that some folks have played so many games that it seems scripted, however I’m nowhere near there yet (I’m imagining that I’m likely to be somewhere in the 20-30 games range as I played a fair amount before I began logging plays here) and the game continues to reveal interesting tactical possibilities and responsive strategies. My only gripe about this game ten years after it came out is that it’s highly functional components don’t quite stack up to most games aesthetically – although I prefer a good game to a pretty one if it ever comes down to it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Oooh, so close to a 10. I've played too many people who are VERY good (I'm not). It soon becomes clear that there are certain formulaic paths that lead to victory, hardly noughts and crossses broken but just knowing that another player is making almost yawn-worthy no-choice decisions is enough to drop it to 9.
Don't be fooled by this rather critical comment though it's a supremely beautifully crafted game. It's almost as if the shine has gone off it and led to a bit of disappointment.
Buy it, play it about 30 times, try not to take it too seriously and you'll love every game. Just steer clear of mathematicians who have played it too much.

RATING: 9
[Initial impression: 9]
The design is quite brilliant. At its heart is a particularly ingenious mechanic - every player performs actions on everyone else's turn. The elegance of the game's core is diminished by having to track all the special powers associated with the different buildings and how they interact. Nonetheless, a wealth of strategic decisions and constant competition for scarce resources make for compelling and tense fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A true Strategist game!

Player pick turns on different roles. Each role gives player bonus and other players play the same role what the player chose. 

Objective of game - obtain most VP by gaining resources to ship or by obtaining buildings which gives u VP.

A brain drain game at later part of the game 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

Very strategic, a good tense design to be appreciated, but it had  its time...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
It has some neat aspects as i love RFTG i can see why Puerto Rico is his grandfather, and i can see why this one is so popular. I like this game, however it can be too long for my taste, but after all this is just my first impressions. I think the rating might go up a bit later, however im sure already this won't be my favorite game. It has cool artwork, and an average theme, im looking forward to play it more. After a few more games i think the game lacks of the needed interaction and can become boring so qickly. The game has a ton of components while the price is relativly low, but im still not sure if i like it enough to keep in my collection or it will be just a game on the shelf that will be never played again. Well the answer what only time will tell... Im surprised this game is the top6 strategy board game of all time, what? This is kind of a joke i guess, maybe my taste is so much different than the average.

Pros / Cons:
-It is a deep strategy game, where you have to think over the situations. While the rules are relatively easy to teach.
-The role selections with some bonuses are always welcome.

-The game became boring after 1 offline + 4 online plays. It was a great game when it came out, but the time ran over it. Thats all.
-The lack of interaction between the players kills the fun for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
OK, first home solo play and I remember a lot fo the good things about this game better now. First play on a friend's copy and I enjoyed it then too (though in hindsight I was probably one of those newbies who unintentionally helped the person on the right).

That said, for a role selection game there are am lot of interesting choices and it can make for a very tight game at times (49-47-42-37, on 1st home solo 4-player).

It IS susceptible to accidental king-making, but the decisions are interactive ("He's not likely to choose that, so...", or, "If I take that I'll deserve the pain it causes me, better go with the Prospector."), and the actual thinking is light enough that it's not too susceptible to AP.

Still a great game. +0.5 to 7.5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Beautiful, intricate, interractive, customizable, and plays in under 3 hours.  Pretty much my favorite game.  The only down side is that a good game needs all players to be at a competant level or else experienced players take advantage of them.  As a house rule (along with the expansions) I have reduced the cost of the University by 2.  

As an aside, I have downloaded the graphics files to add San Juan style pictures on the buildings, and added a few fan expansions to bring it up to 6 players.  I like the look of the buildings, and wish that this would have been added from the start!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I hated this game when I first was taught how to play it, as I was new to Eruos and new to the "new" generation of German-style boardgames (grew up with AH games). I didn't know what was going on, as the 'pick a role' mechanic was new to me, and got destroyed several times over. Several years later, I bought the game, read the rules, and introduced it to a new bunch of friends who were new to gaming--they loved it. So, with the right people--analytical types--this can be an effective gateway game. Over time, the nearly perfect information leads to stereotypical opening play, like chess, and the comments about weak players becoming kingmakers is true. This is an unforgiving game--with plenty of opportunity to exploit your opponents' mistakes, or have yourself screwed with--and it is difficult to realize you are losing, badly, until the end. With players of similar experience, this can be a fun game.

Update (4/05/09): upping this to a '9', after playing with five players who know how to play the game--so there was no downtime, makes for quick, snappy play.

Update (12/26/10) 16 plays: 2x plays with Expansion II buildings and nobles (no entry yet). Newest expansion adds yet even more variety, with a new mechanism through nobles. The game feels fuller with more colonists available, and nobles add interesting twists. Highly recommended expansion, and I much prefer it to Expansion I.

Update (02/10/13) 21 plays: It's frustrating to know the game is already determined by who is sitting to the left of the weakest player. I don't have the heart to play anymore, given the weakest player is the one suggesting the game--Uh, no thanks. It's a great design, but very fragile with uneven player skills, and that is its biggest flaw. Dropping the rating to a '7'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
