RATING: 7
Ein solides Strategiespiel. Ich persönlich sehe den Vorteil am Rollselection-Mechanismus vor allem darin, dass enorm wenig Downtime entsteht. Jeder ist in den Zug der anderen involviert. Auf der anderen Seite finde ich gerade diesen Mechanismus enorm anstrengend, da ich mich über eine ganze Weile nicht nur auf mein, sondern auch auf das Spiel meiner Mitspieler konzentrieren muss, um mit der Wahl meiner Aktion nicht meinen Gegnern Vorteile zu verschaffen. Darüberhinaus finde ich was neben diesem Mechanismus passiert relativ uninspiriert. Angesichts des Alters dieses Spiels muss man ihm jedoch zugute halten, dass damals weit weniger Eurogames mit derartigem Resourcenmanagement im Umlauf waren. Zusammenfassend könnte man sagen: Puerto Rico ist in Würde gealtert.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
PRO:
- challenging, fun gameplay
- introduces the concept of taking roles
- no direct player interaction, but still you have a lot of possibilities to influence your opponents
- starts off slowly, but more and more possibilities open up when the game goes on
- hidden victory points (partly)

CONTRA:
- unattractive looks (lots of text, almost no art)
- an "irrational" move by another player can ruin it for you
- some downtime when players ponder over their best possible move

VERDICT:
Slow at times, rather boring to look at, but nevertheless a game that deserves such a high rating. The competition is tense, the gameplay is fun, great game!

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
起始設定:
分數:75/100/122( 3/4/5)
田地:開出人數+1片
角色卡: 3人(拿掉2張淘金) 4人(拿掉1張淘金)
船: 3人(456) ，4人(567)，5人(678)
人:(起始拿與人數相同放拓荒船上) 3人(55) 4人(75) 5人(95)

遊戲流程:
由起始拿總督卡，選擇一名角色(擁有特權)，輪流進行執行能力，沒有選擇之角色會放置1元，總督卡等輪完一輪行動後會傳給下家。

1.拓荒者(開田): 一人選一片(特權:可以選礦場)
2.市長:每人輪流拿1個拓荒者，並重新分配(特權:從供應區再領一隻)
  領完計算全部玩家建築物的空洞補人到船上
3.建築師:建造一間建築板塊(礦場可以減免特定價錢)(特權:減免1元)
4.商人: 交易物品(只能容納一種)(特權:可以多獲得1元)
5.船長: 賣貨，每船只能容納一種，必須全賣，除非船滿，每個貨物1分。(特權:多得1分)   結束上貨後，清空運輸船，每個遊戲者只能有一個貨物。
6.淘金者:獲得1元
Call Game: 分數用完，人用完。有人建滿12格建築。

農莊:可以多拿取一片供應區面朝下的田。
小倉庫:1個加1種貨物儲存。(大倉庫:2種貨物)
商會:可以出售已有的貨物，如果貨品格被填滿無法使用。
收容所:拿田地可以直接上人
大學:拿建築物可以直接上人
港口:每次上貨多得1分
船鎢:擁有一艘私船
公會:小型生產建築物1分，大型建築物2分(不用上人也算)
官邸:計算農田數量(擁有9/10/11/12田或礦得到4/5/6/7分)
堡壘:每三個拓荒者得1分。
市政廳:每擁有1棟紫色建築多1分

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
When I played with this game for the first time I felt a bit weird, it just didn`t clicked for me, I heard a lot of good things about this game, but after the first 8-10 rounds I just didn`t get it, I asked the question from myself. This was the nr. 1 on BGG, why??

Finally, in the last rounds of the game and after the points couting I understood why this game is so great. It`s an elegant game what is quite simple to learn, but the depth of this game is huuuge. I really like it.

Puerto Rico could really use little player aids for the buildings, because there is a bunch of it and it`s hard to memorize at the first few plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favourite Euro. As a game with very little randomness all the interest lies in the interaction between the choices of player roles, with a chess-like combination of tactics and strategy required to play well. I wouldn't call it quite perfect: if I were developer I'd recommend changing the purchase prices of some buildings (I always think that Construction Hut should cost 1 Dubloon and Small Market 2, for example), and inducting new players should be done via training games as sub-optimal play introduces a chaos element that's impossible to overcome. However, this is a genuine classic that should be played for generations to come.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Suffers from being over analysed and disected by regular players, still great if all players similar experience be it high or low. Not played for a long time though.

There are more different ways to go than I originally suspected and it's possible to pivot and do different things. Whatever, you don't need me to give you an explanation of Puerto Rico, but I've been enjoying it quite a bit lately.

RATING: 9
Great game. Incredibly intelligent game design. In terms of euros this is as good as it gets, at least for me. I rate it a ten, but whether I would really choose this game over some of the wargames in this category is questionable, but I think it fills its niche perfectly, takes 90 minutes to play and provides wonderful depth and plays 3-5 players. The only problem I have with it is the blind vp, but sometime I can convince people to play with open vp.

update: I have been playing a bunch of this with the Evolver spreadsheet for excel. It is a great way to test out a few strategies.

RATING: 7.6
Lo sobrevaloré en exceso. Es un juego que se basa en un algoritmo: una vez que lo descubres, los primeros turnos se realizan de manera mecánica… hasta que alguno comete un error.  Las decisiones a tomar en cada turno son muy limitadas o muy evidentes… con la única excepción de qué construir. Eso me aburre. Reconozco sus logros en la fluidez del juego y en sus mecánicas originales (elección de roles, tableros personales y edificios que no son sino “excepciones a las reglas generales”). Sólo lo juego con gente poco jugona porque me sorprende más. Clara ventaja del cuarto jugador y de quien esté sentado a la izquierda del novato.

Una volta appreso, scorre molto bene e a fine partita è possibile valutare dove si è sbagliato, per poi imparare dai propri errori.

RATING: 5
Call me a hater but I don't like the theme of this game since I find it plain boring. The mechanics are the synonymous of the Euro-style and therefore they are too mechanical and competitive for me in an extreme Chess-like manner. I much prefer Contract-Bridge-like hidden elements interaction like in Twilight Struggle or War of the Ring. You just too simply grab things for you: want a colonist? You have them. Want a building? There is surely one for your budget. Want a plantation? No problem. Take it. Grab, grab, grab.
No sense of any epic just shipping goods to the Homeland with plenty of strategy behind. So 5 for the deep strategy and only 5 for the boredom of theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Played maybe 10 times before 1/24/08. Taught in 15 min, played in ~2 hrs for 1st time. This game has many choices & has good luck/strategy ratio. Each player begins w/ $3 & 1 indigo or corn plantation (others are: sugar, tobacco, & coffee) A player is elected governor & gets 1st choice of roles. Roles are(special ability; all action): Prospector($1; n/a), Builder(-$1 cost; buy 1 building), Trader(sell good 1st; sell unique goods for $ until all pass, cleared if full), Craftsman(extra good; produce goods for each worker plantation/building, corn requires no building), Captain(extra VP, ship goods for VPs to 1 of 3 ships going clockwise until all pass, clear full ships), Mayor(extra worker, worker distributed clockwise, refilled based on empty buildings, min # of players), & Settler(may choose quarry [-$1 building]; choose 1 plantation). After each player chooses a role & actions are taken, place $1 on remaining roles & pass governor to left. Game ends: run out of VPs, workers, or building space. Most VPs wins. Buildings produce goods(w/matching plantation), give you special actions &/or produce VPs. Strongly recommended play w/ owner or borrowed. Otherwise give purchase consideration & a place in your rotation of games to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2/10/09
-------------------------------

[i]Puerto Rico[/i] is a game about developing plantations on the island of Puerto Rico during the colonisation era, and attempting to profit by using colonists to build refineries, town buildings, and crop plantation. This game caters for 3-5 players, though there is an unofficial expansion which lets you play with 2. The game scales well for all levels of players, with there being almost no difference between the different amounts. It is not a light game, and has many routes to victory.

The main mechanism behind [i]Puerto Rico[/i] is a role selection one where each player chooses a role to taken within the colony. Everyone gets to take an action associated with that role, but the player who chose it gets a special privilege. Having chosen a role, the effect can be used to build buildings, plantations, ship goods, or other colonial actions. The aim of the game is to accumulate victory points, which you get primarily from shipping. Everything else should be towards this aim. And that is also this game’s great strength; it allows you a lot of leeway in how you go about this goal. It lets you create your own economic engine from scratch, a task that requires a lot of planning and tactical ability: strategy in order to find out what to work towards, and tactics to determine how you can take advantage of your opponents’ position. And yes, there is a great amount of player interaction in [i]Puerto Rico[/i], and much can be said for disadvantaging yourself in order to ruin someone else’s plans.

The one thing that I do not like about [i]Puerto Rico[/i] is how much you are constricted to a single strategy. If you make bad choices in the beginning, you will have to run with them for the remainder of the game. The high scarcity and short playing time ensure this. This stifles new strategies, I find, and makes it hard for newer players to know what to do and compete.

In conclusion, [i]Puerto Rico[/i] is an excellently designed game, and allows you great scope in determining your own strategy with minimal luck. The variable player scale makes it a good fit for most occasions, and the planning makes it a good brain-burner. There are no flaws I can find in the gameplay, and I have not noticed the supposed advantages of sitting near a new player, likely because my group started at the same skill level.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Multiple paths to victory
- Room for strategic planning
- Almost no luck at all
- Supports a good amount of people

[b]Cons[/b]
- Can be unforgiving
- Definite learning curve
- Very tight with regards to opportunity
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

* Note *  -this game is very difficult to rate for me. When I first bought it I thought it was the best thing since sliced bread. But, as I have now played it hundreds of times (too many) and matured in the hobby and become more knowledgable on what other games are out there it's now way down the list. It is only considered for play to introduce new gamers who are ready for a step up. So - do I rate this the 9 or 10 that it was for the first 2 years that I owned it? Or, do I rate it the lower rating that it currently is?

RATING: 5
Puerto Rico is a typical city building, farming and delivery game. The game process is performed by variable job selection. Every choices made by players influences the game dynamically. The game is ever-changing and guarantees replayablility. From the historical point of view, Puerto Rico is very controversial. Puerto Rico can hardly be free from the criticism of the biased historical viewpoint. To sum up, Puerto Rico is wonderful in game, but controversial in history.

RATING: 7.5
Ideal Players: 3-5

Description: A classic euro-game. Win by shipping goods and building your city.

Pro: Role-selection and special buildings provide incredible strategic depth. Many ways to win. Constant player interaction. Interesting enough to provide great replay value.

Con: Can be completely deterministic with experienced players. Theme pasted on neat mechanics.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the best board games I have played. Although it may seem very complicated at first, Puerto Rico becomes quite easy to play as you begin to get used to it. It is not always possible to decide beforehand which role to play and which buildings to buy, because your choices are affected by the interaction with the other players. On each turn, there are opportunities to improve your own position and often you can spoil the opposition's plans at the same time, which makes it great fun to play. Highly recommended!,

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I still can't figure out why I like this game so much. There are really only two strategies:shipping or selling. Everything else is a slight tweak of one of these two. You're also often forced a certain direction by your first few plantations or building.

All that being said, role selection is incredibly tension filled. It's not about taking the action that is objectively best for you, it is about taking the action that is best for you relative to the other players. I also love setting up an action based upon how the Governor will be moved.

Best with 3-4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This one will remain one of my favourites. I think I like it even better than Agricola (after having played both games more than a dozen times). 
The only drawback seems that sometimes the play can feel a bit mechanic, but luckily everyone in my gaming group (myself included) pulls enough "weird" or unexpected moves to keep plays away from becoming "scripted". It keeps the game fresh, even after 30 plays (from Sept. '08 until May '09). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I finally had the honour of playing this legendary game a bunch on BGA recently - and while I wanted to call the game bloated and outdated - I can't.

This is a wonderful game.  Having only played it online I feel I have gotten off easy with some of the games weaknesses as oh boy does it look fiddly and a time sink to set up and manage.  When played online however - the game takes about 10 minutes a player which is great.

Without having to worry about managing the components, the true beauty of the game really comes out.  Some buildings could probably use a couple of tweaks in balance and going 4th in a 4 player game is a slight handicap but that's about it.  There are multiple strategies to aim for, you have to always be ready to adapt to what other players are doing and you must always keep a -very- close eye on your opponents.  While high level Stone Age became a math contest very quickly on BGA - Puerto Rico looked better and better - with a brilliant mix of tactics, strategy and player interaction.

Hate to say it - but this one deserves the title of classic.

RATING: 10
Seems an interesting game from first acquaintance, but it is only after a few plays that you really begin to appreciate its depth and variety. Considering the very limited element of chance, and lack of chrome, it really is amazing the game is different every time. Add to this the flexibility (equally good with 2-5 players), moderate playing time and relatively streamlined rules and you have an excellent example of a modern board game. Although I still feel that something is lacking in Puerto Rico, and that a better game could be designed, it will remain a 10 for me until that game comes along.

RATING: 5
A classic.
Very good economic game.  It just appeals to me every time I play it.
Maybe there are better, or more innovative/complex, mechanics out there, but this one has its irresistible charm...

EDIT: A word of warning: the replayability might be an issue after some time.  You follow more or less the same lanes every time.  Two expansions alleviate the problem, but I'm not sure about their staying power.  I'll give them enough opportunities to shine, that's for sure.

EDIT2:  Yeah, after almost 20 plays I have enough.  The expansions help, but only temporarily.  Patterns and strategies repeat themselves too much from game to game.  And the tactical element is not interesting enough to compensate for it.

Sold.

EDIT3: Ugh.  After precisely 20 plays I have no desire to play it ever again  The replayability is thoroughly exhausted (even with expansions).
PR, thank you for nice moments, but it's time to move on.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
8.1 / 2-5p Best 4 / Overall 9 / Strategy 10 / 90-150m / 3.29 (Engine Building)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
Why I took so long to pick this up, damn! This still plays great as a 2 player, we're currently playing 2 boards each and using the lower score of the 2 to determine winner. Playing with the official Alea variant is very very good but be sure to use a 3/2 role selection so the same player can't go twice in a row. 

Strategies/tactics are very much based on timing and you need to adapt throughout the game depending on what else is happening. Very enthralling, much much better than San Juan IMO, I prefer the depth and don't mind 10 minutes of set-up time, I also prefer the longer more detailed game. The replay value is huge and I see a ton of games being played in the near future. I wish all rule books could be written this well with examples, I had but one question after reading. This could be the one that finally takes over DOA for me, I don't think so but we'll see...

[u]UPDATE:[/u] Before 3 more plays we realized that the University was no good and bought the expansion because it was so cheap. Glad we did, balances the building selection out great now with a few small changes overall that improves the game a fair amount. See my comments in expansion...  

[u]EXPANSION UPDATE:[/u] The new Puerto Rico expansion in Alea's treasure box was pretty nifty, some of it was quite good, some I think was too strong. Tweaking might be needed but overall I would like this as it adds one more solid path to take albeit maybe too strong as mentioned. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Not sure how as an almost entirely euro guy it took me this long (almost 250 other games first) to try this game. It's a solid game, and I can definitely see the Race for the Galaxy connection. It seems to be mostly a game about figuring out what actions your opponents will take and how to be most ready for that, and also a game about tempo. And I can see how it would be really weird with players of very different skill levels, moreso than most games. Certain buildings definitely seem stronger than others but I think that's okay since they're in a common offer. I don't think I have any particular complaint about the game other than it felt a little familiar, and that's certainly not the game's fault. But for whatever reason it just didn't much excite me. definitely a solid game and I'd like to try it again, I could see the rating going up.

RATING: 8
I love this game, don't get me wrong, but the more I play it with "gamers" the more I'm soured on playing it with them. Games can tend to be overanalyzed which can suck the life right out it. It's a game though, not brain surgery, don't take this so seriously! Yes, the moves do sometimes seem scripted as the best choice is sometimes obvious but that depends on if you react correctly to what is thrown your way. Try the online version, it plays in under an hour or the Excel verison where you can play a solitaire game in 10 minutes. Anyway this is a great game which I'd happily give a 10 rating if only it wasn't taken so seriously by so many. After all, you're supposed to play the game, not let the game play you. So, as a game, in and of itself, I'd rate it a 10 but played with over-analyzers I have to give it a lowly 4.

RATING: 8
Friend Owned
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great. A worthy game for the innovative turn-sequence system alone - and there's more. The game also combines the "multiple paths to victory" as in Princes of Florence, and the "break normal game rules" aspect of some CCGs (or Cosmic Encounter, Ursuppe/Urland etc.) in the form of purple building functions. (And yes, the buildings can be very powerful.) And yet the balance between the various game elements (building costs etc.) seems to be just right, so that there is no single obvious winning strategy (at least it seems so) nor elements which become useless because they're too weak. A most excellent, finely-crafted game. Perhaps the best of 2002, my bet for DSP winner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Like Agricola, the strength of this game is that even the weakest players feel a sense of accomplishment throughout the game, even if playing against a veteran. That really opens up the crowd I can play this with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
3.3
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Some thoughts so far after limited plays:

1) You can not be able to load any resources on a ship during the captain phase if you are far down the turn order or if the ships are full of the goods you have etc, and of course and unshipped goods go back to the general supply if you don't have a warehouse(s)

2) When gathering resources there can be none left of the finite supply by the time it's your turn to collect them, especially if those resources are still sitting on a half full ship.

3) It's easy to get locked out of trading resources unless you buy the office tile, and even then still locked out due to turn order and/or how many goods are already on the trade ship

4) If several players go for shipping, whoever doesn't has an advantage, the same applies to trading. As part of these two strategies, if there is a clash of one type of good, that can leave other players unchallenged.

5) A player who makes a bad decision can give the next player an advantage.

The game is all about tactically choosing an action that benefits you while benefiting other players as little as possible AND/OR setting up future turns. 

The important thing to remember is that being denied the ability to ship any goods when someone else chooses to ship is part of the game. The same goes for any other form of denail that the role selection throws up. This makes the game a lot more negative to it's very core than other euros, however this denial is too much for me in 5player.

I gnerally don't go for tactical games or negative games, so this is one that i struggle to enjoy.

Edit: This game is much much better as a 3 player, the issues mentioned are much more managable (previous plays were 5 player!).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Puerto Rico is a classic game.  I always feel a craving to play again.  You accumulate plantations that provide crops to buy buildings that provide useful abilities.  The goal is to get the most points via shipping crops and building buildings.  There are multiple paths to victory.  Every turn you choose a role that provides you a bonus but every gets to benefit (like getting to buy a building but the builder gets an extra discount).  My understanding is that once you play enough times it starts becoming scripted but I'm far from that point.  This game has a lot of replay potential!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A masterpiece.

RATING: 9
One of our first euros.   Play 2 player variant.  Very competitive games, always fun and requires thought.  A classic.  Giving it nine stars because I'm not sure I've seen the full potential of this game with 2 players.  On 8/14/16 reintroduced playing 2p variant.  3/2 Governor phase.  3 ships less one good, 3 trades, 2 offices, no construction hut, 5 quarries.  Excellent.  Tight games.

Starting to explore different playing strategies. I usually lose to my son, but a quarry building strategy seemed to catch him by surprise ca win for me.  Just a great game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Puerto Rico has a reputation as a classic, but it's just not a game enjoy that much.

The main reason is that it's a game that doesn't scale well across experience levels. I've only really enjoyed the game when I've played with people who have about the same familiarity with it as I have. Any other time I've played, I either destroy new players or get clobbered by veterans. This mostly has to do with the lack of variety in game setup - an element of randomness that most modern Euro games include.

I'm not going to get into the debate about whether or not the theme (namely the use of "colonists") is a serious problem with the game because the theme isn't anything worth defending to me (there are plenty of games about agriculture, so this theme isn't anything special). At the same time, it's not the reason I may choose not to join a game of Puerto Rico - if I don't, it's actually because a lack of variety that leads to predictable results.

RATING: 9

This game brings a different kind of fun, trying different strategies, outguessing your opponents, and hopefully being the one ending in front at the end.

Different strategies possible
Good game lenth (2h and less)
Great player indirect-interaction

A game that will always have a place on the table.

RATING: 3
I have two primary problems with this game.  First, the well-documented "left of the newbie" problem is something I have a hard time forgiving. My second problem is that I almost invariably make a major blunder during the game, which I recognize about 30 seconds after I make it.  The last time I played this game (in July 2006), I won, but only because my friends gave me a mulligan on my blunder.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A friend took a chance on purchasing this game after I suggested it might be a fun one to try. I'm glad he did - we've gotten a lot of play out of it. The online version allows play in time slots and places where the tabletop version would be impractical, but it's still satisfying to move all those little bits around when we can.

Just got this to the table for the first time in a long while... I'd nearly forgotten how fun this one is! After growing accustomed to Agricola and Power Grid (and even Settlers), this one has surprisingly little down time. The decisions are fairly straightforward while still containing a significant amount of depth, and since everyone gets to do something on each turn it rarely feels like you're waiting around. Great game!

RATING: 5.5
2011-08-21

Initial Rating: 7.0 (May 2010)

Puerto Rico is a good economic game, no doubt about that. Still I think it is overrated (at the time of writing this, it is number 2 in the ratings) as there are many games I would choose over this one.

I love the tactics (role selection) and strategies (buildings) the game offers, also it has little luck which makes it very attractive for me. 

On the bad side it isn´t fun to play with people of different skill level which lead to unintentional kingmaking and the theme is awful (I would have never played this for the theme, I´m glad I was introduced to it by a friend)

Current Rating: 7.0

2012-09-10

I´m sure I will play it again but, for now, I’m adjusting the rating so it matches my new feeling toward the game. In all truth, the game NEVER really catch my attention and almost never I had fun playing it.

RATING: 8
The first Euro that I was "exposed" to. OK, I probably exposed myself to it but that's beside the point. Used as a base for a class assignment which asked us to design a board game. Basically, I re-themed Puerto Rico. Had been looking for it ever since (2005), but didn't really know where to get it in the country at that time. Got it now and managed to play a number of games. It's quite a thinky game, with many ways to win (apparently). I seem to use the factory/building strategy most of the time, though. Like wine, this game gets better with time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.7
Excellent, excellent game. Make sure you know that the people you are about to introduce it to are ready for it, though. It's about 20-25 minutes to properly explain, and then 2.5-3 hours to play that first game. It's definitely worth it. I played it once with a 13-year old girl whose favorite game is Life. She played the mechanics just fine, but I'm sure she was missing the strategy of it all. It's at least playable by non-gamers, though.

Multiple paths to victory. I don't think role selection is always an obvious choice. Which building to build next is an important, though tough decision.

Second only to Magic: The Gathering, in my book.

RATING: 9
A classic game that still holds it's own today. The only reason it's not a 10 is because the person sitting to your right can make or break your game. RATING: 9
A great deal of fun but I've found that I have a lot less fun with inexperienced players involved. 

The game moves along at a decent pace when everyone has played before..otherwise it drags as everyone insists on reading every single building card even after having already read it three of four times. 

There are a great many strategys that can be used and many interesting and tough decisions to be made as you go. You also have to be clever and adapt your strategy at the drop of a hat when someone snags up that one building that was key to your strategy.

The game is not nearly as complex as it may appear , nor as dry. It has been a real favorite.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
One of the games that should reside in every games collection (along with all of the other alea titles).

Even though I have a hard time winning this game, I will never turn down a chance to play. The fact that is scales so well for different numbers is a plus too.

There are three reasons why my rating is not higher:

1. There is NO direct player interaction. Sure, what you do will affect the other players in some way, but you cannot trade resources or money with others... why?  This would shorten the game considerably.

2. It seems to be too easy for two players to 'gang up' on a third and force a 'kingmaker' situation.  This is very common in three player games.

3. It is very prone to over analyzing, so the game length can reach 2 hours or more... a little long for most Euros.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Seems a bit dry. I've had a few games where its fun, but the last couple have been down right boring.

RATING: N/A
[b][url=http://www.spieldesjahres.de/cms/front_content.php?idcat=8]2002 Spiel des Jahres Nominee[/url][/b]

[thing=108687][/thing]

The players are plantation owners in the days when ships had sails. By growing up to five different kind of crops – corn, indigo, sugar, tobacco, and coffee – they try to run their business more efficiently than their close competitors: growing crops and storing them efficiently, developing San Juan with useful buildings, deploying their colonists to best effect, selling crops at the right time, and, most importantly, shipping their goods back to Europe for maximum benefit.

Players: 2, 3, 4, 5
Time: 90−150 min
Mechanics: [property=2079][/property]
References: [url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B3571nngkAIHeXJSYXlMVU5teEk]Rulebook[/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vOA2pplBvvQ]Video[/url]

[u]Expansions[/u]		
[floatleft][center][geekurl=/thing/12382]New Buildings[/geekurl][/center][geekurl=/thing/12382][IMG]http://cf.geekdo-images.com/images/pic981318_mt.jpg[/IMG][/geekurl][/floatleft][floatleft][center][geekurl=/thing/159761]The Nobles[/geekurl][/center][geekurl=/thing/159761][IMG]http://cf.geekdo-images.com/images/pic981317_mt.jpg[/IMG][/geekurl][/floatleft]

RATING: 6.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a well-made game.  There are a lot of rules, but just about all of them are very intuitive.  If you like economic games at all, this will be a hit.  It mixes near-determinism with an inability to compute the precise outcome too far ahead of time, because the decisions of other players change the game dramatically.  

One flaw is that it works poorly when one player doesn't really care that much and is just along for the ride.  Decisions they make substantially affect the other players, and a player not trying to act in their own rational self-interest messes up the balance.  Who they effect will not be random or averaged out in the end, but will depend heavily on the seating arrangement. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This will always be the gold standard, in my mind.  My group played the socks off Puerto Rico, and then I logged hundreds of games on BSW.  That was then.  Now?  A classic case of burnout.  I feel compelled to drop my rating from 10 to 9, because it hasn't hit the table in three years!

UPDATE-  I gave PR another try, years after I wrote these initial comments.  I've changed my mind about the game.  I think Race for the Galaxy, perhaps my favorite game, has caused me to re-evaluate PR.  I like the role selection, the privilleges, and the scarcity of the different building types.  Perhaps I've matured as a gamer, or I'm just more willing to deal with a eurogame now, but I'm looking forward to playing PR again soon.

RATING: 10
Puerto Rico is everything a game should be: rich in strategy, dynamic interaction, meaningful decisions every turn, rewards advanced planning, deep gameplay balanced with a simple ruleset, multiple paths to victory, virtually no luck/randomness involved, and doesn't take all night. It is a beautiful, elegant game that is instantly addictive and appeals to a wide audience. A masterpiece in every respect.

RATING: 2
While this was one of the first "Euros" that I played when I started seriously boardgaming a few years ago, I hadn't played it in some time.  
I had to lower my rating, as I was not quite as impressed by some of the aspects of the game that had been new and intriguing when I had not played many modern boardgames.
After playing Thurn & Taxis, I saw a much better use of roles (and one that didn't allow for the same crippling of people who went later in a turn), and had to lower PR's score.  After playing Endeavor, I can honestly say that I have no desire to play PR again, so PR's score went down again.

We need a "Hall of Fame" for landmark games like this whose time has passed.

So, jetzt hab ich es endlich auch mal gespielt und bin nicht entäuscht, allerdings kommt es für mich nicht an Caylus heran. Grundsätzlich ist es genau so gut, sicherlich, allerdings hat der Spielmechanismus eine kleine Schwäche, man ist als Spieler nicht gegen "Klüngelei" geschützt. Durch die Reihenfolge der Spieler bedingt kann man leider an "Zusammenspieler" geraten gegen die man nicht gewinnen kann :( wenn sie es clever anstellen! Wenn die Gegner geschickt am Tisch sitzen, dann ist man ausgeliefert. Dies ist bei Caylus nicht bzw. nur schwer möglich da die Spielerreihenfolge mit jeder Spielrunde wechselt. Aber trotzdem muss ich natürlich neun Sterne verteilen. Was sonst?

[u]METRICS THAT DON'T NECESSARILY AFFECT OVERALL RATING[/u]:
Weight: (Very light) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Very Heavy)
Conflict: (No Conflict) :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Lots of Conflict)
Luck v. Strategy: (Luck-Heavy) :star::star::star::star::nostar: (Purely Strategy)
Theme: (Abstract) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Lots of Theme)
Interaction: (Little Interaction) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Lots of Interaction)
Learning Curve: (Easy to learn) :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: (Hard to learn)

[u]METRICS THAT MAY AFFECT OVERALL RATING[/u]:
Component Quality: (Cheapish bits) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Awesome bits)
Fun Factor: (I think it's no fun) :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: (I think it's LOTS of fun)
Value for the Money: (A waste) :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: (Worth it)

RATING: N/A
artur / dacio / igor
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Tras unas cuantas partidas empecé a ver el valor real de este juego.

Tienes tu isla, donde puedes producir distintos tipos de productos. Para esto necesitarás materia prima (café, tabaco,...) en tu isla y, después de la cosecha, puedes transformarla en productos reales.

Si realmente quieres producir y transformar tus materias primas, necesitarás algunos edificios en tu tablero. Esto es muy importante, sin edificios no puedes producir barriles de materiales procesados.

Hay dos tipos de edificios: edificios de producción (blanco, azul, marrón, negro) y edificios violetas. Los edificios de producción están centrados en procesar materiales y los edificios violetas están enfocados a ayudar a los jugadores a ganar dinero o puntos.

Los edificios y las plantaciones necesitan gente para funcionar. Un edificio o una plantación vacía no funciona y su poder no se aplica. Cuando obtienes tus barriles los puedes cambiar por puntos o dinero.

La mecánica del juego es simple, un jugador elige un rol (acción) y cada jugador hace la misma acción. El jugador que eligió el rol además consigue un privilegio. En cada ronda todos los jugadores eligen un rol.

Mi opinión: éste es un juego muy bueno. La primera vez que jugué no lo entendí, y no lo consideré un juego que pudiera pertenecer al TOP10 de la BGG. Unas cuantas partidas después, empecé a ver su potencial, puedes hacer más de lo que piensas en la fase de selección de roles.
[color=green]
LAST PLAY: 2011
[/color][color=blue]
After a few plays I started to see the real value of this game.

You have your island where you can produce diferent kinds of products. For this you will need raw material (coffee, tobacco,...) in your island and, after you harvest it, you can turn it into real products.

If you really want to produce and transform your raw material, you will need some buildings on your board. This is very important, without buildings you can't produce barrels of processed materials.

There are two types of buildings: production buildings (white, blue, brown, black) and purple buildings. Production buildings are focussed on processing materials and purple buildings are focussed on helping the players to earn more money or points.

Buildings and plantations need people to work. An empty building or plantation is not working and its power can't be applied. When you get your barrels you can trade them for points or money.

The game mechanic is simple, one player take a role (action) and every player plays the same action. The player who took that role aditionally gets a privilege. Each round every player takes a role.

My opinion: this is a very good game. First time I played it I didn´t understand it, and I didn´t consider it a BGG TOP10 game. A few games after, I started to see its power, you can do more than you think in the role selection phase.[/color]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

WIFE RATING/Comments - 7
My very first euro.

UPDATE:

In recent years I have grown tired of economic snowball games, of the mechanical interaction and resource maximization that are hallmarks of them. Puerto Rico is the progenitor of these Euros and while I'd never call into question its design, I am no longer interested in it.

UPDATE: 11.7.10 

My wife finally won a game of PR beating me in a 2 player session 80-56.

Traded for Die Macher and Primordial Soup.

RATING: 6
First game was a disaster....After struggling with the arcane rules, the myriad mysterious tiles and all those funny little brown things  my family began laughing at me and the game, and then gave up and  left me to clean up. . But after more play I turned them around and they now enjoy the game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My #2 all-time favorite (Die Macher is still #1), PR is easily the best new game of the past five years and also the best game playable in under two hours.  The elegant role mechanism is its most unique design concept, meshing with the fact roles not selected in a turn become more attractive the next turn.  Each game, the player is faced with a series of tough decisions, the obvious ones being what role to select and what to build, but even smaller ones such as how to allocate colonists, what plantation to take, which goods to ship, which ship to use, which goods to keep and which goods to warehouse, all these can have a big effect later in the game.  Having an overall strategy is nice, but you need to be flexible and watch what your opponents are doing, too, as it is primarily tactics that decide the outcome among good players.  Knowing when in the midgame to convert from income generation to points generation is critical, as is the endgame (i.e. accurately predicting how the game is going to end and being prepared for it.)  The only random elements are player seating and the plantation draws, yet each game of Puerto Rico is different.  Andreas Seyfarth is a genius for creating this wonderful design, whose elegantly simple mechanics drive a deeply strategic and cerebral game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.6
Very nice game mechanism.  The role choice which allows all players the action is inspired, as is the increasing the value of the unselected roles.  Good scope for both strategic and tactical play without being too complicated.  Offers new ideas and variety on each playing.  Excellent theme.  Crucially, PR includes money as a commodity, which I regard as a design shortcoming - the truly great designs bypass the need for money - Settlers and San Juan are two of the best examples.  Verdict:  I would not rate it the very best game out there but I can see why many would - certainly in the top group of games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The classic role selection game.  It's imperative to make moves that advance your cause, while assisting your opponents the least.  Although this is not considered at two-player game, I find it fantastic at two.  It is also great at three.  I would not play it with more than three.

The draw back to Puerto Rico is the set up time.  Playing it on an iPad solves that dilemma, while cutting playing time in half.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A marvel.

Puerto Rico strives for the ideal of non-random, no-luck play where the variability emerges almost entirely from players' actions. Each decision you make is a wave that other players are trying to catch. Each wave that comes your way is designed to flatten you. The game is smooth, fast, accessible, deep, complex, and variable, and it makes it all look easy. Few games can live up to it.
 
Rated a 10 a year and a half after first discovering it (12/24/08). 

[April 2010] Rating downgraded to a 9. Doesn't have quite the same breadth of options I look for in my absolute favorites, but that's about all I could say against it. Still great. 

[September 2010] Puerto Rico has been falling in my esteem lately, if only slightly. The thing is, after 40 plays I just don't see the kind of even viability (balance) across all the buildings. There are a full handful of buildings that don't seem to pull their weight, and though this may vary situationally, it seems generally true. The Large Market, Office, University, and Large Warehouse all seem like sucker plays too much of the time. The Hospice is borderline. I love the overall design of the game but the building set just doesn't seem to allow players the freedom of approach that it promises. This has sent Puerto Rico from a top 5 position to the back end of my top 20. A great game, but perhaps with an Achilles Heal.

It's an extremely cleverly designed game, and many aspects of it (though it is not the first) will be classic economic boardgame fare for years to come: e.g. variable phase order through player roles, conversion of money into VP, multiple paths to victory, etc.

This is in my top ten games.  An all time classic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not game #1 for me but being #1 on the Geek 8 years after its release certainly is enough proof of lasting goodness. The unique point is that even after this long time there are no big numbers of me-too-products like El Grande or Caylus have produced. The role selection and tight gameplay still feel fresh and good play needs concentration on various dimensions like strategic planning, efficient engine building, timing of roles and control of the game end.
Compared to today's (2010) eurogames it shines in its comparably streamlined rules creating a fluent gameplay without much downtime. Agricola is fiddly as hell in comparison. Too much love for chrome and aimless complexity today. Troyes anybody? That being said, Puerto Rico is a design that I respect rather than admire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
original shrink

UPDATE: Con cada partida le veo una pega más. Tiene una excesiva dependencia del orden de juego. He reducido la puntuación a 8, pero podría bajar más.

UPDATE: La dependencia del orden de juego cada vez me resulta más molesta.

RATING: 9
This is one of those games that get better the more times you play with the same people.  There is very little luck, but more outmaneuvering other players.  You have to understand what other players are going for, and what you can do to counter it.  Sometime you have to decide between doing what helps yourself the most, and what helps other people the least.  The depth of strategy is very satisfying, and the fact that many people claim there's an *unbeatable* strategy (each different from the other)  there's an oppurtunity to try out different things each game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Awesome game that involves maintaining a settlement on Puerto Rico. You and others will compete for resources, colonists, plantations, goods and other things in your question to build the best settlement. The turn mechanic is simply brilliant and extremely intuitive. The player whose turn it is will select a role they wish to take. Every player will take that role, but the person whose turn it is will get a bonus. Extremely interesting game, with little to no luck involved. Takes 2-3 hours, but is very fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
The absolutely darling of my game group, which is why I don&#039;t end up going to the gaming sessions as much as I should. It gets a 3 only because it represents my introduction into German board games. Otherwise, we are talking about another major yawner of a game. To its credit, it has excellent player interaction and strategy, but once again the theme is an absolute joke. Who wants to play a game that takes more mental preparation than taking a written examination? It&#039;s plain from their board games that the Germans eschew violence - so why don&#039;t they do something right up their alley, and produce tastefully erotic sex themed games rather than snoozers like Puerto Rico? Guys, gaming is supposed to be fun, not a nerdfest or braniac convention.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My initial review of this game was horrible. I still think [b]it's a rulebook game[/b]: if you don't have a few plays under your belt or you're an excellent listener with a fantastic teacher, you don't stand a chance and end up producing nothing. 

On the other hand, after understanding the system this game is [b]purely brilliant[/b]. I can see why it was #1 for the longest time. Though it may look as everyone starts relatively equally, the positioning of each player effects their role completely. No special rules for each player, just positioning. That's amazing in itself. The mechanic of having mostly everyone participate in a player's turn is marvelous. It's been done in Twilight Imperium 3, but Puerto Rico's method is [b]far more simple and engaging[/b].

The [b]strategy is compellingly deep yet simple enough - actually quite similar to chess.[/b] There are multiple ways to win and most of the time, you are doing your best to isolate the market instead of directly screwing over someone else. This makes it [b]generally a more friendly game[/b] compared to some of it's rivals (like Caylus where moving the Provost can really hurt other players).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One of the best games ever -- really!  My initial feelings in reading about the mechanics and the game system were not good.  I figured this to be one of those stupid, clumsy cut-sey games.

But I bought it because of the rave reviews here.  Thank God!  Great game!  Great system!  I'd rate it a 10 if I knew what a real 10 was -- but this has got to be as close as it gets.

RATING: 9
A game where the dynamics change so rapidly, both on a tactical level from role choice to role choice, and on a strategic level from the early rounds and on up to the endgame.  PR requires a lot of analysis and it can be easy to miss something or to get stuck on accomplishing some minor feat that one misses the big picture.  Because of this and the fact that poor plays can swing things for everyone else, it can seem intimidating to play against self- proclaimed "experts".  But the loud ones are usually not quite as expert as they think they are.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Was good until I realized there is a strict strategy you have to follow in the opening sequence or else you're pretty much going to lose. Seems to be best played by a group of equal experience levels. Whoever sits next to the newbie usually gets the advantage.
In the beginning, cash is king, prioritize it over everything else.
Buy the harbour.
Don't manufacture the same good as the player ahead of you in turn order, but do try to manufacture the same good as the player after you in turn order.

*EDIT: Is it fair to rate these classic games for what is it now or what it once was? Back then it would've been a solid 8..

I feel this game could have been released this year and still be in the top 10.

RATING: 8
In many great Euros, the key to success is "do what others aren't doing". In Puerto Rico, however, you have to time your actions such that you don't lose too many actions on other players' turns, but also that they lose efficiency during your turn. This game of denial is why this game is still heralded 15 years later.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A great strategy game. Very little luck based on a tile flip mechanic. However very difficulty to not only teach but play with people of different skill levels as 'ignorant' plays can completely destroy another's game inadvertently.

RATING: 6
Played once and my experience was not a good one.  I found the theme and gameplay boring.  I really didn't care if I chose to plant more grain or buy a warehouse.  There are few mechanics that I don't like in games but I don't enjoy the mechanic of picking a role/choosing an action and then having everyone benefit from it (also found in Eminent Domain).  This game also felt like the game was fairly unforgiving; those who fell behind early had no chance to catch up.  I'd play this again and certainly I would be interested to see the components improvement in the anniversary addition but it certainly isn't anywhere near the top of my playlist.

RATING: 10
A fantastic game, one with apparently endless replay value.  One concern is that there is a strong "player order" effect, so the game really works best with all players of the same skill level; a poor player can destabilize the game.  For all of its components, the game is surprisingly simple and accessible; can be pretty much internalized by the end of the first turn.  One of the best I've ever played.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.3
For the fun:time ratio, I'll always choose San Juan over this. San Juan offers far more dynamic play whereas Puerto Rico seems to be more predictable—every game the same. But I do still enjoy playing.

Edit: After having played again years later, the reasons I've been avoiding pulling Puerto Rico off the shelf have become clearer. 

Everything you do in Puerto Rico needs some extra component to activate it. Just bought a sugar field? Want to produce some sugar? Too bad! You have to wait several more turns to set things up just right so that this simple outcome can be achieved.

Compounding this is the loss of goods when another player decides to ship. You put hard work and many turns into getting a field, building a factory to match, populating both with colonists, and finally producing something... only to have the final product evaporate. It's very demotivating. And how the hell does my [i]inorganic[/i] supply of indigo go bad because a guy down the street decides to ship some barrels of corn, anyway?

For the whole game, you just feel roadblocked and pinched in a way that doesn't make for a fun time.

Try [thing=8217][/thing]. It's got phases and similar artwork, but the feeling you get from playing is completely different.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

~ Will play this game on BoardGameArena!

RATING: 7
I was impressed with this one.  Not a pretty game, and it looked terribly dry, so I wasn't itching to try it, despite it being a classic for 15 years now; I tended to avoid it. In the end, I got roped into a game of this and had quite a good time with this one.  Didn't expect that!  :-)  The whole using slaves part of the game feels pretty icky, though... and I would have rated it higher if it didn't have that.

RATING: 7
The game itself is a 7 but I'd rate it a 3 because of its players. Puerto Rico is entertainment and there are not enough "casual" PR players. PR simply isn't strong enough to carry the burden so called "serious" players want it to carry. Recrimination starts immediately and is continuous. PR, though a good game, breaks under this intensity. When victory is the piece de resistance, you have to look to real life endeavors as few games can suffice. Those that do are probably two player and abstract games with brilliant handicapping systems or between peers.

RATING: 8.6
This was the first "gamer" game that I owned. It's a great game that really excited the euro game type.

Puerto Rico can be a little rough for very new gamers as it's possible for a poor play to benefit the following player. Familiarization with the various buildings also gives an advantage to experienced players, though that's common in many games.

Although I don't play this enough to own it anymore, it's still a great game that I'd be happy to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Update April 2014.  I haven't played this in a while and I think it would be tough to play again due to having to relearn how to play well.  Good game, but too difficult to play well with people who don't play it frequently.

Updated September 2008 after a few more plays.  This game is great once you get over the learning curve.  Each action is important, and you must develop the ability to see how your actions will impact the other players.  Once you do that, the game opens up and you can see why it's one of the top board games.

Easy rules, tough strategy.  Great multi-player game.  It can be frustrating though if you're the least experienced player in a game where everyone else is very experienced.  There's a tough learning curve for the strategies and in determining how you're moves will impact the other players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Seemingly complex game that has more strategy than luck once you actually get into it. A lot of challenge and fun for everyone.

RATING: 7.5
A really great game, deserving of its spot of honor at the top of the BGG rankings along with Agricola and the others.  The design is obviously genius, with so many elements blended so perfectly with the simplicity of role selection.  You have to use your privileges gained from role selection very wisely to get ahead in this game.  Also, the violet buildings can be game breakers and are difficult for newbies to fully grasp the first time around.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lives up to the hype.
Though the player interaction wasn't direct, the role choice they made indirectly and immediately affect you.

So many routes to victory, and luck factor kept to a low.  Buildings can become scarce quickly, so weighing options on buying early or increasing capcity creates high tension.  As crops get planted, do you want to grow what your opponent has, making it harder to sell at market, but perhaps more likely to ship when needed?  Do you adjust by buying a building that lets you sell the additional resource at market or buy warehouses that lets you stock the goods up, buying you time to strike when opportunity arises?

Should I grow the free crop and ship them away for victory points, or grow the expensive crops and make some $$$ and buy buildings?

Oh no, I've built too many crops and buildings and don't have people to man them...should I take the mayor role to get more people, or take the role that has a ton of bribes on it?  What would the trade-off be...can't decide, can't decide; brain aneurism!

Wow this game blows my mind.

I've seen complaints that the gameplay dilutes down to the same strategy after repeated play...I'll see.  My only real complaint for now is the setup.
===
5/16/07 Dropping score.  Enjoyed it on the PC, but so much setup/cleanup in real life detracts from pulling it out.

RATING: 9
Simply put: a very good game, with heaps of agonising choices and optimisation. Takes a longish time to set up, but the actual game length isn't too long, especially when players have some experience. There is virtually no downtime anyway, as every player choice usually involves all the other players. I do like the theme and atmosphere as well.

RATING: 8
It's a brilliant design that suffers from one rather minor flaw (factory and university should have switched costs), but otherwise it deserves a high place. Yet I traded it away. Why? Because 

a) Too many fiddly bits, especially the colonists
b) Requires a lot of thought-power to invest in the game
c) Not easy to teach to impatient people wanting to start the game already.

It was never going to get played. So trade list it went.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
:star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star:  (50 plays August 2014)
I wish I rate this game as 11 or higher if I could. This is the best worker placement game. One player choosing everyone doing the same action is just mind blowing mechanic. The depth of economical and strategic decision making process is tremendous within this game too. I have the anniversary edition with gold coins and that makes the game even more immersive. I have introduced this game to new gamers many times and quite often I see they order a copy immediately after the game ends. That is how existing and fun this game is.

RATING: 9
It was the second Euro game (after Carcassonne) I tried and it blew my mind and is largely a reason why I started to get interested in board games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great game.
I love the skill involved and the various stategies and the weighing up what other players tactics are and how to react to them.
It's a nice short game - about 90 minutes and it keeps all players fully involved throughout. (There's none of this being knocked out)
Another great thing is you are always doing something - not sat arounmd waiting for your turn - it is always your turn and you are always deciding what is the best thiung to do compared to other players.
The game is very different but equally good with 3 , 4 ot 5 players.
My only criticism is I expect that the game will tire after a number of plays with players having their own view on the best strategy and with no chance elements involved the game will become repetitive - but then loads of games are like that.
Highly recommend.

Quality rating: 9
Willingness to play rating: 6
Fun rating: 5

The biggest difference yet between quality and fun. This game is well made and has lots of elements, but doesn't play out as smoothly as it should.
Fun, when you're not impossibly behind and short of money.

W/F average: 5.5
Final average: 7.25

RATING: 7
I love that everyone gets an action no matter who the governor is. It's a little annoying that the game has been so analyzed and I have so little willpower that I have read and re-read strategy guides to this without much opportunity to play, rather than discovering myself through trial and error what does and doesn't work. The CURL online game is a good environment for practicing against AI opponents. My main weakness is that I am not flexible in my strategies, and once the one I have chosen looks thwarted, I drift aimlessly through the rest of the game, not being skilled enough yet to change direction or to accurately anticipate opponents' decisions.

RATING: 6
An enjoyable, if not spectacular game, that was innovative at the time of its original release (2002) but has lost much of its luster (at least for me). The role selection aspect has now been copied many times – sometimes with better results – but the game mechanics rely in large part on everyone making the right decisions at the right time. Although kingmaking potential is present in many games, it can often be the unintentional result of another players bad decision which could quickly destroy your best laid plans.

RATING: 10
Excellent game and one of my all time favorites!  Quality bits and artwork.  Plays best with 4, imo.  It is a bit of a stretch for non-gamers, but possible if they are bright, genuinely committed to learning it, and ok with the fact they're only going to score 12 points on their first go.  Endgame suffers only minimal analysis paralysis and scores are almost always close among experienced players.  This was my first "next level" game after Settlers and it will always be in my main rotation.  If you're a fan of German-style board games at all and you don't own PR, stop reading, go to your local shop, buy it, add friends and enjoy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tense, cutthroat, interactive build-your-engine. Brilliant game with an intelligent, economic design. 

This is euro gaming at its best but hardly a multiplayer solitaire experience. You need to be on your toes or you get hosed by the other players. At the same time, you can follow a strategy and have the satisfying engine building feel. Brilliantly balanced. A classic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Puerto Rico is a very solid game with lots of breadth complexity as well as tons of indirect interaction in between players. While not without flaws, it's both balanced and deep.

Lots of people complain about the seating order problems, and not without reason: its the game's greatest flaw, by a long shot. There is a super strong right/left binding, which in turn also makes certain interactions mechanical ("do that or X, who is seated to your left, wins").

The game is also based on snowball economies: all players are effectively competing to create the most efficient plantation. Thankfully, there are multitude of ways of affecting your opponent's plans, which makes the game engaging, deep and fun.

The game would have been a solid 10 for me if not for the seating order problems: I usually don't mind kingmaking, but for it to not be an issue most players need to be able to affect the situation in one way or another. In Puerto Rico you can find yourself seating at the other side of the table, powerless to do anything, while someone gives the game away.

Yet even despite this, it's an 8: the rest of the structure is extremely solid and deep.

Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:4~5
:thumbsdown:2~3

[i]For more information on how I rate games, [geekurl=/user/Kodeir]go to my profile[/geekurl][/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
In some forum post about some other game, I saw someone describe PR thusly, "about as exciting as watching paint dry." That might be giving it too much credit. For me (and apparently, save for one, my whole gaming group*) there is no intellectual, emotional, or competitive payoff. I am willing to say I just don't get the fascination. I don't question whether the people who love it have good taste in games, but I have trouble understanding how it could be considered a top 5 game, and carry a rating of 8+. That just seems excessive.

*And he defends it with about as much gusto as Avon Barksdale defends Stringer Bell

RATING: 6
[size=12][b]Top 200 board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I like Puerto Rico:[/b][/size]
+ I like the pure variable phase order mechanic.
+ There is high player involvement.
+ The game is easy to teach.
+ The duration is decent.
+ The game requires meaningful decisions to win the game. 
+ There is the right amount of decisions to make.

[size=12][b]Fixable dislikes in regards to Puerto Rico:[/b][/size] 
/ The game seems to have bad replayability. There seems to be no variance in set-up. I would like the game more if some buildings were cycled with the active buildings. Fortunately some of the expansions for the game seem to address this problem.

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Puerto Rico:[/b][/size] 
- I dislike the slave theme
- I ought to try San Juan / Race for the Galaxy before rating this game higher or keeping the rating the same.

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Sometimes willing to play this game[/size]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I confess.  I absolutely cannot stand playing this bloody thing, and so I've continued dropping my rating following repeated plays.  It is not the theme (I enjoy Goa, Cuba, and other such colonizing/spice trading games).  It is not the role selection mechanic (I enjoy Citadels, San Juan, Cuba, and Race for the Galaxy, which also have role selection).  It is not the fact that it is a resource management game (most, or at least, many Euros have an RM component).  It basically boils down to two things -- do I ever want to play again?  No.  Could I be talked into it?  Maybe *once* more, before declaring that it is a 2, once and for all.  (EDIT: I have done so).

The main thing for me is that you *have* to play with other newbies your first game, or it breaks -- playing with a mixed group in this game, because of the left-right binding issues and how much (over)analysis has been done on it ensures that veterans will argue the whole game over who is being benefited by the newbie, and trying to coerce the newbie into taking moves favorable to them.  Also, a game in which you must know what all the buildings do in advance to *enjoy* the game is irritating...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very nice, neat and fun game!

I'm not too certain if this strategie will work again. i would say the replay factor of this game is very high because of the different ways to get VP.

RATING: 6
Elegant, clever, challenging, fun, spans age and personal backgrounds... Everything I look for in a game. It's amazing the number of diverse people I'm able to introduce this game to. I'm also amazed at how much I can play in a row without burnout. I'm still not sure if it's completely balanced (the harbor and wharf are ALMOST a game breaker) but yet overcoming these seemingly unbalanced features became a game unto itself. When everyone is aware of the same 'unbalances' it balances back out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I know that you are supposed to love this game but to be honest it is one I prefer not to play. I simply think it is quite boring and not at all interesting.

The game does not have any particular flaws, it is just not a good game. If I should try to pinpoint where it fails, however, there are two points I would like to make:

1.	There are too little surprises
   - There is almost no interaction between the players.
   - There is almost no random element.

2.	It is messy and overworked.
   - Too many roles (I guess the designer didn%u2019t want to limit the number of players).
   - Too many different tasks (shipping, immigrants, trading etc) as a result of there being too many roles.
   - Too many different buildings.

I get the impresion that the game designer wanted to make a strategy game and thus left dice and cards out. That would have worked if this were a game where the players interact more with each other. When you remove both interaction and randomness it starts to get predictable and simply boring.

Maybe this was the reason for the game being overworked. They had to add some complexity to prevent each game from being played in the same way.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The return of Puerto Rico to BSW prompted me to revisit this game after a couple of years of not playing.  I noticed some things that made me decide to drop my rating.

I realized that more often than I would like, near the end of the game, the system forces a player into a kingmaker position.  This is unacceptable in a modern game.  It is possible that no matter how you've played up to that point, you will win or lose based on this person's whim or his personal kingmaker philosophy.  They may not even be aware of these consequences, but they are no less given the power to determine the game outcome.

The other games, however, can be fun puzzles of trying to optimize your moves and predict other players' actions.  If only you knew what type of game it was going to be when you sat down to play.  At least it only takes 15-20 minutes on BSW.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Had this for a long time, and it's never let me down. The mechanics are great, strategy is key, and the luck factor is almost non-existent. Nearly all my friends enjoy this game because it's easy to play and the winner is the person who played best, not who was luckiest.

The only real downsides are that without the expansion(s), the same buildings are available every game, which sometimes leads to experienced players adopting an identical strategy every game. Also, the University and the Large Warehouse are often considered to be too expensive to be worth buying.

RATING: 8.4
The fact that you can see (and soon buy) all the buildings from the beginning is both good and bad. It makes it possible to plan a long term strategy but it also makes it harder for beginners and causes some AP. I still don't know how to win. Overall, it's a solid eurogame, but not the most fun IMO because you have many tight restrictions on what you can trade and ship. A lot of the buildings you can buy are just there to get rid of these restrictions. I prefer a bit more freedom.
I didn't actually like Puerto Rico the first time I played but second time was more enjoyable.

RATING: 6
I'm not a fan of "multiplayer-solitaire" games. I hated St. Petersburg, but fortunately Puerto Rico is little bit better - still there should be more direct interactions between players. Now all you need to do is to focus this "common pool" (=What role should I choose? If I choose this it means that I get this, but then the next player might do that... etc.) and all the rest is to build your own game in your own board. 

If there are 4-5 players the game takes too much time, with three fast players this is an okay game. Definitely a game, which is better when played via computer, because the game is faster.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In Puerto Rico players assume the roles of colonial governors on the island of Puerto Rico. The aim of the game is to amass victory points by shipping goods to Europe or by constructing buildings.

Each player uses a separate small board with spaces for city buildings, plantations, and resources. Shared between the players are three ships, a trading house, and a supply of resources and doubloons.

The resource cycle of the game is that players grow crops which they exchange for points or doubloons. Doubloons can then be used to buy buildings, which allow players to produce more crops or give them other abilities. Buildings and plantations do not work unless they are manned by colonists.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[2007.Jun.11] I wondered for a long time what all the fuss was about over this game. No game can be that good... can it? Finally, I got a chance to play it, and after only one game, I was hooked (but I've played it many times since). I am thrilled with depth of the game—there is no single way to win the game. Additionally, there is a wonderful subtly in attempting to select the most appropriate role when it is your turn to do so. This is not a light game by any means, but it is also not the heaviest game out there. If I could make one suggestion to a anyone interested in trying Puerto Rico for the first time, it would be: Play the San Juan card game first! I did, and understanding the concept of choosing different roles as well as tracking how each building affects your own game was invaluable. Learning Puerto Rico, after having played San Juan, was extremely easy. Once you learn it, you will be sure to love it; everyone that I know does. If you have not already done so, add it to your own game collection. I'll see you on the island of Puerto Rico, just please don't ship my coffee.

:star::star::star::star::star:

RATING: 9
The archetype of the limited player interaction, each building his own board type of game.  With roles ala Citadels, you get smooth play, nice strategy and friendly fun everytime.  Probably the most well rounded, best put together game around.  On the downside, there is somewhat of a learning curve and playing with experienced players can turn off new players.  A bad player sitting next to you can also tip the balance one way or another, depending on side.  Over the years, this has decreased in appeal to me because lots of great new game don't have the same "flaws".

RATING: 4
Clever-clever design that opened my eyes to the possibilities of euro games when I first played it years ago.  I like the flow of the game and the indirect ways you can harsh your opponent's mellow, forcing him to discard resources or make sub-obtimal builds.

However, to me there isn't enough to keep the game from getting repetitive on repeated plays, so it's not something I would want to play that often.

Too, there are some parts of the game that I find dull and procedural -- for instance, having to wait for colonists to man your fields and buildings.  I'd be very interested in looking at "San Juan", which seems to streamline the game and keep most of the things I like about Puerto Rico while losing some things I don't.  (Update:  played "San Juan", liked that one even less.)

RATING: 7
Pros:

+ The turns are fast.

+ A fine euro.

Cons:

- I did not get the right seat/buildings (part of it might be experience, but my long term investment goes preferably towards go): I felt like I was in a trap: that was not fun. (Basically I was not able to do much with my specialty [Indigo] because the player just before me did the same thing, and with a warehouse (?) to stock it, on top of this.)

- On top of this, you do not know clearly who is just in front of you in points, so I could not even have the meaningful goal of trying to pass him.

- Lack of much social interaction.

Overall: a fine euro where one can be stuck and feel powerless, with not even a small "sub-goal" to fight for (like beating the opponent just in front of you), and littl interaction.

RATING: 10
One of my all-time favorites and the one which introduced me to Euros. Love the mechanic of choosing roles and being greatly affected by the decisions others make on their turns. This one has probably seen the most play in my gaming group over the years and for good reason.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
amazing game...one of my favs. a must have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Waited a while to enjoy this game, and it is a marvellous game. There's not been too much talk about this game (though it is very highly rated), but it is a relatively old euro so it's probably because the newer games like Agricola and Caverna dominate the talks. Even though the first time I played the rules were screwed up on almost every turn, I still had a lot of fun playing it. It doesn't play that long, because everyone only has one action a turn, so it flies by quick. It's also quite possibly the most strategic game I've played, you have to think multiple plays ahead of you at a time, and it combines with being very competitive as everyone's moves are similar to yours (which, compared to other euro games like Agricola where you can just relax and do your own thing, means you basically have to out-strategize your opponents to win). This game is probably not going to be for everyone, but I love this game, even with the mishandling of the rules. It's just great to play a game where you're almost always going to win because you completely outplayed and outsmarted your opponents, something that you don't get in a lot of other games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The rules can be understood at the first time. You have to know what the roles are, what buildings are there and what they do, and keep a close eye on the handling of the roles. The first time I played it, I thought it was far from clear what was now a good tactic. But after a few times the good depth and the excellent balance of the game become clear. It is not a game that you 'just start playing' within fifteen minutes, but it is absolutely worth it to start. Special if you like Eurogames.
I think the game is diverse and well balanced. You are also constantly busy with something. After a few games, the two main tactics quickly become clear: whether you go for a large production of cheap products so you can gather glory points in the role of captain, or you go for the expensive products, to sell them for a lot of money and thereby building expensive buildings that generate many fame points. You also get more and more insight into how you can bother your opponents. Whichever tactic you choose: it turns out that the points are never very far apart at the end. The few times we played, we ended up with around thirty-five points, with the difference between the highest and lowest score being five
Good stuff with wooden raw materials and settlers, and thick cardboard game boards, plantations and buildings. The whole looks colorful and of good quality.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One of the first games to add to my collection, and still one of the best.  Perhaps nostalgia causes me to cling to a high rating after all this time; however, it's still a wonderfully brilliant euro game.  Elegance in design.
