=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
El juego de juegos, un clásico, el número uno de la lista  BGG y por tanto en las preferencias de muchos jugadores de juegos de tablero. Una compra IMPRESCINDIBLE para engrosar la ludoteca ideal de cualquier aficionado al género.
Un juego que asienta sus bases en la gestión de recursos y la construcción de edificios mientras se asumen diferentes roles (capitán, constructor, colono...) en el Puerto Rico posterior a la conquista del Nuevo Mundo.
Un juego que lo tiene todo: una alta adictividad, mucha rejugabilidad y una profundidad y diversificación estratégica como pocos en la que radica la grandeza de este magnífico juego; y es que Puerto Rico puede jugarse de diferentes formas, tomando distintos caminos y alternativas que te llevarán a la victoria, al tiempo que permite poner trabas y bloquar la estrategia del rival... y él a ti.
Si bien pueden jugar hasta 5 personas, para poder disfrutar de una gran experiencia a PR personalmente recomiendo partidas con 2 (un auténtico duelo) y 3 jugadores.
Inconvenientes a Puerto Rico: No es un juego para toda la familia ya que requiere cierta dedicación,y quizá su duración y el relativo esfuerzo en la comprensión de las reglas de juego puedan echar atrás a jugadores ocasionales, pero una vez se comprenden las normas y se está inmerso en una partida de este fascinante juego estos tres factores quedan relegados en favor de una gran experiencia de juego. El juego de los jugadores. ¿Qué más se puede pedir?

IMPORTANTE
Una buena estrategia general para cualquier partida podría ser esta:
1: Diversificación en materias primas añade posibilidades en las fases de Mercader y Capitán, además de ser una estupenda combinación con los edificios de 2.
2: Es importante tener siempre un almacén a tu disposición; si es grande te puede permitir hacer bloqueos navales con más facilidad y si es pequeño puedes combinarlo con alguno de los edificios de 3.
3: Un muelle propio o el edificio de "+1 PV al enviar mercancías" pueden combinarse muy bien con los almacenes.
4: "Vender mercancía repetida" combinado con "+1" o/y "+2" doblones por venta es una combinación genial/fatal si está en tus manos o en las del rival (no hay que dejar que esto ocurra), pero puede paliarse con la "fábrica". 
5: Es preferible comprar edificios violetas "grandes" que más favorezcan al rival antes que te favorezcan a ti, ya que de todas maneras te otorgan 4 PV al comprarlos y generalmente la ventaja que otorgan es relativamente baja.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
We're probably one of the last people to the party, but we finally got a copy of [thing=3076][/thing] in the last B&N sale.  We're big fans of Puerto Rico's children games ([thing=8217][/thing] and [thing=28143][/thing]), but we never had a chance to try the original.  Although we heard some mixed things about the two-player game, we found that the official variant was actually pretty good---it felt a lot like two-player San Juan or Race so it was easy to just dive right in.  It didn't feel like a variant at all.  In fact, we felt that the ability to take two roles per turn helped to make the game feel more strategic.  

However, I can start to see some faults in the game for us.  The lack of randomness seems like it will lend itself to scripted game play (we're already settling into a couple of the same strategies each game).  Plus, the lack of randomness can make the game pretty unforgiving and "mean"---in one game, I was able to lock up both ships and my wife had to throw away all of her goods.  After that, she was basically out of the game.  While we like this type of game, I think that the role selection mechanism is more suited to the cardplay of San Juan and Race (and maybe [thing=19857][/thing]?), since the randomness requires more creative play and is more forgiving to players.  

Still, it's a game worth trying for just two---it really is an elegant game and it's wonderful how each action interlocks with each other to make something more than the sum of its parts.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
A tedious facsimile of fun, this heavily stodgy hard-core Euro would later lend its role-driven mechanics to the (arguably!) more successful "Race for the Galaxy" franchise. Given the widespread availability of Tom Lehmann's finest moment, I hardly understand the impetus to suffer through this, its outdated, outmoded, and fairly inferior ancestor. A fail on all accounts. (Gods, how I am bored by this one!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Revised from 8 up to 9.

(Comment on second game) A four year gap between games.  I realise now how elegant the game is with the interaction between each element.  The relationships of the cards have a clear logic and the flavour of them provide a coherant driving force to gameplay.  My development of warehouse plus harbour and increasingly taking the captain in the latter parts of the game provided a strong coherant strategy but also provided a believable narrative to the game and my game experience.

Though each player has their own version of the island due to the variety of options none are the same.  A Puerto Rico multiverse.

It is incredible how within a few simple mechanisms you not only have the framework for an excellent and competitive game but a context for a realistic and rich environment.  A tour de force.  

(Comment on first game) With a bit of patience maybe some coaching from experienced players you will realise the subltety, the flavour and the contrasts and see that Puerto Rico flourishes into a fine wine (or maybe more appropriately a very strong coffee). . . yes a very strong argument can be made for making it the finest blend.

RATING: 9
My first game was 2-players with my significant other and it was fabulous. One thing is I regretted not learning this game earlier. It was really easy to learn and teach, especially when you're more familiar with the medium-heavier weight games. Also, we know Race to the Galaxy so we understood the roles easily. In 2-player the game was pretty easy-going. We just did things according to our pace so we really enjoyed the experience. In my second game, it was a 5-player game. I was worried that it would take too long to play, but that was not a problem at all as everyone got to do something as a role gets taken during every person's turn. We cheered when someone took a role that helped us and we jeered when someone selfishly took a role that only helped themselves. Either way, we had a really fun game and my only concern is whether this game will become stale over time especially after you've discovered most or all possible tactics or strategies. 

I still prefer Agricola to this. But this is a very, very close second as of now . :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A truly brilliant design that I have a great deal of respect and even admiration for.  Unfortunately, that brilliance doesn't make a connection with me when I'm actually playing it.  I think the fact that good play depends on heavy calculation of variations, combined with potentially plan-shattering multi-player chaos just doesn't work well for me.  On a more tangible level, the level of play that this game has received, unforeseeable during the design process, has shown that there is not just a hierarchy among the buildings, but actually a rather distinct hierarchy, to the point where being shut out of two of the "big three" (factory, harbour and wharf) makes winning extremely difficult, and it only takes a mistake or two to get into that position, while, conversely, taking one of a few other buildings (office, university, large warehouse, perhaps the hospice) is rarely, if ever, a quality play.  On a related note, for some reason the constraints on the number of copies of each building that are available in a game feel glaringly artificial and inelegant amid the rest of this design.  Still, despite these comments focusing on the negative parts of my perception, I do play this game willingly when asked, and once in a blue moon on my own initiative.  Also, my feeling that my criticisms are highly particular to me does not only arise because this is the number one rated game on BGG :)

UPDATE: have now played this face-to-face, and it was quite fun.  It seems I'm more immune to flying bits than I thought I'd be.  If, after another couple non-online plays, the fun stays the same, this may get bumped back up to an 8.

UPDATE: okay, it's up to a 7.5. I'm just not likely to suggest it, since there several other games in this category that I greatly prefer (PoF, Goa, T&E), so it's not a full 8, but it's more fun than a 7, which feels like a half-hearted recommendation.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
2004, from Orc Nest.
(played the two players variant)
After sitting in the dust for more than one year, this gem finally get on to our table. It was hard for me to learn the rule before i can explain to my wife. And the functions of each characters and the building can be quite daunting to a new learner. 
So, i spent a lot of time studying the rules. And when i explained the rule to my wife, she looked scared!

However, when we started to play it, it was a blast!!! We started to pick things up, and learn it. It is not that difficult as it looks like!

A very enjoyable game. We like it.
Initial rating is 9, but, it might jump up to 10.

Updated: A truly 10. My wife asked to play it everynight. After every game, we talked about the strategy, and what we will do in the next game. We can never have enough in this game.

RATING: 6.5
While using solid mechanisms in good combination to each other (I like the variable turn order), this game lacks a nice artwork or theme. In other games I am a Knight, an Alien, a Soldier or a hero. Here I am a wooden cube in different colors. 
For being in my top games it needs much more interaction between the players und more options in the mid and late game especially. Sometimes it seems like you don't have any choices to make in a round and the game starts playing you rather than the other way around...And that is the point where you can wait and see you winning or losing without really having the power to controll that.

RATING: 10
Oh, my god! This game is awesome! First, I am form Puerto Rico and love that there is a great game out there named after my birthplace. Second, I really liked the logic of the design of it. In the first rounds (years) the sequence of the roles is very similar because the players don't have the resources or buildings yet but as the game progresses and the players build and produce, the mechanics change more to the strategy involved in making your city more successful than the other players'. I really love this game. I see ourselves playing it for years to come.

RATING: 8.5
I've wavered on this game in the past, but recently I think it hit home.  I really liked this game.  No auction involved, but lots of dynamic play due to the nature by which the roles are drawn by the players.  The adding of money to the unused cards is interesting.  Very well thought out, but a lot of little rules.  Whenever I've had a break from it, we tend to forget a rule that we discover later.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really like this game and the decision-making involved, but it has a hint of dryness that knocks it down a bit for me.  With that said, I think this game is a must-have for any serious or even quasi-serious gamer.

UPDATE:  The more I've played Puerto Rico, the more I enjoy it.  I have gotten better at the game, and this has increased my enjoyment because I understand what I am doing.  It is one thing to recognize depth in a game, and another to truly understand it.  I feel like I am beginning to understand PR's depth and this makes it all the more fascinating.  Consequently, the game is less "dry" and a lot more fun.

Upping my rating to a "9," from an "8."

UPDATE:  This is a game that stands the test of time.  A classic.  Far better than most games around it in the BGG ratings.

RATING: 7
A 10-year classic, still a decent game.  I have found with repeated play that if, by luck of turn order and plantation tiles available to you, your strategy follows down the shipping goods path, your actions are automatic and boring.  Even if it ends up being the winning strategy.  One game all I ever did was alternate Captain and Craftsman on my turn, everyone at the table knew what I was doing, and I still managed to win.  I could have written down on a napkin the decision tree and had the napkin play for me the rest of the game and win.  Meh.  Disappointing.  TTFN.

RATING: 7
I never liked this game as much as other people, and I finally figured out why. There is a culture of hardcore PR players who always seem to know exactly what the best move is. I am not one of those people. Hardcore players, I've found, usually fall into two groups: the ones who constantly tell you what role to take; and ones who are visibly upset when you don't choose the 'right' role. Both of these types COMPLETELY RUIN THE GAME for casual players. This won't change and I predict the PR backlash will only grow as these people act more and more asinine. If you are one of those types, please take note and stop ruining other people's fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
When I first encountered PR, loved it. Now, I agree with a BGG user who put it on their Geeklist of "Games of Diminishing Returns" (in terms of enjoyment). It has been analyzed to death, and one needs to study-up on it to play anymore - like learning opening moves in Chess.  Keeping an eye on everyone's player board to see who is leading is also a minus for me.  And, in line with THE great controversy on BGG, I'm not happy with games that involve slavery, minus any consequences to strategies that employ slavery (i.e., no uprisings, revolts, loss of victory points or other such reprecussions). I find San Juan the card game to bring much more bang for the buck with the "develop colonial Puerto Rico" theme.

All that being said, I do understand it to be a very good game, and I do enjoy it still.

NOV. 09 Update: Over time I'm finding I enjoy this game as an occasional game, perhaps a few times a year, much more than I did when first introduced to it.

RATING: 9
One of the best games ever designed.  It is a really brilliant role selection game.  It has a simple economic system and relatively simple rules.  I view this as the perfect transition from family game to more serious Thematic or Euro game.  It has depth although it does now suffer a bit from optimization and experienced players can be very difficult to beat.

Overall, it is a excellent game and I would always play it if offered.  I have played this with the family and even relatively younger children (8 year or so) can understand the game.

RATING: 6
PR is a good game seemingly full of options and with essentially no luck.  The only drawbacks I've found are that the setup can be a bit of a pain and there can be a bit of a learning curve for new players. Otherwise, it plays well with any number of players 3 to 5 and plays as well online as it does face to face.  I am starting to feel that PR could be played out--there is a sort of sameness to it now.  Still, it's a great game to discover with other new players and learn the strategies on your own.

RATING: 3
Originally rated this game higher, but dropped it's rating to a 5.  I've found that games that do not rely on any luck at all often rely on the interaction of players to determine the outcome (naturally).  The problem here is that one bad player can give someone such an advantage that it doesn't matter what strategy the other players use, whoever sits in the beneficial spot related to the poor player (usually to his left) will win regardless.  I've decided that I'd rather have risk managment decide my games rather than a poor player.

Dropped the score even more (from a 5 to a 3), as I realized I basically never want to play it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
PR seems to be an elegant, balanced, game that requires careful thought with every turn.  Lack of art work/graphics on the buildings is disappointing, but the game's mechanics are well designed.  

Each person picking a role makes it very interesting, and studying how your choice will benefit you vs. the other players is very interesting.

While the overall strategy after only 2 plays seems building vs. production/shipping (or combination of the two), there seems to be many ways to get there - and you might have to change as each turn you don't know what the others will do to force an adjustment to your plans.

RATING: 9.5
Superb game! Rules are not so hard a new player can't jump in, but the game is rich and strategic enough for heavier gamers to really enjoy it as well. Settlers got me interested in boardgames, but Puerto Rico really got me *hooked*! (Update: bumped to a 9.5, hard to see turning a game down, it gets even better with time and with stronger players)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Warning: rating exclusively based on online (BSW) play. A great game; maybe a little bit on the dry side, but elegant, brilliant design, with almost no downtime and a lot of decisions to be made. Replayability is extremely high; after  70+ games, I still want to play it. Two minor quibbles: most of the decisions are tactical (short term) in nature, and a mistake by one player can give a huge advantage to someone else, thus leading to a "kingmaker" problem (but this is next to impossible to avoid in multiplayer games). If you're looking for a light, fast game which can be played in under an hour while still giving a satisfying experience, look no further.
UPDATE: over 100 online plays now, almost exclusively with basic set, and I still love to play. Rating up from 8.5 to 9. Definitely great.

RATING: 9
A good skill game with not a huge amount of luck involved. Sometimes you get lucky with timing and who needs to play cards at times that benefit you, but often you can see that coming and work it to your advantage.  As a result, games with good players are usually quite close to the very end, and I really enjoy that.  Similar to Agricola in some ways, but I enjoy it more

RATING: 9.5
Not sure if it actually is the first of it's kind, but IMO this is the king of all worker placement games.  It's the game that introduced me to the worker placement game mechanic and it plays brilliantly.  It's so deep and so excellent.  Slightly a little less fun for me now since I've played this game a couple hundred times most likely - all online or iOS - still dying to play this game live with a group, but haven't yet.  I have the board game version but sadly never even opened it. But there are some great digital AI versions out there that have kept me happy for years.  Understanding and playing this game also really helped me understand and play other games - Race for the Galaxy for one.  I never really understood RftG until I really comprehended the whole worker placement and role picking strategy element. Once that clicked for me it opened another whole world of games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It's obvious why this game held the top rating for so long.  The turns involve players selecting roles.  Everyone gets to take part in each selected role, but the selecting player gets a special bonus.  Unused roles get coin added to them to make them more attractive the next round.  It's really an ingenious and very fun system that leaves room for a lot of strategy.

RATING: N/A
The players are plantation owners in Puerto Rico in the days when ships had sails. Growing up to five different kind of crops—corn, indigo, sugar, tobacco, and coffee—they must try to run their business more efficiently than their close competitors: growing crops and storing them efficiently, developing San Juan with useful buildings, deploying their colonists to best effect, selling crops at the right time, and, most importantly, shipping their goods back to Europe for maximum benefit.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Puerto Rico is a tough one to rate.  It really is a great game and fun to play.  Much easier to get into than today's 'medium-heavy' euros because it doesn't try to throw a handful of different mechanisms together, but still offers multiple strategies that are fun to explore.  However, it just doesn't get pulled out very often any more.  I have a handful of role selection games that I jump to first, such as Race for the Galaxy & Eminent Domain.  I don't see it ever leaving my collection, but it's not the first game I look to pull off the shelf when wanting to play a medium-ish strategy game.  

I think I prefer Race for the Galaxy and Eminent Domain because there is more randomness in each game, which can make each play feel different.  That just means Puerto Rico isn't likely to rack up as nearly many plays as those games for me, but it's still a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.311
Played once on 3-18-06, and thoroughly enjoyed it.  This game has to be played with the right type of gamer.  Newbies who enjoy simpler fare like Ticket to Ride may become frustrated at first with the unfamiliar complexity of the game, while others will enjoy the decision making and planning.

[b]UPDATE 4/23/06:[/b] After a weekend of gaming with my group, this has vaulted to the top of our 'must-play' list of games, right next to El Grande.  Even the new players got a kick out of it, prompting me to regret not having bought it sooner.  This will see a lot of repeat play.

[b]June '06:[/b] Definitely a group favorite.  Has become so popular that it's usually the first thing out on any given Friday night.  Well deserving of its number one spot.

[b]March '07[/b]  I'll never win this game, but I still enjoy playing it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best game ever
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I once considered this a good game, but as time progressed and I played this more and more it started to wear thin. I can understand the uniqueness of this game when it was new and as long as everyone playing is at about the same level it can be pretty good, if a little scripted.  However, It is so much the same each time and so predictable I have little desire to play it. The game is usually won by the player who gains the biggest advantage either through seating advantage or through poor play of another player. There is little control other than you running the engine as best as possible. For me the fun in this was gone once I understood the game enough to know how that engine ran. Now it is a boring game of over analysis that in my group turn into hours of needless bickering of how someone could have played better. 
Never does this game come down to masterful play by the winner. 

To play this with a person who is new or not at your level is a complete waste of time. (I would rate it a 2 in that situation) 

Played again for the first time in about 18 months (June 08) and man I can say that little desire has turned into no desire to play. Do not believe the hype on this game folks, it really is an exercise in understanding the scoring engine and making tactical moves to maximize your point and minimize others points each turn. If you like to figure out your score and then do some light math to figure out what other will score when taking each card then you probably will like this game. I for one find that rather boring. Never does this game create a memorable experience, in fact it is more fun to play this thing via the PR evolver spreadsheet than it is in a face to face game. I have play tons of this game and I can't remember the details of any of them. Compare that to something like Ti3 where I can tell you who won each game and how they did it. This game being ranked no 1 here is a classic example of groupthink combined with people not updating their ratings. PR is stale, its old and it really isn't as good as you remember it. There are a few set strategies that win all the time, the programmed machine nature of this game make it so that the game engine just runs itself and there is little you can do to stop anyone not directly to your left. Once the fun of learning the engine fades then this thing is a boring exercise in  score keeping.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Top-notch, if not the best, as a typical Euro. Innovative mechanics, like role selection and variable phase order, work quite good. Well-balanced, many ways to win, many ways to be nasty and screw your neighbor.

However... sadly I have no attachment for a typical Euro. Its theme is stunningly boring. It's too logical. It allows only very indirect interactions. It feels very dry. It's over when it feels like a beginning. Its nastiness tastes bitter. 

And more, it has ugly artwork.

RATING: 7
Dropped a lil bit in my ratings as I find myself not wanting to play every time this one is mentioned. It often feels that there is little that can be done to stop a leader in a runaway position. Time will tell.

Update 03/06/2006 (drops to 6.5)
Played yesterday and although fun, it's SO obvious that a poor player helps the one that follows after them that I think that determining your seating position at the start of the game is as important as any strategy during gameplay. I played an excellent game and came in 2nd to last. My brother in law (to my left and who came in last)repeatedly made role choices that helped the following player - who ultimately won. I'm having a hard time stopping this ratings slide with a game that depends on so much on the experience of all players being equal. 

Update 09/15/2007 (rises to 7.5)
Played this again after a long hiatus. It has regained some of it's luster as we were all newbies again and the game play felt much less scripted.

RATING: 9.5
Resource handling, shipping, producing. Take turns as Governor, picking your role as prospector, builder, producer and others. Which gives you a bonus to that role and then each other player takes there turn at that role. This is not unlike game play in Citadels.
Victory Point system. Finally bought my own copy. :)
Very enjoyable!

RATING: 6.8
First impression: 8

4 games in a row for a first time play session with a game speaks good things in my opinion (add to this that the last game ends at 2 a.m. wishing to have a fifth game).

Some random toughts:
- For me the art is far from nice, but it is functional
- I don't think the game is a multiplayer solitare at all
- If you are not super obsesive about winnig and hyper-analytic with game mechanics, I don't see any obvious flaws in game play
- I don't think the game is too complex (in fact we play with a 12 year member that beat us in the first game), IMHO the rules seem complex but after the first play you are ready to go (set asyde strategy...)
- I would say that if you are going to play frequently, probably is better to play wiht the same group, as the game have a steep learning curve regarding strategy

For me it deserves it deserves it status as a modern classic, maybe it's not for everyone, but no doubt is a pretty good game.

---------------------------------------------------------

Update: 6.8

After a few more plays I'm thinking the game is maybe too dry, and needs some more excitement... anyway I thing is a good game, but I'm not so sure if I'am willingn to play it that much, hence 6.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very good, complex game.  Your strategy may change depending on the # of players and what those players happen to be doing.  

The one downside I see is that your game can be hurt by newbies, or players who simply do not understand the strategy of the game and make moves that help other players more than themselves--of course, you might be helped by this, but it's still frustrating.

Despite that factor, this is a solid game.  I even enjoy the 2-player variant.

The expansions are nice: They alter the strategy just enough to keep you on your toes.  Worth picking up, especially because they're so cheap!

[i]Sold after I got the Limited Anniversary Edition.[/i]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The game mecanisms of Puerto Rico are beautifully interlocked, all effecting eachother in intuitive, subtle ways.

Part of this game's fun is to develop and try out new overall strategies. There are several ones that seem to work about equally well, but their success always seem to depend on the stategy the others choose.

On a tactical scale the game is outstanding as well. What Role to pick? What building to buid? What goods to ship in which boat first? Etc. And what will the other players do?

And constantly you are aware that your opponents are trying to guess your decisions and you are trying to outguess theirs.

Finally, the rules are clear, the theme fits smoothly and the playing pieces are fine!
I cannot imagine a better game in its genre!

RATING: 9
Le principe général du jeu est celui de la gestion d'une colonie. Il va falloir planter, récolter et transformer vos produits agricoles, les vendre ou les exporter. 

Pour réaliser toutes ces opérations, il vous faut construire les bâtiments nécessaires et faire venir des colons de la vieille Europe. Le but est d'acquérir des points de victoire. L'argent, qui est le nerf de la guerre ne sert au final qu'à départager d'éventuels ex aequo.

RATING: 7.1
Bastante estratégico y con un factor suerte limitado al máximo (la adquisición de plantaciones).Es un juego que se juega tranquilo, con menos interacción obvia y ruidosa y que hace que se desee jugar de nuevo por superación personal. Es decir, pese a que se pierda, queda la impresión que si UNO lo hubiese hecho mejor, con un mejor plan, se podía haber logrado algo más.UPDATE: baja de 8 a 7, porgue de solo pensar en su configuración inicial, ya no dan ganas de jugar. Voy a hacerme la idea de lograrlo.ENERO 2007: pese a la configuración latosa, sube a 9, porque aprendimos correctamente la regla del capitán: son varios turnos de embarco y no solo 1, como lo habíamos estado jugando. Adquieren importancia el Harbor y el Wharf.Baja a 7 en agosto de 2007, porque esta un poco esquematizado en su forma de juego.

RATING: 8.5
An absolututely terrific game. Now one of my top 10 games of all time. No nauseating auctions, no voting, no down-time, very little randomization. The role choosing mechanism where everyone gets to do the role and the chooser gets first crack with a bonus is just perfect. Great strategic choices in role, building, plantation selections. And the new expansion buildings are great fun and really add to the permutations. Even inspired me to make up a set, just like the old days in Cosmic Encounter. Can't wait to try the 2-player variants. Do not miss this game! Update 2014-01-25: still one of my top 10 games, but don't seek to play this as much as the strategies have become a bit too rigid.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Puerto Rico is every bit as good as I'd been led to believe, and it looks a lot more intimidating than it actually is. The mechanics interlock brilliantly, the tension level during play is palpable (especially towards the end), and there's plenty of turn angst to go around.

I absolutely love the role selection mechanic and the number of possible paths to victory. There's a good amount of room to plan ahead, but there are also plenty of opportunities to screw with the other players; it's an excellent balance.

Puerto Rico changed how I think about board games, and turned me on to games with greater depth and complexity. Playing it for the first time was one of my best board gaming experiences ever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Finally got to see what the hype was about.

It played okay, but didn't stand out.  It may be that I've played enough derivitive games that I'm not seeing it with the same eyes as folks who discovered it did.

Most of us were newbies, which helped since it was more forgiving of mistakes.  That said, I suspect that the game would get better as skill levels increase.  It was hard to tell how folks were doing and when I won I was quite surprised (feeling that my all-corn strategy was falling short).

RATING: 7
I created a homemade copy of Puerto Rico. Colonists are not brown round disks, but soldiers from an old copy of Risk. The goods are hand-painted necklace beads which I managed to take from ny niece. (Don't worry, she let me :P). All the plantations and buildings are made from old Monopoly cards - the properties and chance/community chest cards. Each player board is made from a section of the 6-foldable Risk map.

Looks like a turned 2 bad games into one great one. :)

UPDATE: I finally bought the real version of the game. It's nice to have the authentic thing in my hands now. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.49
Efficiency, efficiency, efficiency, that's the name of the game. To be sure, most euro games focus on efficiency, forcing players to make optimal moves in order to be successful. What makes Puerto Rico unique? Well, nothing really, other than the fact that it is pretty darn boring. This game makes me appreciate pasted-on themes. What is wrong with pasting on a theme? Stone Age, Kingsburg, Alien Frontiers…there are tons of games with light themes, but they're still solid games in their own right, partly because they are fun (I understand that Puerto Rico is a shipping game, but it is SOOOO dry it feels like there is an absence of theme). While fun is a subjective notion, I don't see how anyone could have "fun" playing Puerto Rico. It's a great game for tournaments and leaderboards, for people that want to top their latest high score, but it's not for "most" people who want to have a fun time. It is beyond me how this game is still so highly ranked. It suffers from the same problem as Settlers, that is, it has been improved upon a thousand times over. This game clearly brought a lot of gamers into heavier games, and maybe into gaming in general, but that's no reason to inflate its rating to this point. I'm not saying I won't play it again, and I'm definitely not saying it is a bad game, but it's definitely in my bottom 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good engine building/ role selection classic. It doesn't hit the table all that much with me; as i'll usually pick Castles of Burgundy over this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Puerto Rico is a game which I continue to enjoy more with each play. Once I figured out the mechanics, it became much more enjoyable.  The fact that one of my other favorite games is based off of this is no surprise either (Race for the Galaxy).

While I am not particularly convinced by the game's theme, the interactions between players is bar none.  Every time that someone captains a ship and I get left out it pains me, while being able to capitalize on something nobody else can feels like an achievement.  Tons of replability.  If you enjoy euro games, this is a must-have.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The number 1 game on the geek. Plays 2-5. The game is good. Really good. The game has little luck which can lead to scripted play. Who acts before you (specifically what type of player they are and their skill level) is often more important than your own play. I prefer San Juan. 

Personally I rate this game (flaws and all) in my top 25. It doesn't make my top 10 however.

3-30-08 2-player v. Karen 67-66 Win. Factory with 4 goods (all but Coffee led to early cash) Built small office, then factory then wharf. Karen had large office and coffee for 7 dubloons per sale in the market.

5-11-08 
Karen, Sean, Ang, Moi. 37,43.40, 48
Ang had 10 vp build, 30 shipping. Karen had 15 build, 18 shipping, special (Fortress?) Sean had 20 build, 16 ship, 7 special, Moi had 24 build, 17 ship, 7 special (Guild Hall) 
Karen was first player. I went with (quarry grabbing building) and eventually Hacienda. My cash crop was coffee. I purchased a Factory and got into Sugar for 3$ per craftsman phase. I used my 3 quarries and Factor cash to buy a harbor,wharf and Guild Hall sequentially. The game ended in Sean's governorship (probably turn 12) I was faced with the prospect of shipping 1 barrel of corn for 3 VP or crafting, knowing I could ship 5 VP worth of coffe via the harbor in the likely event Ang picked captain, but not knowing if I'd ship any of my other goods. So I went conservative and eeked out a small win.

RATING: 6
Easy to learn for a game that looks horribly complicated, and the role selection mechanism is beautiful - you're always involved in the game despite the pace of game being slow. However, it is long, fiddly, downright ugly to look at (even the building cards are just text), has a weird slavery theme, and it's kind of dull - nothing happens that is memorable (unless you can remember events like "oh, so-and-so crafted instead of captained, it was seriously sub-optimal"). For enthusiasts of careful resource management games only. Winning seems a matter of accumulating many very slightly better decisions, there is no killer play. Play seems very programmed, some buildings seem to be entirely ignored under all circumstances. Summary: clever game that's too long for what it is. Give me a game of Citadels any day.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Played 12+ times.
Last play on July 27, 2008

I did have this at 9 after only playing it a few times.  But I have played it more times now and have decided to move it up to a 10 (my first).  The reason this has moved up is primarily because this game avoids one of my biggest hangups with games.  I hate playing a game where I feel like I have no chance of winning.  If about halfway through the game the winner is so far ahead that I feel I have no chance, I get bored.  But what is so great about this game is that you really don't know who is in lead. Most games the person we think is in the lead is not, and the person we don't think did well, is likely the winner.  

Just tried the 2player varient and found it just as much fun.

I haven't played this game in quite some time as we have been playing other games and our friends arn't as keen on this one, but I found it was just as much fun as I remember.

Just tried it with the expansion.  It totally changes the game up.  Very fun.  Gets you out of your own strategy rut.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
De momento el juego que más ha triunfado con todo el mundo que lo ha probado de los juegos que conozco. Eso tiene que significar algo...

2018-01-31: Redondeo la nota a 9 (desde un 9,2).
A pesar de que solo tiene dos caminos básicos (construir edificios o embarcar mercancías) sigue teniendo suficientes estrategias dentro de estos dos caminos como para que siga siendo un gran juego con rejugabilidad más que suficiente. El juego que me descubrió los eurogames (de peso medio) y que hizo que me metiera de lleno en esta afición. Los hay mejores, pero Puerto Rico aguanta el paso del tiempo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I am not a fan of games that require:

1) Squinting to read cards/tiles (especially to see those of your opponents)

2) Memorizing all of the cards/tiles and their functions/combos prior to being able to play the game at a reasonably high level

I suspect this is why I am not a fan of some highly rated games such as [i]Puerto Rico[/i] and [i]Ora et Labora[/i].

That being said, PR is a well-designed game and there are aspects of it I enjoy.  The variable endgame is nice and I enjoy being able to select roles that thwart my opponents' plans.

----------

After having read the rulebook and playing without the expansion tiles, the game seems a bit more manageable. It's still not a game I would choose to play too often, but it's a solid 7 for me.

RATING: 7.5
Good game, an excellent design best illustrated by the fact that I don't think I'll ever be able to play it particularly well.

I play it on iOS which has a nice implementation and animated/illustrated buildings and plantations. The original edition's board game is rather ugly with buildings just being little chits and having to scan around the table to see what you're denying opponents. 

I think the board game could be done much better, but, alas, even the 10th Anniversary Edition falls short.

I'm waiting to see if the game, reissued in German only recently, will republished again in English with some of the recent graphic improvements found in the 2014 Ravensburger edition. I can hope!

RATING: 9.5

****3 years later I need to correct the fact that I wrote that this game was as close to perfection as you can get. After several plays we found buildings combination way better than other. Found that the game doesn't play equally good at all players configuration and takes longer to setup than most of my games(except Battlelore).
But overall, the game experience is still the best in my collection.

Good with 2 players.
Best with 3 players.
Very good with 4 players.
OK with 5 Players.

RATING: 8
The best of the German games, "Puerto Rico" somehow manages to present a paralyzing array of strategic choices while still keeping the rules simple and clocking in at about 2 hours.  It also integrates its theme very well and avoids the weightless, abstract feeling that ruins many of the German games for me.  Only the limited interactions between the players and the fact that you can never just whomp somebody reduce this from a 10 for me.

RATING: 7
Used to be one of my favorite games. I had been searching for a "Puerto Rico killer" for a couple of years before I found (and loved) Funkenschlag.

I wonder how it will age though, since the game tends to get a bit predictable with experienced players, and very much in favor of experienced players versus not so experienced players.

Contrary to some expert opinions there's still various ways to win. And the best part: there's hardly any downtime in this game, once people are used to the game...

RATING: 10
This is easily one of my favorite heavy strategy games, and it was a clear choice for a 10 rating.  I love that there is minimal downtime between turns since everyone benefits from everyone else's choice of action.  It definitely makes for some really interesting and unique gameplay which varies heavily from game to game, despite the fact that there is so little randomness within the game itself.  There's a reason this game has been ranked #1 on the Geek for so long.  I love taking multiple paths to victory and working hard to vary my strategy based on the strengths and weaknesses of my opponents.  Always great fun, and everyone feels like they have a chance to win.

RATING: 6
This game got me back into Board games. before this gem, all i knew was Monopoly, Cluedo, Masterpiece, Hero Quest, and Talisman. 
But here was a game that threw out the dice! winning and losing was now completely up to you. i was in awe as i managed to tune my strategy just right so that the brilliantly laid out mechanics of the different phases started to click into place for me, and id watch and scheme as my city grew and the VPs came pouring in at the cost of my opponents!
Now though, this game for me is the Granddad sitting on the porch as he watches all the young whippersnappers, that he begat, pass him by and come to the fore. It no longer wows me like it used to.
Alas, i cant seem to part with my copy though, because it will always hold a special place in my gaming heart as my first love.

RATING: 10
This is probably my favorite euro. I fell in love with this game in 2002 when it came out (and I am really kicking myself for not getting the Puerto Rico Anniversary Edition in 2010 (?)).

I have probably over 30 undocumented plays with this game. All the criticisms are true: If you are playing after a weaker player, you are advantaged in the game.

Despite that statement, the range of viable strategies made this game brilliant back then. The action-selection mechanism was the first of it's kind.

Since then, I don't play it much, but I have a soft spot for this title in my heart. I would still play this game if someone offered.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a superb Euro-style game. I won't say that it's immune to criticism, but it's pretty damn good. 

One flaw is in scalability: the game becomes a building-race at 5 players; 3-player games don't have enough scarcity. For this reason, I'd recommend playing with 4. 

Table position also matters quite a bit in this game; having written a game with the same problem, I don't consider this fatal.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Game in a Nutshell: Gain victory points by shipping or selling crops to build a city. Be the best in managing what it takes to do just that by selecting limited roles each round.

Played as: 3,4,5 player

Pros: I like selecting different roles. The partial hidden victory points leave a sense of tension until the final tally. It's hard not to find someone who doesn't like it for one reason or another.

Cons: Sometimes I wonder if the game couldn't have been slightly more balanced so there would be more routes of equal opportunity to victory. While on the subject of routes to victory, the lack of randomness doesn't offer much incentive for going about a different strategy.

Other: I'm sure I could win this game a lot more if I executed the same strategy that's worked for me in the past. I prefer to try as many new routes just to avoid robot playing syndrome. I'd like to think more seasoned playing partners (myself included) would make optimizing the best strategy more interesting, but as for now, I'm bored of watching the same few strategies win every time.

Best Use: If you want to blow away the gamers still standing in gateway land yearning for more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
After numerous games, I still like Puerto Rico, despite all of its obvious flaws (scripted nature, processional feel, optimization instead of creativity, standard opening moves due to the starting situation always being exactly the same, etc). I used to only play it with 2 or 3, but now also enjoy it with 4. Still refuse to play with 5 though - too messy. Though direct screwage is difficult, one can still outwit opponents into forcing them to make moves they might not really want to make. PR is incredibly easy to explain to newbies for the broadness of the game, which makes it pop out time and again. I think I am getting close to, well not solving, but reaching a ceiling with PR though, since I do find myself performing more or less the same tactics each game. Three player games offer more economical flexibility (more gold on roles) so I still prefer these. In the end, tough, what is truely missing from PR is some "tightness" in managing your opportunities - you'll always get around to playing half-decent even if you're not playing very well. I'd still rather be punished by a game for messing up, which results in better, more competitive play over time (i.e., Age of Steam).
I will soon be trying the Expansion to see if some of the main issues with Puerto Rico becoming stale after extensive play can be resolved.
In short, I still value the "elegantness" of PR but am slowly but surely getting to the point where I'd rather pick something else for the same complexity/playing time/# of players involved. This mainly because, amongst experienced players, game strategy is actually only about the order in which things happen, and I'm not too sure I like that part so much.

RATING: 9
When I first played Puerto Rico, it blew my mind a bit - so many layers of complexity. I loved reading up on the different strategies; this is the game that brought me to the geek. I considered it worthy of its number 1 rank. (I suppose I still do - [gameid=31260] doesn't rock my bells.)

Recently, I played PR again for the first time in over four years. And while my opinion of the game hasn't really changed, I'm lowering my rating anyway, because my preferences have. Lately I tend towards shorter games that I can play more than once: [gameid=3], [gameid=36218], and yeah, [gameid=28143]. I'll keep part of my original comment though...

I still feel like I am learning something each time. Haven't felt that way about a game since Zertz. Hey, who wants to play Zertz?

RATING: 8

RATING: 3
I was interested in this game because of the hype.. almost bought and sure glad I didn't.  Played with some friends.  I like good production in a game... everything seemed plain and small to me...that wasn't a good sign.  Player interaction is minimal, game plays like a multiplayer solitaire, except its like you go to the bathroom and you kids took some of your cards, which messed up your game.  Thats PR, the only player "interaction" comes with someone taking a starting card you wanted.Some intesting mechanics, but some more complicated games of solitaire have interesting concepts...you see them, experience them, then your realize how boring a game this is.  Goes for most other Euros... what people see in them I will never understand :-O   I guess they would rate the games I like down... different strokes for different folks.

RATING: 10
Time has dimmed PR's playing time a bit, but it's still THE role selection game for many of my friends. It's also the game that opened my eyes as to what a game could be- complex interactions, difficult decisions, short game/long game balance, changing game states and variable game length. PR was my gateway to a larger gaming world, and for that it's a top ten desert island 10 for me.

RATING: 8
Players take turns picking roles and completing actions based on those roles. Strategy comes through targeting specific bonuses, and from preventing your opponents getting other bonuses.

The gameplay is super solid, and heavily strategic, but the pieces are flimsy. In all honesty, the game is excellent, but the production quality keeps me from giving it a 9.

If somebody gets into the coffee business as well, get an office ASAP.  Add a small and large market as needed.  A great victory strategy... or so it seems.  You'll dominate the captain and trader phases.  Need I say more?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
"Klasszik", az euro játékok egyik pionírja.

A játék központi mechanizmusa a szerepválasztás, de a legtöbb szerepválasztós játékkal ellentétben itt nem csak az aktuális játékos, hanem mindenki annak a szerepnek megfelelően végzi el az adott kör akcióját. Akkor mi értelme van? Egyrészt az időzítés miatt (behajózáskor pl. nem mindegy, ki kezdi), másrészt a privilégiumért. Utóbbi annyit jelent, hogy a szerepet választó bónuszhoz jut a többiekhez képest (több pontot kap ugyanazért az akcióért, drágábban tud eladni, stb).

A legzseniálisabb az egészben, hogy az igazán jó játékosok olykor a számukra megmaradt és látszólag kevésbé hasznos szerepek közül azt választják, ami a többieknek a legkevésbé felel meg, nem pedig azt, amivel rövid távon a legjobban járnak.

Ezek a szerepek:
 - iparos: termelés, privilégiummal egy termékkel több jár
 - kereskedő: termék eladás, privilégiummal eggyel több pénz jár
 - kapitány: behajózás (termékek hajókra győzelmi pontokért), privilégiummal eggyel több pont jár
 - építész: épület építése, privilégiummal eggyel olcsóbban tehető meg
 - polgármester: munkások beszerzése és letelepítése, privilégiummal eggyel több munkás jár
 - ültetvényes: ültetvény telepítése, privilégiummal kőbánya is választható (ami olcsósítja az építkezést)
 - aranyásó: egy pénzt hoz a konyhára, nincs privilégium (mivel senki más nem kap, csak aki választotta)

Az adott körben amelyik szerepet senki sem választotta, arra egy pénz kerül. Így azzal is taktikázni lehet, hogy csak azért választunk szerepet, mert már 2-3 vagy akár még több pénz van rajta.

Épületekkel tudjuk feldolgozni az ültetvényeken megtermelt terményeket (cukrot, dohányt, indigót, kávét, a kukoricához nem kell feldolgozó épület, viszont nem is ér sokat). Illetve egyéb extrákat is szerezhetünk építkezéssel (pl. több termék raktározható, játék végén plusz pontok szerezhetők bizonyos feltételek teljesülésekor, stb).

Bár egyszerűnek tűnik a képlet: telepítsünk ültetvényeket és feldolgozó épületeket, amikre tegyünk munkásokat (különben nem működnek), termeljünk, majd a termékeket adjuk el pénzért (amivel építhetünk) vagy hajózzuk be, amivel győzelmi pontokat szerezhetünk, de szinte soha nem fogunk az ideális sorrendben haladni, rengetegszer kell már körökkel előre gondolkozni, figyelni a többiek lépését és folyamatosan nehéz döntéseket hozni.

A pontozásnál nem érzem igazságosnak, hogy a megmaradt pénz és termék semmit sem ér (oké, döntetlen esetén az dönt, de az elég ritka szitu). Sokkal jobb lett volna 2/1 vagy legalább 3/1 arányban beszámítani ezeket is, mert gyakran fordul elő, hogy bizony még egy picike akció kellett volna a végére, hogy a maradékból győzelmi pontot csináljunk vagy megépítsünk egy 3-4 pontot érő épületet a pénzünkből.

Ezt eltekintve vérbeli euro, amit kár lenne kihagyni bárkinek is. A szabályok logikusak, jól érthetők, egyedül az épületekkel nem árt tisztában lenni még pluszban az első 1-2 játéknál, mert ismeretük hiánya jelentős hátrányt okozhat a játék során (muszáj átlátni, hogy melyik épület mire jó).

Csak azért nem adok neki több pontot, mert elég gyakori a kényszerakció, amikor kevésnek érzi az ember az opciókat és megint várhatja a körét, hogy végre választhasson mást (ha tud). Persze valaki meg ezt imádja (mazochisták előnyben). Ja, és kiválóan működik 2-3-4 és 5 játékossal is.

"Ha ezt nem próbáltad, nem próbáltál még semmit." (híres dakota indián mondás)

Update (2017.12.17.): eladva, mert nem nagyon került elő, BGA-n ha nagyon hiányzik, majd játszom vele.

Update (2018.01.29.): nem bírtam ki, megvettem a magyar kiadást, pedig BGA-n is játszottam vele azóta (nyilván erősen motivált, hogy a magyar kiadásban a két kiegészítő - új épületek és nemesek - is benne van)

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Another classic multiplayer game. Every time I play this game, I learn something new that makes me a better player. Also, the fixed roles (no cards) and turn ordering make this game one that you can analyze at a fairly deep level.  Good players still argue about the ideal first few turns.

While there is much hype over the new Euros that come out every year, I find this one to be just as engaging now as it was when I was first introduced to gaming.

There are a few flaws perhaps, such as the importance of seating, but I think a simple handicap system using victory points makes this work well. Also, if you are playing with a few suboptimal players, it comes down to which good player's benefits the most from what the person is doing (i.e. crafting too often, mayoring too often). 

Nevertheless my rating stands. Honestly, any skill-based game, especially a multiplayer one, will have those same issues.

RATING: 8

I'm less a fan of some of the start --- especially with experienced players, I tend to see "standard openings" which I don't know and I don't care to play.

RATING: 9
This got me back into boardgaming. It doesn't get old, though I do find that I get into a rut once I have sucess with a particular strategy (I find it hard to get away from my focus on shipping). To enhance the thematics, it is necessary to speak Spanish when playing. Like many cilization building games; it is politically problematic. As part of the theme of colonization, players ship in slaves to work their plantations. In the expansion, the "colonists" can be sold on the black market. Yikes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Like many other popular Euros, Puerto Rico is ostensibly an engine builder featuring the now tired process of gaining resources (money, crops) and converting them to victory points (buildings, shipping). But unlike these other games, Puerto Rico is not multiplayer solitaire in which you try to "solve" the [-]spreadsheet[/-] tableau/board before you better than the other players. Instead, Puerto Rico requires attentiveness to the other players' plans and the rhythm and flow of the game to do well. Furthermore, while it's largely a tactical affair, you do have to have a strategy in mind from the outset.

I can see the lack of variability becoming dull after a while, or maybe I'll become concerned with the seating arrangements. But I'm still too new to the game to really have much of a problem with this stuff yet. I'm looking forward to many more plays of Puerto Rico.

RATING: 7.9
Puerto Rico is a great game, though it can often feel like a math problem.  The game is quite tight and small choices have huge repercussions across the table.  At times, other players' actions have such a tremendous impact on your own position that the game can feel random and swingy (until you all understand the ramifications of your actions, in which case it feels kind of scripted).

RATING: 9
Are you ever mildly disappointed after watching a movie that everyone else says is a "must see"?  Even though the movie was "good", your expectations were so high that nothing short of perfection will do.  Such was the case when I played Puerto Rico.  The game was fun but perhaps not as earthshaking as I was expecting.  I still rate it a '9' because it is a well designed, fun game; but I fully expected it to be a '10'.   Maybe it will be after the hype dies down and I can judge the game on its own merits.

RATING: 8
While I respect Puerto Rico's great design, a session of it with similarly skilled gamers is a bit dull because most of the opening and closing moves have become too predictable. I just don't feel strongly motivated to put this one on the table, especially considering the setup and breakdown time, which is reflected in my current score. I'd still recommend that anyone who has yet to play it should at least try it a couple of times. I think I'd only be interested in playing PR a few times a year at most. I think a lot more BGGers should revisit their rating scores for this game and base it on whether they still have the same passion for PR.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is about building a prosperous colony by selecting the right action at the right time. Initially I liked the idea that your actions give both you and your opponents advantages and thus require you to carefully choose your strategy. However, the more I played, the more I began to feel that nothing new happened, particularly in the end-game where the choices are limited. I also felt a lack of control as most actions you take in the game are actually chosen by another player.

Pros: Chance plays little part, all players participate to the end, short game sessions
Cons: Little player interaction, little variation, little control, difficult to get back from bad start
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
10+
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Puerto Rico is one of the pinnacles of game design.  It has just about everything that I look for in a game: multiple viable strategies for victory, deep gameplay, interesting tactical decisions, and good player interaction.  For a long time, this was my #1 game, and for good reason.  I've probably played over 50 times face to face, and it took me many plays to become comfortable.  The reason Puerto Rico is no longer my #1 game is that it needs to be played by players of equal skill level.  Because I've had several play groups recently and I have taught this game to several new people, I no longer have opponents with the same experience as I do, and as a result, I find myself winning more often than normally.  As a result, in my latest games I've sort of played on auto-pilot and still won.  This is still a great game and a fantastic design, but I now find myself leaning towards other games.  On a side note, I find that Puerto Rico is actually a very good next step game after I teach people Settlers or Carcassonne or Acquire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first Euro game, and the game that brought me into this hobby. And it's still the best!

RATING: 7.96

RATING: 4
Not Bad. The great Puerto Rico is on top of BGG ranking. I think this game is just fine. I've lost my respect for this game when, after playing with some new gamers, one of them called it "Monopoly without dice" . Most of the time, I'm just not in the mood to play this game, but I don't give it a lower rating because it deserves some respect for being BGG #1 :D
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Overall comment: An excellent game for 4 or more players.  It is not too heavy and involves many simple value based decisions.

Ratings:
Initial(wow factor): 9 (all components are interesting and have a good feel to them)
Family: 8 (sometimes requested)
Game Group: 7 (marginal - too simple, no tough decisions)
AP: 9 (little down time)
Solo play: 9 (#3 solo play - raised the overall rating of the game)

Purchased: 2006
Luck factor (1-10high): 2 (only in flipping the plantations)
Recommend expansions: Yes (for variety in the buildings)
Age range: 8+

Reason purchased: Geek reviews and game shop conversation

Pros: plays quick with little down time and little A/P, expansion makes it more varied and less programmed.  Solo and 2 player variants have significantly added to the replayability which has increased the play requests.
Cons: not as interesting with fewer players

Recommendation: Worthy purchase
Replay rating: Moderate
Game value(plays to game cost) : High

RATING: 9

After 2-3 plays with 4p,I was heavily impressed by its gameplay and realized that I found my new hobby. After learning that Puerto Rico was first published in 2002, I was extremely thrilled and couldn't wait to learn about other board games that have been developed since then. This game was a definite 10 for me (in Spring 2014). It has become a 9 after I was introduced to Agricola.

April 2015, Stuttgart

WAIT FOR NEW EDITION JUST LIKE WAIT FOR IMPERIAL SETTLERS UPDATED ERRATA EDITIONS ARE MARKED.

Plays: 5+

Edit: will wait for an edition with expansions included though, but would like to get this some day as its the best role selection and good strategy game where I dont feel downtime very much, even in 5p. One caveat is you must play with experienced players (or maybe create some handicap for yourself) because the skill gap here can be significant.

RATING: 9

It's still the best in it's genre of resource building and balancing (little/no luck, multiple paths to victory, fairly quick, not hard to grasp, medium/low fun factor) but there are so many games of this sort that I'm getting a little fed up with the wboth mechanics and theme.

I truly believe this is a highly over-rated game. I can kinda understand some people enjoying this game, but the rating does not seem to fit the amount of enjoyment provided by this game.

RATING: 9
Puerto Rico is like a swiss clock. The gameplay is very fluent, brings interactions between players. All is question of strategies and tactics. If you want to win, you must choose your role at the good moment. You have to watch the situation of other players and adapt your strategie. It's always a pleasure to play this game. I recommend it for 3 to 4 players. With two players, it can be like chess. With five players, the game is too long for me but very interesting.

RATING: 7
2-5 (3-5) [3.3]

Theme: Goods Production

Mechanics: Role Selection, Worker Placement

RATING: 4

first seat:25%
second seat: 16%
third seat: 33%
fourth seat: 26%
Indicates to me that there's a real problem with the game.
Once my group got to the point where everyone was playing at about the same skill level, our stats more or less fell into line with those above.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Puerto Rico is a fantastic strategy game that has an unfortunately high barrier to entry.  First time players are overwhelmed with the number of options that veteran players are comfortable with.  If you can find a player willing to invest in learning the game, it can be great fun.  Players select roles on each turn, and all players get to take advantage of the role while the player selecting it gets a special privilege for the role.  You must constantly evaluate whether it is better to help yourself or harm your opponents, as doing both is rarely possible.

RATING: 5
I won my very first game of Puerto Rico against other veterans!  I had a great time playing Puerto Rico.  The whole design is very interesting and enjoyable.  Every round each player takes his turn selecting a role card and performing their action.  After selecting a role each player after gets to do the same action, although a bit diluted.  During the course of the game you want to sell goods and buy new buildings so that you have the most points at the end.

Great game.  I remember reading someone describing that although Agricola and Puerto Rico are both great games, Puerto Rico manages to do it with more finesse and less stress.  I agree, although sometimes I like to feel the stress of Agricola!

RATING: 8
A wonderful game -- I'm almost always up for a game of Puerto Rico.  Close to being ranked a 10, but the order of play is too large a factor in this game: a weak player to your right can make mistakes in your favor; an experienced (and/or vicious) player to your right can be devastating.  While the game has a bit of a learning curve, most people catch on to the flow  of events by the second or third game.  One of those rare games that I tend to enjoy even if I'm not doing particularly well :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Players spending round after round choosing a character each to carry out actions for them was already a known mechanism when Puerto Rico arrived, having been used in several popular games; though, it had never before been the motor of such a complex creature, where players had to get an island's economy to move balancing several variables (crops give money and victory points, money buys buildings, buildings improve crops and yield victory points).

This quantum leap is due to a little twist/stroke of genius: one player chooses a role to act FOR ALL PLAYERS, getting a benefit from being first (this benefit would depend on the chosen role). This enables both the possibility for each player to carry out unique and ambitious plans in each round and to keep everyone constantly busy, as one role has to be played by all before the next role is able to start. Players don't stay close for too long, either: the changing available plantations and an impressive array of buildings offer a myriad of ways to follow.

This is arguably one of the very best German games ever released - it's difficult to find a game based almost exclusively on tactics that is as rich as Puerto Rico. The real surprise, though, is that when actually comparing it to the other "complex" classics (from El Grande to Le Havre, you could say) the striking simplicity of its core lies bare for all to see.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Another brilliant game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Evergreen. Gioco perfetto. Numerose sono le opzioni per fare punti vittoria, interazione tra giocatori enorme, assenza di fortuna, pianificazione a lungo termine indispensabile ma non semplice da attuare. Insomma un gioco con infiniti aspetti di mio gradimento e dalla durata contenuta. Trovo come unico difetto il fatto che sedere a sinistra di un giocatore esordiente o meno bravo possa portare sensibili vantaggi. Il gioco solitamente non piace a chi predilige giochi semplici e veloci anche se regolamento e meccaniche non sono complesse. La definizione perfetta è in 4 giocatori, ok anche in 5, meno bello secondo me in 3. Consigliatissimo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The really remarkable thing about this complex game is the sheer intuitiveness to it. There's very little a good gamer can't pick up instantly, and a competent gamer within a few turns, even if the strategy requires constant honing. The sell-for-money or ship-for-VPs decision is delightfully agonising and the role selection mechanic may never be bettered. Is it a problem that the components aren't really the best and that the seating order might just be the be-all and end-all?

Cheap         :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Quality

RATING: 9
I really like the mechanism of this game; you don't actively oppose other players, but your choice of role each round does impact heavily on them indirectly, so compared to some German-style games you are encouraged to watch your opponents and factor their aims into your strategy. 

I also really like the counters, which you can imagine as being like barrels - something that adds theme to the game, which is a strong point, as the game mechanics fit well with its theme, as you can imagine that you are developing your colony and exporting goods to the old country.

RATING: 10

RATING: 10
A true 10. The game is pure strategy, no luck included. It is not only about making a good strategy, but also requires you to be able to react to the other players' strategies and tweak the situation to your own advantage. It's not an overly long game, but manages to be great fun while it lasts.

The game mechanics are easy to understand and you start playing right away. 2-player rules work fine as well.

If you're only getting one game, this should be it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

波多黎各 (繁中豪華版)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Even if there is already immense accolades for this game, I must add my own. It's a great game. What I really like about the game, is its many possibilities on how to play for victory. The variations are also good for many replays of the game. The other thing I really like is the constant interaction. Even when its not your turn, you almost always get to do things anyway. The strategies are subtle, but they are there. F.e. in the last game when I went for maximises income from trading, the other player could stop me by either trading the goods I had before it was my turn, or by using shipping and forcing me to ship the few expensive goods I had. Somewhat more dependent on what the others do than you'd want, i.e. even if you are a good experienced player, its hard to win if the Role selections of others goes against you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

But I found that you can play this game online.  So after 200+ games of PR online, I discovered a couple of things: because so many of the housekeeping duties are automated online, when switching back to the cardboard version, it becomes almost excrusiatingly slow; and the face to face interactions with friends over a board game is at least half the fun.  As a result of playing PR online, I never want to play a board game that I enjoy online again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An excellent game! Just reading the rules makes the game seem a lot more complex than how the game actually plays. Turns, actions, et al move along very smoothly. The bits and pieces are of very good quality. Instructions and player guides are on almost every piece in one fashion or another. There is a typo on the player boards ... the builder action states "The mayor" when it should say "The builder".   We played with five and had a lotta fun. If you can gain a "monopoly" of one of the items being produced, you have a very good chance of winning the most victory points. Well worth the price of admission.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
規則:
*每個玩家拿一個圖版，3-2-3-4元(2-3-4-5 p)起始農地(染玉-染染玉-染染玉玉-染染染玉玉)
*中央擺上所有建築物(兩人時生產建築物兩棟，其他一棟)，分數(65-75-100-126)，礦全開，其他全洗勻開人數加一張(兩人全部都移除三個)，根據人數使用對應張數的腳色卡(7-6-7-8)，使用對應的貨物船(46-456-567-678)，物品兩人時移除各兩顆，殖民者先放同等人數顆在殖民船在跟據人數放在供應區(40-55-75-95)
*遊戲每輪輪流由 玩家選擇職業>然後所有玩家照順序作行動 ，直到所有玩家都選過職業後，沒選的職業放一元，然後換起始玩家，繼續下輪直到結束條件發生(兩人時輪流選完六個職業卡，只有最後一個職業卡放錢)
*遊戲有三個結束條件
1.殖民者不夠補殖民船
2.有人12個建築物蓋滿
3.分數被拿完
>每個玩家加總所有分數跟建築物分數，跟額外有啟動的建築物分數，平手比錢跟貨物加總
*選擇職業卡的玩家可享該職業特權(船長外可選卡不做事)
1. 拓荒者 拿一塊開著的農地 特權為可改選礦 ，全部選完後全部清空開新的，當玩家農地滿不可以再選此行動
2. 建築師 買建築物 特權為少花一元 (有啟動的礦可讓建築物少花錢，根據建築物在的欄位對應最多可以少花多少)
3. 市長 每個人輪流從殖民船拿殖民者 特權可從供應區拿一個， 拿完後市長清點所有建築物的空人口，補對應殖民者到殖民船(少於玩家人數則補玩家人數)
* 人口只能在這個時候移動，多的可先放旁邊，供應區空的時候市長不能使用特權，人口必須盡量放
4. 工匠 生產貨物 特權為多生產一個(要至少生產過)，玉米外產物都要有處理廠才能產
*特權必須等所有人產完才能拿，供應區空了就不能產 
5. 交易商 賣貨換錢 特權為多賺一塊錢
*每個人只能上一次，且上面只能有不同的貨，上完四個該次結束後清空
6.船長 強迫上船換分 特權多一分
*輪流上船，有得上一定要上，上一個一分，一次上一種，不能故意選裝不下的船上，輪到每人可上為止，每艘船只能載一種且每艘貨物要不同種，上船階段後，每個人只能存一個貨物，其他棄掉，滿的船在階段結束後清空
7.勘探者 拿一元
*建築物每種只能蓋一棟，蓋了不能移除，有人才能啟動
*****一擴*****
商用建築可在一開始輪流由玩家選擇要加什麼，每種價值的建築物都要出現對應張數在建築物圖版
***二擴***
*使用建築版圖背面，新的建築物放進去
*使用所有殖民者跟貴族，殖民者用完不會結束遊戲，每次補船時把一個殖民者用貴族取代，貴族一個一分
**平衡設定***
*工廠八元 大學7元
*起始玉米田的起始少1元
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the first board games I played after a long hiatus and still one of my favourites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It's overated- it's a good game, but I don't understand why it's number one. Too much setup time, small fiddly bits, not quite enough interaction (i.e. no central map to compete for space on), weak theme, "buildings" components are poor- no artwork, doesn't scale well, steep learning curve, everyone needs to be the same skill level, etc, etc. 
You see- lots of little things niggle me with this game. 

EDIT (12 April 07)- I've upped this from an 8 to a 9 (I think I first rated it either a 7 or a 7.5) The more I play it the more I like it! This is rather odd, because I didn't like it that much until I had played about 15 odd games or so, but one day I found myself thinking about it quite hard, and all of a sudden I found that I really like this game!

I think this is something to do with familiarity- I hate having to teach this game (because there's a lot to explain and there is the new/weak player craftsman issue), but *I* still want to play it under the right condidtions (i.e. with other players who are already familiar with the game). Just typing this I'm busy contemplating some new tactics hehehe... :)

What do you know, I've rated this a 10 (Dec 2007)

Bought Spring 2005

RATING: 8

[i][In my profile, explanation of this evaluation system.][/i]


Superb design. A pleasure to play again and again, trying different approaches to win. It's amazing when you finally find how to use that building that you used to despise. Don't listen to the people that think you can force a win with some specific strategy: not always the elements are at your disposal for this. Sometimes you simply cannot pick all the corns you perhaps want for the "corn strategy", for example.

RATING: 9

The perfect game for trying to leech your opponents efforts!

Due to this, this game suffers a lot when experienced players are faced with newbies, as they can help more an opponent than themselves.

RATING: 10
50+ plays. A great game that's provided enough variety to stand the test of time. It's about the constant need to assess the intentions of the other players, both short and long term, and set yourself up so you can take continual advantage of their moves and not be left out. Securing income is the initial goal, and then buying combinations of buildings that work well together will define your VP strategy. Whilst being on constant alert for short term tactical opportunities. I have the expansion and we'll occasionally pull it out for variety, but most times we're still happy playing the base game. Which is a testament to its durability.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
What I like:
- Interesting without being too heavy
- Multiple strategies, apparently
- Reasonable length (75-90 minutes with 4p)

What I don't like:
- Feels like a needlessly-bloated San Juan
- Too many ways to get unintentionally screwed
- Can feel like a game of "chicken" because your best move can set someone else up for better
- If you really think about it, it's really clear that the colonists are slaves

Where SJ is all about leaching, PR almost feels like it is all about preventing successful leaching. I don't like either approach, but dislike the SJ way less. SJ feels like a far more refined design. PR 2p variant sounds awkward.

It's a classic, and I can see why it was popular when it came out. Like Settlers (but less so), it no longer stands out as a top-notch game. The 3.3 weight seems reasonable--probably 3.0 rules complexity and 3.5 depth.

Rating dropped from 6 to 5 after a second play. Could drop further.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
As brilliant as ever. Great system. Everything is related in this game, and picking a role will have other players do the same thing. So one of the interesting mechanics of the game is to chose when's the best moment to chose a specific role, trying to minimize other players benefit from it. Loads to think about, much management... very good game indeed!

RATING: 9.5
Although there is a lot more to the game and a lot more constraints, I don’t want to get into each one. But if you like a lot of management and quick thinking, this is a must. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Based on one play.  Found it to be deep, but not hard to understand.  We were comfortable with the rules and flow of play within a couple rounds.  I love how everyone is involved throughout the game.  I was worried that due to the theme, I may have found it to be dry.  But it turned out to not be the case.  Everyone enjoyed the entire two hours it took to play and we all agreed we want to play it again.  I can see how many became quite addicted to this game.

One minor negative though:  This game has A LOT of set up and take down time, even if you keep all the stuff organized.

UPDATE:  Played several times now (I dont log every play).  The game deserves its high ramking.

ANOTHER UPDATE:  I am moving this down to a 9 from its previous perch at 10.  It is still a classic and always will be.  But I find that at times play gets scripted.  Also, in a 4 or 5 player game, you will at times feel like the outcome is beyond your control and there is little to nothing you can do to improve your position.

RATING: 7

The only down side is introducing it to newbies. I have yet to find a new player who has a chance against an opponent who has played it at least once. There is not enough time to make up for bad plays at the beginning. Another issue with new players is helping understand that Money is not the object, a paradigm shift from regular life.
