=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Beautiful, elegant. Almost perfect. It is the kind of game you always wanted to make, and play. Not for the immature gamer, as it is easy to make a bad play at just about any point in the session, and play king-maker. (Be patient with newbies) This game will be in my collection for as long as I game. I bought 2 extra copies because I will wear them all out over the next 20 years.

Oct 2014: I think I wrote the above words shortly after I joined BGG in the early 2000's. Since then, against my prediction, I've given away my extra copies, and my regular copy of the game, and did not wear them out. I did buy a sealed Anniversary Edition that I may break out some day. The people I play this with have copies, so I usually play theirs. Although not in my recorded plays, I have played PR easily more than 30 times face-to-face, and another 50 or so on the iOS App, the "PR Evolver" excel spreadsheet, or on Brett Spiel Welt. That's a pretty solid exploration of the game, but still far from what I anticipated, particularly in the face-to-face arena, particularly after 2005.

What happend that threw off my optimistic prediction of PR plays was probably 3 things: the incredible general expansion of the boardgame hobby, the evolution from German -> Euro ->  "hybrid" games, and the rise of the Tablet. (Ok, a fourth might be the arrival of Caylus - which I hate - and it's ilk, like Agricola - which I like very much).

(In 2014, it's rare but a real hobby grognard (like Mark Johnson of "Board Games to Go" fame) who can somewhat inteligibly define what a "German" game is anymore. I'm not going to bother. But suffice to say that game design and development has immensely benefited from general improvements in the internet (speed primarily), and social media. This led to the migration away from more theoretical "hard-core" games like PR, Tigris and Euphrates, and even El Grande.)

Anyway - more stuff has come out. Like everything else in the world today, the boardgame hobby has become fractionalized and turned into a multitude of niche interests.

I still love the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When I first purchased this game many years ago I really enjoyed it. After 5-10 games it's appeal quickly wore off. 

Experienced players will predict multiple turns in advanced as they wait for their own. It plays out almost mathematically. Those who need creative strategy should look elsewhere. The game is poorly balanced, throw one lesser experienced player into the mix and the person next in the cycle has a very strong advantage. 

The game has a slickness to it - little room for confusion once you know how to play. It kind of a reliable little game that will play as expected, but its not going to give you the 'WOW' moments that such a high rated game may lead you to believe. 

If you are a collector this is one to have on the shelf, but if you have $50 to buy just one good strategy game I would pass. 

   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Polo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
PO
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pros:
+Great gateway game once players have gotten into boardgames a bit more. This one brings a lot more depth without being too overwhelming.
+Interesting theme
+Game flows pretty smoothly, multiple ways to kill the game.
+A lot of depth and strategy.
+Extra "colonists" in case you lose them.

Cons:
-Pieces are so-so quality. The wood components are nice, but the cardboard is not that great.
-The colonists are very small. They have the potential to get lost easily.
-Theme is too dry for some people.
-Game is vastly different than what most people are used to, can be a bit much at the beginning until after a few rounds.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A great strategy game. You begin with a fistful of doubloons and a plantation, with a goal to benefit more from each role than your opponents. This game has much double-thinking, predicting "what my opponents will take next" and always keeps in you "in", as you play in every turn. Despite its static setup, each game turns out to be different and has room for a lot of strategies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
OWN Jan/04: Beautiful, well-balanced planning game, which plays best with 3-4 experienced people (5 is good too, but plays differently, and feels WAY more vicious).  Definite choices available for picking the highest-reward highest-screw-your-neighbours role per round, not necessarily just whatever's best for you.

But for casual gamers, or those that don't game together frequently, I feel that Puerto Rico would not be a good choice.  Too many building functions to learn; experience is just too valuable to allow newbies any chance to beat those that know the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is just brilliant. It is very well balanced and there are plenty of ways to win.

February 2011: I haven't been playing this much lately, but every time I do I wonder why this doesn't hit the table more often. One of the reasons I like this game is that it is very delicately balanced and there are many evenly strong strategies. In order to win with more experienced players you have to constantly think at least one turn ahead. However, even this clearly is a complex game, the rules are surprisingly simple and easy to learn.

RATING: 10
Used to play it with the wrong rules and it's much better with the right ones. :) 

There's a really good mix between tactics and strategy. You need to know where you want to go, but the tactical play each turn is where the game is played. Players' actions have a significant impact in everyone else's game. The base game is extremely balanced and it shows that a lot of work was made during development and playtesting. 

After more than 50 games played, none of the charm is lost. Wonderful game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It simply doesn't get any better than this.  Puerto Rico is basically a pure-strategy game.  Luck?  Fahgeddaboutit.  This is a HARD game to learn and I honestly don't know if it's possible to master.  I think it fair to say that when it is your turn there's almost never a clear "correct" choice,  instead you always have to choose between 2 or 3 very good and justifiable options. It's not until later that you'll find out if you made the right choice.

Definitely one of my all time favorites.

RATING: 9
There's nearly no luck at all in Puerto Rico, and nearly limitless ways in which to achieve victory.  Game design is very good, components are nice, the box design is stellar.  Everyone does something on every turn (a game mechanic we're seeing more often; Age of Mythology, Twilight Imperium 3rd) so there's very little personal downtime, and even when there is you're trying to figure out your next move(s).  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One Game to Rule Them All. Well, at least most of them...

It think it's not only the number of different ways to victory but also the absolutely fantastic artwork.
The colours of the personal gaming boards... yum!
Few games are as balanced as Puerto Rico is.

Edit: Well, the time goes on and gaming experiences change. Compared to those other 10-rated games in my collection, this one qualifies to the topmost ratings no more. This doesn't mean, that the game is bad. It's still better than most games.

Fun Factor: 6
Components: 7
Theme: 7
Mechanics: 9
Theme + Mechanics: 8
Replay Value: 9
Scaling/Players: 7
Subjective -0.5 Hit because the interaction is so indirect.  I need a bit more direct contact with opponents!

This game doesn't see as many plays as it should.  A bit dry for the persons I typically play with, unfortunately.  Otherwise the game is very solid, and stands on its own merits.  My complaint is that when all is said and done, there is a fairly steep strategic learning curve for new players.

RATING: 8
Played this game a lot with a few friends before I discovered BGG. Recently have only played 2P, and enjoy it. This prevents one player getting 2 choices in a row and introduces just a bit more cash. Only a couple plays this way, though, so more experimentation is in order. I'm interested in the 3-spot trading post and 3 ship variants posted here.

RATING: 9
01/11/12 - When I don't play Puerto Rico for a long time it gets into my head that the game is super fiddly and takes forever and that I'd rather be playing something more exciting. When I actually play I remember what a wonderful game this is and how it's full of meaningful choices and smooth worker placement mechanics. It's such a great game. (Rating: 8)

I played it again and it was just as good as the last time. Glad I have it.

10/21/12 - Again, it's been a long time since I've played it but it surprised me again. I really wish that they would re-theme it but keep it almost exactly the same. Puerto Rico is such a boring setting. I know there's Race for the Galaxy but it's not exactly the same. Maybe I'll re-theme and print and play it myself. (Rating: Upgraded to a 9)

RATING: 9
(10+ plays)  

Who can play? Strategy game for 3-5 players.

A strategy game where everyone does something on everyone's turn, so not a lot of waiting for things to happen.  Each turn someone chooses to take one of 7 unique roles, and each role can be chosen only once per turn - so the game flows very differently than other games.  Another of my many favorites.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Nearly never got to appreciate what a gem this is ... I purchased PR early on in my gaming infatuation (just after TTR - yes the #1 on BGG sucked me in !) but was set to trade it away in an Aussie math trade as each time I read the rules I could not get my head around it . Decided to get down and dirty with rules and give it a go before the trading deadline and after one play decided to hold onto it ..
Have since taught around 40 people to play - with almost unanimous success . I now wonder why I found it so hard to grasp the rules and gameplay when I see how well many others have picked it up . Will play this anytime and my admiration for it continues to build . Buy it !
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic game - many plays. One of my favorites. I can see owning and playing this game for the rest of my life. Are there some "strong" strategies? Yes. Does the game become a little scripted when you've played it many times? Perhaps. But Chess is a bit like that too. Patterns in this game are more in the form of strategies to counter the opponent. If an opponent leads in one area, you counter by playing in another area. If an opponent rushes the game by building quickly, you will likely enter that race to a full tableau, but the games can vary greatly in duration and strategy. Not so much "head to head" as "doing my own thing while keeping an eye on what my opponent is doing and reacting accordingly."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is actually two games, one for the occasional player and one for the expert player.  I have enjoyed my 5 or 6 plays enough, enjoy the multiple types of game options, but have never understood why I did well or poorly.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Yes, this game has very little luck in it, but it's there. I don't like complicated games in which turn order and role selection HEAVILY influence the game, because then the guy sitting to the right of you is having a massive impact on the game. I don't like being to the leftof another experienced player, who happens to have a newbie to the right of him. It wrecks the game that apparently has 'perfect' balance. In my book, anything that snags a 7 or higher is a fantastic game, and this is fantastic - but I've never seen a game so massively impacted by seating order. 

Yes, Race for the Galaxy can have situations where you unexpectedly play into an opponents hand, but PR can absolutely destroy you if an unfortunate sequence of roles are chosen. There's no contest of comparison, which is why RftG doesn't get dinged so much in this regard.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic euro. I love the way you have to utilize your workers and make sure everything you want to use has a worker to operate it. I love the mechanic. A great game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Let me try to say something useful about this game:  it moves very quickly, with very little downtime.  Each decision is important, and good foresight is tremendously essential in order to win.  The same strategy will not work every game, and depending on your fellow players and seating order, you will need to adapt on the fly, usually changing or tweaking your chosen strategy.  Finally, experience results in more victories.  I have played far more than my friends, and tend to win about 75-80% of the time.  On a bad note, there can be a "bad choice effect" that helps one player more than the others, knocking one or more skilled players from contention strictly due to seating order.  When played among good players, though, it has few rivals, especially 3 or 4 player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fiddly setup aside, this is a nearly perfect game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My only critics (after only playing the game once) is that it gets slow at the end as all the different rule bending cards come into play

(compared to Concordia and Clash to Cultures). Its mechanism of leader action and other players will follow is cool and a lot of other games seem copied it. It is a classic game that we all should own.

2013-12-17 --- Just bought it as got a 30% less discount. Heard that it is a heavy game. Still don't have time to open its box. :P

RATING: 8

None of us knowing French, we eventually interpreted his words and gestures as him asking who won.  We pointed at my brother and he eyed James, then my little sister and I, snorted, pointed at James and said... "plus grande!" Haha!  

Anyways, I like it, I wish my siblings and I played it more.

San Juan is a nice simplified version of this game that may more easily be played a couple of times in an evening.

RATING: 9.5
Justifiably popular.  The greatest strength of PR to my mind is the almost complete elimination of the element of luck in the game; you have to rely on planning ahead, but at the same time being flexible enough to respond to changes resulting from the actions of other players.  Fairly quick to play, and always enjoyable (even though I seldom win!).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
For a change, this typical German-style game is not thin on theme, with a logical game flow and almost every building and role making sense. Only a few feel like add-ons to the game-mechanics (like the 25% VP bonus). The richness of options (incl. the variable phase order and the rearranging of colonists) offer variable paths to what can be a very close game.
There is only one thing missing for me to give it a 10: the fun factor that e.g. Cartagena or Intrigue have. Puerto Rico is more of a tense, serious affair.

RATING: 1
A serious, nerdish game. Naturally, some combos are clearly a lot better than others, so the luck of the draw can be a big factor. Sadly it's another typical euro-trash game with a boring & soulless mechanic. BArey any player interractions which is quite sad for a boardgame when your suppose to interract with the other players, otherwise why are you into boardgame ? lol

The only interaction is in choosing roles, and if someone picks the one you wanted you'll have to completely re-think your selection. The whole thing is clunky, with a zero excitement level, and after your turn you can go read a book for a few minutes. Oh, yeah -- the game drags on far too long, and I pondered quitting after the first two hours. 

My second and third plays found me constantly thinking "When will it end, already!?" It was a complete pain to endure. I hope I never have to play again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I know Puerto Rico (PR) is many people's favourite game. But though I find the mechanic for choosing actions an interesting one, the rest of the game just doesn't click for me. The game is about producing different types of goods and trading them for victory points. You do it by buying buildings and manning them with settlers. Despite there being five types of goods, they are all worth the same in VP terms. The good type is only important when selling a good for cash in the trade house (an action severly restricted throught the game) and determining how many units can be sold, as each ship can only carry one good type (go guess why...). Of course you can also buy buildings to "bend" the rules in your favour and to get extra VP, but, all in all, PR feels rather plain.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.8
What can I say?  Its Puerto Rico.  The game to which all others are compared.  I was surprised to see, way down at the bottom of the scale the (often amusing) vitriolic criticism of this game.  While I can appreciate that no game is EVERYONE's cup of tea, I must wonder if some of these people really are gamers and are turned off by the the depth (beyond parcheezi) or are uber-patient and have hours and hours at a time to play the often tedious games they mention.   

This game does not play itself. And I do not ask monkeys to play so it does not take forever to explain to newbies.

RATING: 7
Bringing the rating down to a 7.  After owning this title for over a year now, I can say it really grows on you in time.  At first I wasn't so keen, but after a while of playing and seeing so many different types of games played, it's great to know that it'll always be a fun time whn the PR comes out.  Many of my friends went from "What the heck is Puerto Rico?" to "Puerto Rico's a lot of fun!" in under 2 hours.

When do I play this?:
Best played with board-game inclined friends and newbies.  It can be daunting to teach, but once the concept is grasped it's accessible to all but the youngest of children.

RATING: 8
Not a 10 for me, but I'd never turn down a game.  The most dangerous part of this game is the "weak link" mechanism.  If the guy to your right sucks, you have a better chance of winning, which can be a tough pill to swallow for everyone else.  This game is a 10 when played with a even playing field, though goes to an 8 when playing with a weak link.

RATING: 8
Original boardgame that "San Juan" cardgame was based on. It is (a little) longer and heavier than SJ, with several more things to think about.

Can be played with official 2-player variant (from "Alea"), although it isn't as good with only 2 players(?) or at least not as good with 2 as SJ is.

WARNING: Minimal luck involved - might develop into quite scripted sequence of play / openings, although there appear to be many possiblities to try. The gameplay itself would still likely be enjoyable anyway.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
So far the best implemented mechanic of role-action selection (seen in Verrater and adopted in Citadels), being that once chosen each player executes that action to a lesser degree, rather than wait for their turn to choose a role. However this mechanic is repetitive and is less fun than the bluffing way it was employed in Citadels. And lack of fun is an issue I have with this game. It is a dry exercise of evaluating your best options to maximise your victory points, not much randomness except with the plantation tile draws. So this is a game for those who like to explore the way buildings and roles interact to develop tactics and strategies. It doesn't help first timers that evaluating involves text reading of the effects of the numerous buildings which makes play confusing and slows pace; personally I prefer coloured symbols for the buildings and having a player aid to refer to. And because I've seen Amistad and read Serpent & the Rainbow I relate too much to the very strong theme of black slavery; I play games at times to engage my narrative attitude to have fun and promote an atmosphere, and when I play Puerto Rico I have to abandon this attitude which then reduces the rating. Still I appreciate this design as one of best in the business management style of game, which I guess is one reason alot of people enjoy it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
-

At the pinnacle of multi-player board game genre. A fantastic game design. Unlike most games, the more I play it, the more respect I have for it. Many facets of the game are quite impressive: its elegance, clean mechanics, nice flow, multi-dimentional, infinite replayability, no down time, etc, etc... A masterpiece that is destined to become a classic. 

-

RATING: 9
I really like Puerto Rico, but I am starting to think that it's not random enough. This is bad because victory and defeat can be at the mercy of where you are sitting with respect to the bad player, which makes the game more random than other games with real random elements.

Having said that, the mechanics are brilliant, and the game is a terrific thought problem. I highly recommend Puerto Rico!

RATING: 8
The biggest complaint that I've heard about this game is that it is ultimately solvable -- there are correct and incorrect actions that players can take at any given time. I haven't dealt with this...I (and all of the players in my game group) are TERRIBLE at this game, and as a result, we end up with a pretty wide array of play styles. I love the game at this point because I haven't "figured it out." Only time will tell if it gets stale as I improve, but for now, it's one of my favorites.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[floatleft][ImageID=93199][/floatleft][b][u]Initial Impressions:[/u][/b]
No one can deny the greatness of Puerto Rico (PR) which has stood at the top of the BGG rankings mountain for years and years. I think people sometimes forget how great a game PR is because it has been around for so long and was played with such intense frequency when people first learned of it. PR was a game changer over a decade ago and it helped bring the modern Euro to the forefront of the board gaming world. 

[b][u]What I like:[/u][/b]
So many games mimic the role selection mechanism in Puerto Rico for good reason. It's brilliant.

[b][u]What I dislike:[/u][/b]
I think what I dislike most about Puerto Rico, and most people will agree with this, is that there really are only two distinct avenues to victory: violet buildings or shipping lots of goods via the Captain. I still love this game though.

[b][u]Overall:[/u][/b]
PR has withstood the test of time for over a decade. Very few games can make such a claim. If there was a Board Gaming Hall of Fame, there is no question that PR would be one of the first games to be inducted.

I upgraded to the Collector's Edition copy and sold off my standard copy.

[i]The captain is an a$$hole.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I originally gave this a 7, but after 3 games, I'm a believer. Played 2 games with local gaming groups, then bought it. Taught the game to my 10 year old daughter who loved it. I'm always ready to play so I can try a different strategy. Addictive!

31/10/17: 2pl with Derek @ TLGC. Excellent game.

P: 2-5, T: 60 min, ON BGA
+No luck outcomes, all based on player decisions. Many paths to victory and paying attention to other players actions. Encourages many strategies and adapting to game conditions mid-game.

=A bit complex, beginning players will likely need 1-2 plays to get a grasp of the rules 

-A bit like multiplayer solitaire, player interaction can seem too subtle for some. Some buildings aren't ever used. 2 player set-up suboptimal

You're doing coffee?  Alright.  I won't do coffee.  You're going after that building?  Alright.  Me, too.  Aw, someone else got there first.  There goes my entire strategy.  Oh well.  Want to play again?  Nah, me either.  
I'd put this in the same category as Catan.  It was innovative at the time, but I need some chrome on my games these days.  This just doesn't scratch the Euro itch the way it did ten years ago.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
So what's the deal here anyway?  Is each player in a parallel universe with their own island of Puerto Rico?  And are these parallel universes somehow synced up in such a way that when goods are shipped in one of the Puerto Ricos, they must also be shipped in all of the others?  Some kind of quantum entanglement perhaps?

I can't answer these questions, but I can say that this is truly a design masterpiece.  It definitely has some weaknesses, but playing a game with experienced players is a great challenge, and more importantly, great fun!  This is by no means a "luckless" game.  The random plantation draw is a much bigger factor than most people think.  On the other hand, the plantation draw keeps the game fresh by making each play a different experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
What can I say that hasn't been said before? Well: this is the game design that all other games should be judged on. If there is such thing as a perfect design, this game would have my vote. 

Update: This game has lost a bit of its luster. It's not that it isn't a fantastic game. It is just that board game design has improved so much that other games have managed to outshine it.

It still has the best balance of long term strategy and short term tactics and the perfect play time.

RATING: 7
After 6 playings and a lot of tutorial discussions with my son, I'm beginning to figure this game out. Everyone needs to be on the same level in this game or the player after the dolt (aka ME!) has a huge advantage.  Need a lot more thought on the more expensive building tiles and on how to optimize what the player before me allows me while minimizing what I allow the player after me.  Certain strategies and devious/heinous tactics, if allowed to occur, will effectively end the game.  Like Chess, once a winning position is obvious, no need to play out the remainder of the turns. Very good, but not great, game; WAY over-rated on BGG. (My gut gives it a 6, my head thinks I should be able to play well enough to admit to a 7).

RATING: 9.25
Excellent game. I recently introduced this game to my gaming group. They suddenly wanted to play it again. And again. And again. 

As we broke up for the night conversation focused on ideal strategies, what errors we may have made, when we would want to add the expansion. And when we would play Puerto Rico again.

I have never seen my group get so excited about a new (for us) game. So I granted Puerto Rico my first 10 rating. Then I realized I was just so excited at scoring such a hit with my group. A rating of 10 means "Always want to play and expect this will never change."

Update: realistically, I can't justifiably give this a rating of 10. It will have to suffer with being my highest rated game at 9.25.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There's just something about putting those little disks on your plantations and seeing the goods roll in!  In Puerto Rico you operate a plantation and can produce several different goods.  It's your job to provide employees and buildings, which give you certain benefits.  Can you put your benefits to work for you and earn the most points?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a game!!
The bits could have been better (imagine 3D plastic buildings, little colonistmeeples, wooden toy boats...) but the gameplay is just perfect.
There are lots of options and it's very little luck dependent. Each time the optimal role choice is different, and usually not any obvious. It's always fun, but as players are more experienced the game gets better.
Plus, it's quite tactical: you've got to be very flexible and open minded as there is not such a thing as a best strategy that can be applied to every game. It depends on the other players actions. That's real interaction and that's what makes PR fascinating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Played at: mine & Asda
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
First impression:
Played a two player variant. The game turned out very smootly. There's a lot of possibilities and you have to manage the fact that you opponent will do the same move as you. So you need to make sure that you won't advantage him more than you. The goods management, without being revolutionnary, his effective.
There his a definit learning curve. You need to learn all the building fonctions to be good and built yourself a strategy during the game.
Deserve to be in the top 10 on BGG but may be not first.
Can't wait to try it in a multiple player game.

Update: Played a 3 player game. Even better this time, upgraded my cote from 8.3 to 8.75.

Première impression:
Partie à deux à l'aide d'une variante. La partie s'est déroulée de façon très fluide. Il y a beaucoup de possibilité et vous devez gérer le fait que votre adversaire fera la même action que vous. Vous devez donc vous assurer de ne pas l'avantager plus que vous. La gestion des biens, sans être révolutionnaire, s'avère efficace. Il y a une courbe d'apprentissage définitive pour ce jeu. On doit connaître le rôle de chaque bâtiment afin d'être bon et de pouvoir se bâtir une stratégie à ce jeu. Mérite d'être dans le top 10 de BGG mais peut-être pas en première place. J'ai bien hate de jouer une partie à plusieurs joueurs.

Mise à jour: Nous avons joué une partie à trois joueurs. Le jeu s'avère encore meilleur. J'augmente la cote de 8.3 à 8.75.

RATING: N/A
There's a lot of good stuff going on in this one. It's a great example of a worker-placement Eurogame, and the role-selection mechanic just flat-out works. It's exactly what it claims to be: a dry, strategic, largely non-random and well-balanced Euro. If games that are dry, strategic, non-random, or European make you balk, you should move on. But if those types make you happy, you can get a lot of mileage from it.

Tentative rating: 7.5/10 it might not be for me, and that's ok.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I am surprised that I had not rated this until now. A classic game that I enjoy, especially with a random selection of buildings from the original as well as the expansion. The base game has been analyzed nearly to death, but with the expansion there is a lot more fluidity to the game, a greater need for tactical skill in dealing with a changing environment. This is easily a top-shelf game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's hard to say something that hasn't been said about Puerto Rico.  I'm sure nothing I say is new and the only unique thing about what I say is that I said it.

How does Puerto Rico work?  There are two major parts.  First players all have identical player boards that represent a section of the eponymous island and a piece of the city San Juan.  Players have spaces to develop plantations of various kinds and build buildings.  Plantations produce various goods, though Corn is the only good that doesn't require an accompanying building, while the buildings provide special powers.  The produced goods can be converted into money, necessary for building buildings, or points, necessary for winning the game.  A neat twist in game terms, though the cause of some social controversy, is that plantations and buildings need to be manned by "colonists" in order to perform their function.  A good player in Puerto Rico will get a combination of buildings and plantations that efficiently work together, producing more VPs relative to the other players per action taken.

That's what players do, but the other major part of the game concerns the method by which things get done: role selection.  Everything in this game is done with role selection, from producing goods, to hiring colonists to building buildings.  In Puerto Rico you can't just say, "I got money so I want to build a building".  Rather you have to select the Builder role and in doing so, you give everyone else the opportunity to build a building, assuming they have the cash.  If the Builder has already been picked when your turn comes around to pick a role, you are out of luck till the end of the round and all roles become available again.

This makes timing critical.  Sometimes your "best" role choice will help another player out much more than it will you.  Good players put themselves in a position where other players' role selections help them while their own role selection will either minimally help, or even hurt other players.  Figuring out how to ride these various waves is my favorite part about Puerto Rico.  However, many people hate it.  They don't like that a weak player can set up a wave that really helps others.  Frankly, I think such players take this game too seriously.  So what if a noob gives the game to another player, if he has fun then he'll play again and eventually get better.  Rule wise the game is very simple.  What complications there are arise from the plethora of powers the buildings provide and how their effects can snowball.  Set up is kind of fiddly, but over all Puerto Rico is a solid game and preferable to many of its descendants.

Speaking of descendants, it's hard to believe that at one point when we talked about German/Euro games we meant Settlers of Catan, El Grande, Tikal, Ra and Tigris and Euphrates.  Now the genre is dominated and almost defined by "efficiency engines" and Puerto Rico is the originator of this trend.  Sure there were efficiency engines before Puerto Rico.  Outpost and Princes of Florence spring immediately to mind.  But neither one of those games defined a genre that has been hemorrhaging games of various quality ever since.  Caylus, Leonardo Da Vinci, Pillars of the Earth, Stone Age, Dominion, Agricola and Le Harve, not to mention card games like Race for the Galaxy and San Juan are all part of this genre [Note: as of Oct 2009 4 of the top 10 games on BGG are games of this type while Space Hulk has knocked a fifth down to number 11].  

The link between these games and Puerto Rico is not just that they are efficiency engines, but that they are role selection games as well.  Prior to Puerto Rico players would have fought over who could do what using some kind of auction.  By not having an auction Puerto Rico changed the game.

In my opinion the most innovative element of Puerto Rico is not its efficiency engine-ness or its role selection.  Rather, Puerto Rico is a phasing game but on a turn, when a player chooses the role they want, they are also choosing the phase that the game will enter next.  Most games of this kind, like Power Grid or Age of Steam, are vary rigorous in the way they step the players through the phases.  Oddly enough, this element of Puerto Rico is the least copied.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Rules are very intuitive (the game mechanics and the theme are so well integrated, and the game itself is so easy to teach) and turns go by quickly. Because there is no hidden information, it's much easier to make rule clarifications during the game.

Personally, I admire this game—I like its economic model—but I prefer games with positional tactics. More significantly, this is a game in which you make very little major decisions (although these decisions have a huge impact on your game). The rest of the decisions you make in this game are rather straightforward. I would rather have more turn angst—or rather, I’d rather have my angst better distributed.


UPDATE: Downgrade to a 4. Will always keep this game because it is so easy for newbies to play. But I prefer to play against players, not a system.

RATING: 8.5
The upside:
-The first love. Eye-opener, groundbreaker, masterpiece.
-In the core is a role selection mechanism that I like, but what really makes it for me is being able to have everyone take the same action but a bonus given to whom selected it.
-Lot's of buildings to incorporate in your strategy, and the same one can be considered broken, worthless, to just right in different games, the key is the obvious "select the right ones for what you're doing".

The downside:
-It's been studied so much that you stumble everywhere with optimal strategies, plays, openings, etc. I guess it only happens to the great ones.
-I can't say it is as fresh as it once was, but which is?

RATING: 9
The passage of time has made me appreciate Puerto Rico much more than I used to.  I've always liked it, but after 7 plus years playing boardgames, I've realized just how well designed this game is.  It might be a little dry and overly deterministic for some, and I can somewhat sympathize with that.  But I tend not to be bothered by those elements in a game, if the rest of the game can provide me with the kinds of decision making I find engaging about games in general.  In my opinion, there are few middle-weight euros that provide this much depth of gameplay, and Puerto Rico is certainly one of the best of that few.

RATING: 9
This is a great game.  Always a favourite at game night and never seems to get old.  The strategy is difficult and the randomness of the plantation tiles keeps you on your toes enough that you can't employ the same strategy game in and game out without changing the game play.  There is no direct player interaction, but every move you make immediately affects everyone on the board so the indirect interaction creates quite a bit of tension without making the game a friend ender.  Great fun.

When we purchased the game it didn't have enough pieces for a 5 player game, so we were sent a new copy which ALSO didn't have enough pieces for a 5 player game.  We combined the two and made a game large enough for six.  That being said, 5 players are a bit much for this game so I wouldn't get too hung up on that.  

The other downside is in game artwork is extremely lacking.  It's as though they put so many resources into game play development that they just didn't even bother to decorate building tiles.  It's not the most aesthetic game ever.

But in conclusion these negatives are external and have zero effect on the quality of the game.  You can find variants for two players as well.  We've found the best 2P variant to be one where the governor selects two roles and the second player selects one role, like the San Juan game.  It speeds up game play and brings in more strategy that going through all roles every round.    Depending on your gaming crowd expect games with first time players to run a minimum of 2.5 hours.   Once players understand the mechanics (usually after one playthrough) the game shortens quite a bit. We've yet to find a person who didn't enjoy this one.  I hope you do as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Playing with the Wednesday group, they were all veterans of this game. Took me a while but now I can hold my own. You can't do much better with 5 people than this

RATING: 8
Similar to Caylus, it took me a while to "get" this game, and really understand and appreciate the far reaching implications of even my minor decisions.  I do think there is some merit to the notion that where you sit can be a benefit based on how good the other players are, but I also think it is slightly overstated.

Maybe you could have people bid VPs for seating order, with the higher bidders choosing their seat later (highest bidder choosing last).  This would nicely handicap the players that thought themselves "better" while still allowing those players to make a tactical decision on that aspect of the game.  Might as well let the highest bidding player name the "starting" player as well.

RATING: 7
This is one of the few games where my enjoyment is very dependent on my opponents.  If the players are casual Puerto Rico players, I enjoy the game quite a bit and have fun enjoying the ride.  However, if my opponents are dedicated players, that have analyzed the tech tree and have min/maxed the game to its fullest extent, the enjoyment of the experience plummets quite a bit.  While that can probably be said for many games, there aren't dedicated people out there for many other games, but it isn't hard to find one for Puerto Rico.  So, because of this, it must reside somewhere on the 6 or 7 scale on the BGG system, because I'm not ALWAYS willing to play, but I am with the right crowd.  I'll go with the higher rating and give it a seven.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Very good and deep Euro with only a minimum of randomness (and variety). This is really a classic now, but still sees a lot of plays, because of its solid mechanisms. First (or  at least most importantly) it is game with action/role selection, which determines the action for all players. 

Producing, selling and shipping goods is thematic at first glance. But since turn order is that important in Puerto Rico and  every action sets your opponents up as well, you cannot play this game just with thematic intuition. You really need a few games to understand the game. This makes Puerto Rico very rewarding for "core" gamers, but in my view it is exceptionally bad for a gateway game (I have seen discussions, in which it was recommended as a gateway). The most clever but also for new gamers least intuitive mechanism is the forced shipping in combination with rotting resources: If you produce resources with the plan to sell them and then someone becomes captain, you will ship or lose most of your resources. This is a rather unforgiving, but very iconic mechanism of Puerto Rico, which really awards experience with the game. 

I do not rate Puerto Rico higher, because this really feels much more like playing the mechanisms and less like playing a game of Caribbean economy and trading. But I have  to give credit that this mechanisms are really good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Only played the iPad version, but after a bunch of games, the depth of strategy really shines here. High quality experience with very interesting decisions!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It was not so bad as to indict a total avoidance of the game in the future, but I would rather play a good game or a newer game than this.

RATING: 8.5

RATING: 9.5
Players: 2-5
Time: 90-150 min.  

Players are colonizing the island of Puerto Rico and producing crops in the plantations as well as constructing buildings in San Juan. Players have several paths to victory and many tactical decisions to make. The fun of the game is building your own "business", seeing how well it works and choosing from many different options. There is little downtime as every player has decisions to make regardless of whose "turn" it is.

RATING: 10
It stayed at number 1 for years for a reason.  It is that good.  The players are plantation owners in Puerto Rico in the days when ships had sails. Growing up to five different kind of crops: Corn, Indigo, Coffee, Sugar and Tobacco, they must try to run their business more efficiently than their close competitors; growing crops and storing them efficiently, developing San Juan with useful buildings, deploying their colonists to best effect, selling crops at the right time, and most importantly, shipping their goods back to Europe for maximum benefit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Hand Management
Simultaneous Action Selection
Variable Phase Order
Variable Player Powers

RATING: 8
An excellent game with only minor
problems in game design:

The game has a number of buildings
which are overpriced and thus rarely
are purchased.

The game tends to end earlier than I
would have thought best; and thus
Many interesting strategies are not
Feasible because the game ends before
they can effectively get going.
Thus also game strategy tends to follow 
a few patterns of development repeatedly
Instead of allowing a greater range of 
players decisions
or strategic options.

All in all however this is a fine game.

RATING: 7
This is one of those classic games which I've never really played enough to get into, and appreciate its depths. But more or less everyone else in my group feels similarly to me - that it's a good game, and always enjoyable to play, but never one that comes to mind as a "we must play this again" when choosing a game on a game night.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We've only played this once and we screwed up the rules even, but I can see that this game is going to become a family favorite. The game mechanics of role selection, worker placement and economic development are fun and educational. It's fun to build your plantations and factories, man them and then produce your goods. There something satisfying about that to me. The only thing holding me back from rating this a 10 is the enormous learning curve for non-gamers. It's an odd thing though...as soon as you've "got it" it doesn't seem difficult at all, but try explaining it to someone who doesn't play these kinds of games and...wow...it's not easy to explain. It's a bit fiddly with LOTS of pieces-parts and the setup time can be a pain if you don't separate the pieces well. But despite that, it's an awesome game.

UPDATE: I've played probably closer to 60+ games of PR now and it is a truly awesome game. You'd think it would get repetitive, but not really. This a truly a classic that will stand the test of time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great game, but mastery of this game system is for greater minds than myself.

RATING: 10
Hervorragend!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
Puerto Rico is a clever game with real replay value, but in my opinion it has two huge disadvantages:

The points required for victory are "hidden", which means (given all players match each other) you never know who is in the lead. This results in an absence of climax and satisfaction.

Next to this, when you play this game with unexperienced players, I get the feeling there is not enough interaction between players as novices usually try optimize their own board, rather than interfere with actions of other players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Now a classic, I still enjoy this one, probably because I have avoided reading any strategy articles. Experienced players have their favorite routes to victory; I'm taking a different approach. I'm slowly eliminating all the methods of losing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Clearly, this game is well thought out and offers a near luck-independent experience.

That's not to say it is exempt from defects and one of them is that each player's score and therefore the winner is heavily influenced by who is around the table, and what strategy they pursue.

On the one hand this makes it a tactical game worthy of its salt, but on the other it reduces greatly the viability of quite a few game-length strategies and my expectation is that after the initial dozen games where you explore different paths the game will feel like a rinse and repeat if you don't inject the group with new blood.

... trouble is, new blood and old guard really don't mix well in this game and benefit from pitting players of equal standard against one another...

Played with 4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Update (8/08):  Puerto Rico was one of the first games I purchased in my return to gaming. In that context it was a 10 since all I had to compare it to was Settlers of Catan, Roborally, Magic, and all the Parker Bros. stuff. My collection of games is much broader now and there are games that I just would rather play if given a choice. There are also games that are derivative of Puerto Rico such as Twilight Imperium 3 and Race for the Galaxy that I find much more exciting and fun. So, design-wise Puerto Rico is a classic but in all honestly I am never the one to suggest playing it--although I always have fun when I do play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very good game for people who want a lot to think about.  This is, I believe, a game for more detail-oriented people, who like to open up a watch and figure out what all the gears do.  Not to say that it's so terribly complicated--it's very easy to pick up, because the theme is an excellent fit and the game mechanics are surprisingly intuitive.  But you have to pay attention to so many details of what other people have.  As much as I like this game (I do really like it), it's not quite my cup of tea.  But I can see why others would really REALLY like it.  Chess : Puerto Rico :: Physics : Biology.  Get it?    UPDATE:  Clicking together for me as a nice light game, rather than the intricate hard-game I had thought it was.  Like a machine with lots of bright buttons that are fun to push.  May change my mind with further plays.

RATING: 4
Traded this away to Jeremy Avery (familygaming).  I used to rate this a 10, but I think I was just caught up in the PR GeekFever of '02.  It certainly is a masterfully designed game, it's just not *my* type of game.  The part I dislike most is the "stifling."  Essentially, each move consists of figuring out how to stifle your opponent so they won't be able to do anything productive on their move.  This is the same reason I don't really like Detroit-Cleveland Grand Prix or Cartagena.

RATING: 6
I admit that this is a good design. But this kind of encapsulates everything about the modern Euro design, BGG fetish object that leaves me cold - tightly constrained play options, optimizable starts, coldness. It's all the work of calculative exhaustion of go without any of the profound ringing payoff. Compare it to: the psychological fluidity and drama of El Grande, the tenseness and desperation of Taj Mahal...

I'll probably still avoid pulling this out very often - it's a pretty dry experience for the most part - and only with people that don't play it religiously.

RATING: 8
I've had a lot of fun with this game so far. It has many choices, and the game becomes faster paced and more angst-inspiring as it goes along. I tried to play it once or twice on BSW, but that's incredibly boring. I would strongly suggest playing it face to face with some friends. 

The best advice I can give is this: avoid outside analysis of the game. Just play it and enjoy it. It seems that most people get bored with it after they do the chess-like analysis that Puerto Rico is prone to.

My rating is based on the advice that it not be studied. I suspect my rating will go down as I learn more about the game. For a fully studied rating, I would put it at a 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Most everyone should be familiar with this one. It is a classic game where each player builds buildings and shipps goods to gain victory points.  The thing that sets this game apart is the role selection. Players choose there rolls which allow the player to play that action with an added benefit, however all the other players get to do that same action too. Players must always guage whether it helps them out or other players out more.  This is a classic game which I will always play.

Pros: unique role selection, little downtime between turns,fun decision making process.

Cons: specific avenues for victory, not a high production value.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Amazon
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Until Agricola came into my life, Puerto Rico stood as the "most complicated" game I had ever played. The role selection dynamic is fantastic (you choose a role, perform it first (with a bonus), and then your opponents all perform the role). As with most games, you must think ahead to what your opponents will do, but in Puerto Rico, your position and timing of future actions are often more important than your current action.

This leads to repeated situations where choosing the role that benefits you most at that moment is a poor decision.

Another great aspect of Puerto Rico is that rarely do you feel that you are hopelessly behind. Or maybe I'm just an eternal optimist! Best of all, the luck factor is the lowest of any game I've ever played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A well-deserved classic status!
But sometimes I feel it should have been a bit longer than an 1 hour-game...

The pieces are easily set up, without much color confusion....it evokes the colonial economies and the age of West African slavery very well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Classic for a reason. Like any good euro, you are constantly thinking about all the moves you want to do, but probably don't have time to do. However, the twist in Puerto Rico, with the role selection, is that you might not want to take the role directly despite your desire for it, hoping someone else will do it for you. That whole element adds quite a bit of depth here as you consider when to pass up a role and when it is worth taking. It's a wonderful decision tree.

RATING: 8
Lapkák: Magyarított HomeMade verzió.
A BGG-n elérhető redesign majd egy egész pontot dob a játék értékelésén! Máskülönben eléggé prototípusszerű a grafikai kivitelezése, ha lehet ilyet mondani erre a klasszikus nagyágyúra.

A mechanika kifogástalan, elegáns, egyszerű. Mégis valami (meg nem tudnám mondani, hogy mi) még hiányzik nekem ahhoz, hogy tökéletes 10-esre tudjam értékelni. Jó, egyrészt az, hogy a személyes kedvenceim a "szimulátor" jellegű játékok; de másrészt meg valami más (lehet már kissé elhaladt felette az idő?). Na, persze ez mind túlzás, nagyon jó játék a fenti okfejtéstől függetlenül.
---
Eladtam, mert úgy döntöttem, hogy inkább beruházok az új kiadásra!

RATING: 6.5
[color=#CC0000]

I just don't see why this game gets such stellar reviews.  

Given the nature of the setup it's largely play-by-committee.  You can leave for fifteen minutes, miss two of your turns and it won't matter -- the rest of the folks at the table can pick the right action for you and play it out.

A good game, but not a great one.

RATING: 9
PR is simply put one of the best games ever made. The mechanics are clean and the games just flows. Little AP but lots of options. There are several strategies each of which can be successful. Update: After more and more plays (far too many) I have noticed that due to the near identical set up every game that certain patterns appear and most games are somewhat similar. Thus this game has been somewhat lowered. Still a great game, but not the best.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Puerto Rico is a game with deep strategic play offering more than one path to victory due to the abstract method employed to gain points.  Each turn players select a role from the pool which gives each player an action, but the chooser gains a bonus.  The roles vary from adding a plantation, adding workers, building, producing goods, shipping goods, selling goods, and being greedy and taking money.  Shipping is the only role with an action that grants points, while two roles grant money which is used to build buildings which are worth points at the end of the game.  Production only works if you have a plantation and a production building of the same kind and they are both staffed.  Players will find they need to carefully balance what roles they pick at what times, and have a few backup plans as someone may choose a role at a disadvantageous time.

Players do not directly interact, however after shipping goods players may find themselves with spoilage causing all but one of their goods to be discarded.  The plantations and buildings in the game are finite, not every player will get what they want, so players must choose the right time to act or else lose out.  There are three end-game triggers, so it is difficult to delay the game, and if you are not paying close attention the game may end before you realize it.  There are a few good strategies for winning the game, but not all of them will work for each play, so players need to maintain a Plan B while also doing some form of damage control.

Puerto Rico offers depth of play and rewards careful planning and adaptability.  There is no luck in the game, though the forces at play cannot always be predicted.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Strategy (3.3/5.0)

RATING: 5.5

RATING: 8
My favorite game -- hasn't changed after all these years.  Can be taught to new players fairly easily, and the game play is quick.  

It does suffer from disparate skill levels causing newbies to accidentally throw the games to experienced players, but the game itself is still wonderful.

My casual gamers are iffy on this.  This is a GREAT litmus test game -- if a new player to my group sits down at PR and says "I need to play this again!", they are a gamer at heart.

My first thought after playing this game (and again after my first 20 plays) was "Oh.  Ok.  NOW I got it figured out!  Let's play again"

RATING: 7
The game is very good and I would still gladly pay it in an evenly skilled group, but that's the catch: add a newbie and you can as well crown the player on their left the winner. I don't have a constant group which is the main reason this doesn't land on the table as often as it has a potential for. It's also not as fun for me to play it with either newbies or experienced gamers. Other disadvantages are tacked on theme and below average producing. On the plus side, the game has lots of replayability even without the expansion and what is a good move and not depends on the number of players involved.  If you want a quicker, but deep game for a constant group it's hard to beat though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Has climbed in the ratings for me. It really is a clever, fun little game, and a good challenge for the brain without being a brain burner. Hard choices and the ability to play different strategies and still be competitive make this a good game. There's a combination of buildings that will work for you if you can find it, based upon what your opponents are doing and what you've done up to any point. The game starts out by players usually looking to get some sort of income stream going, but with the money being added to unused roles and other opportunities coming early, this doesn't fall into that category of game where predictably each player has to build an income engine before they switch over to earning victory points. That's one of the strengths of the game - there's great variety and many ways to approach it. Top stuff.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A "pure skill" game that is extremely streamlined.  Masterful.

RATING: 9
The grand-daddy of gamer games, PR uses almost no luck as players use the cleverly designed role selection to determine what they will do next.  The brillant design is such that during each player's turn, everyone is involved and doing something.  This makes downtime non-existant and strategies are constantly changing on the fly.  The only downfall may be the lack of luck and randomness makes replayability a bit less for some seasoned veterans.

RATING: 9
Is any euro really meant to be analyzed within an inch of its shelf-life like Puerto Rico has been?  Yet, it has withstood all that analysis and remains a challenging and clever game.  If it has a fault, it's probably that it's very unforgiving, and a small mistake can essentially put you out of contention early on, which is fairly unusual for euros.  Primarily a tactical game of selecting the right role at the right time to be prepared for the builder, trader and captain, overall strategic play is a must.  A well-planned shipping, building or mixed strategy can win the game.

I've played it at least once a month for the last 3 yrs. I still think its great, my friends still think its great, and while I have a pretty steady strategy, it isn't a guaranteed win so there is always room for manuever. This one has stood the test of time, so rates a 10.

The mechanics is well designed. Maybe too much, there is almost no place for entertainment in this computer-like system.

DEPTH ★★★✰✰
I can feel that there are strategies to understand, but I'm not sure I'll have the patience nor the motivation to dig into them.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A classic that might look dated nowadays, but still grips you when you're in the game. Puerto Rico perfected the Action Choice Drafting mechanism, putting a twist such that you often do not want to pick a phase and let your opponent free-ride, but instead should set yourself up to free-ride and let your opponent pick it, such that he wastes a turn. The whole game is about setting yourself up to free-ride based on your prediction of sequential events. The only complaint is the fixed turn order (which results in left-of-newbie wins).

This is so much better than Agricola because the preset buildings are finely balanced and combine with each other in a multitude of ways, allowing you to play a much more satisfying perfect-information game (whereas Agricola's Family Game only has legs for fewer than 5-10 plays). That said, it often does seem like the first player to 2 out of Factory-Wharf-Harbor wins (at least in 3er, which I've played the most). Get all 3 and it's game over. I'm very intrigued whenever I see building-strategy victories.

4+3

[b][color=gray]Favorite 4-player Med-length - Runner-up[/color][/b]

RATING: 9
I've played it a lot despite the fact that I'm not very good at it :-)  That should tell you something.  It's fun, but I don't really have a burning desire to play it as I once did.  Don't get me wrong - I still like it very much, but it doesn't grab me like it used to.  Could be that there is so much more to choose from now.  It's ok with 3 players, but even more fun with 4 or 5.  Game can get a little unfair if the same person keeps making a bad choice - sort of like the end seat at a blackjack table.

I forgot to amend my comments after my last play.  If you have 5 people who know what they are doing and enjoy each other's company, the game can be one of the best experiences in gaming.  I especially like that it allows for chit-chat without excessive downtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorites.  Different paths to vicotry in each game forced by opponent choices.  Lotsa blocking/ planning ahead (if I take the craftsman, he will captain, and she will do the trader, which would be bad for me, so instead I will be the mayor).  Your outcome is greatly influenced by others, so everyone at same play level is a plus.  Hardly any luck involved (so little you have to look for it hard).  Very good game.  One of my classics (along with settlers and carcassone) that really got me into the hobby deep.

RATING: 7
While I still enjoy Puerto Rico a lot, it has definitely dropped a little in the desire to play category.  I find that 3-4 times a year scratches my itch.  This means I no longer suggest it as I can guarantee this minimum number of playings without it.  Still, it IS a fun game that I've not yet tired of playing.  While each game is no longer as different as they were at one point, since there is so much to do -- variable roles, buildings, crops -- I don't really notice all that much.  With more experience, it becomes even more important to adapt your strategy to your opponents.  A final note here -- I have to be in the mood for in order to play well.  That doesn't mean I won't have fun or maybe even be competitive, just that I won't play well.

RATING: 8
Great game, nice that there is a good amount of strategy and still a short game. Seems like most of the other heavily strategic games take a long time to play. 

Of course, that's always my main complaint too: that the game ends before my long-term strategy has had time to unfold.

Had some bad runs early on with this game and gained a dislike for it (probably due to sitting to the right of the most experienced and cut-throat players.... booo). But now that I've learned the game better and can get a good quicker strategy going the game is really growing on me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Updated again. On Boardgamearena you can find players that are on your level and beyond. This means that play is now more balanced and not dependant on bad play from others. Over there your own tactical choices start to matter more. Still, a game that needs those kind of conditions to shine should not have a higher rating than 7.

Update. Improved my rating from a 3 to a 6 after playing this on Boardgamearena. Over there you can choose the level of the opponents. So being stuck with a weak player to your right is not an issue. That makes for far more interesting plays.


I did a lot of research for my first play, and it felt pretty obvious how to play 'best'. My first two plays I won from 4 moderate players. That - to me - is not good. If you can win easily from experienced players as a beginner, something smells... My third play I had the misfortune of sitting next to someone who 'didn't know what to do' so he took the Goudzoeker (I believe it's called) and so I couldn't benefit from the ground work of someone else. That ruined it for me.

RATING: 8
Puerto Rico -- For me, this falls just short of greatness due to two factors:  The involution of the steps of play (though, I admit, a game so rich in theme can't reasonably be expected to have the elegance of less intricate rules) and the almost mechanical necessity of making certain choices in response to particular moves.  These may seem rather minor, but I consider Puerto Rico so good that if it weren't for these quibbles, it would be among my  favorites.

RATING: 1.5
2 solo plays. Not sure if I ever want to play it for real. Maybe once. Will see. 

It's a game in logical sequence of murdering fun in eurogames including Goa and Princess of Florence. It's the optimisation masterwork and invented leeching as "interaction". More interesting than Goa because there are more options - building one can build, paths one can pursue and there's actually a narrative to this. Actually in this regard it's similar to RFTG, a game I enjoy a lot. 

The minus side (and why I think I'll like PoF better) is that its ultimately calculable. Too much open information, too many clear limitations. Problem with optimisation games is that they give you clear confines and the only space open is to do more within that space and doing more means optimisation, mathiness and general banging of head against the wall. Actually PoF seems to mo a bit more charming and at least offers auctions. 

In short: card games with this system manage to eliminate it's problems (calculability, changing optimisation one can learn for managing risks and dealing with odds) while retaining it's strengths.

EDIT: finally played (and this after quite some time, so I forgot the "script"). Impression was pretty tedious and pedestrian. Yay, I need some plays to learn the machine and then I need t optimise it, depending on what others are doing. Can I go watch the grass grow, now, please?

RATING: 8
Having played 3 games so far (2 with 5P, 1 with 4P), I think this game is highly strategic, but also mechanical at times. The rules are surprisingly simple, and I enjoy the different combos that the buildings can pull off. However, I have finally come to realise that taking the Craftsman is usually a bad idea, and players have to set it up somehow so that an opponent has to take it. 

I enjoy Euros such as Homesteaders and Cuba, where you can personalise your own VP engine. Like those games, Puerto Rico's shine wears off a little once you discover the optimum engines to build. After that, it becomes a race to snag the buildings that you need. Still, Puerto Rico is a great game in the engine-building genre, and time flies by when I'm playing this game.

RATING: 6
I have seen this game listed so many times. When I looked at the game it just not seem that special. The game play videos did not add any excitement and I still did not understand the amount of respect it gets. Wow was I wrong. Once you wrap your head around what to pick which you learn in about 2 rounds. What really struck me about this game is I did not spend any time thinking about how many points I had or focus on getting points. It was like I was playing and getting points was secondary. It was great just to focus why I am picking this card, oh cool you picked that I can do an action too. Then I will do this. I now understand why so many love this game.

RATING: 9
[20 plays] I sometimes catch myself thinking about this game for days afterward. I enjoy everything about it. Our wives enjoy the game and play it fairly competitively - so that is a big plus. PR is highly ranked because a wide variety of individuals have found it to be a fun and interesting game of strategy, it is as simple as that. It is a solid game with minimized luck and plenty of fast turns that keep all players involved. I enjoy the mechanics and theme - I really get the feeling I'm building a colonial enterprise.

Have played the 2 player variant 4 times now and I'm highly impressed that the game remains such a tight and tense contest.

The Alea expansion with the nobles is a nice addition to the game.

Most recent play May '14.

RATING: 10
When I first played Settlers, it had a 'wow' factor, as much because it was so different to any other game I had ever played.  Puerto Rico has the 'wow' factor for experienced gamers. How did Mr. Seyfarth do it?  The game takes roughly an hour to play with straightforward rules, but it packs so much into that time, so much tactical and strategic play, with depth that the game stands up to the analysis it has received.  Playing it is always a rush (quite heady when played at the speed you can play on BSW).  As close to a perfect game for me as I have played.

My friends and I find it hard to ignore that most of the actual "colonists" in Puerto Rican history were slaves, and they are essentially treated this way in the game; I would be very uncomfortable playing this game with African Americans or Puerto Ricans for that matter.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Although there are some standard strategies, there is enough interaction to keep you on your toes. This kind of balancing act in the game's design is incredible to me. The core mechanics are elegant and ingenious, but there are some shortcomings for me: I think there is tense goodness in 2- and 3-player games. With 4 , the game slows down some, and I don't care for it so much, even though it is more interesting in many ways. Then again, maybe I just need to log more 4 and 5 player games. The game revolves around players choosing "roles" on their own turns which give themselves the most advantage and others the leat advantage. So there is a bit of min-maxing going on - but hidden victory points help prevent too much analysis paralysis. And I like the way the landscape changes based on player choices, as opposed to randomness - such as a card draw or dice role. Another game which is ingenious in this regard is Indonesia.

Puerto Rico vies for the title of "Wife's favorite game", which is great! Even though the theme (growing crops, processing crops, shipping the finished commodities to Europe) is about as exciting as a wet noodle to me, Puerto Rico truly transcends its thematic drawbacks to provide an awesome gaming experience. Puerto Rico also possesses a certain kind of dynamism by way of player interaction that I really like. It reminds me of how players bid for action selection order in El Grande, and how players can announce and bid on mergers in Indonesia - this is a hallmark of superior game design. Even though I'm personally lukewarm on El Grande, I think the game is put together really well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A heavy game I can get people to play! Hurrah. I think that because of all the tokens the game looks more complicated than it is. Unfortunatly all the tokens and woodern thingys mean it takes a while to set up.

RATING: 8


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The best European style board game encountered so far. Deservedly ranked #1 on BGG.

The mechanics are very elegant and the theme fits although there is some obvious dissonance in that area.

It can be unbalancing to have inexperienced players in a group, which is probably the biggest flaw of this otherwise excellent game.

Oh, and the components and graphics are definitely sub-standard. I'm hoping for a re-design and re-print, but am not holding my breath.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Alea Big Box Series #7
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is going over really well.  I find myself wanting to play it frequently.  Not surprised it has stayed high on the list over time.  Wife really is liking it as well, we have enjoyed the Alea 2 player variant and haven't bothered with any of the common alterations to it yet.

Introduced it to some friends that aren't hard core gamers and they all really seemed to enjoy it.  One specifically said they really liked it a day after we played.

RATING: 9
A BGG TOP 1-es játéka, nem véletlenül. A kinézete puritán (a nem mai kiadása miatt), de a játékmenete igazi csemege. Nagyon sok későbbi játék ebből építkezett, nem véletlenül. Épületépítés, ültetvényezés és a legfontosabb a jó akció kiválasztása, amit mindenki végrehajt, de a választó egy kis előnnyel. Ugye ismerős elemek. Agricola, RFTG, stb...
A játék fantasztikussága abban rejlik, hogy annyira eltalált a játék összetettsége, játékideje, mechanizmusai, hogy mindig úgy érzi az ember, hogy ha felajánlják szívesen ül le játszani vele.

A játék nagyszerűségét jól jellemzi, hogy az eredetileg kiadott 3-5 fős besorolás ellenére a jól megalkotott 2 személyes változat is tökéletesen működik. Ugyanolyan élménnyel, mint a több játékossal játszva.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I didn't get to try Puerto Rico until very late after entering the hobby. And I didn't know what to expect. I was aware of its classic status; but it also draws a lot of criticism due to importance of player position, dry theme, and also simply because many gamers consider themselves to have gotten past it.

Rubbish! This is beyond doubt one of the most innovative and sophisticated games ever made. The mechanisms are still fresh and can put any run-of-the-mill "worker placement" game to shame. And the game balance... just perfect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Mechanics: Superior 3.5 out of 3.5
Theme: Poor 1 out of 3
Entertainment Value: 3 out of 4

Good: Amazing game to exercise the brain and think about your turn. Winning feels rewarding.
Bad: If it wasn't for the amazing mechanics being a puero rican plantation owner would be really boring

Bottom Line: Great thinking game, great game to play just for mechanics.  Not a party game.

RATING: 4.5
Very disappointed in this one.  Felt very old and clunky.  Tremendous chaos with 5 players which makes it difficult to put any sort of strategy together.  I must be a bit spoiled with modern games that tend to have multiple paths to victory.  This one has tons of limits that you are bumping up against constantly (limited goods, limited buildings, limited ships, etc.) meaning that you are funnelled along a path throughout the game.  Surprising that it is so highly regarded.

RATING: 10
Perfect game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One play only over the board, several plays against AI in the app.  The game has grown on me with app plays.  Two complaints from our over the board play.  One, the setup is a bit painful, counting out colonists and VP for the number of players and stacking all of the buildings in their places.  There are worse setups of course, but I find some long setups fun.  Two, the components are bland (but sturdy).  The buildings are tiles, the colonists are discs, the ships are tiles, the plantations are tiles. 
 A lot of sameness.

Game play and mechanics are more important than components (as long as they don’t fall apart, which these won’t), so overall it’s a great game.  The app has the same boring graphics but does take care of setup, so this may be one occasion where I stick with the app.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
At first I didn't like this game much.  But after getting several plays under my belt, I finally starting seeing the intricacies of the game, and the strategic depth.  Now I know why it is amongst the top rated games in the world.  Easy to learn, hard to master, and several possibilities for strategies.  Also, it is fun for non-gamers. My parents really like this game for some reason.  They even get into the PVP aspect, strategically blocking other players!

If it had better artwork, I'd rate it higher.

RATING: 8
I went into this with a sour mood, expecting to hate a game about shipping off corn and coffee.  I expected to be burned by the good ratings Puerto Rico has gotten.  I am VERY pleasantly surprised to say that this is not so.  I am big on theme, yet even though sugar plantations don't evoke the most epic of images, the game was involving, challenging, and just plain fun.  Kudos to you, Andreas Seyfarth.  Kudos to you.  I am impressed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
OK, with over 300 comments on this thing, what else is there to say? One overlooked aspect of the game's "value" is (IMHO) its unique approach to gaming itself. Its multi-task oriented basics are just so different from what most of us who've been gaming for years are use to. It broadens one's thinking about what games are basically all about. Not that there aren't a lot of "multi-tasking" games out and about these days, but Puerto Rico (thank you Andreas Seyfarth) seems to have refined the process into a gem well worth owning, teaching and playing and playing and playing and. . . .
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Two reasons why this game appeals to me: (1) The theme is well integrated with the play; you really do feel that you are managing a plantation rather than just trying to meet some arbitrary set of conditions. (2) You can establish a clear-cut strategy early on rather than just reacting to situations, and at the end of the day, you are left thinking of other strategies for next time. The official two-player variant works well. This is a lovely game that loses points only for lack of direct player interaction, somewhat elaborate setup, and a slight odor of political correctness.

RATING: 10
Better than Le Harvre; mostly not just because it a very approachable and has fine mechanics, but also it lends some value to more than just monetary or material prosperity (without preaching any socialist gospels)... but VPs can be gained (not only by accumulating wealth) but by using wealth gained for things that would otherwise unattainable, that there is value in building harder and larger things that a community as a whole can benefit from.  La Havre, much like Monopoly is just a bit too hedonistic and greed (only) based.
