RATING: 7
I was hella skeptical about this one before I took the plunge. Turns out that Puerto Rico actually is all that and a bag of (VP) chips. I don't get as into the whole optimizing-the-bejeezus-out-of-it as other Euro-drones might; there are other ways I would prefer to spend 90-120 minutes. But given rum and a full complement of friends, PR provides a great time in/fun out apparatus.

UPDATE: Knocked the rating up by 1 - who am kidding? Puerto Rico is rad. I'm curious to see whether this holds up over increasing plays.

UPDATE UPDATE: Burrrrrrned ouuuuuut.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm still getting that fun feeling from this game.

Each player has a board representing Puerto Rico, with spaces to place buildings and plantations.  On your turn, you select one of 7 unique roles.  The Builder allows you to purchase a building, Settler allows you to add a plantation to your settlement, Craftsman allows you to produce goods from your plantations, Trader lets you sell goods for cash, Captain lets you ship goods for victory points, Mayor gives you colonists to activate your plantations and buildings, and the Prospector gives you cash.  You are interested in everyone else's turn because when a role is selected, everyone gets to do it (build, trade, etc).  Once everyone has had a chance to perform the action, the next person selects a different role.  

My regular group never lets too much time pass before requesting this, and I have almost always found it to be a satisfying gaming experience.  

Plays best with 4 or 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Every other game wishes it could be as cool as Puerto Rico, with a perfectly meshed blend of intuitiuve rules, inherent player interaction, and its every-turn tension between strategic need and tactical necessity.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I respect the design of Puerto Rico. The role selection mechanism creates an interesting dynamic and injects some tactical considerations into an otherwise static strategy game. Without the role selection, it'd be too close to Saint Petersburg and its ilk for my liking. Puerto Rico is a lot more interesting, as it's way better at weaving together the effects of player actions. But at heart it's an engine-building game, and I'd rather play San Juan, Race for the Galaxy, or Glory to Rome in this genre, and I only ever find myself requesting Glory to Rome. If I hadn't played any of those games, I suspect I'd like Puerto Rico a lot more than I do. It's a lot drier by comparison. And count me among those who don't like the theme of the game, as abstract as it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

[b]Craftsman Angst 2-player variant[/b]

● Player setup: 
  Player 1: 3 doubloons, 1 Indigo (GOVERNOR)
  Player 2: 3 doubloons, 1 Corn

● Remove:
  3 plantations of each type
  3 quarries
  1 of each small violet building
  1 prospector role tile
  2 of each good

● Use:
  3 face up plantations
  5 quarries
  2 of each production building
  1 of each violet building
  6 remaining role tiles

● Use:
  65 VPs
  40 colonists plus 2 on the ship
  4- and 6- capacity cargo ships

● Game-play:
  Players alternate selecting a role as usual, until the Governor has selected 3 roles and the opponent has selected 2 roles.
  Place 1 doubloon on the 2 unchosen role cards.
  Then, the other player becomes Governor.

RATING: 8

I always find Puerto Rico enjoyable, although it doesn't jump off the shelf at me, and I prefer a bit more turn angst.

RATING: 8
This was the first game I played with the whole "choose a phase, everyone plays it but you get a bonus" mechanic and also one of the few games I've played with almost no random elements integrated (there is still a small bit with the randomly chosen plantation tiles).

This is a fun, easily picked up game with a good amount of depth and strategy.  I've heard that depth and strategy gets somewhat diluted over time while players start to learn the best and most effective strategies but not many great games can claim that's not true.

Es uno de los juegos mÃ¡s jugados en nuestro grupo. Ya empezamos a dejarlo un poco de lado, ya sabemos que es lo que hace cada uno.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I like the game (like everyone else does!). Simple rules, full of decisions to make and almost no luck at all. 

Puerto Rico happened to be one of mine first board game crushes. This game invented a very important slice of modern board gaming and we all have to respect that as players. I do suspect that a few years from now the willing to play it will decrease as the time passes but that's only because newer things will appear and Puerto Rico, as a lucky free kind of game with no random elements becomes a dry mechanical game resulting in a "obsolete" gaming experience sort of speaking. This is even more true if the group of players remains the same over the years and if the game is played sufficiently to understand all its buildings and characters.

New expansions are needed to fight this cristalisation. I mean, not only new terrains and buildings but also new characters to use and to give new options to players. Maybe it's something that this game deserves.

This is one of the games of my life!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.5
Now I've finally played the famous "Puerto Rico", and I think I still prefer "San Juan". I don't think it is a terrible game or anything, it is good and I can see how one can get lost in exploring the different strategies to try and win. My main indicator in liking a game is whether I want to do exactly that, try again no matter how much I got crushed the first time playing (which I did this 1st time) but it doesn't itch me the right way, and therefor I would rather play the shorter and less bloated variant that SJ offers.
I think the design could be a more exciting, too, (I know there is a fancy deluxe edition which I have -0 intention in playing) the writing on the buildings/ plantation was rather small which is annoying for something that is placed in the middle of the table for everyone to read.

RATING: 8
Brilliant game. Highly scalable and interesting mechanics. Only issues I have:
1. Steep learning curve - even if newbies pick up the mechanics, the strategy takes multiple games to grasp.
2. Susceptible to king-making and benefits the player on the left of a newbie.
3. Some buildings are clearly better than others which result in the same few buildings bought each game and others left untouched.
4. Prone to group-think.

RATING: 10
Highly recommended!  Your decisions about which role to play and which buildings to buy cannot be planned beforehand, but rather must be adjusted as you react to the other players&#039; decisions. I always want to do more than I&#039;m allowed each turn; this tension in decision making will probably keep the game fresh and addictive for quite some time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
For a long time I left Puerto Rico with a 9 rating a blank comment. It was probably the first real gamer's game I bought and holds a special place in my heart. :)

Having recently had cause to revisit it, I am less excited. It's certainly a good game, particularly notable for its including genuinely multiple paths to victory (e.g. shipping, buildings) linked to separate game clocks.

Perhaps the best thing about it (and the worst) is the notoriously strong issue of turn order, where it is vital to follow what other players are doing so as to not give them the game. This is comparatively strong interaction for the genre.

I am less enamored of how scripted the early game can become, the "point salad", and the clunky mishmash of different mechanisms.

An excellent game, but one I no longer think I even need to own.

Ratings history: 9->7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There is no question that Puerto Rico is a superb game that can offer a lot of hours of non-boring play if you are into the resource management euro genre.

It's ease of teaching to new people does not at all imply lack of strategic and tactical depth. It has all the characteristics of a good euro game - important decisions, subtle but very strong player interaction, balance between long term strategy and short term tactics.

It's thin list of disadvantages should probably contain the fact that there are not many valid general strategies once you get to figure the game out and that the elements which make every play unique are not very strong, especially among experienced players. Every play remains unique, but only slightly. In short, it is these points that the designer of Agricola picked up to make an even better game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Well now I see what all the fuss is about.  I think this is a great game.  It has lots of decisions to make, requires long-term planning, has a cool theme, is aesthetically pleasing, isn't too difficult to learn, and doesn't take too long to play.  The only minor complaint I have is some of the rules can be a bit confusing at first.  I suggest downloading a list of rules commonly played incorrectly here on the Geek.  I definitely want to play this one some more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Needs a few more play to decide whether it is a 10, but so far it has been a blast.  The mechanics are great, but I've been told that the game grows stale after 15 or so playthoughs, so we shall see if that is the case.  This was my gateway game, and though there seems to be many that think this game doesn't work for introducing non-gamers to this hobby, it worked for me.      There seems to be a really vocal minority creating a backlash to the popularity of this game.  Complaints range from it being dry and boring to people using the same strategy every time.  For me, the game is filled with tough, tense, interesting decisions, and so I really don't understand the dry complaint.  And I can't really see the same strategies working too often, to me that just says your play is really weak.  While this is certainly not the perfect game, and it probably isn't the best ever created, it certainly deserves high praise.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[RGG 2002 edition] {Merchant, economic; variable-phase, action-draft, development, resource management, utility cards; optimal 4p} Before playing PR, I occasionally play board games, and I was mostly interested in RPG and abstract games. After I played PR, I found that board games can be very interesting and a player can learn different styles of thinking and social style of friends. Since then, I enjoy playing board games much. I could say that PR inspires me about collecting board games.

PR is commonly known as an excellent strategy game, which I do agree. I regard it as the gem of contemporary games: novel mechanic, efficient system, little down time and thematic. PR is cleverly and carefully designed: well balanced, multifaceted, nice player interaction and strong competition.  PR does not offer direct confrontation but the competition is still strong and this creates much indirect player interaction.

The explanation of rule of PR may take a time (mostly explaining the function of different buildings) but the rule itself is not complicated because it's remarkably intuitive; thus, it's easy to understand its concept and game flow. Nevertheless, it takes time to master this game because of multiple paths of winning and variety of strategies. Players have to continually evaluate the situation and make decisions, but it's not as agonizing as other strategic games. PR involves no luck and is quite unforgiving. Since it's a development game, early settings are very important - failing to build a strong foundation will not lead to winning. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I'm the guy you want sitting to your right. ;)  It's a shame that most people are burned out on this. I need to play more. My rating may go up with more plays, but as of now it feels very programmed.

Update: After playing this game with people with similar experience levels, I've increased my rating. Much more fun with people who do not know all of the "perfect" moves. God, this game makes my head hurt.

RATING: 8
Very little randomness but I enjoy the interaction between players and trying to maximise my performance at the game. It might be a little dry for some, but for me the theme never disappears while playing. Feels less like a spreadsheet than Agricola and less maths heavy than Power Grid so this one hits the table quite a lot.

Missing out on table time a bit. I suspect we need to get in to this one more as a group so it may come in to it's own more in the future. At the moment it lags behind Power Grid in my affections as a medium-heavy euro, and it's not light enough to challenge Settlers/Carc as more fun/family games.

RATING: N/A
Tableu building, engine building,worker placement, tile placement, svaka je od ovih kategorija primjenjiva za opis Puerto Rica. Bilo ih je i ranije takvih ali PR ima povijesnu distinkciju kao tipping point prema Euro stilu za mase. Odlična igra, gateway prema igrama euro stila, neki kažu da je potrošna, u mojoj kolekciji (nažalost) nije jer ne dolazi na stol toliko često da bismo automatizirali poteze. Zapravo sad kad razmislim Stone Age, Pillars of the Earth, Caverna pogotovo, pa čak i Manhattan project ili Junta:Viva el Presidente, sve su to 'inačice' Puerto Rica. I to sam nabrojao samo koje su mi prve pale na pamet. Nije mi PR omiljena igra (premda je volim zaigrati tu i tamo) ali kad bih nekome išao pokazati kaj to ovaj hobi jest, definitivno bi bila među prvim igrama koje bismo zaigrali.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
A classical, very decent euro-game. I had much of pleasure of analysing opening moves and whole strategies. There is a random element (drawing of plantation tiles) that gives the game replayability. However, after a large number of plays the game could be a little boring, especially as the theme is not strongly connected with mechanics. When playing, you feel like solving an abstract quest, rather than like a governor of San Juan island. But, I must admit, Andreas Seyfarth did his job very well: the gaming system is very solid. 

Personally, I don't like graphics of the standard edition. I made my own game, printing the board designed by Michael Doyle and adding some wooden markers. Respect to Michael, too!


Number of plays: about 5 (plus extra 5-10 with AI).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nice role-picking game. Set up a good trade commodity and then find a way to ship loads of cheap stuff for points. Monopoly is the key. Or build quickly and end the game before your opponents can get the shipping points. The first turns are super important - one small misstake and there's no easy coming back. Starting player usually picks a quarry, second player builds (small market or small indigo plant), third player bring in colonists. Same thing every time. But then the game really begins...

RATING: 7



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
One of the best of the Euro-games out there.  Nice components, straightforward rules, and an unique system of assigning roles within the game.  Doesn't suffer from the problem that a lot of other Euro's have when it comes to victory conditions.  Victory points are derived from a limited number of sources.

Update - after several plays game is starting to get a little stale.  There are now better Euros out there than when I first wrote this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
P
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
An exceptional, standout game when it was released in 2002, and even now it is an excellent game for those looking for a relatively easy to learn, medium complexity Euro.  For me personally, after so many plays, it has become a bit repetitive, as the main strategy for winning is too much about trying to screw your opponent(s) over during the Captain and Trading phases.  Good player interactivity though, the theme is rich, it is "thinky" (in a good way), has superb balance, and it really does feel like you are managing a plantation.  You will definitely be immersed and engaged.  It just has become a little stale and predictable for me and now rarely gets played.  I'd heartily recommend it to newcomers though.

RATING: 8
I have finished making the illustrated buildings.

I like the easy flow of the game.  There are a good spectrum of strategies to try but are not too dense to figure out.  A Very nice spread of styles and controlling the game end is key.  The interaction is nice and builds a slight tension but not overwhelming.

update : I find myself never reaching for this game. hmm..

update : Just played a 2 player after a long while and completely forgot how to play!  At least the good strategies.  I think I know why I haven't played it in a while.  I just would rather play a more fun 2 p game.

update 2014: Really enjoying this as a two player game.  Raised my rating.  Our familiarity with the buildings has really changed the dynamic.

Fun Factor : :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

Fulfillment Factor : :star::star::star::star::halfstar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
Over 50 plays with a consistent group (mostly five player games)later I can't do anything other than recommend this game, highly.

If you think there's not enough player interaction, you can influence the "chain reaction" of production, trading and loading onto the ships by choosing the prospector or a role that benefits anyone but the leader.

+ long playing time (we regularly have >2 hour sessions)
+ different strategies can all pay off (I've seen people winning with a great variety of strategies)
+ components; simply, but work well
+ very little luck involved
+ comebacks are possible, but require planning and determination

We use the improvements suggested by the designer (factory and university cost the other way around, one dubloon(?) less for grain starters.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Pure genius! LOVE AT FIRST PLAY!

2nd Update:  Dropped this to 4.  Too unbalanced for my tastes.  First corn has a huge advantage.

RATING: 5
A decent role selection game. It suffers from solvability somewhat and also, like too may euro games, that if you build a money engine, you'll almost certainly win.

Update: I can see a lot of good things with this game and if it was new and I had a group and we all learnt it together (and improved together), it'd be a lot of fun. As it is, there always seem to be one or two players that have played it a lot and run away with it. For that reason, it's less fun.

Further update: I dislike teaching this to newbies; it is too opaque and so they have little to no idea what to do to win, and they can gift the game unwittingly to someone else.

Rating down from 7 to 6 and down again to 5.

RATING: 9

And if you are picking it up for the first time with others who are just as new - I encourage you to AVOID reading the strategy articles and learn the game with your fellow players.  You won't regret it.

RATING: 9
Some minor-to-moderate gameplay imbalances plus poor production values keep this otherwise very good and innovative game from 'perfect 10' status.

The late-2011 release Puerto Rico 10th Anniversary Edition version corrects most of the production value deficiencies (with the glaring exception of the US version's 'copper-instead-of-gold-looking' doubloons... tsk), but does nothing to clean up any gameplay flaws. 

It's also quite steeply priced, i.e. almost triple what you can pick up the old version for.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The amazing thing about Puerto Rico is that there is never downtime for any player.  Players take turns selecting an action to take, and every player takes that action in succession.  So, while you do wait your turn to select an action, you will always be taking actions based on what other people select.  I rate this one very highly because the strategy and strategic depth found in this game is simply delicious.  It's not too complex to learn, but a challenging game to master.  A near perfect, and at this point a classic, euro-style game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Playing again and again since almost 15 years with a long brake in between. Never gets boring.

RATING: 8.5
Consider your first game of this a write-off. Generally new players tend to spend the first half of the game trying to grasp the many subtle things going on or even clue into the games flow. I find pretty much everyone I've introduced it to REALLY enjoyed it by the end and totally was up for another game of it.

Addendum: Enjoyed further games much more, had a better grasp of why I wanted buildings, what they could do for me. Everyone did their own little thing and played the game differently using different strategies, yet we all came out pretty close at the end (tied for first actually), that being said it seems very very well balanced. It's an interesting game; mind you the lack of player interaction and a fairly low fun factor makes it less then perfect but its pretty god damn close! 

Addendum: Lots of plays, freaking grand game.  Endless possibilities and every changing strategy.  Love the game, HATE teaching it to new players.

Puerto Rico from Rio Grande Games Ages: 12+ Players: 3-5 Avg. Length: 90-150 minutes

This is the game of colonizing and crop production. Players vie to win by a combination of building their colony buildings and shipping the most goods. Great strategy game with many routes to victory. My personal favorite boardgame

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
#7 big box series
This is a classic with lots of choices and a lot of "I wish I could do A and B and C". Unfortunately, it has been played and analyzed to death. This is one that is best played by folks with the same amount of experience with the game, otherwise things become quickly lopsided. The other issue I have is that there are a bazillon bits and its a bit fiddly to deal with the pieces. I actually prefer the computer version, which I can play in roughly 15 minutes.

After some online play, I've decided I just don't care for this game. Each game feels the same and I don't care for what seems like very stale choices each turn. A player that doesn't know the game throws it to the person following them. When everyone knows the game well, the choices are very limited and it just isn't a fun game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My group has not had the chance to analyze Puerto Rico to death, so we are still exploring the depths of this game.  I love the plethora of varied decisions you must make during the course of a single game, such as Do I take the Settler for a quarry now while I have a chance, or the Prospector which would give me two doubloons and wouldn't help anyone else?  Or do I build the Small Warehouse now before they're gone, or save up for the Coffee Roaster?  Which boat do I use for my indigo, and when does taking the Craftsman ever help me more than even one other person?  And on and on.  Puerto Rico is a fun, deep, and varied game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
My go to game. If you haven't search around for the Puerto Rico Evolver. Best board game to MS Excel port ever.

The things I love about this game are that the randomization doesn't really effect the game much (plantations) and that there are truly MANY ways to win. I recently saw someone win using a Hospice/Office strategy. I would have NEVER thought that would work.

The only downside to the game is there are a few improperly balanced buildings like the lighthouse which costs too much and the small market that costs too little.

RATING: 6
I want to give this game a lower score, but I'm having trouble managing to.  I think there are a lot of much better games.  But where PR does do a good job, is in making a game of building-up your own stuff and yet interacting fairly well with the other players.  This is something I have to say PR does better than Goa.  In Goa basically everyone could decide to focus on spices and ships first.  With the Colonies and plantations it wouldn't be too hard.  In PR you do need to think about what the other players are doing and do something else -- ideally, something that complements their activities perfectly.

RATING: 10
[b]Possibility Space Landscape (Exploration=Fun)[/b]
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Challenge (Depth) Fun derived from analyzing and predicting the optimal path to take through the possibility space landscape.
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Variety (Width) Fun derived from trying out a large variety of meaningful paths through the possibility space landscape.
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Atmosphere (Height) Fun derived from the experience or anticipation of encounters along a path through the possibility space landscape.

[b]Gaming Skills Employed[/b]
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Analysis
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Tactics
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Strategy
:nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Direct Player Manipulation (Diplomacy)
:nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Indirect Player Manipulation (Bluffing)
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Player Reading/Prediction
:star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Luck

[b]Misc.[/b]
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Theme Integration
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Rules Complexity
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Bookkeeping
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Downtime
:star::star::star::star::star: Scalability

[b]Presentation[/b]
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Components
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Artwork
:star::star::star::star::star:Rules

[b]Comments[/b]
I never get tired of playing this.  Best when all players are equally familiar with the game.

RATING: 10
One of my favorite games. I absolutely love the role selection mechanic, and Puerto Rico still does it better than anybody. You're always engaged on every player's turn, the competition can be fierce for ship space and buildings, and you get to build a nice engine that can be different every time (production, shipping, buildings). Just great.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the game that made me fall in love with BGG.  When I first got into gaming towards the end of high school (2003-2004) my brother had a copy of Settlers of Catan which we played to death.  That year I wanted to get some board games for Christmas. So, I went on BGG, found the rankings, and asked for every game in the top 10.  I got this under the tree and discovered my first truly elegant game design.  I love that there is no luck only your own skill and wits.  This game frequently fights with Agricola for my #1 eurogame spot.

RATING: 4
Try San Juan instead of Puerto Rico.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There's a reason this game has been in the top 3 for a long time. It deserves it for its impeccable balance and incredibly interesting decision-making throughout every play.

I keep it at a 9.5 (and not a 10) simply because teaching it to players who are not familiar with role-selection games is a bit of a task. And it usually takes a new player a few games before it clicks.

For the record, the "click" is totally worth every minute you spend learning this gem. This is my #1 game of choice.

UPDATE: I have since matured a bit in my gaming, I suppose, because I no longer find this game a challenge to teach new players. Or I've played it enough that I know how to teach it better. Probably a combo of the two. Also, PR is no longer my game of choice. In this stage of the game, I go with Through the Ages as my top pick. I'll probably keep this at a 9, however, because while it is elegant, streamlined, balanced, and interesting, it does not offer the depth of play as something like Through the Ages. It's probably still in my Top 3 games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Puerto Rico is really just awesome fun. Almost as fun as Cities and Knights.

RATING: 8.5
Rules seem more complex at first than they are, due primarily to the huge number of pieces and the variety of boards, so new players may need to be assured that everything makes sense.  Rules are logical and gameplay is buttery smooth. Can't wait to play more.  
UPDATE: I've now played a couple games with two players, and this is an amazing experience.  I really enjoy the game, even though I seem to completely stink at it.  I find it still remains a bit intimidating to a new player due to the number of pieces, but this is an easy mental barrier to break through.  I've had much luck teaching this to people new to the hobby.

RATING: 9
This is a great game.  I like Race for the Galaxy a bit more, but that's just because I prefer tactical decision-making to strategic decision-making.  The interaction here is more straight-forward (since others can't choose the same role, and your decisions have a more immediate effect).  Although long-term strategies seem to be more in the fore-front, there is definitely a need to think on your feet, in everything from deciding what to ship, to which role to take after the previous player took my intended choice.  Lots of fun, definitely looking forward to learning how to play better.

RATING: 8
Once you graduate from Settlers of Catan (an excellent game in its own right), you're ready to face a more complex European-style game like Puerto Rico. It is colorful, it has an interesting setting (plantations in America), and many things to keep track of (farming, trading, building, slave-- er, "colonist" management, etc.) There is also a streamlined card-only version called "San Juan".

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There are two things I'll never understand in this life: Why people like smoking and why people love Puerto Rico.

This is a eurogame that crossed the line and is hardly a game: 
1) Boring concept almost totally disconected to the mechanics. Other games have no concept at all you might add, BUT : 
2) It has terrible player interaction mainly because it depends heavily on how the players sit, 
3) You need to force-play at least 3-4 games to realise that the mechanics are good and at least 6-8 games to start making some strategic and sensible choices. Now Combine this to 
4) The game plays crap with people that don't know what they're doing (meaning they're still below 6-8 games) and you get a fail.

If you want to enjoy this you need to find a group of at the very least 3 people that are willing to waste 15-20 hours of their life without enjoying themselves + risk that 1)They won't like it even after that, 2)They will hate it long before they'll get a chance to like it and quit the painfull process.

Even if everything goes right you'll have a few people trained to play a game that has excellent mechanics and little else. (although some of us would argue that mechanics is 90% of a game) 

------

+ Excellent mechanics (role selection, engine building)
+ Tough Decisions
+ Little Downtime
+ Fair Replayability
+ No luck

- "Bad" Interaction (poor choices mostly benefit others instead of ruining just you)
- Barely working theme
- Boring until you figure what's going on
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
What I like: 

-Classic eurogame and it's quite fun to build your distinct part of the island

What I do not like:

-I really really dislike the action selection mechanic where everyone has to do each others' stupid action. I know folks say that means you have to look at the opponents situation and evalute what their next move is, but that is exactly what I hate. This means that to play optimally I should actually spent more time looking at your board than my own. Not to mention the fact that sometimes you are stuck with the strategy you chose early game (for instance builder) and some idiot at the table hasn't realised that he is spoon feeding my other opponent the victory by constantly picking the craftman. This could also be the other way around. Generally the problem is just the result of my strategy is based primarily on what my opponents decide to do (and who is more experienced and where they sit on the table versus the newer players).
-It's definitely not a pretty game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Finally played this, 4p. Was nervous to try it because of the higher than average "weight," but it's actually pretty easy to play, just a little fiddly. It feels most like AOE3 and Endeavor, of games I've played. You work on building up an economy that produces gradually more and more of desirable stuff. Direct player interaction seems lower because of no map, but indirect interaction is more visible than in Endeavor. What you do will affect others, but can be hard to think through.

Labor feels less scarce in PR. Money feels scarce, because you don't have a steady income. The shipping is the most interesting part of the game, where you can really bone somebody. I considered trying San Juan instead of PR due to it being simpler, but as I hear SJ lacks shipping, I'm glad I went straight to PR.

It may be due to my inexperience, but strategy felt pretty short-term to me. I look at what I could most use at the moment, and attempt to improve that. Like Endeavor, but with less random outcomes to my choices, and more concern about what the other players are going to do if I take certain actions.

At the end of the day, I don't think I'm that interested in these economy-building games.

...Revisited many months later. I don't think I missed much except that the different combinations of buildings allow for some exploration of the strategy. Not just the long-term strategy but also a lot of the appeal of the game is probably located there.

I still feel like I'm making tiny moves, and am supposed to calculate whether I shouldn't make a tiny move because it will let somebody else make a slightly less tiny move.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After the first game, everyone wants another round.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
While I think the game is very balanced and has good mechanics, there's just something about it that makes we not ever want to suggest playing it.  However, I also won't walk away from a game of it.  The game experience is much lower if you have experienced and new players playing together.  The new players can basically give the game away to the people on their left and unless you table talk the game there's nothing you can do to stop it.  More minor problems of PR are that you have perfect information and therefore the game plays you more than you play the game.  Your best choice of action is pretty much always apparent and you can also predict what most players are going to do on their turn.  You also have the problem of having only one strategy in PR work:  MONEY EARLY - VPs LATE.  Following that overall strategy, you have the problem on only two paths to victory:  Building or Shipping.  OF course you have different tactics to choose from to accomplish those paths, but it's still only two paths and one strategy.  I also think the game is dry and not FUN!  I can see why people like it, but it just doesn't grab me like better games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
he players are plantation owners in Puerto Rico in the days when ships had sails. Growing up to five different kind of crops—corn, indigo, sugar, tobacco, and coffee—they must try to run their business more efficiently than their close competitors: growing crops and storing them efficiently, developing San Juan with useful buildings, deploying their colonists to best effect, selling crops at the right time, and, most importantly, shipping their goods back to Europe for maximum benefit.

The game system lets players choose the order of the phases in each turn by allowing each player to choose a role from those remaining when it is their turn. No role can be selected twice in the same round. The player who selects the best roles to advance their position during the game will win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
An innovative, well-designed game that I greatly enjoyed exploring ten years ago (and would have rated a 9 when it first came out) and which I no longer play.

PR does lots of things right: its underlying strategic tension between shipping and building is spot on; mostly, the buildings are priced well; and the different ending conditions work nicely.

However, its "pressuring" style of interaction (where each player mostly constrains and biases the choices of their left-hand neighbor, inducing very strong left/right binding) is far too strong, imo.

The winning strategy all too often, especially in 5-player games, is to simply sit to the left of the weakest player. PR really needs all of its players to be equally strong; its core action mechanism simply isn't robust in the face of different skill levels.

Further, its extremely low level of randomness leads to overly stylized play.  Attempting to be creative (if the given "expected" readout of future moves doesn't favor you) leads to far more second-guessing, acrimony, and criticism than I enjoy.

Frankly, I'd rather play Diplomacy, a far more enjoyable game for the level of acrimony I've experienced playing PR. Two of the most painful gaming experiences I've had in the last 10 years have involved PR. Yes, obviously, this is primarily the fault of the players involved, but I also think that the game system lends itself to it.

For two better, more recent and more enjoyable games, in this general vein of no-luck "pressuring" interaction, consider Navegador (where the strong left-right binding of the markets is tempered by the timing considerations induced by the rondel) or Hansa Teutonica (if you can get past the dreadful theming and bland presentation of the base game -- the expansion maps make far better historical sense and play better).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
This game does not feel elegant to me; the rules seem a touch fiddley and contrived to me.  That's not a bad thing, it just disqualifies it for "elegance".  The rules are not excessive, and they felt more managable on this play.

I didn't rate this game after my first play because I barely knew what I was doing.  I feel like I have a better handle on it after several more plays, but they have been infrequent enough that I don't really know all the buildings very well.  I really want to learn the ins and outs of this game on my own, so I am avoiding any serious strategy discussions about it.  It just doesn't sound like fun to follow the "best moves" in every case, and I hope the reports of it being scripted are overblown.

Fortunately, the times I have played it have been with my normal group is similarly minded people.  I think having some PR jackoff tell me that I ruined his game because I didn't play the way they expected would really put me off the game.  As it is, I like the game pretty well, but don't find it stellar.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a smart game.  It can be taught relatively easily. I'd recommend teaching how a round works and explaining each role with one sentence like *With Builder, you spend gold to build in your city* then proceed with actual gameplay. How each role works is better understood through play than explanation.  A more extreme suggestion is to NOT include purple buildings and quarries for a player's first game.

Puerto Rico has interesting tactical options and different methods of advancement.  A neat bonus is that nobody *runs away* with the score, the ranges between player scores is low.  My only complaint is that it takes too long to get going (having individual baggies for 3, 4 and 5 players is a good idea!) and the initial struggling is painful.

RATING: 9

Just about everything this game *does*, from the economic engine to the city-building aspect to the two dimensions of draftable and purchasable variable player powers, are all excellent as far as I'm concerned.

RATING: 1
Typical euro with some interesting mechanics. Small text and small pieces so its difficult to read the board. If you do enjoy euros you'll probably enjoy this game. The theme isn't too strong as some things that happen make no sense at all. 

I dislike these types of games because unless you're able to study and fully understand the entire game you have no chance at competing with others. While learning the game you'll ruin it for everyone else by setting up players with advantages because you didn't take the appropriate move. Might as well play it solo as there is really no player interaction.

RATING: N/A
Our first game (5 newbies!) was a disaster, but after getting some experience we've really enjoyed this. A little vulnerable to overanalysis (clearly, the way that some people seem to have "solved" the game backs up this point... I will never play this at a con). Lots of decisions to make - deciding which buildings to build, which roles to select and when. With more plays the decisions have gotten somewhat easier, but it still makes me think hard. It seems to be good to have a main strategy in mind, but because you can't always get the plantations you want, you don't have unlimited freedom in setting that strategy. Deserves its high ranking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Pros: original variable role selection mechanic with tableau building, highly tactical with nearly no luck, balanced strategies, engine building, little downtime

Cons: no direct player interaction, sometimes prone to kingmaking, little variability in initial set-up without expansions

Love this classic, unique variable role selection/resource management game. The fact that everyone does the role chosen means there is nearly zero downtime. Though some may complain that there is too little player interaction, in order to succeed, one absolutely must examine their opponents' boards to not only optimize your own role selection but also predict what other players will do and plan accordingly. I enjoy this level of player interaction as well as creating my own economical engine. On that note, the strategies are so finely balanced across the board, I can try something one game and win, and then try something completely different the next time and do just as well. Finding the right balance of shipping and building is pure delight, and each game is different, even without the buildings expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fairly heavy game with very little random luck and lots of thought process trying to figure what the players behind you will do based on what you do.  Seems likely to get a little scripted with experienced players in the same group, which has gradually lowered my rating.

RATING: 9
Solid game. Lots of choices. It's almost comparable to RftG. Probably wouldn't say "No" to a game of this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
"Gamer's game" with almost no hidden information. Players vie to collect the most victory points by carefully managing their resources to build plantations, make and ship goods, and obtain buildings that improve their assets. The most interesting mechanic is the role selection: players choose a role based on what remains available to them - each is valuable but can only be selected once per turn. The catch is that all players still get to perform the same action without given bonus. The game thus centers around careful role selection by taking into account your game standing but also considering the position of others. Solid medium-complexity game with broad appeal, as attested by its long standing #1 position on BGG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This game, along with Power Grid and Tigris & Euphrates, takes 2 hours to play, and so I rarely play it because these days I don't like being trapped in a game for more than an hour. I'd rather play several shorter games than one long one. Hence, I don't recommend these games for anyone but the most serious board gamers, even though they are excellently designed and get the highest rankings. 

In fact, a shorter, card game version of Puerto Rico was released, called San Juan (2004), with a rating of 7.32, and ranked 152 in board games and 159 in strategy games, that most of my friends who love Puerto Rico prefer, because San Juan takes less than half the time to play.

RATING: 8
1st update (Sep 2010)[8]: I find that it can suffer a bit from optimal play; if someone on the table just throws at random actions, the game suffers as a whole. I still like it for what it is though. 

2nd update (Dec 2010)[7]: Recent plays has seemed nearly mechanical and lifeless. For some that's probably a good thing, but I would like some options/multiple paths. Suffers a LOT from position around the table.

3rd update (Feb 2012)[8]: Back up to an eight. I think I had played it too much when I wrote the last update. I feel myself yearning to play recently, and it is a really good game!

Eighth play got me a victory while sitting next to two newbies in a five player game. But I had some tactics myself, and managed to points by myself as well.

RATING: 9.5
[u][i][b] This game is timeless! [/b][/i][/u]
Since getting the game in 2004 it still gets frequent play year after year. The same copy we have is now worn and tattered but like fine wine it's smooth and enthralling. I don't mind teaching it, but it has now come to a point, that I dislike playing this with first timers or people who aren't familiar with the mechanics, strategies and play of this game. 
[u]THEME: [/u]  < Pasted-On - [b]{2}[/b] - - - - - - - - Spot-On >
[u]MECHANICS: [/u]  < Simple  - - - - - - - -[b]{9}[/b] -   Complex>
[u]INITIATION: [/u] < Hard to explain  - - - [b]{4}[/b] - - - - - - Toss the rule book >
[u]DEPTH: [/u]  < Luck based  - - - - - - - - [b]{9}[/b] -  Skill based >
[u]ENERGY: [/u]  < AP Prone  - - [b]{3}[/b] - - - - - - - Royal Rumble >
[u]ENJOYMENT: [/u]  < Zen Like - - - - [b]{5}[/b] - - - - -  Chaotic >
[u]VALUE: [/u]  < Avoid - - - - - - - [b]{8}[/b] - - Must Have > 
--- it's a classic game that will stand the test of time. the expansion is a must have. don't expect too much getting in the game. don't be impatient and chill while learning this game.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Andreas Seyfarth; The players are plantation owners in Puerto Rico in the days when ships had sails. Growing up to five different kind of crops: Corn, Indigo, Coffee, Sugar and Tobacco, they must try to run their business more efficiently than their close competitors; growing crops and storing them efficiently, developing San Juan with useful buildings, deploying their colonists to best effect, selling crops at the right time, and most importantly, shipping their goods back to Europe for maximum benefit. A novel game system lets players choose the order of the phases in each turn by allowing each player to choose a role from those remaining when it is their turn. No role can be selected twice in the same round. The player who selects the best roles to advance their position during the game will win. Expanded by: Puerto Rico Expansion; Re-implemented as: San Juan (Card game) 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
Really good when players are all at the same level. Our group is new to this, and we all enjoy playing it and figuring out various strategies.

RATING: N/A
------------------------------
NOTICE : Due to my poor spoken & written English, the rest of my comments will be written in French only but you can read my profile for more informations about the kind of games I prefer and how I rated them.
------------------------------

►ÉDITION : Tilsit, français, 2004.
Éditeur, nb joueurs : 2 à 5 joueurs.
Éditeur, durée : 1h30 à 2h30/partie.
Éditeur, âge : 12 ans et plus.

►PUBLIC(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
☺ Jeu de stratégie quasi-pure (très peu d’éléments aléatoires et/ou de hasard raisonné).

►JOUEURS, NOMBRE(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
# Nombres non-déterminés.

►COMMENTAIRE(S) ABRÉGÉ(S):
± THÈME : plutôt plaqué; mais agrémente le jeu.
- Aide de jeu : non-inclus, j’aurais aimé qu’il y en ait au moins 1.
- Adversaires : plus agréable lorsqu’il est joué avec des joueurs de même calibre.    
- Déroulement scripté : peut favoriser l’adoption de "scénarios répétitifs" d’une partie à l’autre.
+ Icônes : sont faciles à comprendre ou à mémoriser.

►REMARQUE(S) PERSONNELLE(S):
® Je recommande son essai car il pourrait être apprécié par d’autres joueurs.

L’un des premiers jeux "Euro" que j'ai essayé et qui avait alors impressionné la novice que j’étais à l’époque. Cependant, il s'est révélé trop stratégique pour moi et je n’ai aucun plaisir à subir des parties où des adversaires passionnés maîtrisent par coeur toutes les tactiques d’ouverture et leurs enchaînements. Par contre, j'accepterais peut-être de l’enseigner à des nouveaux joueurs ayant des aptitudes pour ce genre de jeu auquel cas je préférerais guider la partie sans y jouer moi-même.

►EXTENSION(S) ESSAYÉE(S):
& Je n'ai jamais essayé l'(les) extension(s) parce que je ne crois pas qu'elle(s) puisse(nt) améliorer mon appréciation du jeu de base.

►JEU(X) COMPARABLE(S) ESSAYÉ(S):
≤ « Age of mythology » (2003) : améritrash avec combats dont les plateaux individuels rappellent certaines mécaniques de « Puerto Rico » (ouvriers et bâtiments à construire).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What can I say that hasn't already been said?  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I like the balance of all the choices, but I don't like the huge learning curve for new players.  It wouldn't be quite so bad if not for the player-to-the-left-of-the-noob-reaping-the-benefits-of-the-noob's-mistakes aspect of the game.  There's a decent amount of pain and angst going into a given turn, as you try to determine not only what's best for you, but what's least favorable for the other players.  Knowing how picking a role will affect EVERYone, including yourself, adversely, is the key to understanding this game.  I'm not quite there yet.

4 plays: 5 players

RATING: 8.5
Wow. Just wow. What a clever game this is! I was very apprehensive about purchasing this game after reading all the comments about how dry it is and the famous left-right binding problem. After trying it out, I can safely say that it has definitely been blown out of proportion. There are so many moving parts here that it will be a while before I uncover those issues (if at all).

Almost a 10. Docked a quarter of a point for setup, cheap components and some fiddliness. Why... oh why didn't they make the buildings, workers and goods prettier. Borrow a page from AT games and give us some miniatures! I'll fork out the cash.

EDIT: Ok, I give in. 10 it is. My group cannot get enough of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
The players are plantation owners in Puerto Rico in the days when ships had sails. Growing up to five different kind of crops: Corn, Indigo, Coffee, Sugar and Tobacco, they must try to run their business more efficiently than their close competitors; growing crops and storing them efficiently, developing San Juan with useful buildings, deploying their colonists to best effect, selling crops at the right time, and most importantly, shipping their goods back to Europe for maximum benefit.
\13\\13\
The game system lets players choose the order of the phases in each turn by allowing each player to choose a role from those remaining when it is their turn. No role can be selected twice in the same round. The player who selects the best roles to advance their position during the game will win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is close to perfect for me.  I don't own it because my game group owns multiple copies, but this is one of my favorite games and I'm always happy to play.

RATING: 8
And I finally have a chance to play the classic!  I liked the role selection aspect of the game and how everyone got to participate in each role that was selected (except prospector).  You really had to plan your moves well, and it was fun to see things get turned on their head a bit depending on the order in which the different roles were carried out.

*Own iPad version*

RATING: 7
This game is fun but seems overhyped. A lot of the buildings are just flat out unplayable, and feel like they need huge buffs (Office? Hospice?). Others are practical must-haves and direct the entire flow of the game (Small Market?). It is possible I am missing a huge part of the strategy here but as a whole Race for the Galaxy seems like a much deeper and more balanced game.

There is also the problem that after repeated plays, people just start doing the same boring openings over and over again. A bit of input randomness to mix-up the opening game would go a long way here.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I was a little slow to the Puerto Rico party. Although interested in the BGG #1, everytime I read a review or a session report it looked about as dry as dirt. The seemingly endless parade of droning threads about "How the player to your left ruins the game..." made it seem anything but interesting. I had managed to play San Juan a few times, which I happened to like quite a bit. Finding out that Puerto Rico was basically a more complicated version of that game made me think, why bother?

Well, by happenstance I finally got a chance to play this past summer. It didn't take more than a couple of games to change my mind. It was everything I enjoyed about San Juan, but with the randomness of the cards taken out of the equation and the addition of a few more methods to interfere with the plans of my opponents. It wasn't long until San Juan was all but permanently retired. (Don't place ALL the blame for San Juan's disappearance on my exposure to Puerto Rico, his career was living on borrowed time anyway, ever since Race for the Galaxy arrived on the scene...)

At any rate, I now believe the hype. Puerto Rico is a damn good game and completely deserving of it's legendary status. Is it the best game ever? Probably not. It's sort of ugly and the theme isn't really exciting enough to make you wet your pants. As far as being solved goes, I doubt I'll ever play it enough to worry about it. The issue only crops up when the game is played among people who have logged a bajillion plays. I think it plays just fine...

RATING: 10
I think PR may be the most elegantly designed board game out there.  I think it's a great "first heavy gateway game" for people just getting into games (that's what it was for me).  

It suffers from not having too many strategic options.  After a few games you know that a good number of buildings are pretty bad and they never see play.  As a result, a lot of games unfold the same way, but it's always an enjoyable experience despite that.

RATING: 9
2 a 5 jugadores - 1 hora y media
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
10/25/2007: Revised rating to a 4. It will definitely take some talking to get me to play this game again. As I noted in my earlier comments... with additional plays it loses it's luster. It's a dull and dirty gray now. But also for me I'm stuck in a Puerto Rico playing world of insanity. One of the common definitions of insanity is "repeating the same actions but expecting different results." And in my group that definition is very fitting. More damaging to our game play is that we seem to always have a new player, which Puerto Rico cannot well handle. It is a game where everyone should be of the same level of understanding. Sure, most games are like this, but Puerto Rico suffers catastrophically from the problem of uneven playing levels. This is mainly because it is such a procedureal game and someone making the "wrong" selection can cause havoc (or great reward) to others game-plan. To me this is a shortcoming and a fatal flaw in this game. Thus I rate it a 4: I do not enjoy playing it, I don't think it is very good, but every now and then allow myself to be talked into it. I predict that if I do not wait and play this with "capable and compatable PR players" it will certainly fall to a 3 or a 2 rating.

Earlier comments:
I like this game a lot, but with each play it gets more and more scripted. Fun, quick, exciting - requiring people to remain constantly focused, plan ahead, and make tough decision. However, there are many many games better than this.

1/20: Played the 2-player official varient vs. the wife. I was very pleasantly surprised at how good this works. I'm sure we'll be playing this far more often now. Playing this way, I should think, will be a great way for someone to learn the nuances of the game and grow comfortable with making decisions.

10/3 - Lowered my rating from 8.5 to a 7.5 and here's why: firstly, the three-player game, while quick, is terribly rote. There is ALWAYS someone or often more than one person attempting and getting the harbor/wharf combo. Oh boy that's fun. I've done it myself many times and while it can be stopped, it must be done early and with very concentrated precise play by the other two players. Conversely, the person hooking up with both can practically blunder along and just flat-out win. Perhaps a change in the number of buildings available, like is done in the 2-player varient, would create a much more tense and thought-filled game. The second reason I dropped my rating is because I'm finding this game to be more and more scripted with each play. If (insert action) is selected, then do (insert response). It has become more and more rare during my playings that this isn't the case. And that leads me to my third reason for dropping my rating - I've simply played this game too often in the past year and I'm kind of getting burned out on it.

RATING: 9
Puerto Rico was one of the games (along with Settlers) that got me into Euro-style games.  It's a great, deep game, with multiple paths to victory and plenty of player interaction despite a lack of "take that" game play.  

Considering the set up is almost exactly the same every game, it also has a remarkable amount of replayability.  I got about six months of multiple plays every weekend in when I first got it, and I'm still up for a game any time.

RATING: N/A
There are moves you must make / avoid in key situations, or you lose. Worst of all, [i]your mistakes are going to bring down other players, due to no fault of their own[/i]. You can't play Puerto Rico with people of differing skill levels, otherwise the game devolves into a long, drawn-out kingmaking. If you make a mistake in the first rounds the game is already over, but you have to keep playing for the rest of the evening.

I enjoyed the setting and building my little town. The Anniversary Edition's artwork is beautiful.

The only thing I do not like: The minimalistic graphic design that is so typical for ALEA. This game looks soo dated...Just imagine how a Days of Wonder version would look like ;)

I just downgraded my rating for this as the criticism aimed at this game (scripted nature with experienced players) are legitimate. A bit more randomness would have helped the game to remain fresh even after a decade for two.

RATING: 8

Anxious to try it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In Puerto Rico players assume the roles of colonial governors on the island of Puerto Rico. The aim of the game is to amass victory points by shipping goods to Europe or by constructing buildings.
 players grow crops which they exchange for points or doubloons. Doubloons can then be used to buy buildings, which allow players to produce more crops or give them other abilities. Buildings and plantations do not work unless they are manned by colonists. Who can create the best and most effecient colony?

RATING: 6
I finally played Puerto Rico after it sat on my shelf for 9 months -- three players: my first time, against 2 players that played about 4 or 5 times each.  I won 50-42-42.  I honestly don't know how I was able to beat 2 moderately experienced players in a game that has little luck involved.  In terms of enjoyment, it has a very Euro feel in that every player is in their own silo doing their own thing and may occasionally make a move that disadvantages someone else.  I can't really say it was an extremely fun game, but I'll try it again at least once before I give a final judgment.  A 5 for now.  (And could this game be any more fiddly on the setup?!)

Traded for Blue Moon Allies, Flit, and Mimix. (9/16/10)

Building my city and plantation. Variety of strategies. The way roles accumulate incentive money if not selected. Managing the timing of getting building you like before your opponents. What I Dislike-
May get stale with same buildings available every game. Certain set strategies.

Puerto Rico is one of those games that I can play and will never quite win. Always second or third in our 4 player group. I kinda like the game, but dont find it a must play that everyone else seems to do and I did feel in the beginning. There's no in your face or tension, just agonizing decisions that lead to an emotionless end...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Best Game ever, as simple as that. 
Overall, Puerto Rico does a good job of isolating individual decisions--so that, for example, you choose one of the roles, and then you decide what individual action is required by the role. However, because of the high strategic element of the game, the players are encouraged to look ahead, and this can mean that they end up spinning their wheels with too many choices. A few of our players ended up frequently paralysed by the choices, and I expect this is a somewhat common occurrence.

Overall, the strategic gameplay of Puerto Rico is superb. There's a lot of opportunity to plan ahead in a lot of different ways. Thus I agree with the general assessment of the game and give it a full "5" out of "5" for Substance.

RATING: 9
This is one of my favorite games.  Depending on the day, it is my favorite game.  In includes all of the aspects I look for in a game: multiple strategies to victory, almost no luck, making choices that affect the strategies of the other players, and you don't really know who won until the points are counted at the end of the game.  My ONLY complaint about this game is that it usually takes a long time to play and is not a friend of new gamers.  If you like board games and are looking for something deep and strategic, and not super frustrating, get your hands on Puerto Rico.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very fun game. I can see why this held the top spot for so long here on the Geek.

I particularly enjoyed the Governor (First Player) mechanic mixed with the roundabout occupation mechanic. I liked that everyone got to do what the occupation initiator got to do, but that the initiator got a little something extra for being the first one to do so during the round. Player geography played a big part, in that whoever you sit after in the turn really seemed to matter, which is something I don't like, but without a point-buy or auction initiative (which wouldn't really fit in PR) I don't see any way to fix it.

The rules are vast at first glance and really quie simple in play. We found that the only thing we really needed to look up during the first game was the individual rules for buildings and the specifics for occupations, which is still simple enough, and something that you would do less and less as you would become more familiar with these nuances after several plays.

We enjoyed the constant necessity for decisions. There are a great many options available to each player (we played a four player game) at almost every junction, so no one ever felt bored or cornered by previous decisions, which is great. Ultimately, I think that this is PR's biggest strength: Good decisions each round, but with a great deal of strategy involved. 

Players do interact quite a bit. There is certainly some room for screwing over your neighbor and sometimes forming slight alliances (which may not be in the spirit of the game, mind you).

The components are very well done, especially considering how well they stand up against some more recent high production value games (PR is six years old already!).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
My opinion on the THE BIG HEAVY: it's okay. As a gateway game, it serves its purpose, though not as well as Settlers or Shadows Over Camelot or even Return of the Heroes for that matter (depends on the "gateway" you're trying to open). But c'mon. Balance? No, not really. Repeat playability? Well, it's better than going to the dentist once a week. Attractiveness? Feh. I play it once in a while, and I can't say that I'm particularly good at it. But the thing is, I don't care. I WANT to be good at A Game of Thrones. I WANT to be good at Twilight Struggle. I WANT to be good at even El Grande before this. You get the point. If you ask me to play Puerto Rico and offered me a beer while we played and I wasn't doing anything else, I'd say yes. But otherwise? I'd take the beer and run.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Not enough plays to rate it properly, especially since I've only played it two-player, but I think this is going to be a favorite. The first game was extremely close (I won by a point) and the second had a little larger gap, but moved faster and was more fun overall since we were beginning to know what we were doing. The interplay between players is way more interesting than I thought it would be; I spent most of the game looking at my opponent's board, trying to decide what it was he would benefit from the most (or, better, how I could choose a role that would screw over his plans yet wouldn't hurt me too badly). This made for a nice, tense game and lively banter. 

Edit: played three player, and it was as fun as hoped. Amazingly, this is a very easy game to teach. It looks hopelessly complex coming out of the box, but all those bits mask the fact that it's a simple game to pick up. It's the new Catan for my roommates, which makes me a happy man (because they'll play with me once every few weeks).

RATING: 10
Played numerous times face-to-face, and hundreds of times on BSW (mainly with 3 or 4). I have been impressed by this game since my very first play - and still after so many plays, the game keeps its elegance and its interest. A very limited randomness still leads to highly variable games, and even the admittedly best buildings are not necessary to win. The main drawback would be the fact the seating order can affect the result quite a lot, for players of unequal experience. Still, a wonderful design and a very enjoyable game.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This really is a great game that truly deserves its #1/2/3 (wherever it is this week) rank.

There are multiple paths to victory, it's fairly easy to learn, and there's very little downtime.

It loses some appeal if players try to over-analyze it too much, but the same could be said of almost any game.  If you ever find yourself reaching that point you just need to put it away for a while and play something else.


The tired old [i]"win by sitting to the left of the newbie"[/i] complaint needs to go away, because it's stupid.   If the new player is about to take the Craftsman and that's going to dump a ton of points into the next player's lap, TELL THEM WHAT WILL HAPPEN and then give them the option to pick something else instead.  If you do nothing and the game gets "ruined" by a newbie you have only yourself to blame.

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
What stops me from rating this game higher is its lack of enough chaos.  Holding a card in hand (be it and ending victory condition or a type of resource) gives a game just enough luck for the number cruncher to forsake running everything through.  Without such chaos I find (1) playing this is only an exercise in crunching the numbers and (2) the game more or less reduces to a single optimal strategy of "money early - VPs late" with everything else being tactical (yet excellent tactical) playing.  This "tactical richness" or "tough choices in miniature" I fear is the new prototype for gamers games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I simply cannot get over my admiration of this game. Where can I start? Wonderful bits, everybody is almost always doing something (very little downtime), a dizzying number of paths to victory, lots of decisions, and many fun ways to subtly screw your neighbors. I can't think of a better game than this. A work of art. Can I give it an 11?
Edit: While still a great game, I'm not as amazed with it as I once was. I've been exposed to more games, and I am looking for more theme lately.

RATING: 8
I get why this is considered a classic. Game components feel a bit cheap, but the gameplay itself I enjoy very much. The game does feel like there are some fixed build-orders at the start, but I haven't played enough to know for sure.

I can strongly recommend taking up the 'balancing patch' from the BGG forums of this game into account. There empirical as well as simulated evidence that this balances out the win-ratios a bit for every player (regular rules seem to favor the starting player the least and the 3rd player the most).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Suffers some serious imbalance issues.  Not the gameplay, but w.r.t. the players themselves.  You don't actually play this game, you play the players in the game.  This does not appeal to me, and results in too deterministic outcomes.

Last time I played, I predicted how the scores would fall at the end of the game with 100% accuracy.  How was that fun? Save me the 3 hours of torture and play something I like.  But, I could still be convinced to play, as long as it is with folks of the same ability level.  In groups where this is one or two experts, it is torture and no fun at all.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game surprised me as the first time I played it, I was sure that it wasn't for me, but after having the opportunity to get it as a gift and playing it again, I really enjoyed it.

I don't know if it was a function of the players that I played it with the first time or the fact that I had only recently started playing board games at that point and have since been exposed to so many more, but I can see why this game is popular.

Given my limited plays of it at the moment and the amount of time that has passed since I played it last (July 2013), I can't realistically rate it, but I think that it looks very promising. The problem that I think that I'm going to find about getting this to the table is the game length and the fact that it's such an old and established game.

The variable phase order mechanic is implemented in the more streamlined and quicker playing San Juan. While not as heavy of a game by any stretch of the means, it does give you a little taste of what Puerto Rico is like. It also plays in a fraction of the time. The age of the game is also a knock against it as my gaming group generally falls in to the "cult of the new", so this really isn't top of mind.

I would like to play this game again soon to see what my thoughts are on it again... and also to figure out whether or not this is something that I should trade away if it's just going to sit on my shelf.

RATING: 6.4

I don't like how this game encourages going for corn and shipping it as fast as you can or building buildings as fast as you can so that you end the game early. I am more of a long-term strategy player so I appreciate games that allow for long-term strategies.

RATING: 10
Fantastic game!  There's a reason this classic has remained in the top 10 for over a decade.  My wife and I love this game at any player count; the 2-player variant is definitely worth checking out.  One of my favorite games, and one that my family keeps asking for us to bring when we visit!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a good game, but I don't know that I will rate it higher than a 7.  It is a euro through and through.  The rule set is elegant.  However, there are a couple of major issues that will depress my ranking.  First, as with a lot of games, skill level makes a better player.  However, with PR, the skill level curve appears to be exponential.  Coupled with this skill level curve is a huge down stream kingmaking potential.  Everything that is done directly affects the player to your left.  A poor player will always give the game away to the player on the left.  This creates the 'group think' way to play a game to where it becomes 'you must do this or else...' type gameplay.  While I will play it, I find that these items will not elevate the game to one of the top 9 or 10 spots.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Maybe it's the constrained way that players can interact. Nevertheless I'm always willing to play if someone requests it, though I personally won't suggest it.

RATING: N/A
Another long neglected legendary title on my shelf. Finally got drawn out and played by me and my friends at our last monthly meeting. 

Oh boy, it was a one hell of a draining session! That's how we felt about the game after our very first playing of Puerto Rico (it took almost 4hrs to finish). 

My first blunt impression of the game is following. 
 1:It is too tight when all the information in the game, except prestige tokens, is open to all players participating. 
 2:At an early stage, it becomes obvious that for losing players, turning the tide is almost impossible.

But of course, this is probably one of the most discussed and the most studied board games in Euro game society all over the world. And with the fact that we have played the game only once. So above is my humble, embarrassing 2yen for the time being. Need much and much more play anyway.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not too sure how I feel about it yet, and while I don't wholeheartedly agree with the #1 ranking it has received, I can see why it's such a beloved title.  Puerto Rico is a multifaceted game that often present players with some agonizing decisions.  The fact that everyone participate in the action you choose (with the exception of prospector) will often make you think twice not to select one that will benefit others more than yourself.  Furthermore, turn order become increasingly more important and as a result, it is obvious that if someone inexperienced is playing, the person after will more often than not benefit from a poor play.

Another aspect I'm not too fond of is how scripted gameplay seem to be.  Although there are many paths to victory, the way you react to other people's selections often does not vary.  Not to mention the game drags on painfully for those prone to AP.  Puerto Rico is a good game no doubt, but is it great, the jury is still out for this geek.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
It's likely that this game doesn't need any introduction. Most of the gamers will know this one, or at least have heard of it. So did we, but we never played it before. This one was on our monitor for a long time, but where-ever we looked, we never saw a Dutch edition in the stores. Until yesterday. Bought it instantly and after bagging the game yesterday, I placed it onto the shelves. And there it was, hidden between a couple of hundred other games. How long would it stay there, before one of us, would free him from his neighbours Agricola and Le Havre?

Well, not too long, just one day. We really wanted to play this one, and as we had a couple of hours left, we decided to watch a video of it, and then started to read the rules. The video was a very good one, because I read through the rules pretty quick. Mostly I used the rulebook to set-up the game for 2 players.

This is a pretty easy game to explain to somebody else. The only thing you have to explain is the 7 different roles which are possible. That should be possible in less then 10 minutes I think. When playing, there are a lot of things to choose from, but there's very little to choose. You want to choose 2, 3 or maybe even 4 things, but you're allowed to pick only 1. Every decision is important, and will effect the choice which the other player has to make. Yet, it is possible to think about a long-time strategy. This is a game that really works. Everything is well balanced out. 

It doesn't get you bored during a other players turn, because you also have to play the role. Because of this interaction, it's a game you will be playing from beginning to the end. Sometimes the mechanisms reminds me of Le Havre. If I had to choose between those two, it would be a very difficult choice to make.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Simple to learn, difficult to win. Adaptation is the key - if you can't adapt to other players' unexpected choices, you're toast. For all the lack of random elements, it's amazing how much luck always seems to be against you. When choosing a role, it's very easy to benefit your competitors more than yourself. There is a constant feeling of things being out of your control - the more players there are, the stronger the feeling. It's all but impossible to stop a superior player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Awesome game for serious gamers.  As an Agricola player who was maddened when Puerto Rico took the #1 spot on BGG, I now understand why after purchasing this game.  Game mechanics are simple and the strategy is layered.  Lots of good opportunities to cut some throats.

Editor's note:  After 5+ plays, it's now my favorite game aside from chess.

Second note:  As of 2012, we're back in the "Agricola is better than Puerto Rico" camp.  That's what a New Year's gala in Greensboro with Sceadeau does to a gamer.

RATING: 9.5
Total plays ~100

update: March 2011
My children are starting to win regularly. We have been playing once or twice a weekend since for a number of months, and they are learning how to win. Now the game is even more fun.

RATING: 6
It got old – that's all. Fiddly to setup, depends on pre-made combos and sitting position, thematically uninspiring and the main take-role mechanic got more sophisticated through time (I mean why would I need to take the tile when I can just play a card like in RftG?). The fact that the girlfriend wipes the floor with me in this one doesn't help my judgement.

Update: am not so mad at this game any more. Played it again after a year or so. It holds if you purposely avoid silly combos like hacienda-hospice-residence.
So rating adjusted accordingly from 4 to 6.

RATING: 9
After 10+ Plays: Everything fits together seamlessly, and I like how the game produces lots of play variety without introducing a lot of random elements.  On the other hand, I've never been blown away by this game like so many people have.  While I admire the design, and I've enjoyed it every time I've played, I don't have the urge to suggest it.  

After 20+ Plays: I actually do find myself suggesting this game on occasion now, and I continue to enjoy it every time.  While the expansion(s) can add a little variety, the original game is still my favorite.  Upping rating from 8 to 9.

So many games have copied this that it's hard to remember now how original Puerto Rico was when it first came out. 

Own the extra buildings expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A pretty high rating for a game I currently consider excruciating and don't actually want to play. While there may be no randomness, the chaos effect of other people's decisions compounding can be painful. Extremely short-term planning dominates this turn-by-turn efficiency game, but there's no denying there's some important long-term decisions to make, especially right at the beginning. Theme became drier by the minute for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7/19/2017 - The crux of PR seems to be timing the Craftsman action correctly--whether taking it yourself or opting for a different action in hopes that someone downstream will take it.  Essentially every wheel in the game turns on production goods, and taking the Craftsman card at the wrong time can easily cut you out of the points and/or gold you were hoping to earn with the goods you build.  I think Puerto Rico is fun, but too much hinges on a single a single factor--or at least much more than I feel should.  This also, of course, makes the game punishing for new players who haven't figured out this particular nuance yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game deserves its ranking. It's fun, quick and there are multiple avenues open to winning. It's also quick to explain and appealing to new gamers.

RATING: 10
A must Have game. (Instant classic)

Puerto Rico is so balanced and contains so many strategic elements.

Don't let the rules put you off.  I waited for years to buy this game because I tough it was way too heavy.
Shame on me. It's easier than you think especially if someone teaches you the rules. (The rules have a real nice and logical flow)

It is one of the best games that I have ever played, and I would recommend it to absolutely anybody that enjoys playing board games. If you have not played this game, go find a copy and try it.

RATING: 9
无需过多介绍的游戏，在不少爱好德式策略的桌友心中就是帝王版的存在。在优秀游戏层出不穷的今天，波多黎各依旧稳列前茅，其经典地位已经深入人心，难以撼动。不过对于口味颇杂的本人来说，波多黎各离顶级游戏还差那么一点点。目前入手的话，性价比最高的该是十周年纪念版了。。。
【关键词】特权，蹭行动，采石场，种植园，私船，大建筑，货物加工/出售/运送，殖民船/运输船，多种游戏结束触发方式

【推荐度】高 【经济生产建设，中度德式爱好者

RATING: 10
Originally I rated it a '9', but it keeps hitting the table. This game also shines as a 2-player game, if you play: player1 Governor - player2 - player1 Governor - p2 - p1G, end turn, p2G - p1 -p2G - p1 -p2G, end turn. I play this one often with my wife.

RATING: 3

RATING: 8
Very good game design. Interesting theme. Strangely enough, I consider the playing too tense for me. A single mistake can make you lose. Also I don't like the high amount of casualty driven by other players, when they will face equivalent options for them, but their choices will be crucial for you. To be tried.
